text:
Category: Countries and Journeys
Book: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
Author: Ibn al-Ha'ik, Abu Muhammad al-Hasan ibn Ahmad ibn Ya'qub ibn Yusuf ibn Dawud, known as Al-Hamdani (died 334 AH)
Date of Publication in Shamela: 8 Dhu al-Hijjah 1431

[Repeated metadata omitted for brevity]

The middle of the Equator is the Dome of the Earth which is under the Dome of the Celestial Sphere - meaning the apex of the Earth's sphere. The horizon circle of the Dome cuts the sky in half above and half below. The Earth is divided according to that form into two parts: visible and hidden. Thus, they become four parts: Upper Northern, Lower Northern, Upper Southern, and Lower Southern. The division is the horizon circle in these places. In what is on its line in two equal halves, the days become like the nights exactly equal, and the hours are always twelve of the night and the day. The shadow at the head (start) of Aries and Libra is non-existent. When the sun inclines in the north to the head of Cancer, its shadows fall to the north. The limit of the summer and winter shadow there is five digits (fingers) and a third of a digit. The wandering planets (planets) align with them if they are at the vernal point and the autumnal point. Among the fixed stars, those whose orbit is on the path of the day - meaning the Equator. They see all the stars rising and setting since the pole of the sphere is on their horizon circle itself. It is likely that these places on Earth are at the utmost moderation of temperament. That is because the sun does not linger long over them at the points that are directly overhead, due to the speed of its movement from the two equinox points in declination, because it is at the beginning of the declination arc, so it takes a degree in longitude and [changes] declination for most of it. It does not distance from them more than the degrees of declination, which is twenty-four parts less a sixth. Thus, summer and winter there are of moderate temperament. He said: As for the dwellings in these lands on this line, I am not able to say about that what I do not encompass with knowledge, because no one from among us has reached them up to this limit. What is said about them is closer to running the course of conjecture than running the course of news from observation. These are the properties of the Equator and the Great Circle which is under the Equinoctial Line (Celestial Equator) in summary. Whatever deviates from this circle south and north, the two poles differ upon it, so one appears and one is hidden. Thereby stars appear that become eternally visible, and stars are hidden that become eternally hidden, among those close to the two poles. The horizon circles divide the circles aligning with these two halves into two different parts: from above and below. The upper is greater and longer in day, and the lower is [more transparent?] and shorter in night in alignment only. As for on the second half of each half, it is the reverse. That is, the circles of the northern land aligning [with the sun] are cut by their horizons visibly at the larger of the two parts, due to their alignment with the circles aligning with the people of the south visibly at the smaller of the two parts. So the day shortens for them if the sun is in the circles of the south. And likewise it does in the south if it shifts by its declination to the north. Wherever one of the poles appears, there must be stars upon it that are eternally visible, and wherever it is hidden, there must be stars upon it that are eternally hidden. The first circle is finished. He said: As for the Second Parallel Circle: It is the one where the maximum day reaches twelve and a quarter hours of the equinoctial hours - meaning equal hours. The distance of the circle from the circle of the Equinoctial Line is four parts and a quarter of a part. It is drawn passing through the island named Taprobane [Sri Lanka]. This circle is among the circles where the shadow falls to both directions if the sun also becomes directly overhead for everyone under it twice. Such is the way of what is under the two arrows of declination from the head of Cancer and the head of Capricorn to the chord aligning with the Equator. The shadow of the head of Aries in this circle is fifty-three minutes and fifteen seconds of a digit. The gnomons fall under it, and the shadow falls if the sun is between ten and a half parts of Aries to nineteen parts and a half and twenty-four seconds, and that is in one hundred and fifty-nine degrees, which is what is between the two positions we defined in Aries and Virgo. Its longest shadow in winter is six digits and twenty-four minutes and thirty-six seconds of a digit, and that is from nineteen and a half parts of the parts of Virgo to ten and a half parts of the beginning of Aries; that is two hundred and one degrees. It has no shadow at times of the sun culminating the sky on this line.

The Third Parallel Circle: It is the circle where the longest day becomes twelve and a half hours. The distance of this circle from the Equinoctial Line and the Equator is eight parts and twenty-five minutes. It is drawn passing through the gulf called Avalites (Gulf of Aden?). This circle is also among the circles where the shadow falls to both directions if the sun becomes directly overhead for those living under it twice. The gnomons in it, if the sun's distance from the Summer Solstice is sixty-nine parts to each of the two directions - meaning between twenty-one degrees of Aries to nine degrees of Virgo - have no shadow at times of the sun culminating the sky over them. If the sun is moving in these one hundred and thirty-eight parts, the fall of the gnomons' shadows is to the south of it. If its movement is in the remaining parts - which are two hundred and twenty-two parts - the fall of the shadows is to the north of it. The shadow of the head of Aries in it is one digit and forty-six minutes and twenty-five seconds of a digit. The amount of its shadow in the Summer Solstice is three digits and eighteen minutes and thirty-eight seconds of a digit. The shadow of the Winter Solstice from the head of Capricorn in it is seven digits and eighty-four minutes and forty-eight seconds of a digit. The Fourth Parallel Circle: It is the one where the amount of the longest day becomes twelve and a half hours and a quarter of an hour. The distance of this circle from the Equinoctial Line is twelve parts and a half part. It is drawn passing through the gulf called Aduliticus (Gulf of Zula?). This circle is also among the circles where the shadow falls to both directions if the sun becomes directly overhead for those living under it also twice. The gnomons in it, if the sun's distance from the Summer Solstice in the head of Cancer to each of the two directions is fifty-seven parts and two-thirds of a part, have no shadow at times of the sun culminating the sky over them. So as long as the sun moves in these one hundred and fifteen parts and a third of a part - meaning between two degrees and a third of Taurus to twenty-seven degrees and two-thirds of Leo - the fall of the gnomons' shadows is to the south of it. If its movement is in the remaining parts of the sphere, which are two hundred and forty-four parts and two-thirds of a part, it is therein to the north of it. The shadow of the head of Aries on this location is two digits and thirty-nine minutes and thirty seconds of a digit. The limit of the summer shadow in the head of Cancer: two digits and twenty-four minutes and thirty-three seconds of a digit. The limit in the winter shadow in the head of Capricorn: eight digits and five-sixths of a digit.

The Fifth Parallel Circle: It is the one where the amount of the longest day becomes thirteen hours. The distance of this circle from the Equinoctial Line is sixteen parts and twenty-seven minutes. It is drawn passing through the island named Meroe - meaning Ma'rib the land of Sheba. This circle is also among the circles where the shadow falls to both directions as the sun becomes directly overhead for those living under it twice. The gnomons in it, if the sun's distance from the Summer Solstice - meaning the head of Cancer to each of the two directions - is forty-five parts, have no shadow at times of the sun culminating the sky aligning with it - meaning with these parts from half of Taurus to the beginning of Cancer to half of the sign of Leo. If the sun is moving in these ninety parts, the fall of the shadows is to the south of it. If its movement is in the remaining parts of the sphere - which are two hundred and seventy parts - the fall of the shadows is to the north. The shadow of the head of Aries on this location is three digits and thirty-two minutes and eighteen seconds. The shadow of the head of Cancer on it is one digit and thirty-three minutes and twelve seconds. The shadow of the head of Capricorn on it is ten digits and ten minutes and thirty-six seconds of a digit. The Sixth Parallel Circle: It is the one where the amount of the longest day becomes thirteen and a quarter hours of the equal hours. The distance of this circle from the Equinoctial Line is twenty parts and fourteen minutes. It is drawn passing through the places named Napata - meaning parts of the First Clime in what overlooks Mecca. This circle is also among the circles where the shadow falls to both directions if the sun becomes directly overhead in it twice. The gnomons at midday, if the sun's distance from the Summer Solstice to each of its directions is thirty-one parts - meaning the last part of Taurus and the first part of Leo - the sun has no shadow in these two parts, and they are in alignment with this location. If it passes from these two parts in the north, the shadows fall in the south. If its movement is in the remaining parts of the sphere, which are two hundred and ninety-eight parts, the fall of the shadows is to the north. The shadow of the head of Aries in this location is four digits and twenty minutes and sixteen seconds. On the head of Cancer, forty-five minutes and fourteen seconds of a digit. The shadow of the head of Capricorn is eleven digits and thirty-seven minutes and five seconds of a digit.

The Seventh Parallel Circle: It is the one where the amount of the longest day becomes thirteen and a half hours of the equal hours. The distance of this circle from the Equinoctial Line is twenty-three parts and fifty-one minutes. It is the direction of the maximum declination. It is drawn passing through the island named Syene - meaning Hejaz. This circle is the first of the circles called 'those of one shadow'. That is because the shadows of gnomons at midday do not fall for those living under it at any time to the south; rather, the sun at the Summer Solstice itself only becomes directly overhead, and no shadow is seen for the gnomons then. That is because their distance from the Equinoctial Line is the distance of the Summer Solstice from it. As for all the rest of the time, the shadows of the gnomons fall for them to the north. The shadow of the head of Aries in this place is five digits and eighteen minutes and forty-five seconds of a digit. There is no shadow for the head of Cancer as we mentioned due to its alignment with this position. The shadow of the head of Capricorn on it is thirteen digits and eleven minutes and thirty-six seconds of a digit. All circles that are more inclined to the north than this circle have no southern shadow to the furthest north since the sun does not reach them. The Eighth Parallel Circle: It is the one where the amount of the longest day becomes thirteen and a half hours and a quarter of the equal hours. The distance of this circle from the Equinoctial Line is twenty-seven parts and a fifth of a part. It is drawn passing through the city named Ptolemais, which is known as Hermopolis in the land of Thebais. The shadow of the head of Aries in this location is six digits and ten minutes and twelve seconds of a digit. The summer shadow in the head of Cancer is forty-two [minutes] and twelve seconds of a digit. The winter shadow on it in the head of Capricorn is fourteen digits and fifty minutes and thirty-seven seconds of a digit.

The Ninth Parallel Circle: It is the one where the amount of the longest day becomes fourteen hours of the equal hours. The distance of this circle from the Equinoctial Line is thirty parts and twenty-two minutes. It is drawn passing through the lower land of Egypt and what surrounds it east and west. The shadow of the head of Aries in this location is seven digits and two minutes and fourteen seconds of a digit. The summer shadow from the head of Cancer is one digit and twenty-two minutes and twelve seconds of a digit. The winter shadow from the head of Capricorn is sixteen digits and thirty-nine minutes and fourteen seconds of a digit. The Tenth Parallel Circle: It is the one where the longest day becomes fourteen and a quarter hours of the equal hours. The distance of this circle from the Equinoctial Line is thirty-three parts and eighteen minutes. It is drawn passing through the middle of the land of Sham (Levant). The shadow of the head of Aries in it is seven digits and fifty-three minutes and twenty-four seconds of a digit. The summer shadow from the head of Cancer is one digit and fifty-nine minutes and fifty-one seconds of a digit - it is two digits approximately. The winter shadow from the head of Capricorn is eighteen digits and thirty-five minutes and twenty-seven seconds of a digit. The Eleventh Parallel Circle: It is the one where the amount of the longest day becomes fourteen and a half hours of the equal hours. The distance of this circle from the Equinoctial Line is thirty-six parts. It is drawn passing through the island named Rhodes - meaning Babylon. The shadow of the head of Aries there is eight digits forty-three minutes of a digit. The shadow of the head of Cancer is two digits and thirty-four minutes and fifty-seven seconds of a digit. The shadow of the head of Capricorn in it is twenty digits and thirty-nine minutes and thirty-nine seconds of a digit.

The Twelfth Parallel Circle: It is the one where the amount of the longest day becomes fourteen and a half hours and a quarter of the equal hours. The distance of this circle from the Equinoctial Line is thirty-eight parts and thirty-five minutes. It is drawn passing through the island named Smyrna. The shadow of the head of Aries in it is nine digits and thirty-three minutes and twenty-five seconds of a digit. The summer shadow of the head of Cancer is three digits and sixteen seconds of a digit. The summer shadow of the head of Cancer is three digits and sixteen seconds of a digit [repeated]. The winter shadow of the head of Capricorn is twenty-two digits and fifty-nine minutes and thirty-four seconds of a digit. The Thirteenth Parallel Circle: It is the one where the amount of the longest day becomes fifteen hours of the equal hours. The distance of this circle from the Equinoctial Line is forty parts and fifty-six minutes. It is drawn passing through the lands named Hellespontus. The shadow of the head of Aries in it is ten digits and twenty-four minutes and thirty-two seconds of a digit. The summer shadow of the head of Cancer in it is three digits and forty-one minutes and ten seconds of a digit. The winter shadow of the head of Capricorn in it is twenty-five digits and twenty-nine minutes and sixteen seconds. The Fourteenth Parallel Circle: It is the one where the amount of the longest day becomes fifteen and a quarter hours of the equal hours. The distance of this circle from the Equinoctial Line is forty-three parts and four minutes. It is drawn passing through the island named Massalia (Marseille). The shadow of the head of Aries in it is eleven digits and seventeen minutes of a digit. The summer shadow of the head of Cancer in it is four digits and thirteen minutes and thirty-six seconds of a digit. The limit of the winter shadow from the head of Capricorn in it is twenty-eight digits and twenty-four seconds of a digit.

The Fifteenth Parallel Circle: It is the one where the amount of the longest day becomes fifteen and a half hours of the equal hours. The distance of this circle from the Equinoctial Line is forty-five parts and one minute. It is drawn passing through the middle of the Sea of (Pontus) [Black Sea]. The shadow of the head of Aries in it is twelve digits and twenty-six seconds of a digit. The summer shadow of the head of Cancer is four digits and thirty-eight minutes and thirty seconds of a digit. The winter shadow of the head of Capricorn is thirty-one digits and three minutes and twenty-eight seconds. The Sixteenth Parallel Circle: It is the one where the amount of the longest day becomes fifteen and a half hours and a quarter of the equal hours. The distance of this circle from the Equinoctial Line is forty-six parts and fifty-one minutes. It is drawn passing through the springs of the river named Ister (Danube). The shadow of the head of Aries in it is twelve digits and forty-eight minutes and six seconds of a digit. The limit of the summer shadow in it is five digits and a tenth of a digit. The limit of the winter shadow in it is thirty-four digits and seventeen minutes and six seconds. The Seventeenth Parallel Circle: It is the one where the amount of the longest day becomes sixteen equal hours. The distance of this circle from the Equinoctial Line is forty-eight parts and thirty-two minutes. It is drawn passing through the outlets of the river named Borysthenes (Dnieper). The shadow of the head of Aries in it is thirteen digits and thirty-four minutes and fifty-six seconds of a digit. The summer shadow from the head of Cancer is five digits and thirty-one minutes and fifteen seconds of a digit. The winter shadow from the head of Capricorn is thirty-seven digits and forty-nine minutes and seventeen seconds. The Eighteenth Parallel Circle: It is the one where the amount of the longest day becomes sixteen and a quarter hours of the equal hours. The distance of this circle from the Equinoctial Line is fifty parts and four minutes. It is drawn passing through the middle of the lake named Maeotis (Sea of Azov). The shadow of the head of Aries in it is fourteen digits and twenty-five minutes and forty-five seconds of a digit. The shadow of the head of Cancer is five digits and fifty-seven minutes and twenty-four seconds. The shadow of the head of Capricorn is forty-two digits and eight minutes and thirty-six seconds of a digit.

The Nineteenth Parallel Circle: It is the one where the amount of the longest day becomes sixteen and a half hours of the equal hours. The distance of this circle from the Equinoctial Line is fifty-one parts and a half part. It is drawn passing through the furthest regions of the south of the land of Britannia. The shadow of the head of Aries there is fifteen digits and half a sixth of a digit. The shadow of the head of Cancer is six digits and seventeen minutes and twenty-four seconds of a digit. The shadow of the head of Capricorn is forty-five digits and forty-one seconds of a digit. The Twentieth Parallel Circle: It is the one where the amount of the longest day becomes sixteen and a half hours and a quarter of the equal hours. The distance of this circle from the Equinoctial Line is fifty-two parts and fifty minutes. It is drawn passing through the mouths of the Rhine. The shadow of the head of Aries there is fifteen digits and forty-seven minutes and twenty seconds of a digit. The shadow of the head of Cancer is six digits and thirty-nine minutes and forty-four seconds of a digit. The shadow of the head of Capricorn is fifty digits and forty-three minutes and forty-eight seconds of a digit. The Twenty-First Parallel Circle: It is the one where the amount of the longest day becomes seventeen equal hours. The distance of this circle from the Equinoctial Line is fifty-four parts and one minute. It is drawn passing through the mouths of the Tanais (Don). The shadow of the head of Aries there is sixteen digits and thirty-one minutes and thirty-eight seconds of a digit. The shadow of the head of Cancer is six digits and fifty-eight minutes and fifty seconds of a digit. The shadow of the head of Capricorn is fifty-five digits and fifty minutes and fifty-two seconds of a digit. The Twenty-Second Parallel Circle: It is the one where the amount of the longest day becomes seventeen and a quarter hours of the equal hours. The distance of this circle from the Equinoctial Line is fifty-five parts. It is drawn passing through the place named Brigantes in the land of Great Britannia. The shadow of the head of Aries in this place is seventeen digits and eight minutes. The shadow of the head of Cancer is seven digits and fifteen minutes and thirty-three seconds of a digit. The shadow of the head of Capricorn is sixty digits and fifty-six minutes and twenty-seven seconds of a digit.

The Twenty-Third Parallel Circle: It is the one where the amount of the longest day becomes seventeen and a half hours of the equal hours. The distance of this circle from the Equinoctial Line is fifty-six parts. It is drawn passing through the middle of the land of Great Britannia. The shadow of the head of Aries in it is seventeen digits and forty-seven minutes of a digit. The shadow of the head of Cancer is seven digits and thirty-two minutes and forty-two seconds of a digit. The shadow of the head of Capricorn is sixty-seven digits and six minutes and nine seconds of a digit. The Twenty-Fourth Parallel Circle: It is the one where the amount of the longest day becomes seventeen and a half hours and a quarter of the equal hours. The distance of this circle from the Equinoctial Line is fifty-seven parts. It is drawn passing through the place named Caturactonium in the land of Britannia. The shadow of the head of Aries in this place is eighteen digits and twenty-nine minutes of a digit. The shadow of the head of Cancer is seven digits and fifty minutes and forty-two seconds of a digit. The shadow of the head of Capricorn is seventy-four digits and thirty-seven minutes and twenty-four seconds of a digit. The Twenty-Fifth Parallel Circle: It is the one where the amount of the longest day becomes eighteen hours of the equal hours. The distance of this circle from the Equinoctial Line is fifty-eight parts. It is drawn passing through the southern regions of the land of Little Britannia. The shadow of the head of Aries in this place is nineteen digits and five digits [?]. The shadow of the head of Cancer in it is eight digits and eight minutes and forty-two seconds of a digit. The shadow of the head of Capricorn is eighty-three digits and fifty-six minutes and thirty-six seconds of a digit. The Twenty-Sixth Parallel Circle: It is the one where the amount of the longest day becomes eighteen and a half hours of the equal hours. The distance of this circle from the Equinoctial Line is fifty-nine parts and a half part. It is drawn passing through the middle places of the land of Little Britannia. The shadow of the head of Aries there is 20, 25, 3. The shadow of the head of Cancer is 8, 36, 21. And the shadow of the head of Capricorn.

He said: We did not use the quarter-hour details in these places because the parallel circles become close together and connected to each other at that time, and the difference in elevations does not amount to even one complete part. Also, it is not necessary for us to investigate the matter of the circles that are more inclined to the north than the circles we mentioned in the same way we investigated the explanation of those circles. Therefore, we saw fit to also set down the ratio of gnomons to shadows in them as they are set down, and as we did in the known defined places of the section. As for the place where the amount of the longest day is nineteen hours of the equal hours, the distance of its parallel circle from the Equinoctial Line is sixty-one parts. It is drawn passing through the northern extremities of the land of Little Britannia. No shadow was mentioned, so we knew it. The shadow of the head of Aries there is twenty-one digits and thirty-nine minutes of a digit. The shadow of the head of Cancer is nine digits and five minutes and thirty-three seconds of a digit. The shadow of the head of Capricorn is one hundred and thirty-three digits. The place where the amount of the longest day is nineteen and a half hours of the equal hours, the distance of its parallel circle from the Equinoctial Line is sixty-two parts. It is drawn passing through the island named Ebuda (Hebrides), which is Ournqa [?]. No shadow was mentioned. The shadow of the head of Aries there is twenty-two digits and thirty-four minutes of a digit. The shadow of the head of Cancer is nine digits and twenty-three minutes and twenty-seven seconds of a digit. The shadow of the head of Capricorn is one hundred and sixty-six digits and twenty-five minutes and fifty-seven seconds of a digit. The place where the amount of the longest day is twenty hours of the equal hours, the distance of its parallel circle from the Equinoctial Line is sixty-three parts. It is drawn passing through the island named Thule. No shadow was mentioned. The shadow of the head of Aries there is twenty-three digits and thirty-three minutes of a digit. The shadow of the head of Cancer is nine digits and forty-six minutes and nine seconds of a digit. The shadow of the head of Capricorn is two hundred and twenty digits and twenty-three minutes and twenty-four seconds of a digit.

The place where the amount of the longest day is twenty-one hours of the equal hours, the distance of its parallel circle from the Equinoctial Line is sixty-four parts and a half part. It is drawn passing through nations unknown and not counted among the Slavs. No shadow was mentioned. The shadow of the head of Aries there is twenty-five digits and a sixth of a digit. The shadow of the head of Cancer is ten digits... The shadow of the head of Capricorn is four hundred and sixty-four digits and twenty-two minutes and forty-eight seconds of a digit. The place where the amount of the longest day is twenty-two hours of the equal hours, the distance of that parallel circle from the Equinoctial Line is sixty-five parts and a half part. The shadow of the head of Aries there is twenty-six digits and twenty minutes and thirty seconds of a digit. The shadow of the head of Cancer is ten digits and forty minutes and eighteen seconds. The shadow of the head of Capricorn is one thousand one hundred and fifty digits and seventeen minutes and nine seconds of a digit. The place where the amount of its longest days is twenty-three hours of the equal hours, the distance of the parallel circle upon it from the Equinoctial Line is sixty-six parts. The shadow of the head of Aries there is twenty-six digits and fifty-seven minutes of a digit. The shadow of the head of Cancer is ten digits and fifty-one minutes and twenty-seven seconds. There is no limit to the shadow of Capricorn. The place where the amount of the longest day is twenty-four hours of the equal hours, the distance of its parallel circle from the Equinoctial Line is sixty-six parts and a half part. He said: This is the first of the circles where the shadow falls circulating around the gnomon and everything upright. That is because the sun, since it does not set there at the Summer Solstice alone - meaning the head of Cancer - the shadows of the gnomons fall to all directions of the horizon. In this place, the circle of the Summer Solstice parallel to the Equinoctial Line is permanently visible, and the circle of the Winter Solstice parallel to the Equinoctial Line is permanently hidden, because they both touch the horizon in it alternately. The oblique circle also which passes through the middle of the signs becomes the horizon if the ascendant from it is the point of the Vernal Equinox - i.e., the head of Aries.

He said: If a lover of increasing knowledge wishes to investigate in another way the circles that are more inclined to the north than the circles we mentioned regarding some of the generalities required in them, he would find the place where the elevation of the North Pole is approximately sixty-seven parts - which is its distance from the Equinoctial Line that is the belt of the Equator - there, fifteen parts of the circle passing through the middle of the signs do not set, which are on each of the two sides of the head of Cancer - meaning from the middle of Gemini to the middle of Cancer - such that the amount of the longest day there and the rotation of shadows to all directions of the horizon is close to one month. Where the elevation of the Pole is sixty-nine parts and a half part, you find there thirty parts on each of the two sides of the Summer Solstice that do not set at all - meaning from the beginning of Gemini to the end of Cancer - such that the longest day there and the rotation of the gnomons' shadows is close to two months. Where the elevation of the Pole and the distance of the parallel circle from the Equinoctial Line is seventy-three parts and a third of a part, you find there forty-five parts from each of the two sides of the Summer Solstice that do not set - meaning between the middle of Taurus and the middle of Leo - such that the amount of the longest day there and the rotation of the gnomons' shadows extends to close to three months. Where the elevation of the Pole is seventy-eight parts and a third of a part, you find there sixty parts from each of the two sides of the Summer Solstice that do not set, which are from the beginning of Taurus to the end of Leo, such that the amount of the longest day there and the rotation of the gnomons' shadows is close to four months. Where the elevation of the Pole is eighty-four parts, you find there seventy-five parts from each of the two sides of the Summer Solstice that do not set, which are from the middle of Aries to the middle of Virgo, such that the amount of the longest day there is close to five months, and the shadows of the gnomons rotate around it for close to this period of time.

Where the North Pole is elevated above the horizon by the parts of the quarter entirely, which are ninety parts, there the entire half of the circles passing through the middle of the signs that is more inclined to the north from the circle of the Equinoctial Line does not become under the earth at any time. And the half that is more inclined to the south entirely does not become above the earth at any time, so that every year becomes a single day and a single night, each one of them close to six months. The shadows of the gnomons at all times rotate around it. Among the properties of this inclination to the North Pole is that the Peg (Watad) - meaning the Pole - is at the zenith, and that the circle of the Equinoctial Line stands there in the place of the permanently visible circle, and the place of the permanently hidden circle, and the place of the horizon circle, as it makes the entire half of the sphere that is more inclined from it to the north above the earth at all times, and the half that is more inclined to the south below the earth - meaning that the point of the North Pole is the middle of the sky of the place and the point of the South Pole is its lower peg.

All of this which he mentioned is according to him in eleven categories and eleven methods. The First Method: The Erect Sphere, its hours are twelve equal hours, which is the orbit of the Equator. The Second Method: The Gulf named Avalites, its hours are twelve and a half hours, and its latitude is eight degrees and a third of a degree and half a sixth. This is what is between the Equator and the start of the First Clime; he made this method part of it. The Third Method: The Island named Meroe, which is Yemen, the First Clime; its hours are thirteen hours, and its latitude is sixteen parts and a quarter and a fifth. The Fourth Method: The Island named Syene - meaning Hejaz; its hours are thirteen and a half, and its latitude is the cut of the declination which is twenty-three degrees and fifty-one minutes. The Fifth Method: The lower parts of the land of Egypt; its hours are fourteen hours, and its latitude is thirty parts and a fifth and a sixth of a part. The Sixth Method: The Island named Rhodes, which is Babylon; its hours are fourteen and a half hours, its latitude is thirty-six parts. The Seventh Method: The lands named Hellespontus; its hours are fifteen, and its latitude is forty parts and nine-tenths and a third of a tenth of a part. The Eighth Method: In the middle of the Pontus Sea (Black Sea); its hours are fifteen and a half, forty-five parts. The Ninth Method: At the outlets of the river named Borysthenes; its hours are sixteen, and its latitude is forty-eight parts and a half and a third of a tenth. The Tenth Method: At the furthest south of the lands of Britannia; its hours are sixteen and a half hours, and its latitude is fifty-one parts and a half. The Eleventh Method: At the outlets of the Tanais; its hours are seventeen, and its distance is fifty-four parts and a sixth of a tenth. The Climes from these Seven Methods are: The Island named Meroe, which is Yemen, is of the First Clime. The second is the Island named Syene. The third is the lower parts of the land of Egypt. The fourth is the Island of Rhodes. The fifth is the lands named Hellespontus. The sixth is the middle of the Pontus Sea. The seventh is the outlet of the river named Borysthenes. Differences of People regarding Latitude and Longitude.

As for Latitude, among people are those who count the First Clime from the limit of the chord of the Equator to its furthest limit in the north. Among them are those who make the Zanj Sea (Sea of Zanj) a barrier between the First Clime and the middle of the Equator. That is whose latitude is eight degrees and twenty-five minutes and its hours are twelve and a half. Among the differences in its latitude is what contradicts the calculation of Sana'a in its latitude and the latitude of Ma'rib and their shadow. That is because they mention that the shadow of the head of Aries in Sana'a is three digits and a tenth, and its latitude is fourteen and a half. Ma'rib of Sheba is like that because it is aligned with it on the line of longitudinal azimuth; it is the east of Sana'a and Sana'a is its west, and between them is a distance of two days for a single rider. The elevation of Canopus over it is the calculation of Sana'a. As for the measurement of its longitude by Al-Ma'mun, it might contradict them somewhat. This is evidence that the middle of this Clime is Wadi Najran of the land of Yemen, and Mecca is the last limit of Yemen. What supports their saying is that we find the latitude of the city of Sheba according to Ptolemy is sixteen parts and a quarter and a fifth of a part, and it is as we mentioned. Then we find him making the latitude of Zafar fourteen parts. This measurement of his for Zafar testifies for the calculation of Sana'a because Zafar is on the meridian circle of Sana'a from the south, and between them is approximately three days. Perhaps Ptolemy meant the desert of Ma'rib, land of Sheba, for it is a desert bordered by Bayhan, Ma'rib, Al-Jawf, Najran, Al-Hujayrah, and the valleys of Turabah, Bisha, and Tabalah. The most famous of these places bordering this desert was the city of Sheba.

As for Longitude, the people of the West among the Greeks and Romans looked at the furthest of their settlements, and that was near the Dark Sea (Atlantic Ocean) taking what is between the north of the West and its south, so they made it the limit. Then they made the end of the longitude in the East at a distance of twelve hours, which is one hundred and eighty straight degrees. Since all the horizon circles of countries cut from the sphere visibly and inwardly at this amount. As for the people of the East from India and those following them and from China and others, they differed from the Greeks. They placed the beginning of the East behind what those placed as the beginning by thirteen degrees and a half, which is the amount of an hour minus a tenth. Then they made the limit of the West short of what its people made by this amount. Each of the two groups came to place the Dome of the Earth, upon which the positions of the stars are calculated, at ninety degrees from the limit they defined. As for the people of the East, they made the beginning of habitation from where a traveler reaches in the extremities of China, like the places a traveler reaches after the limits of the Climes in the North. The first sunrise is on this limit, which is midnight for the people of the Dome upon which the calculation of the Sindhind is placed. So whoever works with Ptolemy's longitudes from among these, he subtracts from his longitudes thirteen degrees and a half so that what remains is the distance of his city from the West. Then he subtracts that from one hundred and eighty. If what remains is less than ninety, his city is behind the Dome towards the East. If more than ninety degrees remain, his city is before the Dome towards the West. If ninety remains, it is under the meridian circle of the Dome. An example of that is that Ptolemy made the longitude of Zafar in Yemen seventy-eight parts. If we subtract it from one hundred and eighty parts, one hundred and two parts remain, which is its longitude from the East according to the limit of the Westerners. The sun rises over it after rising over the people of the Dome by four-fifths of an hour. This amount is for one who takes the saying of Ptolemy. Whoever takes the saying of the people of the Sindhind subtracts from the longitude of Zafar that we mentioned thirteen degrees and a half, so sixty-four degrees and a half remains, which is its longitude from the West according to one who holds the view of the people of the East. If this longitude is subtracted from the longitude of one hundred and eighty, one hundred and fifteen parts and a half remains, which is its longitude from the East. The sun rises over it after rising over the people of the Dome by one equal hour and a half and a fifth of an hour. The longitude of Sana'a when calculating it from the East is one hundred and eighteen parts, which contradicts the longitude of Zafar...

according to Ptolemy because their longitude can only be one. What came from Claudius Ptolemy regarding the natures of the inhabitants of the populated part of the Earth in general. Since the stars share in the management of the regions of the Earth, mixing between the middle and the edge, it was good composition and flow of the system to mention the whole so that the special and general natures of the Arabian Peninsula are known, and that what the wise men characterized it with, which is present and witnessed in its people, appears. In general, the populated part of the Earth, the upper of its northern quarters, is according to him in three disparate zones (Khabbat). The first zone is what is from the Equator under the courses of the stars to the alignment of the end of the declination from the head of Cancer. That is the direction of what is between Mecca and Medina and what aligns with it east and west. The second zone is from this latitude to what exceeds the declination by its half. That is where the latitude is thirty-six parts from the East to the West. The third zone is from this latitude to the furthest habitation and the alignment from the sphere of the orbit of Ursa Major (Banat Na'sh).

He said: Those whose dwellings are between the head of Aries and the head of Cancer, which is between the Equator and the middle of Hejaz and what takes its course east and west, it happens to them that the sun burns them by its passing directly over their heads. So their bodies are black, their hair black, curly and thick, their faces parched, their builds slender, their natures hot, and their morals mostly savage due to the persistence of heat in the place of their dwelling and its connection to them. He said: They are the ones we call by the general name Abyssinians (Habash). We do not see them in this state of heat only, but the intense heat appears in the air surrounding them also in the rest of the animals and plants that are with them. Abu Muhammad said: The wise man, although he attributed this zone to the Abyssinians, the Abyssinians are the least of who is in it. In it are those blacker than them, those purer in color than them, and those who differ from all by whiteness and moderation of colors and by brownness and dark complexion, such as the inhabitants of the edge of this zone from China and from the Arabian Peninsula. For that are causes we have mentioned in the book 'Secrets of Wisdom' (Sara'ir al-Hikmah). Ptolemy said: As for those who live under the orbit of Ursa Major, because their distance from the zodiac sphere and from the heat of the sun is great, cold became predominant over them. Since what reaches them of moisture is abundant and rich in nourishment and there is no heat there to dry it, their colors became white, their hair straight (lank), their bodies huge and fertile, and their natures inclined to cold. The morals of these people are also savage due to the persistence of cold in the places of their dwellings and its connection. Whatever is found in them is found in their beasts and fruits, of hugeness, strength, and difference of composition.

As for those who live in the middle between the orbit of Ursa Major and the orbit of the head of Cancer, since the sun does not reach the place of their zenith - and its distance from them at times of midday is not great, so the temperament of their air was moderate; it might vary but it is not subject to much change from heat to cold and from cold to heat - the colors of these people became medium, the sizes of their bodies moderate, their natures of good temperament, their dwellings connected, and their morals sociable. Whoever of these inclines to the southern direction is mostly more intelligent, more resourceful, and more capable of knowledge of the affairs of the gods due to the proximity of the zodiac sphere and the wandering planets to the place of their zenith. The movements of their souls befit the movements of the stars in the speed of their understanding of a thing, and they are possessing of investigation and examination in the sciences called mathematical - i.e., the science of stars and calculation - as if he means the lower parts of Babylon then the land of Persia, then going to the West to the land of Egypt and the island of Greece. Whoever of them is generally inclined to the eastern direction, they are more remembering and stronger in souls and reveal all their affairs, because the eastern direction is of the nature of the sun, and it is a diurnal, masculine, right-sided direction. As is seen in animals, the right-sided organs of them are stronger and more helpful for intensity and endurance, and the beasts of this direction are stronger, more working, and more patient than others. As for those who incline to the western direction, they are more feminine, their souls are softer, and they hide their affairs mostly and conceal them, because this direction is lunar, and it is the nature of the moon always that its first rising and appearance after conjunction is from the direction of the blowing of the western winds called Al-Dabur. Therefore, this direction is thought to be nocturnal, feminine, left-sided, contrary to the eastern direction. Each one of these total directions must have partial conditions of the conditions of morals and natural laws, just as the conditions of the surrounding air differ in the places we mentioned, hot mostly or cold or moderate mostly. Places and countries among them are singled out by increase and decrease, either due to the rank of the place in position, or due to its elevation and depression, or due to its neighboring what neighbors it. And just as some people are also farmers specifically due to the ease of their land, and others are sailors and navigators due to the proximity of the sea to them, and others are people of ease, comfort, sociability, and wealth due to the fertility of their lands and the abundance of their good; likewise finds...

...man special natures in each of the countries from the natural conformity between the partial Climes and the stars and signs. These differences that we mentioned, we only mentioned them...

Abu Dhu'ayb said describing rain:
It watered Umm Amr every end of the night ... black clouds whose water is pouring
They drank from the Sea of Rome then stood erect ... peaks of single clouds, thundering, productive
If it grumbled one day and settled over a town ... it turned away while the middles of the fields were surging
Its light shines clear, revealing ... bright like the lamp of the Jews, flashing
As the lamp illuminated their affair for the non-Arabs ... after the sleep of the sleepers, flickering
I stayed awake for it at nightfall as if it were ... kerchiefs (or whips) under which a graduate is called
A Najdi wind drives it back and extends ... skimming over the dust, dragging
It has a fringe topping the hills and a fringe ... touching the tails of the watercourses, pouring
Heavy clouds, drowning, quenching, as if they were ... drinking singing-girls whose return is sobbing
As if the heavy clouds between Tadhari' ... and Shabah were a kneeling chest of Judham
For every stream from Tihamah after ... the horns of the clouds were cut, there is a clamor

Sa'idah ibn Ju'ayyah said describing rain:
So a laden cloud watered you, as if its flash ... was a forest ignited by a pierced fire
Quiet, stayed in Al-Badi' eight [days] ... twisting by the obstacles of the seas and avoiding
Until you see 'Amq, and returned over it ... thunder as the braying of the difficult stallion
When Nu'man saw the solving of Bakr ... a group, just as the riders stick to the descent
So the Lote tree is uprooted, so it brought down floating ... between 'Ayn to Nabata the Ith'ab tree
And the Doum tree from Sa'ya and Halyah is a abode ... and the Doum, the valleys brought it, so 'Alib
Then Busra rose and became sitting ... from it to Najd, a covering western cloud

Ibn al-Riqa' said describing rain:
And a companion, not weak, I raised him ... from his sleep while he was in a paved, pleasing place
So I stood informing him of the rain I did not see ... and the lightning, while a feverish man has sleeplessness
Clouds swimming in a Levantine wind ... crowned with the blindness of water, girdled
Then the eastern side of the dune frowned and returned ... to its followers from its journey, gentle
It waited for the night until its driver said ... on Al-Ruwayshid or its exit, pounding
Until when the western view stripped it ... of the redness of the sun when the horizon assassinated it
It threw its chest on Dhat Ajfar ... and kindled its fires and cleared away flashing

He also said:
O longing, what is the matter with you on the day their howdahs departed ... from Dhu al-Muwayqi' in the morning, so he saw it
As if palm trees from Matitah staying ... in Al-Kam' between its bottom and its refuge
Upon the camels when they approached a forerunner ... they brought down the last winded one so he drove it
And they made the litter of the armed one a shield ... the pond of the orphan and spread its banner
And they turned from the valley of Atidah after ... the thicket appeared, so its guide stood up
The village of Habl al-Muqiz and its people ... by Hisa Ma'ab you see the palaces of its villages
And your family occupied Dhu al-Qutud and 'Araw ... then Al-Sahsahan, so where is its intention from you?

He also said:
So I said to her: How were you guided when before us ... were Duluk and the high peaks of the apparent mountains
And Jayhan, the Jayhan of armies and the ... and Hazm Khuzaza and the compelling peoples

Ibn Muqbil said describing rain:
Reflect, my friend, do you see the light of a flashing cloud ... Yemeni, the wind of Najd wrung it so it slackened?
The east wind wrung it in the Ghor, the Ghor of Tihamah ... so when it slowed from it at Sha'fayn, it rained
A Yemeni cloud wringing the white clouds as if it were ... ostrich chicks whose eggs had broken
And it covered the milky camels of the tribes after ... it clothed the wazan from Safwan pure and muddy
So it became putting down the wrist-marked ones, its rain ... and the swaying cloud became moonlit
As if by it between Al-Tarah and Rahwah ... and Nasifah al-Suban was a kindled forest
So it left Malhub, its lizards walking ... free, the torrent left no hole for them
It stayed at the shores of Al-Ruka' and Rakis ... when the water-bird drowned in the downpour, it babbled
It made kneel at the sand of Al-Kawmakhayn the kneeling of the ... Yemeni, young camels, putting down their saddles from them

In this, of what the Arabs mentioned of their homelands, is sufficiency. Whoever wishes to investigate it further, let him follow the descriptions of the Arabs for the locations of rain and the watering places of wild donkeys. These two arts collect most of the waters of the Arabs and their homelands, and we know no one...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful.

Knowledge of the Best Inhabited Lands

The best inhabited lands from the northern section of the Earth to the Great Peninsula, which is the peninsula that Ptolemy calls Meroe [Ma'rib], cuts across four climes, from the habitation of the North to the Fifth. Its south is Yemen [Yemen]; its north is Sham (Levant) [Syria/Lebanon/Jordan/Palestine]; its west is Sharm Ayla (Gulf of Aqaba) [Jordan/Egypt] and what follows it of coasts to Al-Qulzum (Suez) and Fustat of Egypt [Egypt]; and its east is Oman [Oman], Bahrain [Bahrain], Kazimah [Kuwait], and Basra [Iraq]. Its middle is Hejaz [Saudi Arabia], the land of Najd [Saudi Arabia], and Al-Arud. It is called the Arabian Peninsula (Jazirat al-Arab) because the Arabic tongue is common in all of it.

The difference and beginning of its latitude - according to what the calculators say - on the coast of Aden [Yemen] is twelve degrees. The shadow of the head of Aries in these places is two digits and half a tenth of a digit.
What borders it in Sham at a latitude of thirty-two parts and seven digits and a half of shadow: Jerusalem [Palestine].
What borders it at a latitude of thirty-three parts and eight digits less a fifth of shadow: Ramla of Palestine [Palestine], Salamiyah [Syria], Baalbek [Lebanon] - Arabized from Ba'l Bak -, Caesarea [Palestine], Sidon [Lebanon], Anbar [Iraq], and Baghdad [Iraq] from the side of Iraq.
What borders it at a latitude of thirty-four and eight digits and a tenth of shadow: Homs [Syria], 'Ana [Iraq], Tyre [Lebanon], and Surra Man Ra'a (Samarra) [Iraq] from the side of Babylon.
What borders at a latitude of thirty-five and eight digits and fifty [minutes] of shadow: Manbij [Syria], Aleppo [Syria], Adana [Turkey], Antioch [Turkey], Qinnasrin [Syria], and what adjoins the East, Babylon of Nebuchadnezzar.
As for the beginning of its longitudes, and from the East, it is at Basra and what aligns with it

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
to the south, which is one hundred and seven degrees. The sun rises over it after rising over the longitudinal Equator, which is the meridian circle of the Dome [of the Earth], by one equal hour and two-thirds of a fifth of an hour. The end of its longitudes at the latitude of the city of ... and what aligns with it to the south from other than this peninsula is 119 degrees. The sun rises over it after its rising over the place of the Equator by two equal hours less a third of a fifth of an hour, and after rising over Basra by four-fifths of an hour, which is the amount of twelve straight degrees. If we multiply these degrees by the miles of a degree - which are sixty-six miles and two-thirds of a mile - eight hundred miles result for us. If we divide them by the miles of a stage for a diligent traveler, forty stages result for us.

If we want to know its length, we subtract the latitude of Aden, which is twelve degrees, from the latitude of thirty-five, leaving what entered from this peninsula to the likes of Tarsus [Turkey] and Mopsuestia (Al-Massisah) [Turkey] and what has a latitude of thirty-six and thirty-seven degrees. There remains for us from the degrees what, if we multiply it by the miles of a degree, results for us in miles one thousand five hundred and thirty-three miles. If we divide them by the miles of a stage for a diligent traveler, seventy-six and two-thirds result for us. This is the length of this peninsula and its stable width from its bottom. As for its width from its top, in the area of Aden Abyan [Yemen] it is little, then the width increases more in it from the eastern side to Hadramaut [Yemen], then the land of Mahra [Yemen/Oman], then Oman. The sea inclines wherever it enters Tihamah bit by bit to the West, so that its inclination from the coasts of Hejaz to Al-Qulzum towards the West is greater. Thus, this peninsula cuts across the noblest of climes in its middle, and there occurs in it what the sun and wandering planets align with twice in Taurus and Leo, and in Gemini and Cancer. It is the closest habitation to the Equator and is under a sign of the signs of might.

In it is the Sacred House, and the House which Allah made a place of return for the people and security, and the Station of Abraham, peace be upon him, and the Mother of Cities (Mecca), and the outlet of Prophecy, and the mine of the Message, and the abode of Abraham, the place of upbringing of Ishmael, and the birthplace of Muhammad, may Allah bless them all. And the dwelling of the Family of Allah; therefore, the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said to 'Attab ibn Asid: "I am appointing you as successor over the Family of Allah." To it Adam used to travel, and in it was his residence. In it is the land of Yathrib (Medina) [Saudi Arabia], the place of migration of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and his sanctuary, the center of Islam, the station of Imamate, and the pole of the Caliphate,

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
and the abode of glory, and the place of command. In it is the Holy Valley of Tuwa, and Mount Sinai, and the Mosque of Iliya (Jerusalem), and the traces of the Prophets, and the origins of the pious, and the gathering places of the chosen ones, and the courtyard of the Gathering (Hashr), and the mountains of Mercy, and the place of devotion and worship. And Al-Sarat, cutting from the top of Yemen to the bottom of Sham. In it are the spots of eloquence, beauty, moderation of temperament, and goodness of colors - neither extreme blondness nor blueness - and medium hair growth - neither curly nor lank -, blackness of pupils, and intense whiteness of eyes, with zeal, nobility, generosity, honor, and giving what souls are stingy with, and patience at the hour of might. In it are the most skilled horsemen, for they are to them girths and saddle-cloths, and the best camel riders, for they are to them masters and firebrands. And the most faithful in keeping a covenant, and the most eloquent in speaking wisdom. In it are those who count a hundred between Hajj and Umrah, and those who visit the grave of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, intentionally without digression. In it is the Mosque founded on piety. In it are ancient kingdoms and great ruins, such as Na'it, Ghumdan, Hakar, Raydan, Baynun, Ghayman, Bark al-Ghimad, and Iram of the Pillars, and all that the Eighth Book of Al-Iklil included.

Knowledge of the Position of This Peninsula in the Inhabited World and Its Location in It

Know that the Earth is not flat, nor a carpet equal in middle and edges, but it is domed. That doming is not apparent with vastness; its doming only appears by its measurements against the parts of the celestial sphere. Thus, the horizon of every people cuts from it differently than the horizon of others cuts, longitudinally and latitudinally, in all habitation. Therefore, stars appear to the people of the South that the people of the North do not see, and stars appear to the people of the North that the people of the South do not see. These [Northerners] have stars that are eternally visible and circling around the pole, while for those [Southerners], they rise and set. I will set for you a clear measure for the common people regarding that. From that is that the altitude of Canopus (Suhayl) in Sana'a [Yemen] and what aligns with it, when it culminates, is more than twenty degrees, and its altitude in Hejaz is near ten, while in Iraq it is only seen on the horizon line, and it is not seen in the land of the North.

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
And there [in the North], Ursa Major (Banat Na'sh) does not set, while it sets in the places where Canopus is seen. This is the testimony of latitude. As for the testimony of longitude, it is the variation in the times of the start of eclipses, their middle, and their clearing on a line between East and West. Whoever's land is closer to the East, the hours of these times from the beginning of the night and day are more; and whoever's land is closer to the West, the hours of these times from the end of the night and the end of the day reversed to their beginning are more. That is evidence for the spherical nature of the location of dwellings and the Earth, and that the horizon circles differ in all parts of the inhabited world. If the surface of the Earth were a flat sheet, the view of Canopus and Ursa Major would be one.

Know that the inhabited part of the Earth is not all of it. Among the evidence for that: The sun on the two days of Equinox does not align directly overhead (zenith) anyone of the inhabitants of the Earth except those on the Equator, which is the middle belt of the Earth. They are the first inhabitants of the inhabited world from southern China, southern India, the land of Zanj (East Africa), and the Maldive Islands (Al-Dibajat). Then it inclines towards the North in the months of spring, until it reaches the head of Cancer at the limit of the length of the day. It does not align directly overhead except what is between the Equator and the land whose latitude is twenty-four parts, from Hejaz and Al-Arud and what aligns with that east and west. Whoever enters beyond this line into the North, no wandering planet aligns with them unless its maximum latitude in the North coincides with being at the head of Cancer at its maximum latitude; its alignment would be thirty-two degrees distant from the head of Aries. So it aligns with those whose land's latitude is this amount. Thus, it became clear to you that habitation is from the middle of the Earth to its northern side. Since it is spherical, habitation was in this form:

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
The beginning of this habitation is from the Equator, which has no latitude, to the end of the Seventh Clime, until the latitude - which is the altitude of the Pole - is fifty parts and a half. This is the limit of the dwellings of known nations. What almost is inhabited and migrated to in the summer may go beyond that: the extremities of the Khazars, the extremities of the Turks, the Tughuzghuz, and the Bulgars (Burghar) bordering the Romans (Byzantines) and what is beyond that. For its day shortens and vanishes until the night becomes predominant over it. It is the place called the Darknesses. The kings of the Arabs used to compete to enter it for the sake of reputation and far-reaching fame, not that there is booty or jewels there as the common people narrate. In some of those places, Tubba' al-Aqran perished.

As for what is behind the Equator to the South, its nature is like the nature of the Northern half, equal in all its conditions, except the amount we mentioned in the Book of Secrets of Wisdom regarding the difference of the two states of the sun at the head of its apogee and the point of its perigee. Hermes mentioned that there are climes in it like these. What prevents people from reaching it is the widening of the Great Sea before it, the intensity of the swell in it, the power of the wind, the greatness of the waves, and the distance of reach. Sailing almost becomes impossible in its gulfs, among which are the Sea of Zanj and the Sea of the East. So how...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
about it? And what mostly prevents [sailing] it in favorable times is distance and vastness. As for the Dark Sea of the West (Atlantic Ocean), it prevented those crossing it because of its entry into the North and its distance from the orbit of the planets. So its water thickened, and the winds condensed over it due to the lack of the sun aligning with it. Whatever sea the sun aligns with, it refines it and negates much of the thickness of winds from it, and ambergris deposits and shell beds and other things appear in it.

Knowledge of the Division of Climes according to Hermes the Wise

The First: India.
The Second: Hejaz and Yemen.
The Third: The land of Egypt.
The Fourth: The land of Babylon.
The Fifth: The land of the Romans (Byzantines).
The Sixth: Gog and Magog.
The Seventh: The land of China.

He made the Fourth Clime central, and made the remaining six surrounding it until the First meets the Seventh upon it. He made it an equal division; every country of these famous ones includes what borders it and enters into its domain.

Boundaries of this Fourth Clime, which is Babylon:
The First Boundary: Al-Tha'labiyyah of the land of the Arabs.
The Second Boundary: The bank of the river of Balkh [Amu Darya].
The Third Boundary: Nisibis [Turkey].
The Fourth Boundary: Daybul [Pakistan], which is the boundary of the Seventh Clime.
The Second [Clime]: Its boundary is the sea adjacent to Oman to Jeddah, along what circles it from Yemen to the land of Zanj and Abyssinia, to Al-Tha'labiyyah.
The Third Clime: Its boundary is the end of the land of Abyssinia adjacent to the land of Hejaz; to Nisibis; to the furthest Sham; to the sea which is between the land of Egypt and Sham; to the middle of the sea adjacent to Andalusia from the side of the West (Maghreb).
The boundary of the Fifth Clime: The Sea of Sham to the furthest Romans adjacent to the sea; to the land of the Khazars and Gog and Magog; to the boundary of the Fourth Clime.
The boundary of the Sixth Clime: The land of China to the river of Balkh; to the Sea of Sham which faces the East.
The boundary of the Seventh Clime: From India to the boundary of the Fourth Clime; to the boundary of the Sixth Clime.
He made each of these climes estimated at seven hundred parasangs by seven hundred. People have differed in its measurements.

Knowledge of the Division of Climes according to Ptolemy

As for Ptolemy and the ancient Greeks, they saw that the natures of the climes...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
and their constitution can only be strips from East to West adjacent to one another, from the Equator to where the North Pole falls at fifty degrees, which is double the declination plus two parts and a fraction. He defined in his Canon the latitude of each clime and the hours of its longest day at its middle, not its two ends, according to the saying of those who transmitted from him.

He made the middle of the First Clime: The city of Sheba in Ma'rib in the land of Yemen. He made the latitude: sixteen parts and a quarter and a fifth. The hours of its longest day: thirteen exactly.
The latitude of the Second Clime: The limit of the declination, which is twenty-three parts and five-sixths. The hours of its longest day: thirteen and a half.
The Third: The Clime of Alexandria. Its latitude is thirty parts and a sixth and a fifth of a part. Its hours: fourteen.
The Fourth: The Clime of Babylon. Its latitude: thirty-six parts and a tenth. The hours of its longest day: fourteen and a half.
The Fifth Clime: Its latitude is forty parts and nine-tenths and a third of a tenth of an hour (part?). Its hours: fifteen hours.
The Sixth Clime: Its latitude is forty-five parts and a half and a sixth of a tenth. The hours of its longest day: fifteen hours and a half.
The Seventh Clime: Its latitude is forty-eight parts and a half and a third of a tenth. Its longest day: sixteen hours.

He defined their furthest and nearest points and some of the famous lands they include. He said:
The First Clime passes at its middle from East to West over places where the longest day and latitude are as we mentioned. Its beginning is where its longest day is: twelve hours and three-quarters of an hour. Its latitude: twelve parts and a half. Its end is where its longest day is: thirteen hours and a quarter. Its latitude: twenty parts and a quarter. He said: The middle of this clime is the city of Sheba [and] what is at a similar latitude of the places of the Earth. Its beginning from the East is from the extremities of the land of China, passing south of China to the coasts of the sea south of the lands of India and Sindh, cutting the sea to the Arabian Peninsula and the land of Yemen and the Sea of Jeddah extending to Al-Qulzum, the land of Abyssinia, what is beyond the Nile, and south of the land of the Berbers, until it ends at the boundary of...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
the land of the Maghreb, which is before the Dark Sea by the amount we will mention later, Allah Almighty willing.

The Second Clime
The Second Clime passes at its middle from East to West over places where the longest day and latitude are what we mentioned. Its beginning is from the place where the hours of the First Clime ended to where its longest day is thirteen hours and forty-five minutes. Its latitude is twenty-seven degrees and a fifth. He said: The middle of this clime is in Tihamah of the land of the Arabs and what is at a similar latitude of the places of the Earth. Its beginning from the East is from the land of China, passing through the lands of India and Sindh to where the Green Sea - meaning the Sea of Zanj - meets the Sea of Basra. It cuts across the Arabian Peninsula, Mecca, Hejaz, the Sea of Al-Qulzum, Upper Egypt, cuts across the Nile and the land of the Maghreb at the middle of the land of Ifriqiya (Tunisia) and the land of the Berbers until it ends at the boundary of the Maghreb before the Dark Sea.

The Third Clime
The Third Clime passes at its middle from East to West over places where the longest day and latitude are what we have mentioned. Its beginning is from the place where the hours of the Second Clime ended to where its longest day is fourteen hours and a quarter. Its latitude is thirty-three parts and a third of a part. The middle of this clime is approximately in the desert of Kufa adjacent to the Wilderness of the Children of Israel in the days of Moses, peace be upon him; and what is at a similar latitude of the places of the Earth. Its beginning from the East is in the north of the land of China, India, Sindh, Kandahar, Kabul, Fars (Persia), Sijistan, Ashkelon, the land of Egypt, the land of Barqa, Ifriqiya, and the city of Kairouan until it ends at the boundary of the Maghreb before the Dark Sea.

The Fourth Clime
The Fourth Clime passes at its middle from East to West over places where the longest day and latitude are what we have mentioned. Its beginning is from the place where the hours of the Third Clime ended, and its latitude to where its longest day is fourteen hours and three-quarters of an hour. Its latitude is thirty...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
eight degrees and a half degree. The middle of this clime is approximately the city of Isfahan and what is at a similar latitude of the places of the Earth. Its beginning from the East is the end of the land of China, Tibet, Balkh, Khorasan, Al-Jibal, the land of Mosul, northern Sham, some of the Frontiers, the Sea of Sham, the island of Cyprus, and the land of Tangier until it ends at the boundary of the Maghreb before the Dark Sea.

The Fifth Clime
The Fifth Clime passes at its middle to the East from the West over places where the longest day and latitude are what we previously mentioned. Its beginning is from the place where the latitude of the Fourth Clime ended its hours to where its longest day is fifteen hours and a quarter. Its latitude is forty-three degrees. The middle of this clime is approximately the city of Marw (Merv), and what is at a similar latitude of the places of the Earth. Its beginning from the East is inside the land of the Turks, northern Khorasan, Azerbaijan, the districts of Armenia, the land of the Romans (Byzantines), the coasts of the Sea of Sham, the Northern [lands?], and Andalusia until it ends at the boundary of the Maghreb before the Dark Sea.

The Sixth Clime
The Sixth Clime passes at its middle from East to West over places where the longest day and latitude are what has been mentioned. Its beginning is from the place where the hours of the Fifth Clime ended. Its latitude to where its longest day is fifteen hours and three-quarters. Its latitude is forty-six parts and a half and a third and half a tenth of a part. The middle of this clime is approximately the northern land of Armenia. Its beginning from the East is inside the land of the Turks to the North and the land of the Khazars. It cuts across the Sea of Jurjan (Caspian Sea) to the land of the Romans, Constantinople, and the land of the Bulgars (Burjan) until it ends at the boundary of the Maghreb before the Dark Sea.

The Seventh Clime
The Seventh Clime passes at its middle from East to West over places where the latitude and hours of its longest day are what the explanation has folded (skipped/summarized). Its beginning is from the place where the latitude of the Sixth Clime ended.

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Its hours to where its longest day is sixteen hours and a quarter. Its latitude is fifty degrees. The middle of this clime is approximately the places deep in the north of the land of the Turks. Its beginning from the East is from the north of their lands. It passes over the coast of the Northern Sea of Jurjan, the Sea of the Romans, the land of the Bulgars (Burjan), and the Slavs (Saqaliba) until it ends at the boundary of the Maghreb before the Dark Sea.

Knowledge of What is After the Seventh Clime
Then the end of the latitude of the Seventh Clime to a latitude of fifty-four parts is not devoid of these nations we mentioned in the Seventh Clime. This amount is accessible and frequented by them; groups from the Tughuzghuz, Khazars, Gilan, Bulgars, and Slavs continue to frequent it. Then habitation ceases beyond this latitude to the place whose distance from the Northern Peg of the Earth, which has the Pole at its zenith, is the amount of the degrees of declination, which is twenty-four and an added third of a degree. That is whose latitude is sixty-six degrees. Because from this amount to ninety, it becomes distant from the path of the sun, and cold becomes excessive in it. Snow, ice, frost (Darib), chill (Shafif), frost (Saqi'), freezing cold (Qaris), moisture (Balil), and [Haja?] do not leave it, and other things that oppose the growth of animals and plants. Ptolemy detailed all the inhabited and uninhabited [regions] quarter hour by quarter hour. We will mention what he said following this chapter, Allah Almighty willing.

What Came from Ptolemy Regarding the Detailing of the Parts of the Northern Half
Ptolemy the Engineer said: We find the Earth compelling the mind with its geometric proofs that it is spherical inside the circle of the celestial sphere, separated from it on every side by ninety parts. The Circle of the Equator cuts it, which is the Equinoctial Line whose zone circles from the head of Aries to the head of Libra going, and from the head of Libra to the head of Aries returning, in two equal parts in degrees: One of them: The Southern Half. The Second: The Northern Half. The divider between these two parts is the Line of the Equator of the Earth, which is its zone aligned with the zone of the Circle of the Equator.

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
mostly, not partially, although we must mention the summaries of particular things to the extent that is useful.

What came from Claudius Ptolemy regarding the natures of the inhabitants of the populated part of the Earth by division and segmentation.

Ptolemy the Wise said: Since the Circle of Signs (Zodiac) was divided into four sections, which are the Triplicities (because each section of them is three signs on the nature of one of the four natures which are Fire, Earth, Air, and Water), the populated Earth was divided into four sections. Each section is attributed to a section of the Triplicities in nature, because every encompasser [influences] the nature of what it encompasses according to its nature.
The first of the Fire Triplicities are Aries, Leo, and Sagittarius.
The second Earth Triplicity is Taurus, Virgo, and Capricorn.
The third Air Triplicity is Gemini, Libra, and Aquarius.
The fourth Water Triplicity is Cancer, Scorpio, and Pisces.

The Triplicity of Aries is for the North-West; its first governing ruler is Jupiter because it is northerly, then Mars follows it because it is westerly.
The Triplicity of Taurus is for the opposite of this section, which is the South-East; its first governing ruler is the planet Venus because it is southerly, then Saturn follows it because it is easterly.
The Triplicity of Gemini is for the North-East; the owner of its first governance is Saturn because it is easterly, and Jupiter follows it because it is northerly.
The Triplicity of Cancer is for what opposes this section, which is the South-West; its first governing ruler is Mars because it is westerly, then Venus follows it because it is southerly.

He said: Since these things were so, and the position of its habitation was divided into four quarters equal in number to the Triplicities:
As for its latitude, it is divided by the line passing through our sea - meaning the Sea of Alexandria - starting from the place called the Strait of Hercules and taking to the gulf called Issicus, which is at the mountain ridge following it from the east. By this line, what is between the Southern and Northern side of it is separated.
Its longitude is divided by the line passing through the Arabian Gulf, the abyss called Aegean, Pontus, and the lake called Maeotis. It is the line which...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
separates the East and the West. Thus, these quarters divided by these two lines became compliant in position with the Triplicities.
One quarter of the quarters of this entire inhabited place - I mean the one between the North and West - is in the region of the lands called Celto-Galatia, which are generally named Europe. The nations of this quarter are the Slavs, Franks, Spaniards, and Turks of the West in Rome (Byzantium) and Qaliqala.
The quarter opposite this quarter - meaning between the East (Saba) and South - is in the region of the lands called Eastern Ethiopia, which is the southern part of Greater Asia.
The third quarter - I mean the one between the North and East (Saba) - is in the region of the lands called Scythia, which is the northern part of Greater Asia.
The quarter opposite this quarter - I mean the one between the blowing of the West Wind (Dabur) and South - is in the region of the lands called Western Ethiopia, which are generally named the lands of Libya.
He means by the North-West the land of the Romans and what is west of it; by the North-East Khorasan and what is east of it; by the South-East Sindh and India and what is east of them; and by the South-West Abyssinia and Zanj and what is west of them.

He also said: For each of the quarters previously mentioned, whatever of its parts is near the middle of the entire inhabited Earth, its position relative to that entire quarter it belongs to is contrary to its position relative to the entire inhabited Earth. That is because the quarter attributed to Europe, which is the place between North and West of the entire inhabited Earth, the position of what follows the middle of the inhabited Earth from it inclines to the angle opposite the angle in which that quarter is, inclining to the South and East. The matter is likewise in the rest of the Earth, so that from that, each of the quarters has a conformity with the two opposite Triplicities. The parts near the middle of it incline to the matter to which that part inclined, which is contrary to what it inclines to in its totality. The rest of its parts conform to the like of the totality of the quarter. It is necessary to take with the planets of the Triplicity of that quarter in conformity the planets that have governance in those other Triplicities...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
It is necessary in all dwellings to take the planets governing those Triplicities only in each of its quarters, except for the parts in the middle of habitation. For there, the planet Mercury is taken with the planets governing the Triplicities because it is of a shared intermediate domain.
It follows from this arrangement that the parts positioned between the North and West of the first quarter, which is between the North and West of the inhabited Earth - I mean the quarter attributed to Europe - conform to the Triplicity between the North and West, which is the Triplicity of Aries, Leo, and Sagittarius. By necessity, the governors for it became the lords of this Triplicity, I mean Jupiter and Mars, if they are attributed to the evenings.
The general nations inhabiting these parts are the people of the lands of the Slavs, the lands of Britannia, Galatia, Germania, Bastarnia, Italy, Gaul, Apulia, Sicily, Tyrrhenia, Celtica, and Spain. Most of these names may be pronounced with 'Ha' (Ah), so it is said Galatia (Ghalatiyah) whispering the Ha, and Galatia, Italia, Apulia - which is a great city like Amorium -, Sicily (Siqilliyah/Saqilliyah), Tyrrhenia like Cyrene, and whatever is like Malatya like Salamiyah.

He said: The people of these lands must be, mostly due to the leadership of this Triplicity and due to the planets sharing in its governance, unsubmissive, lovers of freedom, weapons, and toil, warriors, people of politics and cleanliness, of high ambitions. Since Jupiter and Mars are partners in them when in the state attributed to evenings, and the preceding parts of this Triplicity are masculine and the succeeding feminine, it happened to these nations that they have no jealousy in the matter of women and became light regarding intercourse with them. They are more desirous of masculinity and more jealous over them. He who commits that among them does not see that he has done a reprehensible ugly act, and he who has it done to him does not see that he is in reality devoid of manhood, relaxed, so he refrains from having it done to him. They hold themselves to manhood, consolation, trustworthiness, companionship of relatives, and doing good deeds.
