These lands we mentioned first: As for the lands of Britannia, Galatia, Germania, and Bastarnia among them, they conform to Aries specifically and Mars. Therefore, their inhabitants became mostly savage, reckless, their morals close to the morals of beasts - meaning reckless with no religion.
As for the lands of Italy, Apulia, and Sicily among them, they conform to Leo and the Sun. Therefore, their inhabitants became people of politics, doing good deeds, and consolation.
As for the lands of Tyrrhenia, Celtica, and Spain among them, they conform to Sagittarius and Jupiter. Therefore, their inhabitants became of sound hearts, lovers of cleanliness.

As for the parts in this quarter and what falls in the Arabian Peninsula leaning towards the middle of the inhabited Earth: Thrace (Taraqa), Macedonia, the land of Egypt, Illyria, Hellas (Al-Las), Achaea (Haya, originally Ahaya), Crete the island, the land called Cyclades, the coasts of Asia Minor which are the coasts of Egypt, and the island of Cyprus. These are the parts adjacent to the direction of the South and East from this quarter. They conform, with what we said, to the Triplicity attributed to what is between the South and East, I mean the Triplicity of Taurus, Virgo, and Capricorn. Venus, Saturn, and Mercury also share in its governance. Therefore, the inhabitants of these lands became more similar in forms than others, moderate in bodies and souls. They are also people of politics, strong, unsubmissive because of Mars. They are also lovers of freedom; each one of them is unique with a special law for himself and a leadership for himself, and they invent laws because of Jupiter. They love music - meaning beautiful songs -, education, jihad, and cleanliness in their management because of Venus. They are people of consolation, loving the hosting of strangers, justice, writing, and using speech because of Mercury; concealing secrets because of their conformity to Venus if attributed to evenings.
Also, if these lands are detailed and partitioned, those inhabiting the lands of Cyclades, the coasts of Asia Minor, and Cyprus become conforming specifically to Taurus and Venus. Therefore, they became mostly luxurious, lovers of cleanliness, caring for the matter of the body - meaning preferring the pleasure of bodies in food, drink, clothing, touch, smell, and hearing.
Those inhabiting Hellas, Achaea, and Crete became conforming to Virgo and Mercury. Therefore, they are people of logic specifically, loving education, and prioritizing care for the matter of the soul over the body - meaning preferring the pleasure of their spirits in wisdom, knowledge, and looking into obscure matters.
Those inhabiting the lands of Macedonia, Thrace, and Illyria became partners to Capricorn and Saturn. Therefore, they love kingship, their morals are not sociable, and they do not share in high things...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
...conform to Aries specifically and Mars. Therefore, their inhabitants became mostly savage, reckless, their morals close to the morals of beasts - meaning reckless with no religion. As for the lands of Italy, Apulia, and Sicily among them, they conform to Leo and the Sun. Therefore, their inhabitants became people of politics, doing good deeds, and consolation. As for the lands of Tyrrhenia, Celtica, and Spain among them, they conform to Sagittarius and Jupiter. Therefore, their inhabitants became of sound hearts, lovers of cleanliness.

As for the parts in this quarter and what falls in the Arabian Peninsula leaning towards the middle of the inhabited Earth: Thrace (Taraqa), Macedonia, the land of Egypt, Illyria, Hellas (Al-Las), Achaea (Haya, originally Ahaya), Crete the island, the land called Cyclades, the coasts of Asia Minor which are the coasts of Egypt, and the island of Cyprus. These are the parts adjacent to the direction of the South and East from this quarter. They conform, with what we said, to the Triplicity attributed to what is between the South and East, I mean the Triplicity of Taurus, Virgo, and Capricorn. Venus, Saturn, and Mercury also share in its governance. Therefore, the inhabitants of these lands became more similar in forms than others, moderate in bodies and souls. They are also people of politics, strong, unsubmissive because of Mars. They are also lovers of freedom; each one of them is unique with a special law for himself and a leadership for himself, and they invent laws because of Jupiter. They love music - meaning beautiful songs -, education, jihad, and cleanliness in their management because of Venus. They are people of consolation, loving the hosting of strangers, justice, writing, and using speech because of Mercury; concealing secrets because of their conformity to Venus if attributed to evenings.
Also, if these lands are detailed and partitioned, those inhabiting the lands of Cyclades, the coasts of Asia Minor, and Cyprus become conforming specifically to Taurus and Venus. Therefore, they became mostly luxurious, lovers of cleanliness, caring for the matter of the body - meaning preferring the pleasure of bodies in food, drink, clothing, touch, smell, and hearing.
Those inhabiting Hellas, Achaea, and Crete became conforming...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
to Virgo and Mercury. Therefore, they are people of logic specifically, loving education, and prioritizing care for the matter of the soul over the body - meaning preferring the pleasure of their spirits in wisdom, knowledge, and looking into obscure matters.
Those inhabiting the lands of Macedonia, Thrace, and Illyria became partners to Capricorn and Saturn. Therefore, they love kingship, their morals are not sociable, and they do not share in high things.

Section between the East and the South:
As for the second quarter which is in the southern region of the lands of Greater Asia, the parts of it which include the lands of India, China, Makran, Kerman, Fars (Persia), Babylon, the confluence of the two rivers (Mesopotamia), and Assyria, and its position is inclined towards the direction of the South and East of the entire inhabited Earth; by necessity, they became sharing in the Triplicity which is between the South and East, which is the Triplicity of Taurus, Virgo, and Capricorn. What governs these lands are Venus and Saturn, if they are attributed to the mornings. Therefore, the natures of the inhabitants of these lands followed the natures of these two governors. Therefore, they venerate Venus and call it Isis, and call Saturn Mithras the Sun. Among them are many who foretell things before they happen. They preserve the reproductive organs with those in the generative [power] for nature - meaning Jupiter and Venus; he means by the child the casting lots? - and the main organs in veneration of their resemblance to the planets. They are people of heat, frequently engaging in intercourse, engrossed in it. They are people of dancing and leaping, loving adornment, cleanliness, and selling because of Venus. Because of Saturn, they do not use much condiment? in their food, and some of them do not see eating meat [as permissible], like the Brahmins. Their management because of it is simple management. They openly display intercourse with women, not hiding for that. They do not bury their dead due to the condition of the form attributed to the mornings. They hate doing that with males very much. In some of these lands are those who approve of marrying mothers, sisters, and daughters, and having children with them. Some of them bow (Takfir) to others by gesturing with chests. Abu Muhammad said: Takfir is that he falls on his chin descending towards his chest and throws his palm to him. It is said it is the meaning of the saying of Allah Almighty: "And they fall upon their faces weeping." They are marked, with what we mentioned...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
towards high matters and compete in them due to the governing power in the heart conforming to the power of the Sun. They are, with most matters in clothing, adornment, and all bodily means, people of luxury and effeminacy due to the condition of Venus. Yet they are strong in their souls, warriors, due to the conformity of Saturn of the East.

Then this management separates into three ways according to the number of the signs of the Triplicity and their lords:
Taurus and Venus are singled out with Hamadan, Fars (Persia), the two Mahs (Media), and China from the East, in wearing clothes dyed with colors like the colors of Venus, covering the whole body with them except the chest, and in good food, comfort, luxury, freshness, mirth, and listening [to music] due to the nature of Venus.
Virgo and Mercury are singled out with Babylon and what is around it of Iraq, the confluence of the two rivers Al-Jazira, Sham (Levant), and the lands of Assyria. So the people of these spots became people of literature, wisdom, knowledge of stars, expertise in mathematical sciences, observers of planets, and [people of] measurement; they have intelligence and acumen.
Capricorn and Saturn are singled out with the land of India, Sindh, Makran, Sijistan, and what adjoins them. Therefore, their appearances are ugly, their colors blackened, not bright, nor morning-like [fair], nor clean. Their morals resemble the morals of beasts; their ways are rough.

As for the rest of the parts of this quarter which follows the middle of the entire inhabited Earth, and what falls in the Arabian Peninsula of it such as Idumaea, the land of Syria, the land of Palestine, the ancient lands of the Jews of Iliya (Jerusalem) - called in Hebrew Yerushalayim, and the Arabs Arabize it saying Urashalam -, the fertile lands of the Bedouins - meaning the desert of the Arabs of Najd, Hejaz, and Al-Arud -, and the lands of Phoenicia - meaning Yemen and what adjoins these lands -, it also accepts the conformity of the Triplicity attributed to the direction of the North and West, which is the Triplicity of Aries, Leo, and Sagittarius, governed by Jupiter, Mars, and Mercury also. Therefore, the people of these lands became more fluctuating in trade than others, people of transactions, people of cunning and deceit, disdainful of wealth due to the generosity in them. With them is weightiness of intellect, intelligence, and management in taking and giving. They love themselves. They are generally two-faced and double-tongued because of their conformity to these planets. Whoever of them is in the lands of Syria, which is the land of the Children of Israel, and the lands of...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Idumaea and the ancient lands of the Jews, they conform to Aries and Mars specifically. Therefore, these became reckless, not knowing Allah, Mighty and Majestic, with true knowledge. Abu Muhammad said: The proof of that is the request of the Children of Israel to Moses, peace be upon him, that Allah show Himself to them openly, and that He make for them a god they worship when they saw the idolaters in much of this.
Ptolemy said: They are deceitful, possessing lightness and recklessness with bravery in them, and they are people of wealth and richness.
As for whoever is in the lands of Phoenicia - meaning Yemen -, the lands of Palmyra, and the people of the deserts - meaning Mahra -, they conform to Leo and the Sun. Therefore, they became of sound chests, merciful hearts, lovers of the science of stars, venerating the sun especially among all the stars and prostrating to it.
As for those in the land of Najd and Hejaz and their Tihamas, they conform to Sagittarius and Jupiter. Their people therefore have good morals, beautiful appearance, easy living - meaning they suffice with the milk of their livestock -, and they have penetration in trade, taking, and giving, and suitability for beautiful doctrines, high matters, and leaderships. Their land is fertile, with many spices. Ptolemy only called it the land of the Bedouins because most Arabs are nomads. He called it fertile because it is the land most abundant in pasture without farms. Therefore, its people relied on grazing livestock and protected it with horses as there are no fortresses for them. He means that it has many spices with the flowers of the sands like chamomile, lavender, and others. Yemen gathers roses and many spices. Most of the herbs mentioned by Dioscorides in his book known as the Book of Herbs are not lacking in it, along with precious gems. It is devoid of width except at its coast in what approximates the weight of a mithqal and exceeds it. In it are places where ambergris is cast on its shores. Mahra and Banu Majid on the two coasts of the Sea of Yemen, east and west, have ambergris camels. That is because their grazing is on the coast. If the camel smells the ambergris, it kneels and does not rise until its owner misses it, seeks it, finds it near it, and picks it up. If he is slow to it, it does not leave until its strength weakens from passion; perhaps it dies, so that is out of fear for it.

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Section between the East and the North:
As for the third quarter which is in the direction of the North-East of the lands of Greater Asia, the lands it contains are Upper Armenia, Lower Armenia, Sogdia and its city Samarkand, Tabaristan, Jurjan, Muqan, Azerbaijan, the Khazars, Gilan, the Alans, Gog and Magog, Khorasan, Tibet, the land of the Turks, the land of the Tughuzghuz, and Sarmatia, which is the land of the women who cut off their breasts and engage in war.
Due to the governance of Jupiter and Saturn over this section, wealth and affluence became predominant over the people of this section. They venerate Jupiter. What they have of the two ancient gems is abundant. They are people of cleanliness in food and drink, wise men looking into divine matters. Their morals are morals of justice, free men, and their souls are noble and strong. They hate evil, detest gossip and slander. Their affection is true; it is easy for them to sacrifice themselves to death for their relatives and whoever asks their help in good, praiseworthy matters. They are moderate in intercourse with women, people of chastity and purity. They wear high-priced clothing and give gifts. Their ambitions are high. They have cunning, deceit, and depth in opinion and consideration. That is because of the partnership of Jupiter and Saturn in the easterliness.
Gemini and Mercury are singled out from this domain with Jurjan, Tabaristan, Armenia, and what borders it. So the people of these places became faster in movement, more inclined to malice; their conduct improved, their good appeared, their stratagems increased, their deceit became subtle, and their secrets were concealed due to the lightness of Mercury's movement and the length of its disappearance.
Libra and Venus are singled out with the land of Balkh, the land of Shash, and what borders it. Therefore, the people of this town became having much wealth, lovers of music, luxurious, and their life became soft and beneficial to them.
Aquarius and Saturn are singled out with Sogdia, Sarmatia - the land of women with cut breasts - and what takes its course - meaning the Turks and Khazars. Therefore, the people of these lands became mighty, strong, people of rudeness and coarseness, and strong bodies with savagery, ill-nature, and morals like the morals of beasts.

As for the remaining parts of this quarter which follows the middle of the inhabited Earth and what falls in the Arabian Peninsula of it or neighbors it, then Azerbaijan, the borders of the dwellings of Rabi'ah and the dwellings of Mudar to what...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
...follows the South and West, to what approached the east of the Levantine Frontiers. These lands are called in Greek Bithynia, Phrygia, Cappadocia, Lydia, and Cilicia - meaning Qaliqala and the side of Syria and Palmyra. It also accepts the conformity of the Triplicity attributed to what is between the South and West, which is the Triplicity of Cancer, Scorpio, and Pisces. Mars, Venus, and Mercury also share in the governance due to its sharing and the location of its share in the middle.
Therefore, the people of these lands mostly venerate Venus and call it by many different names in every name. They call Mars Adonis and by other names, and worship it. They attribute to these two planets secrets in which they follow the path of wailing. They are miserable, humiliated in souls, weary, inclined to evil and baseness. They take wages for going out in armies, war, looting, and captivity. They become in the count of slaves and are owned in war because the state of Mars and Venus is the eastern state which suits it. They are people of deceit, treachery, extravagance, vulgarity, drinking, and drunkenness. Because the exaltation of Mars is in Capricorn, which is the trine of Venus, and her exaltation is in Pisces, which is the trine of Mars, the advice of their women to their husbands and their love for them intensified; they are weary, tired, submissive.

Whoever of these is in the lands of Bithynia and Phrygia, they conform especially to Cancer and the Moon. Therefore, their men mostly became people of piety and submission. And in most of their women, due to the eastern position of the Moon and its masculine form - meaning it governed a land from the eastern domain while it is westerly, so its nature was released there - there came to be manliness, leadership, and warfare, like women who fear and flee from intercourse with men. They are lovers of weapons, cutting off the right breasts because of their need to go out in armies. They reveal these organs at the line-up in war to negate from themselves that it be thought of them that their natures are the natures of women.

As for the region of Syria from its east, Pamphylia, Cappadocia, and Palmyra, they conform to Scorpio and Mars. Therefore, most of them became reckless in religion, fools, people of boldness, deceit, malice, abundance of desires, and endurance of toil.
As for the lands...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
of Lydia and Cilicia - meaning Qaliqala - they conform to Pisces and Jupiter. Therefore, they became especially possessing much ownership in wealth, goods, and trades. They are people of freedom, consolation, and trustworthiness in transactions; they trust one another in taking and giving.

Section between the West and the South:
As for the fourth quarter which belongs to the region of the South-West, which is the land of the Sudan (Blacks) from Zanj, Abyssinians, Beja, Nubians, Fezzan, the land of Kairouan, and from Ifriqiya then Kairouan and Sus, then the lands of the Naked Sudan and Ghana, and other names prevail over it like Numidia and Gaetulia and others in the Greek tongue. It resembles the Triplicity of Cancer and is governed by Venus and Mars. They are westerly - meaning they are from the western domain - and southerly because Venus is southerly and the exaltation of Mars is southern.
Therefore, it happened to many of the people of these lands, due to the partnership of these two planets, that a king and a queen, siblings from one mother, rule among them. The man among them rules over the men, and the woman rules over the women. They preserve this law, and it is permanent, inheriting it.
Their natures are very hot. They are engrossed in intercourse with women who marry before their husbands deflower them. The women of some of them are shared among them due to their voracity and greed in lust. They are beautifiers, lovers of adornment, and adorn themselves with the attire of women because of the nature of Venus. Except that they have manliness in themselves, and their souls are masculine; they advance with it to destruction and ride with it upon danger because of the nature of Mars. They have malice, evil, falsehood, deceit, treachery, and corruption.
Cancer and the Moon are singled out from this division with Ifriqiya and Numidia and what borders them. Because the Moon is on its form of westerliness, the people of these lands became people of partnership and trade, and they are in utmost fertility.
As for Nubia and all Abyssinians and Zanj and what approached them from southern India, they conform to Scorpio and Mars. Therefore, their morals became the morals of beasts, more similar to them than to the morals of humans. They became people of quarrels, enmities, disputes, and hatred, disdaining life. They are not merciful among themselves, nor does one have compassion for another. Perhaps they did not...

they feel pity for their souls lest they destroy them by burning, strangling, and falling. As for Fezzan [Fezzan, Libya] and what is near it, and Al-Sus [Sous, Morocco] and the land of the Umayyads [Al-Andalus/Spain], Jupiter and Pisces have taken authority over them; therefore, they are free people, loving one another, possessing openness and a love for work. They are neither submissive nor subsurvient. They have gratitude and piety due to Jupiter; they venerate it, prostrate to it, and call it Amun. As for what befalls this quarter from the middle of the inhabited earth, meaning lower Kairouan [Kairouan, Tunisia], the borders of Egypt [Egypt], Aswan [Aswan, Egypt], the middle lands of Abyssinia [Ethiopia] which contain Badi [Badi, Sudan], Suakin [Suakin, Sudan], Aidhab [Aidhab, Egypt/Sudan], the land of mines, and the land of Yemen [Yemen] from the Sea of Aden [Gulf of Aden] and Abyan [Abyan, Yemen]: Although they enter into the nature of their domain, and Yemen specifically among them enters into the nature of what precedes it regarding the nature of what is between the West and the North and the Triplicity of Aries, and the dominance of the Sun and Leo over it among this Triplicity, its nature resembles the nature of the northeast facing it. It shares in the Triplicity of Gemini, whose managing governor is Saturn, and Jupiter and Mercury which participate with them if they are western. These places are close to the orbit of the five planets; therefore, they all share in the management of these places. Its people, for this reason, are people of religiosity, worship, love of Allah the Exalted, veneration, and attachment to His causes. They venerate the Jinn, love wailing, bury their dead in the earth, and hide them due to the shape attributed to the evenings, meaning the alignment of the planets to them in the setting. They use various laws and diverse religions. They sacrifice their souls in obedience to their Lord and die upon that with patience and anticipation of reward. If they possess [power], they are patient and acknowledge obedience; and if they rule, they are people of grandeur and great might. Their ambitions are generous. Their men take many wives, and likewise, their women take several husbands. They are engrossed in intercourse. Among them are those who marry sisters. Their men have many offspring, and their women conceive quickly. Their lands generate many things. Many of their males also have weak, effeminate souls, and among them are those who make light of the reproductive organs, meaning one who does not guard against menstruation and withdraw from it, and similar things, due to the participation of the inauspicious planets with Venus in the setting. When what is in the quarter is detailed, then the lands of Kairouan [Kairouan, Tunisia] and the land of Egypt [Egypt], especially...

...its lower parts, resemble Gemini and Mercury. Therefore, they are people of thought, understanding, and acumen in all things, especially in investigating matters of wisdom, obscure knowledge, and divine matters. They are people of divination, and they act upon the knowledge of all they have learned. They use hidden secrets and are, in general, strong in the educational sciences. As for the people of Thebais, Oasis [Al-Wahat], To, Ghalud, and Tiki [Troglodytica?], they resemble Libra and Venus; therefore, their natures became hot. They are people of movement, and their lands are fertile lands, so they are affluent and expansive. As for the people of Yemen [Yemen], Aden [Aden, Yemen], Abyan [Abyan, Yemen], and the middle Abyssinians [Ethiopians], they belong to Saturn and Aquarius and are upon their form. Thus, its people eat much meat and fish and migrate from places of drought to the fertile countryside. Their living is similar to the living of wild beasts, meaning there is no sauce/dye in their food. He said: This is what we have described regarding the resemblance of the planets and zodiac signs to each of the nations and their properties in many matters in a general way. We shall describe the resemblance of each of the nations to each of the zodiac signs in detail, according to what suits what preceded of the discussion on it, to facilitate looking into that in this manner. The lands that resemble Aries are the lands of Britannia [Britain], and facing it Itania, Galatia, and Germania [Germany], which are the lands of the Slavs and Bastarnae. What resembles it from the lands near the center is the land of Ancient Syria [Syria], Palestine [Palestine], Idumea, and the land of the Jews. What resembles Taurus is the land of Farania, Persia [Iran], and Media. From the lands in the center of civilization are the lands of Cyclades, Cyprus [Cyprus], and the coasts of Asia Minor. What resembles Gemini from the far regions is Jurjan [Gorgan, Iran], Tabaristan [Mazandaran, Iran], and Matina; and from the near middle is Kairouan [Kairouan, Tunisia], Marmarica [Libya/Egypt border], and Lower Egypt [Egypt]. For Cancer, from the far side is Numidia, Carthage (Qara Haduina), and Ifriqiya [Tunisia]; and from the near middle is Bithynia, Phrygia, and Colchis. For Leo, from the far side is Sicily [Sicily, Italy], Italy [Italy], Gaul [France], and Apulia; and from the near middle is the land of Yemen [Yemen], which is Qawaniya and Chaldea, which is Al-Kaldaniya and Orchini. For Virgo, from the far side is Babylon [Iraq], the Confluence of the Two Rivers (Mesopotamia), Al-Jazira [Upper Mesopotamia], and the land of Assyria...

...and Cilicia; and from the near middle is Pamphylia, Hellas, Achaea, Crete [Crete, Greece], and Assyria. It is as if he means by Cilicia, Qaliqala [Erzurum, Turkey], and by Pamphylia, the mountain of Al-Qabq [Caucasus]. And by Hellas, Greece [Greece]. For Libra, from the far side is the land of Bactria, which is the land of Balkh [Balkh, Afghanistan], Khorasan [Iran/Afghanistan], and the land of Serica [China/Silk Land]; and from the near middle is Thebais, Oasis, Troglodytica, and Tica. For Scorpio, from the far side is the land of Metagonitis, Mauretania—which is the land of Al-Andalus [Spain]—and Gaetulia; and from the near middle is the land of Syria [Syria], Commagene, and Cappadocia [Turkey]. For Sagittarius, from the far side is the land of Tyrrhenia, Celtica, and the land of Spania, meaning the Spaniards [Spain]; and from the near middle is the populated Land of the Arabs [Arabian Peninsula]. For Capricorn, from the far side is the land of India [India], Makran [Pakistan/Iran], Sijistan [Sistan], and Thrace; and from the near side is Macedonia, parts of the land of Egypt [Egypt], Crete, and Illyria. For Aquarius, from the far side is the land of Samarkand [Samarkand, Uzbekistan], Sogdia, and Alania; and from the near middle is the land of Yemen [Yemen], Aden [Aden], Abyan, and the middle Abyssinians. For Pisces, from the far side is the land of Fezzan [Fezzan, Libya], Nasamonitis, and Garamantica; and from the near middle is Lydia, Cilicia, and Pamphylia. Knowledge of what Mercury (Utarid) was singularized with in this division: Since the total management of the inhabited quarters of the earth belongs to the three superior planets and Venus from the inferior planets, and the Luminaries (Sun and Moon) and Mercury did not enter into it except through what their houses shared of the Triplicities, they dominated with most of their nature over three places of the inhabited world. The Sun dominated the East, so the nature of Saturn and Jupiter flourished in it, bringing enduring kingship, tyranny, long durations, the proclamation of things and their splendor, and the revealing of secrets. The Moon dominated the West due to its suitability to its nature, so the nature of Venus and Mars flourished in it, manifesting godliness, burial of the dead, keeping of secrets, concealing of many things, revelation, prophethood, books, revelation, boundaries, and ownership. Mars affects some of it to others according to its increase towards its fullness and its decrease towards its concealment. Mercury dominated the Middle due to the shortness of its chord and the mediation of its nature between the natures of the planets—sometimes inauspicious and sometimes auspicious, sometimes masculine and sometimes feminine, sometimes diurnal and sometimes nocturnal, and so on. Because...

...its house is Gemini, which is at the center of civilization, and this house aligned with what is between Mecca [Mecca, Saudi Arabia] and Medina [Medina, Saudi Arabia]. Thus, it manifested in this place wondrous logic, brought wisdom, opened the doors of knowledge regarding intelligence, cunning, lightness of spirits and movements, delicateness of the edges of tongues, and the burning of hearts in things whose mention connects to the mention of what entered from the quarters into the Middle. So, the natures of the Triplicities shared in it. Whenever the two planets in the Triplicity governed over their own domain, they manifested the excellence of the indication; and if they governed from the Triplicities over a domain other than their own, that excellence was inverted, becoming a deficiency and corruption... for Saturn and Jupiter, which are for the East and the North. If they govern what is between the West and the South, their indication is corrupt. Likewise, if they governed a people in the west of the earth, or if Mars, Venus, and the Moon governed a land in the East, they brought a corrupt indication, so know this. The first book of the Description of the Lands and their Participation is completed. Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds, and Allah's blessings be upon Muhammad and all his family. Knowledge of the longitudes and latitudes of famous Arab cities: The longitude of Aden [Aden, Yemen] from the East is one hundred and seventeen degrees. The sun rises over it after its rising over the Dome (Cupola of the Earth) by one hour and four-fifths of an hour. The elevation of the North Pole and the depression of the South Pole over it, which is the latitude, is approximately twelve degrees. The longitude of Al-Janad [Al-Janad, Yemen] is greater than the longitude of Aden by half a degree, and its latitude is thirteen degrees. Zafar [Zafar, Yemen] and Sana'a [Sana'a, Yemen] are the same in longitude; the longitude of each from the East is one hundred and eighteen degrees. The sun rises over them after its rising over the Dome by one hour, a half, a fifth, and a sixth of an hour. The latitude of Sana'a, according to what its people found, is fourteen and a half degrees. The latitude of Zafar is thirteen and a half degrees. The latitude of Marib [Marib, Yemen] is fourteen and two-thirds degrees, and its longitude from the East is one hundred and seventeen degrees; the sun rises...

...over it just as it rises over Aden. The longitude of Sa'dah [Sa'dah, Yemen] from the East is one hundred and eighteen and a half degrees. The sun rises over it after its rising over the Dome by two hours minus ten [minutes/parts]. Its latitude is fifteen and two-thirds degrees. The longitude of Najran [Najran, Saudi Arabia] from the East is one hundred and seventeen degrees and five-sixths of a degree. The sun rises over it before its rising over Sa'dah by about twenty-two and a half parts of an hour, and its latitude is sixteen degrees. The latitude of Al-Falaj [Al Aflaj, Saudi Arabia] is eighteen degrees, and its longitude is one hundred and fifteen and a half degrees. Al-Yamama [Al-Yamama, Saudi Arabia]: its latitude is twenty degrees and its longitude is one hundred and fifteen degrees. Bahrain [Bahrain]: its latitude is... and its longitude is one hundred and thirteen degrees. Basra [Basra, Iraq]: its latitude is thirty-one degrees and its longitude is one hundred and seven degrees. Kufa [Kufa, Iraq]: its latitude is thirty-one and three-quarters degrees and its longitude is one hundred and ten and a quarter degrees. The latitude of Al-Mahjam [Al-Mahjam, Yemen] is like the latitude of Sana'a, and its longitude is like the longitude of Zabid [Zabid, Yemen]. The latitude of Al-Khasuf, the city of Hakam, is like the latitude of Sa'dah, and its longitude from the East is one hundred and nineteen degrees. The latitude of Athr is sixteen and a quarter degrees, and its longitude from the East is one hundred and nineteen and a quarter degrees. The latitude of Shibam Hadramawt [Shibam, Yemen] is like the latitude of Zafar, and its longitude from the East is one hundred and sixteen degrees. Al-As'aa in Mahra: its longitude from the East is one hundred and twelve degrees, and its latitude is sixteen and a half and a third of ten [sic] degrees. The latitude of Mecca [Mecca, Saudi Arabia] according to Al-Fazari is twenty-three and a third degrees, and according to Habash it is twenty-one degrees—and it is the most established (aqwamu). Its longitude according to Al-Fazari is one hundred and sixteen degrees from the East, and according to Habash one hundred and ten. Some people of Sana'a said: one hundred and twenty, which is more likely. Habash said the longitude of Medina [Medina, Saudi Arabia] is one hundred and eighteen, and its latitude in degrees of inclination is twenty-four. Al-Fazari says: its latitude is thirty minus a fraction, and that is not found to be so. He said: The longitude of Bayt al-Maqdis [Jerusalem] is one hundred and twenty-seven, and its latitude is thirty-one degrees and five-sixths of a degree.

Damascus [Damascus, Syria]: its longitude is one hundred and twenty-four degrees and the latitude is thirty-three degrees. Description of the Inhabited Earth, which is the Book of the Description of the Arabian Peninsula. Abu Muhammad said: As for the mention of the natures of the inhabitants of the Arabian Peninsula, it has entered into the mention of the natures of the whole. There remains the mention of the dwellings of this Peninsula, its paths, its waters, its mountains, its pastures, its valleys, and the attribution of every place in it to its inhabitants and its owner, in a manner of brevity. And into how many parts is this Peninsula divided regarding municipal parts, administrative divisions, Sultanic regions, open land sides, and Bedouin domains. So that whoever looks into this book is as if he were in the place of Dhul-Qarnayn, the surveyor of the earth, and Tamim al-Dari, the traveler of its populated parts, and the expert guide of its night-conversers, and the overseer of its farthest and nearest parts, so that he may know the vastness of the land of his Lord, the multitude of His creation, and the abundance of His provision. There is no god but Allah, the Mighty, the Wise. Chapter: What was reported from Ibn Abbas, may Allah have mercy on him, regarding the mention of the Arabian Peninsula. As for the hadith of Abdullah ibn Abbas regarding the Arabian Peninsula, it is what was transmitted to us from Muhammad ibn al-Sa'ib al-Kalbi from Abu Salih from Ibn Abbas from a source, and from Muawiyah ibn Umayrah ibn Makhaws al-Kindi, that he heard Abdullah ibn Abbas ibn Abd al-Muttalib when a man asked him about the children of Nizar ibn Ma'add. He said: They are four: Mudar, Rabi'a, Iyad, and Anmar. The children of Ma'add ibn Adnan ibn Udad multiplied, grew, and followed one another. Their dwellings were Mecca [Mecca, Saudi Arabia] and what adjoined it of Tihama. They spread into the lands adjacent to them and competed for dwellings and places. The land of the Arabs on that day was empty, and there was hardly anyone in its Tihama, its Najd, its Hijaz, and its Arud, because Nebuchadnezzar had destroyed its signs and exiled its people, except for those of them who had fortified themselves in the peaks of mountains and their ravines and joined places where no one could reach them, avoiding the paths of his soldiers and the tracks of his horses, fleeing to them from them. So they divided the Ghaur (lowland)—the Ghaur of Tihama—among themselves into seven divisions. For each division was what adjoined it of the highlands of Hijaz, Najd, and the Tihamas of Yemen for their dwellings, their roamings, and the grazing grounds of their livestock and cattle. The land of the Arabs entirely on that day...

...was in five divisions in a surrounding island/peninsula—meaning circling; 'Tawf al-Jabal' is its circumference, and from it is the Tawaf around the Kaaba, and 'Tawa'if' of people are groups from the edges of people. It is narrated as 'Mutiqa' from 'Tawq' (collar), which is what encircles the neck of silver collars and the like—and it is the Peninsula of the Arabs (Jazirat al-Arab) which became the portion of those whom Allah, Blessed and Exalted, made speak the Arabic tongue when the tongues were confused at Babylon [Babylon, Iraq] in the time of Nimrod son of Cush son of Canaan son of Ham son of Noah, on the day Peleg son of Eber son of Shelah son of Arphaxad son of Shem son of Noah divided the earth among the children of Noah, peace be upon him: Shem, Ham, and Japheth. The lands of the Arabs were only named 'Al-Jazira' (The Island) because of the surrounding of seas and rivers around it from its corners and edges. They became in it like an island among the islands of the sea. That is because the Euphrates [Euphrates River], returning from the land of the Romans [Byzantine Empire], appears in the region of Qinnasrin [Qinnasrin, Syria], then descends upon Al-Jazira [Upper Mesopotamia] and the Sawad of Iraq [Southern Iraq], until it pours into the sea from the side of Basra [Basra, Iraq] and Al-Ubulla [Al-Ubulla, Iraq] and extends to Abadan [Abadan, Iran]. The sea takes from that place heading west, bending around the land of the Arabs, coming upon Safwan [Safwan, Iraq], Kazima [Kazima, Kuwait], and reaching Qatif [Qatif, Saudi Arabia], Hajar [Al-Hasa, Saudi Arabia], the coasts (Asyaf) of Bahrain [Bahrain], Qatar [Qatar], Oman [Oman], and Al-Shihr [Ash Shihr, Yemen]. A neck from it inclines to Hadhramaut [Hadhramaut, Yemen] and the region of Abyan and Aden [Aden, Yemen] and Dahlak [Dahlak Archipelago, Eritrea]. That neck elongates and thrusts into the Tihamas of Yemen, the lands of Farasan [Farasan Islands, Saudi Arabia], Hakam, the Ash'aris, and Akk, and proceeds to Jeddah [Jeddah, Saudi Arabia], the coast of Mecca, and Al-Jar [Al-Jar, Saudi Arabia], the coast of Medina, and the coast of Al-Tur [Tor, Egypt] and the Gulf of Ayla [Gulf of Aqaba], and the coast of Raya—a district of the maritime districts of Egypt—until it reaches the Qulzum of Egypt [Suez, Egypt] and mixes with its lands. The Nile [Nile River] approaches from the west of this neck from the upper lands of the Sudan, extending parallel to the sea with it, until it pours into the sea of Egypt and the Levant (Sham) [Mediterranean Sea]. Then that sea approaches from Egypt until it reaches the land of Palestine [Palestine], passing by Ashkelon [Ashkelon, Israel] and its coasts, and coming upon Tyre [Tyre, Lebanon], the coast of Jordan, and upon Beirut [Beirut, Lebanon] and those associated with it from the coasts of Damascus. Then it penetrates to the coasts of Homs [Homs, Syria] and the coasts of Qinnasrin, until it mixes with the region from which the Euphrates approached, descending upon the edges of Qinnasrin and Al-Jazira to the Sawad of Iraq. So the land of the Arabs became, from this Peninsula in which they settled and circulated, in five divisions according to the Arabs and in their poetry: Tihama, Hijaz, Najd, Al-Arud...

...and Yemen. That is because the Sarat Mountain [Sarawat Mountains], which is the greatest and most mentioned mountain of the Arabs, approached from the depth of Yemen until it reached the edges of the deserts of Sham (The Levant). The Arabs named it Hijaz because it formed a barrier (hajaza) between the Ghaur (Lowland), which is descending, and Najd (Highland), which is rising. So whatever was behind that mountain to its west towards the coasts of the sea, from the lands of the Ash'aris, Akk, Hakam, Kinana, and others, and below them to Dhat Irq and Al-Juhfa and what adjoined it, and what sank of its land, is the Ghaur—the Ghaur of Tihama—and Tihama encompasses all of that. And whatever was on this side of that mountain to its east, from the deserts of Najd to the edges of Iraq and Al-Samawa and what follows it, became Najd; and Najd encompasses all of that. The mountain itself is its Sarat (Back/Ridge), and it is the Hijaz. In a narration, it is Al-Jarr, and Al-Jarr is the foot of the mountain. Qays ibn al-Khatim said: 'Ask the man Abdullah at Al-Jarr, did he see... Our battalions in war, how was their fighting?' Whatever was retained to its east by the mountains and descended to the region of Fayd [Fayd, Saudi Arabia] and the two mountains of Tayy to Medina [Medina, Saudi Arabia] and returning to the land of Madhhij from Tathlith [Tathlith, Saudi Arabia] and what is below it to the region of Fayd, is Hijaz. The Arabs call it Najd, Jals, and Hijaz, and Hijaz encompasses all of that. The lands of Al-Yamama [Al-Yamama/Riyadh region] and Bahrain [Bahrain/Eastern Arabia] and what adjoins them became Al-Arud (The Obstructing/Breadth); it contains Najd and Ghaur due to its proximity to the seas and the depression of places within it, and the flow of valleys in it; Al-Arud encompasses all of that. Whatever was behind Tathlith and what neared it to Sana'a [Sana'a, Yemen] and what adjoined it to Hadhramaut [Hadhramaut, Yemen], Al-Shihr [Ash Shihr, Yemen], Oman [Oman], and what follows it became Yemen; it contains Tihamas and Najd, and Yemen encompasses all of that. Abu Muhammad said: What supports this regarding all of Yemen for these places are the letters of appointments from the Caliphs to the governors of Sana'a, Yemen and its provinces (Mikhlaws), Akk, Oman, and Hadhramaut—meaning by Akk the land of Tihama. Sa'id ibn al-Musayyib used to say: When Allah, Blessed and Exalted, created the earth, it swayed with its inhabitants, so He struck it with this mountain, meaning Al-Sarat. Its beginning is from Yemen until it reached Sham (The Levant), and the valleys cut through it until it ended at Nakhla. From it were Hys and Yasum, and they are called the Yasumayn, just as the sun and moon are called Al-Qamaran, and Abu Bakr and Umar are called Al-Umaran. The poet of Rajaz said:

'O She-camel, march! Yasuman has appeared... So traverse them, and the peaks of Ghazwan will appear.' Ghazwan is the high mountain of Arafat [Mount Arafat]. Then the mountains appeared after it, and among them were Al-Abyad, the mountain of Al-Arj, Quds, Arah, Al-Ash'ar, and Al-Ajrad. These are the mountains between Mecca and Medina on the right of one going out from Mecca to Medina and the left of one returning to Mecca. The Arabs have mentioned Hijaz, Jals, Tihama, and Najd in many poems, and all of that confirms what we have described. Amr Barraq al-Thumali from Azd said: 'He frequented Tihama then became a dweller of Jals (Highland)... In peaks between Al-Shatt and Al-Tubaq.' He is sometimes called Ibn Barraqa, but he is Amr ibn Barraqa from Hamdan, then from Nahm, and he was a brave poet. He is the one who said in his Mym-rhyme poem: 'And if a people were my raid target, I raided them... So am I, in this, O people of Hamdan, an oppressor? Whenever a sharp heart, a sword... and a proud nose come together, injustices avoid you.' Layla bint al-Harith al-Kinaniyah said: 'Did Thumalah prevent what is near it... Then a Ghaur (Lowland) afterwards or a Jals (Highland), Thumala?' Umayyah ibn Abi 'A'idh al-Hudhali said: 'Hudhayl protected the heart of Hijaz, and indeed... The Hijaz of Hudhayl overtops people from above.' Labid ibn Rabi'a ibn Malik ibn Ja'far ibn Kilab said: 'Murriyah settled in Fayd and neighbored... The people of Hijaz, so where from you is her destination?' Hubayra ibn Amr ibn Jurthuma al-Nahdi said: 'And Kinda raves with threats, and Madhhij... And Shahran are from the people of Hijaz and Wahib.' Shahran is in the Sarat of Bisha [Bisha, Saudi Arabia], Turabah, and Tabalah, between Jurash and the beginning of the Sarat of Azd. Some of Banu Murra ibn Awf said in the days of Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan:

'We remained in the might of Hijaz while you... Were in the depression of the Bathaa between the two rugged mountains (Al-Akhashabayn).' And regarding Shurayh ibn al-Ahwas: 'I honor you in Hijaz, and if you go far... You find me among the mightiest of the people of Najd.' Tarafa ibn al-Abd said, mentioning the killing of Amr ibn Mamah on the day of Qadib: 'But a band from Qays Aylan called out... Driving the Barabir in the land of Hijaz.' The Barabir here are sheep. It is also narrated: 'Driving the Barair in the upper Hijaz', and Barair here is the plural of Barir, which is the fruit of the Arak tree. 'And he sniffed Barair in the upper... Ranyah [Ranyah, Saudi Arabia] and Turabah [Turabah, Saudi Arabia] among the dwellings of the sons of the sons of Hilal.' Al-Mukhabbal al-Sa'di said: 'If the plains of the land are denied to me... Then I am traversing the paths of Al-Arud.' Jarir ibn Atiyah ibn al-Khatafa said: 'A love in Tihama and a love in Najd... So the Tihamas and the Najds unite.' Dhat Irq is the separation between Tihama, Najd, and Hijaz. In it, the poet says: 'It is as if the riding camels did not kneel at Tihama... When their chests ascended from Dhat Irq.' Another from the people of Dhat Irq said: 'And we are in a high plain, not of Najd... Nor of Tihama, so the eye chokes with tears.' Knowledge of the detail of this Peninsula according to the people of Yemen: It is, according to the people of Yemen, Yemen and Sham (North). Its south is Yemen and its north is Sham, Najd, and Tihama. So Al-Najd is what rose from it from the Sarat and appeared from its peaks going towards the East in a level plain below what descends to Al-Arud. And Hijaz is what formed a barrier between Yemen and Sham. And Sarat is what became consistent and elongated in the earth from the mountains of this Peninsula, likened to the back (Sarat) of leather. And Arud is what extended sideways (a'rada) from these places eastwards to the domain of the northeast. And Iraq and Shihr: Iraq is what...

...aligned with the fresh waters and the sea from the earth, taken from the 'Iraqay' (crossbars) of the bucket. And Al-Shihr is taken from the 'Shihr' of the earth, which is the saltiness of the earth and the growing places of saline plants. We will detail the description of every section of these lands unique in their names. Whatever of them is a narrow land whose contents we can encompass, like Al-Arud and Najran, [we will describe fully]. And whatever is a vast land whose smallest parts exceed the largest of Al-Arud, we will describe with a general, traversing description, and we cannot do otherwise due to the vastness of the lands and the multitude of dwellings. Description of Yemen the Green: It was named 'Yemen the Green' due to the abundance of its trees, fruits, and crops. The sea surrounds it from the East to the South, then returning to the West. A line separates it from the rest of the Arabian Peninsula, taking from the borders of Oman [Oman] and Yabrin [Yabrin, Saudi Arabia] to the border of what is between Yemen and Al-Yamama, then to the borders of Al-Hajirah, Tathlith [Tathlith, Saudi Arabia], the rivers of Jurash [Jurash, Saudi Arabia], and Katnah, descending in the Sarat upon the peaks of Anz, to Tihama upon Umm Jahdam, to the sea opposite a mountain called Kadummul, near Hamdah. That is the border between the land of Kinana and Yemen from the belly of Tihama. The first surrounding of the sea around Yemen is from the side of Dama, then Tanwa, then Al-Jamjah, then Ras al-Fartak [Ras Fartak, Yemen], then the edges of the mountains of Al-Yahmad and what fell and led from them to the region of Al-Shihr [Ash Shihr, Yemen], then Al-Shihr, then Ghubb al-Khays, then Ghubb al-Ghayth—a clan of Mahra—then Ghubb al-Qamar [Bay of al-Qamar] (spelled like Qamar/Moon of the sky), then Ghubb al-Aqar—a clan of Mahra—then Al-Khayraj, then Al-As'aa. In the middle of this coast eastward between Oman and Aden is Raysut [Raysut/Salalah, Oman]. It is a refuge like a citadel, rather a citadel built as a structure on a mountain. The sea surrounds it except from one side, which is the land. Whoever wants Aden, his path is upon it; if he wants to enter, he enters, and if he wants, he passes the path and does not turn to it. Between the path that branches to it and the path traveled to Oman is the amount of a mile. In it resided people of Azd from Banu Jadid. People from Al-Qamar in our early time attacked those in it by night and killed them. Among those killed in it was a man called Amr ibn Yusuf al-jadidi, one of its leaders, an Azdi. Those who scrutinized that from Al-Qamar were Banu Khanzarit, and they expelled whoever remained of its people from it. So they dispersed to the lands of Al-Ghayth...

...of Mahra and inhabited a place called Hasik [Hasik, Oman] and Mirbat [Mirbat, Oman] for a period. Then the Thaghra from Mahra helped them until they returned to their citadel. When they entered the citadel with the help of the Thaghra, Banu Khanzarit feared and went out to the lands. Their leader Muhammad ibn Khalid went out with a group of Banu Khanzarit until they entered a place called Rada' (with a damma on the R), whose inhabitants are Banu Riyam, a clan of Al-Qamar, and they neighbored them. Banu Riyam have a great fortress in Oman that cannot be sought (impregnable). It is said that the ancient inhabitants of Raysut were the Bayasira, and Jadid from Azd descended upon them and became leaders among them. Then people from Arab tribes other than Mahra exhausted it with Jadid, and they sometimes intermarry with Mahra. The leader of those in it after that was Musa ibn Rabi' from Al-Adas. Then the sea turns upon Yemen westward and northward from Aden, passing by the coast of Lahj [Lahj, Yemen] and Abyan [Abyan, Yemen], and the dune of Yaramis—which is a Ribat (frontier post)—and the coasts of Banu Majid from Al-Mandab [Bab el-Mandeb], then the coast of Al-Umayrah, then Al-arah, then to Ghalafiqa, the coast of Zabid [Zabid, Yemen], then Kamaran [Kamaran Island], then Atinah, then Al-Hardah, to Munfahiq Jabir, which is a headland (cape) with abundant, sharp winds, to Al-Sharjah, the coast of the land of Hakam, then the courtyard of Jazan [Jazan, Saudi Arabia], then Athr, then Ras Athr, which has many waves, to the coast of Hamdah. This is what surrounds Yemen from the sea. Mention of the islands of the sea: As for what neighbors the coasts of Yemen from the islands in the surrounding sea, there is Dahlak [Dahlak Archipelago, Eritrea]. And Kamaran, which is a fortress for whoever rules the Tihama of Yemen. Then the islands of Farasan [Farasan Islands, Saudi Arabia]. Then the island of Zeila [Zeila, Somalia], in which is a market to which goats are brought from the land of Abyssinia [Ethiopia]; their hides are bought, and most of their skinned carcasses are thrown into the sea. And the island of Berbera [Berbera, Somalia], which cuts across from the border of the coasts of Yemen, adjoining Aden in the sea from the direction of the rising of Canopus (Suhayl) to what is east of it. What is close to it is Aden, and facing it is Jabal al-Dukhan. And the island of Socotra [Socotra, Yemen], to which Socotran Aloe is attributed. It is the island of Berbera which cuts between Aden and the land of the Zanj [East Africa], fixed on the bearing. If one going out from Aden to the land of the Zanj takes [the route] as if he wants Oman, the island of Socotra goes along with him on his right until it ends, then he turns with it from the side of the Sea of the Zanj. The length of this island is...

...eighty parasangs. In it are people from all the tribes of Mahra, and in it are about ten thousand fighters, and they are Christians. They mention that a people from the land of the Romans (Byzantines) were cast there by Chosroes (Kisra), then tribes from Mahra settled with them and lived with them, and some of them converted to Christianity with them. In it are many palm trees, and Ambergris falls to it. In it is Dragon's Blood (Dam al-Akhawayn), which is Al-Ayda', and much Aloe. As for the people of Aden, they say that no one from the Romans entered it, but its people were the monks (Al-Rahabinah), then they perished, and Mahra and a people from the Shurat (Kharijites) inhabited it. The call of Islam appeared in it, then the Shurat increased in it and attacked those Muslims who were in it and killed them except for ten souls. In it is a mosque at a place called Al-Suq. The Tihami Cities of Yemen: Aden [Aden, Yemen] is southern Tihami; it is the oldest market of the Arabs. It is a coast surrounded by a mountain which had no path, so a gate was cut in the mountain with iron picks, and it got a path to the land and a pass. Its water source is water called Al-Hayq, aquifers in sand on the side of the desert of Iram. In it (the city) itself are wells of salty and brackish water. The Maribiyyun and Hamahimiyyun and Malahiyyun inhabited it; the Maribiyyun say they are from the children of Aaron. Among the people of Aden are Ibn Munadhir the poet and Ibn Abi Umar the Hadith scholar. And Lahj [Lahj, Yemen]: in it are the Asabih, and they are the children of Asbah ibn Amr ibn Harith Dhu Asbah ibn Malik ibn Zayd ibn Al-Ghawth ibn Sa'd ibn Awf ibn Adi ibn Malik ibn Zayd ibn Sadad ibn Zur'ah, who is Himyar the Younger. And Abyan [Abyan, Yemen]: in it is the city of Khanfar and Al-Rawagh, and in it are Banu Amir from Kinda, a mighty tribe. And Mawza [Mawza, Yemen], and Al-Shiqaq and Al-Mandab [Bab el-Mandeb], both belonging to Banu Majid ibn Haydan ibn Amr ibn Al-Haf. And Farasan: a tribe from Taghlib, and they were anciently Christians and have churches in the islands of Al-Farasan [Farasan Islands] which have fallen into ruin. There is martial valor in them; Banu Majid sometimes fight them. They conduct trade to the land of Abyssinia [Ethiopia] and have one voyage in the year, and many people join them. The genealogists of Himyar say they are from Himyar. And Al-Hasib, which is the village of Zabid [Zabid, Yemen]; it belongs to the Ash'aris. Lately, Banu Waqid from Thaqif mixed with them. The villages of its deserts are Hays [Hays, Yemen], which belongs to Al-Rakb from Al-Ash'ar, and Al-Qahmah belonging to the Ash'aris...

...and in it are people from Khawlan and Hamdan. And Dhawal Al-Ma'qar. And Al-Kadra, a city inhabited by a mixture of Akk and Al-Ash'ar, and its desert is entirely Akk except for a small number from Khawlan. Amr ibn Zayd, the brother of Banu Hayy ibn Awf from Khawlan, said: 'A group of us passed, stepping with spears... So Shahr became their home, and Zabid.' Then Al-Mahjam [Al-Mahjam, Yemen], which is the city of Surdud. Most of its deserts and its people of might are Khawlan from its upper and lower parts, and its northern parts belong to Akk. And Mawr [Mawr, Yemen], and in it is a city called Balahah belonging to Akk; Mawr is one of the great watering places of Yemen. Then Al-Sa'id from the land of Hakam, a village belonging to Hakam. And Al-Saqiftan, a village belonging to Hakam on the Wadi Khulab; in it and in Al-Sa'id are the Ashraf of Hakam, Banu Abd al-Jadd. Then Al-Hajar, the village of Damad and Jazan [Jazan, Saudi Arabia]. In the land of Hakam are many villages called Al-Makharif and Sabya [Sabya, Saudi Arabia]. Then Baysh [Baysh, Saudi Arabia], and in it are clients (Mawali) of Quraysh. Its coast is Athr, and it is a market of great importance. The Arabs make it heavy (emphasize it) so they say 'Aththar'. To the volcanic field (Harrah) of Athr are attributed the lions called 'Lions of Athr' and 'Lions of Atud'. It is a village of its deserts, mentioned by Ibn Muqbil who said: 'Their sitting in it is like the lean high-nosed ones (lions)... As if they are lions in Turj or lions in Atud.' And Umm Jahdam is a village between Kinana and Azd, and it is the border of Yemen. The Najdi Cities of Yemen and what resembles Najd: The first of the cities of Yemen on the bearing of its Najd is Al-Janad [Al-Janad, Yemen] from the land of the Sakasik. Its mosque is counted among the noble mosques; Mu'adh ibn Jabal planned it. There is always adjacent dwelling (Mujawara) in it, and visitors come to it. All that we mentioned of the Tihami Yemeni villages are attributed in the registers of the Caliphs to the administration of Al-Janad. And Jaba [Jaba, Yemen], the city of Al-Ma'afir; it belongs to the family of Al-Karandi from Banu Thumamah back to Himyar the Younger. And Jayshan [Jayshan, Yemen], a city inhabited by a mixture of Himyar from Ru'ayni, Rada'i, Sarari, and others. Near it are villages having deserts attributed to them, like Hajr and Badr. And Al-Suhayb, inhabited by a people from Saba called Saba al-Suhayb. As for Badr, the Bahriyyun from Al-Sadaf inhabited it, and some of them inhabited Lahj with the Asabih. Among them was Aws ibn Amr...

...the Slayer of Hunger. The poet, who is Ibn al-Baylamani, says about him: 'Truly, Aws, the Slayer of Hunger, has passed... And bequeathed a glory whose lengths cannot be reached.' Then Mankat, the city of the Sukhtiyyin; they are the remnant of the House of Kingdom from the family of Al-Sawwar. They have generosity and lofty honor, but they are few. Then Dhamar [Dhamar, Yemen], and its inhabitants are from Himyar, and in it are a group of the Abna (Persian descendants). Al-Dhamari the Hadith scholar is from there. In it, and in Al-Janad and Jayshan, there have always been scholars and jurists like Abu Qurrah, the owner of the Musnad, and Abd al-Rahman ibn Abdullah, the reciter of the Musnads. Then Rada' [Rada', Yemen], which is a city inhabited by a mixture of Himyar from the Aswadiyyin, Khawlan, Al-Jarib, and Ans. Surrounding it in its desert are the Rabi'iyyun, Ziyadiyyun, Balharith, and Banu Hubaysh from Zabid. From its people is Ahmad ibn Isa al-Khawlani, the author of the Urjuza of Hajj, which we have established at the end of the book. And Ibn Abi Muna the poet, a Persian from the Abna. Rada' is between the Najd of Himyar, upon which are the fortresses (Masani') of Ru'ayn, and the Najd of Madhhij, upon which are Radman and Qarn. In its south is the city of Hasi, Batra, and Al-Khaniq from the land of Al-Sarw. Then the city of Sana'a [Sana'a, Yemen], which is the Mother of Yemen and its Pole, because it is in the middle of it; what is between it and Aden is like what is between it and the border of Yemen from the land of Najd and Hijaz. Its name in the Jahiliyyah was Azal. The people of Sham (Levant) call it Al-Qasbah. The Arabs say: 'There must be [a journey to] Sana'a, even if the travel is long.' One attributed to Sana'a is called San'ani, like Bahra/Bahrani, because they saw the Nun as lighter than the Waw. Khawlan does not attribute to it except on the structure of the root: San'awi. They all say for a resident of Al-Kadra: Kadrawi, and do not say Kadrani. Sana'a is the oldest of the cities of the earth because Shem son of Noah founded it. I have collected its news in ancient times in the Book of Al-Iklil, and we have turned away from mentioning its ancient history in this place. There has always been in it a scholar, a jurist, a wise man, an ascetic, and one who loves Allah, Mighty and Majestic, with excessive love and fears Him with wakeful fear, in the manner mentioned by Ptolemy regarding the natures of the people of this region. They are, with that, people of discrimination...

...for the occurrence of matters, serving the Sultan with preparedness, ownership, and luxury in homes. They have crafts in foods that the foods of no [other] land can match. They have the San'ani broken script for Qurans and the beautification that cannot be matched. They have the truths of the form [grammar/vowels]; Al-Khalil mentioned them for that. They have conditions (Shurut/contracts) unlike others; no jurist from the people of the metropolises has a condition except that they have one more eloquent, sweeter in wording, more impactful in meaning, and closer in brevity. Among them are orators like Mutarrif ibn Mazin and Ibrahim ibn Muhammad ibn Ya'fur (with Damma on the Ya and Kasra on the Fa). In it are scholars like Wahb ibn Munabbih and his two brothers Hammam and Ma'qal; Abd al-Razzaq, Abd al-Rahman ibn Dawud, Ibn al-Sharud, Hisham ibn Yusuf, and Mutarrif ibn Mazin, the inventor of the distribution of water channels (Ghayul). Among the astronomers: Dardan, Abu Ismah, Abu Jundah, Ibn Asim, Ibn al-Munaydhir, Ibn Abdullah, and others. Among the poets are the likes of Alqama Dhu Jadan, and Waddah al-Yaman, who came with his poetry to Al-Walid and was assassinated because of Umm al-Banin bint Bishr ibn Marwan. And Bakr ibn Mirdas; he was witty, dark-skinned (Adam), of good appearance and freshness. He had clothes numbering the days of his going out from his house in the year. It was part of the perfection of his chivalry that he would not go out of his house until he tied the straps of his sandals, so no one ever saw him with a broken strap on the road. His poetry was widely circulated. Ibn Mirza al-Abnawi informed me from someone who told him from the people of Sana'a, from his father, who said: 'I came to the Hajj and saw in the Tawaf a witty, light-spirited young man surrounded by a group. When he finished his Tawaf and prayer, I said: Who is this? It was said: Abu Nuwas al-Hasan ibn Hani. So I greeted him, conversed with him, and informed him of the popularity of his poems and news in Sana'a, and I asked him for some of it. He said: You seek me for the like of this while you have Bakr ibn Mirdas? I said: Is he of this status to you? He said: Is he not the one who says: "O my brothers, indeed the doctor whom... you hope will cure me is my illness. He did not fail in advice, but he... is blind to the knowledge of what sickness I have. So ask him about his drugs... and ask him what I should abstain from. For...

...medicine is only for one whose disease is... from bile, phlegm, or blood. And love is not cured by Iyaraj (a purgative)... nor by Theriac nor by a cupper. Except by smelling the beloved or embracing... and the sipping of saliva from mouth to mouth. O healer of the soul from its disease... cure my sickness and have mercy, show mercy. If with your eye when... night covers me and the eyes of the sleepers dose off. You circulate at your door weeping... for the heat of a sorrow kindled in the entrails. You would think I am a pilgrim in Ihram... in the courtyard of the House towards Zamzam. And your soul would be certain that love... is the strongest thing that clings to a Muslim. So free your slave from what ails him... and honor your face from being unjust."' Bakr also said on the tongue of two Bedouins who came to Yazid ibn al-Walid, the governor of Yemen, mentioning the beard: 'We lost our beards; how little is their benefit... and the oil is wasted on them, O Ibn Muti'. We oiled them and fluffed them for our Emir... like the two wing-feathers of a vulture falling to land. They drove no good other than length from them... and that they are a grief for every bedfellow. O would that we were beardless from them... hoping like the Bedouins every spring. So we would snatch wealth after which we would not be frightened... by fear of nakedness or fear of hunger.' Among the poets of Sana'a is Abu al-Samt al-Fayrouzi from the Abna, a wondrous poet. He came to Al-Mahdi praising him, and he accepted his praise. He praised the Barmakids, and they treated him according to the Persian custom and cut out for him properties in Sana'a and real estate from Al-Mahdi. We have established his elegy for his brother, which is among the best poetry, in the Book of Al-Iklil. Among the poets of Sana'a was Martal; he was a satirist of the Ashraf (nobles), entering into their honor. He did the like of that with Ya'fur ibn Abd al-Rahman, so he (Ya'fur) prepared someone to drink with him. When he drank one day with those drinking companions and got drunk, his mattress was carried on some beast holding him, and they traveled with him by night and arrived with him at Shibam [Shibam Kawkaban, Yemen] to Ya'fur. He woke up while he was in front of him. He said: 'How have you become, O Martal?' He said: 'In my Takht (container), O my master'—meaning the receptacle in which he was carried from his mattress. He laughed at him and conferred a favor upon him, then released him. But he (Martal) cut his tongue...

...with that favor from harming people, so he was not elevated. Among the poets of Sana'a, rather from its desert, is Abd al-Khaliq ibn Abi al-Talh al-Shihabi. He was naturally gifted, eloquent, and wondrous. We have established qasidas of his poetry in the first book of Al-Iklil along with the news of Banu Shihab. From the poets of Sana'a itself is Ibrahim ibn al-Jadawiyah; we have mentioned some of his poetry in the Book of Al-Iklil. He was naturally gifted in poetry and more skillful in Rajaz. He would sometimes resemble Al-Kumayt in some of his doctrine, as in his words regarding the Alawite Al-Nasir: 'Nasir al-Din (Helper of the Faith), you cease not to be victorious (Mansur)... May Allah thank your thanked endeavor.' He has an elegy for Abu al-Husayn al-Rassi, which is: 'The upper arm of Islam has weakened and its shoulder is broken... and calamities have assassinated a moon among the people.' Most of his poetry was consumed by satirizing the commoners and the lowlifes. Among his best poetry is his word regarding As'ad ibn Abi Ya'fur, the beginning of which is: 'O two birds, I think separation [is coming], so rise... Indeed, distance has decreed its desires, so fall.' There remained in it (Sana'a) scribes of the Diwan who were eloquent, not generating [artificial] speech nor hiding meanings, enslaving metaphors, such as Banu Abi Raja and others. Bishr ibn Abi Kubar al-Balawi was among the most eloquent of people. His eloquence was exchanged as gifts in the lands. He had an approach in it which no one preceded him to, and no one caught up with him in. His eloquence and its preciousness are admired, and that he is unique in it, and that the eloquent do not resemble his eloquence, and that he is unique in the beauty of quoting the Quran. We have established ten letters from it to indicate what is beyond them, and the least trace is a guide to the extent of the track-maker. Bishr wrote to Ibrahim ibn Abdullah al-Hajibi and to Sana'a for Harun al-Rashid—who had come to Sana'a in the year one hundred and eighty-two, stayed there a year and a month, then was dismissed—regarding the transgression of Hisham al-Abnawi against him. He (Harun) had resolved to appoint Bishr over some regions of Yemen, so Hisham ibn Yusuf reduced his income: 'As for after, if the Emir—may Allah give him enjoyment—sees fit not to inform Hisham of what he intends of my gift, for he has never intended good for me or my family, nor has he opened a door of a gift for me that would be pure from him...

...intending by it only the face of Allah alone, and hoping by it only His reward, unless Hisham obstructed it, made it heavy, made it hateful, applied analogy to it, struck parables for it, and cast the trick regarding it to the scribe and the chamberlain, swearing to them by Allah: "Indeed, I am to you both a sincere advisor." He praised me with what is unheard of regarding my character and diminished me in what cannot be hoped for from me otherwise, so that the praise he displayed would confirm the fault he concealed. Then he adorned that with preaching, decorated it with advice, approached it with affection, incited him from the side of pity, and testified against him four testimonies by Allah that he is of the truthful, and the fifth that the wrath of Allah be upon him if he is of the liars. So behold, the chamberlain slips me with his sight, and behold, the scribe scalds me with his tongue, and behold, the servant turns his side away from me, and behold, the governor looks at me with the look of one fainting from death. So the faces of benefit became rejected, and the doors of hope blocked. The good that I used to hope for became like dry stubble scattered by the winds, and the gift which I had overlooked became a slippery slope whose water became deep, so I cannot seek it. So I ask Him who made for every Prophet an enemy from the criminals to suffice me against his evil and turn away his plot from me, for he sees me, he and his tribe, from where I do not see them. Peace.' And from him to Yazid ibn Mansur—the governor of Abu Ja'far al-Mansur over Yemen, who came to Sana'a in the beginning of the year one hundred and fifty-four and stayed there for the remainder of Al-Mansur's caliphate and a year of Al-Mahdi's caliphate, and his arrival was after Al-Furat ibn Salim: 'As for after, a letter came to me from the Emir—may Allah preserve him—with his messenger Nu'man al-Hamdani, ordering me to send to him the imposition (Farad) of Al-Furat ibn Salim—meaning by the imposition something he had imposed on the people of Yemen. And I inform the Emir—may Allah honor him—that before his letter, the Book of Allah the Exalted came to us with His Messenger Muhammad, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, ordering us in it to scatter what Al-Furat gathered and to demolish what he built, and to befriend whoever he opposed and oppose whoever he befriended. I looked into the two messages and compared the two messengers without bias of an accident or suspicion, praise be to Allah, that I entered. So I saw that I should not undo what Muhammad ibn Abdullah came with for what Al-Nu'man—may Allah curse him and be angry...

...with him—brought. And I knew that whoever of us deviates from the command of Allah, He will make him taste the punishment of the Blaze. So let the Emir—may Allah preserve him—decree what he is decreeing, then let him hasten that and not give me respite. For by Allah, indeed well-being is in His punishment, and punishment is in his well-being, and death is better than life with him, if this seriousness is from him and the truth is with him. Peace.' Also by Bishr: 'As for after, indeed among people is he whose bearing of his need is easier than the obscenity of his request. And among them is he whose bearing of his enmity is lighter than the weight of his friendship. And among them is he whose excessive blame is better than the extent of his praise. Indeed, Allah created So-and-so to distress the world and make its people filthy by him. He, despite his filth in it, is one of Allah's proofs against its people. So I ask Him who tested the earth with his life and distressed its people with his survival to give its belly a turn over its back (bury him). Peace.' And from Bishr to Al-Shafi'i regarding Abdullah ibn Mus'ab: 'As for after, you ask me about Abdullah as if you intended him (to visit) since arriving to him pleased you. Do not do so, may Allah have mercy on you. For greed for what he has does not cross the heart except from poor trust in Allah, Mighty and Majestic. And hoping for what is in his hand only occurs after despairing of the mercy of Allah, because he sees the moderation which Allah forbade as the extravagance for which Allah punishes. [He believes] that charity is abrogated, that hospitality is lifted, and that preferring a person over oneself during poverty is one of the major sins necessitating destruction. As if he had not heard of kindness (Ma'ruf) except in the First Jahiliyyah, whose remnants Allah cut off and forbade the Muslims from following their traces. As if the Tremor did not strike the people of Midian, in his view, except for a generosity that was among them; and the barren wind did not destroy Ad except for an expansion mentioned among them. He fears punishment for spending and hopes for reward for stinginess. He promises himself poverty and orders it to miserliness, for fear that some of the calamities of the oppressors might descend upon him, and what struck the criminal people might strike him. So stay, may Allah have mercy on you, in your place, be patient with your difficulty, and await the turns of fortune for him. Perhaps Allah will exchange for us and you one better than him in purity and closer in mercy. Peace.' And from him to Bashar ibn Rudabah: 'As for after, I saw you in the beginning of your time setting out early...'

upon the scholars and narrating from them, and talking about Allah and His angels and messengers, and you have become talking about Ma'n and his workers, and about Abu Muslim and his companions; how evil is the exchange for the wrongdoers! So whom have you left over your family, or on whom do you rely in the horror of your travel, or in whom do you trust in the state of your exile? Is it Allah or against Him? And how so, when I do not fear for you except from Him, for He has excused you and warned you, but you disobeyed His command and obeyed His enemies, and you went out angry thinking that He would never have power over you? So fear for yourself the slip, and dismount from your beast at every mountain. And when you and those with you are settled on their backs, do not say: 'Glory be to Him who has subjected this to us', because Allah, Blessed and Exalted, dislikes to be praised for what He has forbidden, but say: 'Our Lord, whoever prepared this for us, add to him a double punishment in the Fire.' Peace. And from him to Al-Hajibi: 'As for after, indeed Allah—and to Him is praise—had presented to me many directions and gave me choice in lawful gains, and I had, by the success of Allah, Mighty and Majestic, and His benevolence, chosen from them the side of the Emir—may Allah the Exalted preserve him—and I was satisfied with him from every quest, and I limited myself to hoping in him from every gain. So Allah, Mighty and Majestic, rewarded him for that with a near victory and many spoils which He hastened; and Allah is Mighty, Wise. The Emir—may Allah the Exalted preserve him—has known the length of my affection for him and the antiquity of my sanctity, and that I am of those who spent before the victory and fought. Then I did not return to Bedouin life after emigration (Hijra), nor did I become a hypocrite after support (Nusra), nor was I like Hatib when he cast affection, nor like Tamim on the day they called out from behind the chambers. Rather, I remained in my place and was patient with my hardship until the victory came from Allah and the Emir—may Allah preserve him—appeared. When he prevailed and became established, and we hoped for wealth with him when he became rich and powerful, and complete might for the one who did good, he brought the parties (Ahzab) near and drew close those left behind from the Bedouins, and preferred with the spoils those who did not rush upon it with horse or camel. His favors became apparent upon those whose hearts are to be reconciled and those who used to criticize him regarding alms among them, and his benefits upon those who made excuses from the Bedouins who came after them became manifest in the horizons and in themselves. The leaders (Naqib) of Al-Aqaba, the poor of the Emigrants, and the destitute of Al-Suffa became such that their eyes overflow with sadness that they do not find...

...what to spend. The first forerunners among us and the people of Support (Nusra) are deferred for Allah's command. If the Emir—may Allah preserve him—sees fit to turn to us before the hearts of a group of us deviate, let him do so, for man was created anxious; when evil touches him, impatient, and when good touches him, withholding. I do not know what to excuse myself with today to the people regarding my affair with the Emir, while they know that I have seen in him two-thirds of my hope but have not reached in myself a quarter of my expectation. Or what does the Emir—may Allah preserve him—wait for regarding me after Allah gave him kingship, taught him wisdom, empowered him over the treasuries of the earth, and made him distinguished in the world, established in Islam, and obeyed and trusted by the Caliph—may Allah the Exalted keep him? So from whom should one flee to the Emir after this blessing, or who would excuse him with this dignity, and who would be satisfied from him with less than his restoration except one who makes a fool of himself? Peace.' And he wrote to Yahya ibn Khalid ibn Barmak seeking benefit through Al-Hajibi: 'As for after, may Allah preserve Abu Ali, and preserve for you what He entrusted you with of your religion, your trust, and the conclusions of your work. As for what you love to have knowledge of regarding the arrival of Al-Hajibi to us, and what he practiced among us, and the state the Muslims have come to be in with him before us, all of that—by the praise of Allah and His blessings—is according to your best joy, greatest hope, and utmost expectation, regarding the calmness of the populace, the safety of the roads, the goodness of the situation, and the succession of rains. The people have become, by the praise of Allah, merciful among themselves; nothing is heard but "Peace, Peace." That is because Al-Hajibi, when he came to us, turned to the best of people and the people of righteousness among them, so he brought them near and drew them close. He was harsh against the people of immorality and suspicion, and he distanced them and pushed them away. He sent for the bearers of the Quran, and when they gathered to him from the ends of the lands, he selected the jurists and the people of opinion among them and made them his entourage and the people of his consultation. He sent many of them as workers over many of the regions of his work. He entrusted to them what the Commander of the Faithful entrusted to him regarding taking alms and Zakat in their proper ways and distributing the five shares fully among their people. He informed them that the Commander of the Faithful did not order him nor those before him from the governors of Yemen and others except with justice and benevolence, and that the Commander of the Faithful is innocent before Allah of the injustice of every oppressor and the tyranny of every tyrant, and that he has cast off what burdens his neck and placed it in the religion...

...of Al-Hajibi and his trust. At that, there remained no sect of the sects of Muslims, nor a group of the righteous, nor anyone of the poor and destitute, but that he prayed for the Commander of the Faithful for long life. Then they prayed for you, O Abu Ali, with the best of prayers, and spread about you the best of praise, for what Allah drove to them because of you and made it through the blessing of your support, and made it flow for them upon your tongue and hand, and for what Al-Hajibi undertook among them from behind you. For we have known him for gentleness without weakness, severity without violence, and seriousness not mixed with jest. Moreover, he is with that rarely negligent, strongly suspicious; he does not rely on his scribes nor delegate his affair to his trustees, nor feel at ease with his sitting companions until he inspects things himself.
