He brings what is present of them before his eyes and issues what is absent from him of them upon his knowledge. Attending to the great does not prevent him from demanding the small. He has mastered politics and is firmly rooted in management. The people most fearful of his anger are all most hopeful of his reward, and the least secure from his punishment are those who stick longest to his company. He has occupied everyone with himself so each attended to his affair; no one exceeds his limit nor transgresses his measure, nor speaks except in what concerns him. We do not see him, by the praise of Allah, increasing every day except in strength, nor do affairs increase with him except in precision. There is no way for a backbiter to reach him, nor greed for a detractor with him. Peace.' And from him to Al-Hajibi—who had forbidden him from exposing himself to the ministers and the people of Iraq: 'As for after, you wrote to me forbidding me from the Sultan and from his proximity. I do not apologize to you for that. If the Sultan calls me, I hasten; and if he is slow with me, I expose myself. If Allah, Blessed and Exalted, has made lawful for you the service of the Commander of the Faithful, the companionship of Al-Fadl, and the night-conversation of Ja'far, and permitted you to take from their wealth heaped talents of gold and silver, but forbade me from writing to the police, corresponding with the post, serving the eunuchs, and exposing myself to the wet-nurses, and prohibited for me from their wealth what I block the gap with and cover the nakedness with, then I am the destroyed one and you are the saved one. And if the matter is not so, and for every man of us is what he earned of sin, then you are the one who took charge of the greater part of it among them. And he struck a parable for us and forgot his creation. Peace.'

And from him to Yahya ibn Khalid ibn Barmak: 'As for after, I wrote to you letters, to none of which I saw an answer. I do not—may Allah give enjoyment through you—consider myself too great to send successive letters to you, nor do I disdain your leaving writing to me, because the likes of you does not write to a weak one like me except with the help of Allah and His support. Nor does wisdom cast to his scribes except by the success of Allah, Mighty and Majestic, and His benevolence. Perhaps—may Allah give enjoyment through you—the descent of that from your Lord did not agree, for He, Blessed and Exalted, decrees what He wills; indeed, He is All-Aware, All-Seeing of His servants. Peace.' And from him also to Ali ibn Sulayman—who had come to Yemen as its governor on behalf of Al-Mahdi in the year one hundred and sixty-two and stayed there for a year and a half—: 'As for after, when my mind became confused to me, my opinion became ambiguous to me, and I doubted regarding my affair, I did not doubt that Allah, Blessed and Exalted, when He wanted to decree my provision for me and to test me with hardship upon my family, He informed you of the essence of my greed, guided you to the direction of my request, and made you a companion to the people of my need. Then He tested me by requesting it from you. When I mentioned it, you shone and rejoiced, and promised from yourself a good promise. So I distributed my expenditure due to your shining, expanded upon my family due to your rejoicing, and borrowed from my brothers due to your promise. But when I came to you seeking fulfillment, you frowned and scowled, then turned away and acted arrogantly. The expenditure has been exhausted, hope has been cut off, and I have despaired of greed just as the disbelievers despair of the companions of the graves. The greatest distress to me and the severest hardship is that someone other than you offers me the need which I requested from you, and I dislike that it be except through your means and run except by your hand. By my life, that was only due to prior knowledge regarding my wretchedness with you. So I ask Allah, Mighty and Majestic, who made your status part of my tribulation, your good position part of my calamity, and the length of your life a trial for my family, to transfer you to His Paradise before your glance returns to you. Peace.' And from Bishr to another: 'As for after, I saw you in the matter of your religion artificial and forsaken, and in the matter of your world immoral and ruined. In you are traits that do not gather in a Muslim except with an evil secret, or commission of a major sin, or concealing a enormity, by which the friends of Allah are faulted...

...and the children of the Messenger of Allah are singled out. Among the signs of that is that the hearts of the people of the Two Sanctuaries (Haramayn) are disgusted when you are mentioned, and the hearts of the people of the Two Cities (Basra and Kufa/Egypt?) shudder when you are praised. They do not increase except in hatred for you, nor in testimony against you except in certainty, due to their knowledge of you of old and their knowledge of your condition, small and large. By my life, if you are to this day as they claimed, you are then of the mockers. And if you have desisted from what they knew, you have not made your repentance sincere to Allah then, nor your intention true. Indeed, in your faith is weakness, in your soul is frailty, in your chest is arrogance, in your heart is hardness, and in your livelihood is extravagance. I do not think that what has become valid in your hand of the adornment of Allah which He brought forth for His servants and His good provisions which He spread over His creation amounts to a pleasure for you, nor fulfills a dhimma (obligation) by it, because that did not reach you except through the oppression of Muslims, the idleness of mockers, and the lie of slanderers. So I do not think, if you are with this and its likes, that you will clear yourself by anything of your earnings regarding anything of your debt to anyone of your creditors, unless you become, regarding those who clear themselves of that to the people of the earth, a debtor to the people of heaven. Nor do you join anyone of your kin with anything of your accumulation, unless Allah's questioning of you regarding severing them is easier for you than His accounting of you for what reaches them. Nor do you spend a small or large expenditure unless it is recorded for you in Sijjin, nor are you raised a rank unless it lowers you to the lowest of the low. Your heart was not safe until you were known by it and prayed in the East, except due to the weakness of your heart. Nor was your mind sound until your family feared/respected [Rajab] except due to the lack of your mind. Even if you fled in the earth confused on your face, or went to the mountains fleeing from your sin, or gnawed bones with the dogs, or lapped surplus water with the beasts, that would be, according to your crime, a lowering and ease from your crimes, and according to your deed, a comfort from your livelihood. Even if your eyes turned white from grief, and you bit on your hands and severed them from regret, and your heart was cut from worry, or your soul departed in sighs, that would not be an indemnity (Arsh) for what you wounded of your religion, nor a vow for what you twisted of your trust, nor the value of what you missed of your Lord. So when you have reached with your poor soul what you have reached, and your weak soul is satisfied with you regarding what you have done...

...then do not make with Allah another god, lest you sit blamed and forsaken.' Abu Muhammad said: Then after Sana'a, among the villages of Hamdan in its Najd is its town Raydah [Raydah, Yemen]. In it is the Suspended Well and the Lofty Palace, which is Talfum. Alqama ibn Dhi Jadan says about it: 'And that of La'wah, the famous one from the head of Talfum... Remove! And the lion was the protector of truths.' The La'wiyyun inhabit it. And Athafit... it is called Athafah with Ha, and with Ta more often. The chief Al-Kabbari from the people of Athafit told me, he said: It used to be called Durna in the Jahiliyyah, and it is the one Al-A'sha mentioned in his saying: 'I say to the drinkers in Durna when they got drunk... Smell! And how does the drunken drinker smell?' Al-A'sha often spent the autumn in it, and he had a wine press in it where he pressed what the people of Athafit gave him abundantly of their grapes. They narrate in his Ba-rhyme poem: 'I love Athafit at the time of harvest... and the time of the pressing of its grapes.' The family of Dhu Kibar and Wada'ah inhabit it. And Khaywan [Khaywan, Yemen]: the land of Khaywan ibn Malik, and it is among the best of the land of Hamdan, the most noble in soil, and the best in fruit. The Mu'idiyyun, Ridwaniyyun, Banu Nu'aym, the family of Abu 'Ashan, and the family of Abu Hajr from the Ashraf of Hashid inhabit it. It is the border between Bakil and Hashid. Mu'id, their ancestor, was with Ali, peace be upon him, so he angered him, and he spent the night biting the middle of his saddle until he destroyed it and joined Mu'awiyah. There has always been in it Najd (bravery/nobility), a knight, and a poet. Among their poets is Ibn Abi al-Balas, who is the one who said regarding Abu al-Husayn Yahya ibn al-Husayn al-Rassi in a Sin-rhyme word of his: 'If your sword on the day of Adam's prostration... had been drawn, Iblis would not have disobeyed.' Then from this Sarat in the land of Khawlan ibn Amr ibn al-Haf is the city of...

...Sa'dah [Sa'dah, Yemen]. It used to be called Juma' in the Jahiliyyah. In ancient times, there was a lofty palace in it. A man from the people of Hijaz returned from some kings of the sea (coast) and passed by that palace while tired. He lay on his back and contemplated its height. When it impressed him, he said: 'Laqad Sa'adah, Laqad Sa'adah!' (It has gone high/He has climbed it!). So it was named Sa'dah from that day. Some scholars of Iraq said: The Sa'idi arrowheads are attributed to Sa'dah, but it is said 'Sa'adiyyah'; if a poet is forced, he says 'Sa'idiyyah' in place of 'Sa'adiyyah'. It is the administrative district (Kura) of the land of Khawlan and the place of tanning in the deep Jahiliyyah. That is because it is in the middle of the land of Qaraz (acacia leaves used for tanning), which surrounds it at a distance of two days. Its border from the south is Khaywan and the land of Wada'ah. From the north is Mahjarah at the head of Al-Mandaj from the land of Banu Hayf from Wada'ah also. From the east is the falls of Barat in the lowland (Gha'it). From the west is the mine of Al-Qafa'ah from the land of Al-Ajdud from Khawlan. Then there is no city after it from the Najd of Yemen. There were wars and days (battles) in it which we have mentioned in some of our books, and we mentioned who was in it from the poets of Khawlan. Likewise, Najran [Najran, Saudi Arabia] had days, wars, and poets from Balharith and Hamdan. Among its poets was Ibn al-Baylamani from the Abna. What falls in Yemen of the Sarat Mountain and its beginning is Yemen: As for the Sarat Mountain which connects what is between the farthest Yemen and Sham, it is not a single mountain, but rather connected mountains in a single array from the farthest Yemen to Sham, with a width of four days along the entire length of the Sarat; a fraction of a day may increase in some of these places and decrease similarly in some of them. The beginning of this Sarat is from the land of Yemen, the land of Al-Ma'afir, then Hayq of Banu Majid, then 'Arr of Aden, which is a mountain surrounded by the sea. It gathers the Mikhlaf of Dhubhan, Al-Ju'ah, Jaba, Sabir, Dhakhir, Bardad, Sahara, Al-Dabab, Al-Ushaysh, Rasyan, and Tabashi'ah. The descendants of the Ma'afiris, Ya'fur, Hamdan, Al-Sakasik, and Banu Waqid inhabit these places. And Wadi al-Milh, inhabited by Al-Ash'ar, and in...

...between it and Tabashi'ah is the land of Al-Ushurah, a tribe from Al-Ash'ar. Then the land of Al-Ma'afir in this Sarat connects to the land of Al-Shara'ib from Himyar; among it are Dukhan and Ru'us Nakhla. Adjoining it from the land of Al-Kila' is Nakhlan, Al-Thajjah, Al-Sahul, Al-Milhah, Zuba, Qulamah, Al-Mudhaykhirah, Rimah, Qar'ad, Huraqah, Mulihah, Mawdan, Al-Khanan, Al-Rabadi, Ta'kar, and Al-Zawahi. The Ghaur (lowland) of the Sarat of Al-Kila' is Al-Jabjab, Wahfat, and Wuhazah. The Qibla (south/front) of the land of Al-Kila' is Qaynan, Manub, Shi'an, and Al-San'—which are the two valleys—and in them is the prohibited Wars (plant). And Yakhar and Sayd; the west of all is in the land of Al-Kila', Al-Wahsh. This is a land belonging to Hamdan known as the land of Hashid, a land of livestock. Then the Sarat of Al-Kila' connects to the Sarat of Banu Sayf from the land of Al-Ahtut, Wahm, Al-Samlal, Hamd, Siyyah, Humr, and Nu'man from the west of this Sarat. And Jabalan Al-Arkaba, which is the land of the Sharahiyyin, the family of Abu Salamah, and Watih. Then connects to them the Sarat of Jabalan; its highest part is Ans, Al-Jabjab, Sarbah, and Jam'; and its lowest part is Shajban, Wadi al-Shajbah, Sayhan, Rima', Bab Kahlan, Al-Sali, Jabal Bura', Al-Arab, and the land of La'san from Akk. Then connects to it the Sarat of Alhan; its outward part (Zahir) is Dawran, Madhab, Alhan, Maqra, Al-Haqlayn, 'Ashar, Baqlan, Naqil al-Sud, Haql Sahman, and Jabal Hadur. Its lowest part is Wadi Siham, Sabih, and Al-Akhruj. And the land of Haraz, which is seven parts: Haraz, Hawzan, Lihab, Mujayyah, Karar, Masar, and Haraz al-Mustahrizah; Haraz gathers them, and its market is Al-Mawzah. Haraz mixes with the land of La'san from Al-Zihar, the Zihar of Ibn Bashir al-Nashqi from Hamdan. The lowest parts of Hadur: its Ghaur is like the land of Al-Sayd, Shamm, and Mazikh. Then connects to it the Sarat of Al-Masani'. Its highest part is Jabal Dhakhar, Hadur Banu Azad, Bayt Aqra', Muda', Hamlam, Qarin, Al-Muhaddad, and Al-Asam. Its middle and Ghaur is Al-Baqir, Shahidh, Tays, Nidar, Al-Ma'iz, Jarabi, Sari', Sama', Bakil, Surdud, Hufash, and Milhan—which are mountains. Jabal Milhan is attributed to Milhan, a man from Himyar, and the name of the mountain is Rishan. And Fajj Akk; in it are Al-Maddahaqah, Al-Fashiq...

...and Al-Mansul, the land of Suhar from Akk, La'ah, Tamam, Al-Shawariq, Al-Hatar, Maswar, Al-Zulmah, La'r, Jabal al-Takhalli, Qilab, Naml, Sharas, the land of Adran, Hajjah, Ayyan, Al-Ma'yal, 'Awla, Hamlan, and Al-Makhlufah from the land of Hajur, returning to Fajj Akk. Then connects to this Sarat Qadam; its highest part is Al-Zahrah, Ja'ram, Al-Harf, Al-Qahmi, Ja'rah, Madhrah, Shazab, Darb Bali', and Qasr Yashi'. Its middle and Ghaur is Haml, Qatabah, Al-Irqah, Mawtak, and Hajjah. It may be inclined towards the Sarat of Al-Masani', but dominant over it are the family of Al-Rayyan from Qadam, Al-Kalabih, Bari, and Al-Sarhah, going to Jabal al-Sharaf overlooking Tihama. It is a vast mountain containing many villages like Al-Khawqa', Al-Dali', and Al-Maqta'. Their greatest market is Al-Jarib; on its appointed day, more than ten thousand people market there. Then connects to this Sarat the Sarat of 'Udhar, Hanum, the exterior (Zahir) of the land of Al-Jawashah from Al-Fa'ish, Fa'ish Bakil, then the land of the Shakiriyyin from the people of Al-Darb and Nawdah, then Al-Hafr from the top of 'Usman, then Maqtal Sufran, then the land of Harb ibn Abd Wadd ibn Wada'ah—they are Banu Suraym and Banu Rabi'ah—and the land of the Qit'iyyin and Al-Qashab, then the land of Banu Sa'd ibn Wada'ah from Banu Ma'mar and Al-Harathim, and Banu Abd, then Jabal Sufyan, then the mountains of Al-Dahman from Bakil. Its middle and Ghaur is Akhraf, Najd al-Mathan, Al-Shaqiqah, Hanum, Sha'b 'Udhar, Suhayb, Harad, the land of Hayran, Qabr Hajur, Qabr Aliyan, Ras al-Habash, Matraq, Karif Khawlan, Al-Hajabat, Mararat, Wadi Haydan, and Amir (weighing Adbir). Then connects to it the Sarat of Khawlan, called Al-Qadd. The first of it from its exterior is Jabal Abdhar belonging to Banu 'Uwayr from the family of Rabi'ah from Sa'd, then Al-Dahd, then Al-Hallah, Adbuh, Al-Matraq—a mountain belonging to Banu Kulayb—then Al-Aslaf, then Nagham, then Al-Khanfa'ar, then Al-'Arr. From its middle and Ghaur is the land of Saqin, Haydan, Sha'b, Sha'b Hayy, Harjab, the land of Al-Sharw, Maran, Al-Qafa'ah, Al-Bar, Khulab, Jahfan, 'Arama, Gharabiq, 'Arsh, Washah, Ghaylan, Dafa, Qaywan, Bawsan, the land of Al-Rassiyyah, the land of Banu Hudhayfa...

...and the land of Al-Abqur, then descending to Anafiyah, then Abraq from the region of Baysh. Then follows it the Sarat of Janb and the land of Al-'Arr'arr al-Ma'sur. The village of Janb in this Sarat is Al-Kubaybah. A man from Janb said when the night covered him in the land of Banu Shawir: 'He looked, and Al-Ma'yal had become below us... So Ayyan became below us, so Tamamaha. To the light of a fire in Al-Kubaybah kindled... Whenever it faded, its blaze returned and ignited. Kindled by girls with kohl-eyes, virgins... Beloved to us is their sight and their speech. Tomorrow, between us is the width of the desert and its length... So my home is Yemeni and your home is its Sham (North). So if I have exchanged a land for my homeland... A western Yemeni land, pleasing is its residence. Then I set out early while the Bahdal (fledgling/weakling), the confused, is sleeping... Far from slumber, cool of eye is its sleep. And I traverse the feared land with youths... Like the lions of Al-Shara, white, curly-haired, full-haired.' Ra'yuha: seeing her; the Arabs say 'Hayya Allahu Ra'yaka', meaning your person. Then Al-Jabal Al-Aswad to Al-Shaqrar and Sa'ya from the land of Jurash. The Ghaur of these lands is the highest of Zanif, Dhankan, Al-Birk, Al-Ma'qad, and Harrah Kinana. The middle is the land of Tawd, Haqwfatan, and Najd al-Tar. Then follows it the Sarat of Anz and the Sarat of Al-Hajr; its Najd is Khath'am and their Ghaur is Bariq. Then the Sarat of Nah from Al-Azd, Banu al-Qarn, and Banu al-Khalid; their Najd is Khath'am and their Ghaur is tribes from Al-Azd. Then the Sarat of Al-Khal for Shukr; their Najd is Khath'am and their Ghaur is tribes from Al-Asad ibn Imran. Then the Sarat of Zahran from Al-Azd Daws and Ghamid and Al-Hurr; their Najd is Banu Sawa'ah ibn Amir and their Ghaur is Lahb and 'Uwayl from Al-Azd and Banu...

...Amr. Banu Sawa'ah is a mixture, but the claim (da'wa) is Amiri. Then the Sarat of Bajila; its Najd is Banu al-Mu'tarif, and their origin is from Tamim—some of them told me they are from 'Ukl—and its Ghaur is Banu Sa'd from Kinana. Then the Sarat of Banu Shababah and Adwan; their Ghaur is Al-Layth and Markub, so Yalamlam. Their Najd contains Adwan, adjacent to Matar. Then the Sarat of Ta'if; its Ghaur is Mecca, and its Najd is the dwellings of Hawazin from Ukaz and Al-Abar. The Valleys of the Sarat cutting through it to Tihama until they end in the Sea: The first of them are the valleys of Mawza and Al-Shiqaf; Dhubhan and Al-Ma'afir pour into them. Then Fajj, Harazah, and Wadi al-Milh from Rasyan. And the land of Al-Rakb, so it meets with Nakhla at Hays. The side of Wadi Nakhla pours into Al-Qurtub from the south of Zabid. And Wadi Zabid, which is far in origin; its first streams are from Dhu Jazab and the heights of Al-Sharafah. And the western Shar'ah, Yarim, Sahmar, Al-Ahtut, and Al-Simlal, until the flood of Siyyah meets Al-Jabjabah, then the flood of Lahj and Mulh extends it, and the flood of Humr joins all, and they all gather at Hamd—and its people are from Himyar, the people of Hadd. Then it passes by Ma'att al-Fil. The flood of Nu'man joins it. Then they all descend to the land of Al-Wahsh, so they are met by the flood of Al-Sahul, the land of Al-Kila', and the upper parts of Ba'dan and Rayman. Then the valleys of 'Annah meet it, and Al-Fanj, Al-Hafnah, Hajr Qamran, and Al-Malahit gather it to Zabid. It waters all that surrounds it to the sea. Then follows it Wadi Rima'; it is hot and narrow. Its beginning is from the heights of Jahran and the west of Dhu Khashran to Wadi al-Shajbah. It pours into it from its right and the south of Alhan, then Ans, and from its north the north of the land of Jam' and Sarbah until it reaches Shajban, then it passes between Jabalan Al-Arkaba and Jabalan Rimah, and appears at Dhuwal, watering its farms to the sea. At the bottom is the place of the water which used to be called Ghassan. Then follows it Wadi Siham. Its beginning and head is Naqil al-Sud from Sana'a, about a partial day['s journey] to what is between its south and west. It pours into its right side the south of...

...Hadur, the south of Al-Akhruj, and the south of Haraz. It pours into its left side the north of Alhan, 'Ashar, Baqlan, the north of Ans and Sayhan, the north of Jabalan Rimah, Al-Suli, and Jabal Bura'. It appears at Al-Kadra and Waqir, watering that region and what follows it to the sea. Then Wadi al-Arab pours what is between Al-Kadra and Zabid in the region of Al-Maq'ar and Al-Akhawat which are between it and Al-Kadra. The irrigation channels of Wadi al-Arab are between Bura' and the falls of Jabalan Rimah and Qa'ar. Then follows it Wadi Surdud; its head is Ahjar Shibam Aqyan, then the falls of Hadur from Shamm and Mazikh and the land of Al-Sayd. Then Jabal Tays, Nidar, Bakil, Qayhama, and the south of Hufash pour into its right. From its left, the mountains of Haraz and Al-Akhruj. It appears at Al-Mahjam, watering it and what follows it to the sea. Then follows it Wadi Mawr, which is the greatest spout of Tihama. Then follows it in greatness and distance of origin Zabid. The irrigation channels of Mawr take the west of Hamdan entirely, some of the west of Khawlan, and some of the west of Himyar. Its first ravines are Dhakhar and Sharabb from the mountains of Dhakhar, Maswar, Al-Shawariq, Takhalli, the north of Tays and Nidar, Al-Baqir, Al-Adad, Shahidh, Jarabi, Sama', the sides of Milhan, Al-Mudrab—a mountain at the base of Milhan—then the land of Suhar, the land of Banu Haritha and Banu Rifa'a and Hammad. It flows and is supplied from Hajur then Ayyan, then Adran, Hajjah, Naml, Sharas, and Qilab until it meets with Mawr coming from the land of Khawlan and the north of the land of Hamdan. That supplies the falls of Al-Sharaf, east and south. This is one of its two branches. The second branch: its head is the branch of Al-Hallah and Adbuh, then Al-Mawqar, Al-Dahd, the west of Abdhar, Mawtak, Mahla, then the land of 'Udhar and Hanum, the land of Hajur, the falls of the land of Wada'ah, the land of Al-Jawashah, the land of Banu Abd al-Baqar, and Akhraf. It meets the flood of Al-Hafr, Sarayim, Al-Kalabih, Shazab, Dharkhan, the land of the Maraniyyin, then the land of Wathan north of Mawtak and Hajjah. What it takes, it takes the land of Qadam ibn Qadim. From its right is Sadd Saqin and Tadra', in which are Arab, Haydan, the east of Matraq, and Karif Khawlan—and what reaches it from it is called Amir—then the south of Suhaylib and the land of Al-'Ahra.

Then follow it the two valleys of Banu Abs from Hakam, and Wadi Hayran and Khidhlan; their origins are from the lower parts of Hajur. Then Harad, which is average among the valleys. It has two branches: the southern of them is from Al-Shaqiqah and what surrounds the main road (Mahajja) and from there to Harad from the land of 'Udhar and the land of Hajur to Al-Mabah then Al-Marir. The northern of them is Naqil Matraq and what surrounds the stream from the land of 'Udhar and the land of Banu Shihab ibn al-Aqil to Ma'in al-Hanash, until it meets the second branch at Al-Surayn. Both plunge into Al-Lussab, which is the highest part of Wadi Harad. The ravines supply it from the right from the land of Khawlan and from the left from the land of Hamdan. It pours into Al-Saqiftan and waters what this land takes to the sea. Then Wadi Khulab, which is the one that borders Al-Khasuf on its two sides. Its origins are from Al-Qafa'ah and Al-Bar. Its branches are from Ras Khulab at Al-Qadd from the Sarat of Khawlan. It resembles Wadi Harad or exceeds it. Between them are valleys that flow into the bottom of Tihama and water Al-Makharif from the land of Hakam to the sea; they are lesser than these two valleys. The first of them adjoining Harad is Wadi Ta'shar, then Wadi al-Hayd, then Wadi al-Milhah, then Wadi Liyyah, then Khulab. Then after Wadi Khulab is Wadi Jazan and Wadi Damad; their origins are from Ghaylan, the mountain of Banu Razih ibn Khawlan, the heights of Raghafah, and the falls of Anam. They water the land of Damad and Jazan to the sea. Between them and Khulab are valleys less than the like of Za'irah, Al-Faja, and Shayah, watering the north of the Makharif of Hakam. Then Wadi Sabya, which is from the falls of Bawsan, Al-Arr, and Anafiyah; it waters Sabya to Nasr al-Aman in Saddat Athr. Then Wadi Baysh; its origins are from Qaywan, the land of Banu Amir from the Ghaur, and Dafa from the north of the land of Khawlan and the south of the land of Janb. Then Atud, a small wadi. Then Wadi Bayd; its origins are from the Sarat of Janb. Then Rim and 'Armaram; their origins are from the heights of the land of Sanhan and Janb. Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Isma'il al-Saksaki said: All that is between...

...Aden and Wadi Nakhla from the land of Shar'ab of the large valleys that end in the sea from the direction of the West, the first of them is: Itham, from the valleys of Al-Sakasik. It reaches Al-Arah and Al-Umayrah from the land of Banu Masih. Its outlet is from the southern part of Jabal Abi al-Mughallis Al-Silw, then Najd Ma'adin, then the east of Dhubhan, then the west of Jabal al-Rama from the mountains of Al-Sakasik. The second of the valleys of Al-Sakasik is Wadi Adim. Its origins are from the southern Dhubhan and from the fortress of Sudan from its east and the mountains of Dhat al-Surayh from its west. It ends between the land of Banu Masih and the land of Banu Yahya from Banu Majid. In Adim are the sorcerers of Al-Sakasik and the masters of Sadah al-Ghayth (rain calling?), milk borrowing, and other arts of their magic and divination. The reports on these arts of theirs are famous and many. The third valley: Wadi Harazah. Its origins are from the mountains of Al-Matali' and the north of Dhubhan from Najd Ma'adin, the west of Jabal Abi al-Mughallis Al-Silw, and the southern Al-Jabziyyah. Its resource is Al-Mumhat from the land of Banu Majid, then it exits between Mawza and Al-Juraybah to the sea. The fourth valley, which is Wadi al-Hasid. Its origins are west of Sabir and Jabal Sami', Jabal Ibn Abi al-Mughallis, and on its right is Al-Jabziyyah and on its left is Bardad between the mountains of Sabir, Dhakhir, and Jaba, and the entire Qa' al-Samiqah, and the southern Jabal Dhakhir. It ends at Al-Mawza, then Al-Makha exits to the sea. The fifth valley is Rasyan. Its origins are Al-Janad from its east and the north of Jabal Sabir, and from the borders of Al-Kila' Al-Thajjah from its south, Nakhlan Zuba, Al-Ula, Al-Manhaj, Al-Ushash, Al-Matlu', Wadi Ibna, and all the ravines of Shazah—which are the monuments of Ali ibn Ja'far—and Al-Sha'baniyyah from the faces of Sabir, Qa' al-Akhbash, and Wadi al-Dabab to Al-Qar'a from the watering places of Bardad, the east of Dhakhir and its north, all of Al-Juraybah from the homelands of Al-Kila', the land of Al-Qafa'ah, the land of Shar'ab, and from the land of Al-Rakb the mountains of Shamir and Al-Hudum. All the waters of Rasyan gather until it meets Al-Hasid, and they pour into Mawza. Mawza is a homeland of Farasan and a settlement for them from Al-Rakb. Wadi al-Shiqaq meets these two valleys; it is to their south and cannot be compared to them. The origin of Al-Shiqaq is from the neighborhood of Al-Ma'afir bordering Banu Majid...

...until it mixes with the sea at Al-Suhara, the place of the kiln of palms, farms, and habitation on the shore of the sea. Its inhabitants are a mixture of Akk, Al-Rakb, Banu Majid, Farasan, and Kinana. Then Wadi Nakhla. Its source is from Qitab, the land of Al-Kila' from Ma'ayin, Qar'ad, and the land of Al-Qafa'ah, which is south of the valley. The meeting of these waters is to Al-Mawkif. Then Wadi Nakhla; in it are bananas, Mudar (sugar cane?), henna, and all greens. Also to it, after the waters from Al-Mawkif reach it, reach the waters of the land of Habl, the land of Shar'ab, Talaq, the fortress of Juwalah where Ja'far ibn Ibrahim al-Munakhi was killed, and Jabal al-Sirah. All these are south of Wadi Nakhla. From its north are Jabal Damt, Hamim, Adhaq, Wadi Nazzal, Al-Rawahid, Al-Wazirah, Jabal al-Marir, and Al-Fuwwahah. Then Wadi al-Milh from the land of Al-Rakb and south of Nakhla meets it, so they pour into Hays and cross it to the sea. The origins of Al-Milh are from Al-Maj'ar and Al-Mi'ram from the mountain of the land of Shar'ab and Jabal al-Sirah from the north of the valley. To it from its south are Arasim from the land of Al-Rakb, Al-Harajiyyah, the mountains of Ma'bar, then Dabbas. Then it and Nakhla meet at Al-Qana from the heads of Hays, the dwelling of Abu Ja'far ibn al-Nimr. Then Wadi Zabid, and we have mentioned it. What is between the land of Banu Majid and Abyan of the valleys ending towards the South to the region of Aden: The first valley of them from the direction of the East is Wadi al-Raghghadah, a people from Himyar, then Jabal Sarar from the land of Al-Sakasik, then Jabal al-Hasha from the land of Al-Sakasik, then Ba'dan, Rayman, and Al-Shi'r from the land of Al-Kila', Sakhlan, Dalal, Maytam Tibn Maytam—which is Tibn of Ibn al-Ruwayyah, different from Tibn of Lahj—and Al-Thajjah from Jabal al-Ta'kar. The outlet of these waters is to Wadi al-Ahwad from Al-Sakasik. Al-Ahwad pours from its west, and Rawa from the fortresses of Al-Sakasik, and Jabal Humr from the fortresses of Al-Sakasik—which is different from Humr of Jabalan. Then it ends at Jabal al-Nusur, which is a border between Al-Sakasik and Al-Asni'ah from...

...Himyar. What mixes with this valley from its west are homelands of Al-Sakasik, among them the village of Al-Surdaf, the land of Al-Salaf, Al-Rabi'iyyin, Manjal, and Jabal al-Surdaf. Then these waters end in Wadi al-Sawadin from the east of Al-Janad. Then the bottoms (Qi'an) of Al-Ajnad pour into it; all of them are from Ajnad La'la'ah to Al-Farhiyyah from the section of Jabal Sabir from its east, Najd al-Sadari, Wadi al-Arafah, and Wadi al-Armah—which is the place of Banu Abi Kuhayl al-Saksaki—then the east of Jabal Sami', then the east of Jabal al-Silw, Jabal Abi al-Mughallis, and all the waters of Al-Dumluwah, the citadel of Ibn Abi al-Mughallis, which is ascended by two ladders. In the lower ladder of them are fourteen rungs, and the second above that has fourteen rungs. Between them is the trapdoor (Matbaq) and the guardhouse on the trapdoor between them. The top of the citadel is four hundred cubits by the same. In it are dwellings and houses, and in it is a tree called Al-Kalhamah which shades a hundred men; it is the most similar of trees to the Tamarind. In it is a congregational mosque with a pulpit. This citadel is a peak of Jabal al-Silw; its height and border from the side of the mountain from which it is separated is one hundred cubits on its south. From its east, from Khadir to the top of the citadel, is a journey of a sixth of a day, two hours. Likewise it is from its north facing Wadi al-Jannat and Suq al-Ju'ah. From its west, it is double what it is from its south in height. In it are the stables for the horses of its owner. His fortress in the mountain from which it is separated—I mean Al-Silw—is a bowshot away. Its watering place from which the people of the citadel drink at the lower ladder is a stream (Ghayl) with a pure, light, sweet cistern (Ma'jal), the like of which is not found; in it is their sufficiency. The gate of the citadel is in the north of the citadel. At the top of the citadel is a small pool. The waters of this citadel descend to Wadi al-Jannat from its north, then the source is north of Suq al-Ju'ah to Khadir. This Wadi al-Jannat resembles in description Wadi Dahr. It has many streams, cisterns, and watercourses. In it are grapes and wars mixed in its upper parts with all fruits. Its lower part gathers bananas, sugar cane, citron, cucumber, durra (sorghum), snake cucumber, coriander, and other things. The waters of this valley meet with what supplied it from what we mentioned in Wadi Warazan, which cuts...

...in the middle of Khadir from what we named of the fronts of Sami', Al-Ardah, and Al-Nubayrah—which is the village of Abd al-Jabbar ibn Rabi' al-Hawshabi in the front of Sabir. If he feared, he ascended Sabir to a citadel of his called Dhat al-Amm. This Al-Nubayrah has many grapes and fruits. These two valleys, Wadi al-Jannat and Wadi Warazan, meet with all of Khadir at a place called Karish. Then Wadi Haraz intercepts them; its origins are from the east of the mountains of Al-Silw, its north is Al-Rayyisah, and its south is Jabal al-Rama. These three valleys meet at a march of an hour from Karish. Then valleys of Al-Sakasik also meet these valleys from their east and north. From their north is Wadi Haqab and Wadi Dhaba. Wadi Dhaba is the valley of Abdullah ibn Ahmad al-Saksaki and Abdullah ibn Abi Tumah ibn Ahmad al-Saksaki; both are in the land of Al-Sakasik. It is a trampled valley that oozes; nothing is in it except durra. Its origins are Jarban, the fortress of Abdullah ibn Ahmad al-Saksaki, and Nadamah, a village at the base of the mountain north of the valley, which is its head. From its east is Jabal Humr, inhabited by the 'Awadir of Al-Sakasik. Wadi Dhaba belongs to the Akhadir of Al-Sakasik, and they are their leaders. And 'Uhamah, inhabited by the A'hum of Al-Sakasik east of the valley. And Wadi al-Dhawiyyah, which is the place of Musa ibn al-Harami, a Himyari. At the head of the valley is his small fortress. The origins of this valley are Jabal al-Hasha east of the valley, Manjal north of the valley, and Jabal Humr west of the valley. The meeting of all these valleys is at Jabal al-Nusur. Then it descends about two hours, and Wadi 'Alsan meets it. The origins of Wadi 'Alsan from its north are Jabal Haraz and Tha'ubah, from its west Jabal Asham and Wadi Sa'ah, and from its east the crossings of the Yemeni road from the highway of Aden to Al-Janad and others. These valleys meet in Lahj at a march of an hour from the village of Al-Juwar. Then this valley exits in Al-Juwar, then at Thara and Al-Junayb—both belonging to the Waqidis—then the middle of Al-Ra'ari', which is the market of the Waqidis and their city, then Fawr, which is the village of the Asabih.

Then it exits the lowland (Gha'it) from Lahj to the Sea of Aden. The second is Wadi Abyan, which is what adjoins Lahj, and its origins are from Sharad and Bana, land of Ru'ayn, and we have mentioned it. The third is Wadi Yaramis, which is below these two. The fourth is Dathinah, and the fifth is Ahwar, and we have mentioned them both. Mountains of Al-Sakasik: Jabal al-Surdaf and Jabal al-Sudan from the back of Adim. Mountains of Al-Asha'ub: Al-Silw, gathering them, then after that Sami', Lahj, and other than Lahj, Mulh. Jabal Sabir belongs to the Hawashib. Mountains of Al-Rakb: Dhakhir, Shamir, Ma'bar, Al-Jadun, Dabbas, and Al-Marir. Mountains of Ja'dah: Among their great mountains is Jabal Harir (different from Haziz) and Jabal Radfan and Dar'ah. Among their fortresses below that are Shaka', Al-Aslam, and Humrah. Monuments of these places: The monument of Jabal al-Sirr, called Jabal al-Janah. One who hears this name thinks that this monument belongs to Shammar Dhu al-Janah, but it is not so. It is a great monument resembling Baynun in description. It is in Al-Ma'afir near Sahara to its east. Among them is the fortress (Masna'ah) of Wuhazah; its name is Shiba'. It resembles Na'it in palaces and carved stones. At the gate of the citadel from its east is a foothold in the bottom and a cistern (Karif) of Darda', being six hundred cubits by the same. Among them is the Citadel of Khadad, opposing the Citadel of Wuhazah; between them is an hour of daylight. This Citadel of Khadad has a great palace which description falls short of. The citadel has two roads; at the gate of each road is its water. The road of the citadel from its south has a cistern on it called Al-Wafit, hollowed in the black rock. Its depth in the ground is fifty cubits, its width twenty cubits, and the length fifty cubits, retained on its sides by a wall preventing falling into it. The second water is north of the fortress at the gate of the second fortress in a cavity of rock like a well, lined with pavement. Steps descend to it from the top of the fortress with lamps at night and day for a march of an hour until the water is reached. Whoever is at the mouth of the well from above does not know [who is below]. Among them is the ruin of Saluq. It was a great city...

...in the land of Khadir. The name of its site today is Habil al-Ribah. It has ruins of a city in which iron slag, pieces of silver and gold, jewelry, and coins are found. To it, the Arabs used to attribute Saluqi armors and Saluqi dogs. Among them is a mountain in the east of Wuhazah. At the top of the mountain is a mound of a demolished palace, a remnant of a male (structure?) which the Arabs liken to the Palace of Haraz. Gems and gold are still found in it. People raid it just as they raid the ruins of Al-Jawf. In this way (region) are noble mosques: the Mosque of Al-Janad, and the Mosque of Nahrah, which is at the top of Al-Shawafi north of the mountain next to the stone called the Mosque of the Living. And the Mosque of Mu'adh in Sayd. And the Mosque of Jabal San'an at the top of Jabal Alhan, famous for the whiteness on the night of every Friday; the Adhan is heard in it, and visitors are always in it from every place. And the Mosque of Shahir at the top of Jabal Milhan. Shahir is a peak at the top of Jabal Milhan; it is said that there are ninety-nine springs of water in it. It is a noble mosque. It is said: In the end of time, a sign of fire or something else must appear in it, and Allah knows best. Among them is the Seen, Forbidden Treasure between Jabal Jarabi and Jabal Milhan, opposite the bank of Al-Dabbah from Wadi Ayyan (not Ayan). It is next to the mountain of Al-Zahir known as Jabal al-Mudrab of Milhan. Many Arabs have traveled to it and intended it, but a dragon like a great rope intervenes between them and it, so they find no way to it. Villages of Banu Majid: For Banu Masih among them, the first village is Al-Waqidiyyah for their leaders and masters, then Al-Manarah from the upper land. From its lower part are Al-Arah, Al-Umayrah, Al-Jarubah, Al-Mumhat, Al-Shiqaq, Mawza, and the village of Hannah. Villages of Al-Sakasik: Al-Janad, Al-Dum, and Al-Sharar. Ibn Aban says regarding them: 'Indeed, in Al-Dum is our home, then Al-Sharar... Then in my foothill Adhamir, then Al-Arar.' And Dhat al-Simkar, Al-Shifahi, Al-Surdaf, Al-Sudan, Nadbah, Dhat al-Ma'aqim, Al-Mahabir, and Al-Durahimah. Among the mountains that resemble the mountains of Sham...

...from the side of this domain is Jabal Sabir, and from Jabalan is Jabal Yaman (with Fatha on the Mim), which is on the northern bank of Rima' with 'Utmah, and Jabal Humr on its southern bank. The Eastern Islands (regions) of Yemen: They are of the status of Tihama in the West. The first of this domain adjoining Aden: Tih of Abyan. In it is Iram of the Pillars (Iram Dhat al-Imad), as it is said. It is also said: Iram of the Pillars is Damascus due to the abundance of stone pillars in it. Then the land of Dathinah; the mountains of Al-Sarw and Al-Kawr water it from the south of Al-Sarw. As for the eastern waters of Al-Sarw, they pour into Jardan and Markhah close to it, which is the place of the Ayzun. Jardan ends near Hadhramaut. As for Markhah, the lower Sarat of Madhhij waters it. And Bayhan; the land of Radman, Hasi, and Harib waters it, and the mountains of Qarn water it from its east. Then the Spout of Eastern Yemen, which is the greatest of the eastern valleys just as Mawr is the greatest of the western valleys. Its ravines and branches are many. As for from the direction of Rada': Al-Arsh and the places which Al-Rada'i mentioned in his Qasida near Rada', Radman, Qarn, Adhanah—in it is Bishran—and the mountain overlooking Sayuq. From the side of Dhamar and the land of Ans entirely—which is a vast Mikhlaf—and Sama', in which are Baynun, Hakar, and all that we mentioned in the Book of Al-Iklil of the Ansiyyah fortresses (Mahafid), the land of Kuman, the land of Al-Hada, Jabal Isbil, Rakhmah, the mountains of Banu Wabish from Murad, the mountains of Kidad, the land of Qa'ifah from Murad, Al-Diqrar—the mountain of Banu Malik from Murad—Faja'ah, Mikhlaf Dhi Jurrah, Yakla, Jirah, Jahran, Harran in the Sawad of Dhamar, and the falls of the land of Khawlan from its south and what is south of Al-Qahf and Ramak and Mawdih. These floods form Wadi Adhanah and lead to the place of the Dam (Sadd) between the two narrows (Ma'zamay) of Marib. A channel (Sabibah) inclines from behind the Dam to Rahabah, the place of palms. The floods of Al-Suwayq and Habanin bring those two Falaj lands to the bottom of the Right Garden for one descending Marib, so after the Two Gardens, it waters the land of the Two Sabas, then Al-Harajah, then Hazmat al-Bishriyyin, then Al-Rawdah, to Nahyat Daghal at the edge of Sahid.

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Then after Ma'rib [Ma'rib, Yemen], there are small valleys leading to Al-Jawf [Al-Jawf, Yemen]. Their water sources are from the heights of Dhi Jurah and from the east of the Mikhlaf of Khawlan Al-'Aliyah. Among them are Al-'Awahl Al-A'la, Al-'Awahl Al-Asfal, and Hamd. On these valleys are the Banu al-Harith ibn Ka'b, grazing their livestock. Then the valleys of Al-Radrad and Harib Nihm, and their water sources are from the mountains of Al-Sirr, Sara', and Samik, and the slopes of the land of 'Udhr Matrah, Baladyam, and Haylan. Below Samik is Al-Radrad, to which the mine of Al-Radrad is attributed. There is the village of the Mine, the Silver Mine, which is a mine unparalleled in abundance. It was destroyed after the killing of Muhammad ibn Yu'fir. That is because it was a border between Nihm of Hamdan, Murhibah, Murad, Balharith, and Khawlan Al-'Aliyah.

Then Al-Jawf, which is an expansive land between the northern mountain of Nihm, which contains Anf al-Lawdh, and the southern Awan connected to Haylan after ... and Hayna. The width between the two mountains is a stage in the lower part of Al-Jawf, and its length to Ashhar and the heights of Khabash is a stage and a half. Four large valleys lead to it.

The first of them is Al-Kharid [Wadi al-Kharid], its outlet is from between its south and its west. The irrigation channels of Al-Kharid are from various branches. The first of them is from the Mikhlaf of Khawlan in the east of Sana'a [Sana'a, Yemen]. Ghayman pours into it, and what comes from 'Asfan, Tharban, Zabwah, and Haziz. To Haziz is attributed Thabit al-Hazizi, who narrated from Abdullah ibn Umar. Abu Salamah, the jurist of the people of Sana'a, used to say: "I am among those reached by the Prophet's supplication. I saw Thabit al-Hazizi, and Thabit saw Abdullah ibn Umar, the companion of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace." And what comes from 'Adward, which is a valley that pours with Samik, Dabrah, Wa'lan, and Khadar to Al-Haqlayn, Al-Sahlayn, the regions of Baqlan, and A'shar. And what comes from the heights of Naqil al-Sawd, then Bayt Baws, then Mount 'Ayban and Mount Nuqum, and what is between them of the field of Sana'a and Shu'ub, and Wadi Sa'wan and Wadi al-Sirr, and Matrah, which has many valleys. Then Mount Dhubab, then Zujan, then Shibam al-Qassah. The waters of these places pass to Khatm al-Ghurab and Wadi Shara' from below Al-Sama' and Hadaqan. These valleys meet...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
...the torrent of the Mikhlaf of Ma'dhin from Hudur al-Mu'allal, the field of Sahman, Ya'mum, Bayt Na'amah, Bayt Hanbas, Muhib, Musayb, Haz, Bayt Qarn, Bayt Rafah, Al-Badat, and Ray'an. Then Wadi Dahr, then 'Alman, then Rahabah, then Al-Rahbah to Hadaqan and Khatm al-Ghurab. Then from Al-Masani', Shibam Aqyan, Khulqah, Hababah, Hudur Bani Azd, Bayt Aqra', Qa'ah, Hind, Hunaydah, and Al-Bawn to its end. And Ghulah like Nahirah, Dabba'in, Lughabah, Al-Hayfah, Suq, Khazamir, Dhi 'Arar, Bayt Dhanim, Bayt Shahir, Hamdah, and 'Ajib. Then Sayhah, then Masak, then Al-Akhbab, Na'it, and the land of Al-Sayd. In it are valleys from the outer part of Hamdan like Yana'ah and Dhi Bin and what irrigates them from the outer part of Al-Sayd. These waters reach Warwar. They are met by the torrent of Al-'Uqal, Al-Kasad, Sawlan, Akanit, Masham al-Nakhlah, and Wadi Mahsam, and what falls into it from Madar, Ghatwah, Al-Khashab, Lamih, and the land of Dhubyan. It passes by Al-Qahf, Harran, and Al-Manahi, and meets with the waters of Al-Kharid that descended from Sana'a and its Mikhlifs. They meet at Al-Manahi, then both pour into 'Amran and Ta'mal from the land of Al-Jawf. This side belongs to Banu Nashq and Banu Abd ibn 'Ulayan, and as for Al-Manahi, it belongs to Banu Alawi.

The Second Valley: Wadi Khabash. It pours into the middle of Al-Jawf on its western side, issuing from Khabash after irrigating its palm trees and crops. The branches of this valley are from the Sarat of the land of Wadi'ah and its outer part. It passes through places from the lands of Banu Ma'mar, Banu Abd, and Al-Hara'im. It descends to Khaywan and irrigates it. The rest of it is supplied by the torrent of Qi'atuha, Bawban, Al-Adamah, and Malsa'. It enters the pass to Khabash, where it is met by the torrents of the land of Banu Harb ibn Wadi'ah from Rumayd and Huth. It is joined by the torrent of Al-Faq', Al-Hawariyyin, Al-Masra', Athafit, Dammaj, Shawath, Kharfan, the side of Al-Kasad, the Qibla of the outer part of Al-Sayd, Al-'Uqal, the Greater Mount Dhubyan, Rakhmat, Hawatayn, and Al-Sabi'.

The Third Valley: It appears in its angle between its north and its west. Its branches are from the land of Khawlan east of Abthar, the lands of Dammaj, Watran, Al-Sarir, Al-Ghalil, Asal, and the land of Dahmah from Talah, Al-'Assatayn, Aktaf, the heights of Jadrah the Southern, the slopes of Barat, Al-Marashi, and Al-Futul. The torrent of Abthar falls on Al-A'yan, then...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
...Al-'Uqlah, 'Uqlat Khatarir, then Madhab, then Majzar, Al-Habt, then Hazirat Hawsham, Majza'at al-Ghurab, 'Amish, Shajjan, Qasran, the land of Ruhm, Al-'Amashiyyah, Al-Halwa, Tali'in, 'Azalim, Shibraq, Barkan, 'Ayan, Tumu', the slopes of Mount Sufyan, the Qibla of Al-Adamah, Al-'Ablah, Ashar, Al-Hadinah, and Al-Maqbarah. It casts these waters towards Al-Waghirah Al-Shaba. It is supplied by the torrent of Nu'man from the land of Murhibah, appearing at Gharaq to irrigate it, descending to Dar Hashim and the place of Al-Daliyyin, meeting Al-Kharid with the torrent of Yahkish.

The Fourth: Wadi al-Manbaj. Its branches are from the land of Yam the Ancient, the land of Murhibah, Milh, Barran, Maswarah, and the mountains of Nihm adjacent to Mahnun from the land of Khawlan. The opposite of northern Nihm brings small valleys like Awan and others, then it starts at Al-Fart, which is the side of the lowland (Al-Gha'it), and it is from the dwellings of Balharith. Valleys from the land of Shakir from Barat, which belongs to Dahmah, and from the land of Wa'ilah and the land of Amir, valleys including Halaf and Qadib. That which is between Al-Jawf and Najran is of the large valleys (Al-A'rad) and palm groves. In it, the road to Al-Jawf and Ma'rib separates from Wadi Khab, which is Al-'Atiq, then Qadib, then Halaf. All these valleys are from the land of Shakir.

Then Wadi Najran [Najran, Saudi Arabia]. Its branches are from three places: from the land of Banu Hayf of Wadi'ah, from the land of Banu Jama'ah of Khawlan, and from the land of Shakir. And Al-Hanajir from Wadi'ah and the land of Khawlan. As for the Yemeni branch, it is from the north of Watran and Al-Sarir and the west of the land of Shakir to Dammaj of the land of Khawlan. Then it exits in Al-Khaniq from the land of Khawlan, then exits in Lahwat Rahban, Al-Hawatan, Al-Ghayl, Al-Batanat, and Al-Faqarah from the land of Khawlan. It meets the torrent of western Sa'dah from 'Alaf al-Buq'ah, Shi'b 'Ayn, Al-Hadayiq, Farwah, Nu'man, Afqin, then Al-Aslaf, then Al-Fayd, then Al-Sahn, then Daqrar, Al-Mawarid, Dahyan, then Al-Khabt, then the land of Banu Malik from Banu Hayya, then Hadbar, then Al-Akhbab, then Nisrin, then Sa'dah [Sa'dah, Yemen], until it joins the torrent of Dammaj at Al-Khaybah of Al-Batnah. They are met by the torrent of 'Akwan from the east and Qibla of Dammaj, and the torrents of eastern Kahlan, so it joins to Al-'Ashshah. Then it is met by Wadi Kushur, then the torrent of Jadrah and the lower parts of Amlah and the lower parts of Dadah from the land of Shakir. It is met at Al-Faqarah by the torrent...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
...of Kataf, pouring into the bottom of Al-Harba from Wadi Nahrad and the land of Banu Sabiqah from Wadi'ah. It is supplied by the torrent of Qadi Dinah, Al-Dahad, and Al-Rakb until it pours into Wadi al-'Ard, which is the course of the other two branches. The northern of the two is from Al-Thuwayliyah, Al-Shafrat, 'Amdan, Hadad, Buq'ah, and the east of the land of Jama'ah from its north. The western of them is from the east of Bawsan, Yasnam, Qirat, the land of Banu Salman from Banu Hayya, Dal'an, Sarum, and Al-Surum of Banu Jama'ah, Sarum Banu Sa'd, and the land of Banu Thawr. All these waters gather at the bottom of Al-'Ard at Dayqatayn, which is a narrow pass between two mountains. It advances in Shawkan from the top of Wadi Najran, irrigating it and ending in the lowland (Al-Gha'it). Then valleys intercept between Najran and Tathlith, such as Habunan and others from the lands of Wadi'ah, the land of Yam, Zubayd Sanhan, and the land of Janb. We will mention the dwellings of these people later, Allah Almighty willing.

The Desert of Yemen and it is called Al-Gha'it (The Lowland):
As for the desert of Yemen and its lowland, it is Sayhad. It is a desert branching from Al-Dahna from the direction of Al-Yamama and Al-Falaj. The islands (Juzur) of Yemen overlook it from Masamat Banu Amir in the direction of Turabah, then Tathlith, between Tathlith and Dathinah. This desert separates between the islands of Yemen from the lower parts of these valleys and between Hadramawt by four or five stages between Najran and Bayhan. As for what is behind Najran to the north, it is more, because Sayhad approaches from two branches of Al-Dahna: one from the east of Al-Yamama and Yabrin, and the second from the west of Al-Yamama and what is between it and Mount Al-Hidhn. Then the east of the land of Banu Hilal and the east of the valleys of Najd: Tabalah, Turabah, and Bisha, until it issues from Al-Masamah. It is a desert with no water in it. Whoever wants Hadramawt from Najran and Al-Jawf - the Jawf of Hamdan - and Ma'rib, his exit is Al-'Abr, a watering place with wells. Whoever intends it from Bayhan, Al-Sarw, and Dathinah, his exit is from the land of Madhhij. Then valleys exit pouring from the land of Madhhij to Hadramawt until he reaches Dahr, which is the beginning of Hadramawt from that side. It belongs to Kindah and its inhabitants are Tujib. Then to Wadi Rakhyah, and in it are villages including Sama' and Sur Bani Harithah.

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Hadramawt is of Yemen [Hadramaut, Yemen], and it is its smaller part. This town was attributed to Hadramawt ibn Himyar the Younger, so the name of its inhabitant prevailed over it, as was said Khaywan and Najran. The meaning is the land of Hadramawt, the land of Khaywan, and the valley of Najran, because these are men to whom the places were attributed. Likewise, most of the lands of Himyar and Hamdan were named by the names of their settlers. Al-Sadaf were in Hadramawt from their day. Then Kindah returned to them after the killing of Ibn al-Jawn on the Day of Shi'b Jabalah when they departed from Al-Ghamr, the Ghamr of Dhi Kindah. In it are Al-Sadaf, Tujib, and Al-'Ibad from Kindah, Banu Mu'awiyah ibn Kindah, Yazid ibn Mu'awiyah, Banu Wahb, Banu Badda ibn al-Harith, Banu al-Ra'ish ibn al-Harith, Banu Amr ibn al-Harith, Banu Dhuhl ibn Mu'awiyah, and Banu al-Harith ibn Mu'awiyah. From Al-Sakun there is a group, and a group from Hamdan called Al-Mahatil from Dhi al-Jirab ibn Nashq, and they are with Kindah. And a group from Balharith ibn Ka'b in Raydat al-Say'ar, to which the Say'ari camels are attributed. About it Tarafa says:
And at the foot of the mountain are signs as if their traces ... are a Yemeni garment embroidered by Raydah and Suhul.
Al-Say'ar is a tribe from Al-Sadaf to which Raydah is attributed to distinguish between it and Raydat Ardayn.

The Land of Kindah from the Land of Hadramawt:
If one goes out from Al-'Abr, the first thing he meets is Darb al-'Ujayz al-Kindi. Then Haynan, which is a large village; at its bottom is a market and at its top is a fortress belonging to Al-Husayn ibn Muhammad al-Tujibi, and its inhabitants are Banu Badda and Banu Sahl from Tujib. Then Sawran, a moderate village belonging to Tujib of Kindah. Then Qashaqish, a village at the top of a mountain belonging to Tujib. Then 'Andal, a great city belonging to Al-Sadaf. Imru' al-Qays ibn Hujr had visited Al-Sadaf there, and about it he says:
As if I did not play at Dammun once ... and did not witness the raids one day at 'Andal.
'Andal, Khudun, Hadun, and Dammun are cities of Al-Sadaf in Hadramawt. Then Al-Hajran,

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text: which are two facing cities at the top of a fortified mountain, ascended to in impregnability from every side. One is called Khaydun and Khudun - all is said - and Dammun. It is the dual form of Al-Hajar, and Al-Hajar is the village in the language of Himyar and the original Arabs. From it comes Hajar of Bahrain [Al-Hasa, Saudi Arabia], Hajar of Najran [Najran, Saudi Arabia], Hajar of Jazan [Jazan, Saudi Arabia], and Hajar Hasbah of the Mikhlaf of Ma'dhin. The inhabitants of Khudun are Al-Sadaf, and the inhabitants of Dammun are Banu al-Harith the King ibn Amr al-Maqsur ibn Hujr Akil al-Murar. He was named Akil al-Murar only because some of Ghassan opposed him in some of his raids, sweeping away wealth belonging to him and capturing a slave girl of his. They went deep into the land with the slave girl, managing the wealth out of fear of the Tubba'. The slave girl began to turn around. She was asked: "What is your turning around?" She said: "It is as if I see Hujr has come close to you, opening his mouth wide as if he were a camel that ate bitter herbs (Murar)." He did not delay to catch up in that form, so he was named Akil al-Murar. The house of every man in these two villages overlooks his estate. They have a stream (Ghayl) pouring from the foot of the mountain which they drink. The crops of these villages are palm trees, and Al-'Abr is surrounded by them. Al-Dhabr is cultivation. From Al-Hajran palm against palm; palm trees and cultivation surround them. Al-Dhabr is cultivation. The land of Kindah is elevated as if it were Sarat. Its valleys pour into Hadramawt, then Hadramawt pours to the land of Mahra. From Al-Hajrayn to Raydat Ardayn is a valley containing many villages and palm trees belonging to Al-'Ibad from Kindah. Then one descends to Sadbah, the village of Muhammad ibn Yusuf al-Tujibi. Then Hawrah, which is a great city belonging to Banu Harithah from Kindah. Then Qarat al-Ashba, which belongs to Kindah. Al-Qarah according to the Arabs is a hill, and its plural is Qar like Rahah and Rah, Sa'ah and Sa', and also Qur. Al-'Ajlaniyah is a large village opposite Haynan, except that Haynan is in Wadi al-'Abr - and its name is 'Ayn - and Al-'Ajlaniyah is in Wadi Daw'an. The land of Kindah is these two valleys; their upper parts are fortresses and their lower parts are crops and palm trees. Then Mansub, a valley containing villages, palm trees, crops, and cotton. Then Manub pours with 'Ayn and Daw'an between Shibam and Al-Qarah. Al-Qarah belongs to Hamdan, a great village with a fortress in its middle. As for Shibam [Shibam, Yemen], it is the city of everyone, the large one. Hadramawt inhabited it. It has thirty mosques, half of them ruined, destroyed by Kindah. It is the first land of Himyar.

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
And the Fortress of Hadhiah, to which Hadhwi is attributed. Al-Nujayr is a fortress that belonged to Kindah and is today a ruin; to it is attributed the Day of Al-Nujayr in the days of the Apostasy (Ridda). The inhabitants of Shibam are Banu Fahd from Himyar. Then Al-Mazyan, a village whose inhabitants are Himyar. Then Madudah, then Taris which is a great city. Then Mashtah, a moderate village. Then Maha, a great village. Al-Makha is in the land of Banu Majid. Then Al-'Ajz, a great village divided into two halves belonging to Himyar; each half is a village for a group, half for Al-Ashba and half for Banu Fahd. Then one descends from it to Thawbah, a village in lower Hadramawt in a valley with palm trees. Wadi Thawbah pours into the land of Mahra, where the grave of Hud the Prophet, peace be upon him, is. His grave is in the Red Sand Dune, then from it into an overlooking cave in the lower part of Wadi al-Ahqaf, which is a valley taking from the land of Mahra a journey of days. The people of Hadramawt visit it, they and the people of Mahra, at all times. Al-Nu'ayrayn is from the work of the place of Yusuf ibn Abd al-Hamid. Yatrab is a city in Hadramawt settled by Kindah; Abu al-Khayr ibn Amr was in it. It is what Al-A'sha meant by his saying:
With the arrows of Yatrab or the arrows of the Valley
It is said that 'Arqub, the owner of the promises, was in it. About him Ka'b ibn Zuhayr says:
The promises of 'Arqub were a proverb for her ... And her promises are nothing but falsehoods
Tarim [Tarim, Yemen] is a great city. Raydat al-'Ibad and Raydat al-Haramiyyah belong to Al-Ahrum from Al-Sadaf. Shazan and Dhu Subh are two cities in Daw'an. The dwelling of Banu Wahid from Banu Mu'awiyah al-Akramin is in Qabdayn, and their blood is used to cure rabies (Al-Kalba). Al-Hayq belongs to Banu Nabatah from Al-Sadaf. Tafish belongs to Banu Dhahban from Al-Sadaf. As for the place of the Imam who commands and forbids the Ibadis, it is in the city of Daw'an. The coast of these villages is Al-As'a, the place of Abu Thawr al-Mahri. Between Bayhan and Hadramawt is Shabwah [Shabwah, Yemen], a city belonging to Himyar. One of the two salt mountains is in it; the second mountain belongs to the people of Ma'rib. He said: When Himyar and Madhhij fought, the people of Shabwah left Shabwah and lived in Hadramawt. Shibam was named after them; the origin in that was Shibah, so the Mim was substituted for the Ha.

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
He said: In Hadramawt, Kindah settled after they were evacuated from Bahrain, Al-Mushaqqar, and Ghamr Dhi Kindah in the Jahiliyyah after the killing of Ibn al-Jawn. The number of those transferred from them from these lands to Hadramawt was thirty-odd thousand. He said: Tujib inhabits Al-Kasr in the middle of Hadramawt. He said: In Hadramawt today there are a thousand and five hundred of them, among them four hundred horsemen. Al-Kasr is known as Kasr Qasha'ish. About it Abu Sulayman ibn Yazid ibn Abi al-Hasan al-Ta'i says:
And he settled part of us in the palaces of Baraqish ... Then Ma'wad, Wadi al-Kasr, Kasr Qasha'ish
To Qaynan, every dominant featherer ... masters, not base nor obscene
Nor is clemency [of value] if the forbearing one acts recklessly with a reckless one
Al-Kasr has many villages. Among them is a village called Haynan, in which are two clans from Tujib called Banu Sahl and Banu Badda; among them are two hundred horsemen coming out from a single gate. Their head today is Muhammad ibn al-Husayn al-Tujibi. Another village of Badda is called Hawrah, in which are two clans called Banu Harithah and Banu Muharriyah from Tujib. Their head today is Harithah ibn Nu'aym, and Muhammad and Muharriyah sons of Al-A'jam. A village in it called Qashaqish. A village called Sawran. A village called Sadiyat al-Ras, in which is Muhammad ibn Yusuf al-Tujibi. A village called Al-'Ajlaniyah. A village called Manub. And two valleys called Rakhyah and Dahr, in which are many villages. In Rakhyah is a path called Sur Bani Nu'aym from Tujib, and they have many villages in a valley other than that. Their Ibadism is little, and most of that is in Al-Sadaf because they entered into Himyar. Tujib is from the offspring of Al-Ashras ibn Kindah. Al-Sakasik, Al-Sakun, Banu Amir in Abyan, Al-'Ibad, Wayn, Mawiyah, and Banu Bakrah; these are the offspring of Al-Ashras ibn Kindah. As for Banu Mu'awiyah ibn Kindah, they are Banu Yazid ibn Mu'awiyah, Banu Wahb ibn Mu'awiyah, Banu Badda ibn al-Harith ibn Mu'awiyah, Banu al-Ra'ish ibn al-Harith ibn Mu'awiyah, Banu Mu'awiyah ibn al-Harith, Banu Dhuhl ibn Mu'awiyah the Lost, Banu Amr ibn Mu'awiyah, and Banu al-Harith ibn Mu'awiyah. These are Banu Mu'awiyah ibn Kindah. Among them are the Crowned Kings; it is said there were seventy crowned kings among them. The first of them were Thawr and Marta'

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
the two sons of Amr ibn Mu'awiyah, and the last of them was Al-Ash'ath ibn Qays al-Kindi ibn Ma'di Karib.

Sarw Himyar, its Valleys and Inhabitants:
Al-'Urr, Thamar, Habbah, 'Illah, Hatib, Yahar, Dhu Nakhib (a mountain), Dhu Thawib, Salfah, Sha'b, 'Arrumayhan, Sallub, Al-'Arqah, Madwarah, Al-Majza'ah, and Taym. Al-'Urr belongs to Adhan from Yafi'. Thamar belongs to the Dharahin from Yafi'. Habbah belongs to the Abqur from Yafi'. 'Illah belongs to the Aswut from Yafi'. Hatib belongs to Banu Qasid from Yafi'. Yahar belongs to Banu Shu'ayb from Yafi'. Dhu Nakhib belongs to Banu Jabr from them. Dhu Thawib belongs to Banu Sa'id from them. Salfah belongs to Banu Shu'ayb also. Sha'b belongs to Banu Sumay from them. 'Arrumayhan belongs to Banu Shu'ayb also. Sallub belongs to Banu Jabr. Al-'Arqah belongs to the Ahjur from them, and it is a valley, and they are Banu Hajar. Sudur belongs to Kalb from Yafi'. In every place of these places are villages and many dwellings.

The land of their allies and confederates from Banu Ja'dah. Of the valleys: Al-Dabab, Wadi Hadar which has the highway to Sana'a, Wadi Shar'ah, Al-Maknah, Al-Ja'diyah, Wadi Thawbah, Wadi al-Maqtan, Al-Mu'tanaq, Wadi Shaka', Akhlah, Wadi al-Thamra, Wadi 'Amaq, Wadi Samih, Wadi 'Utbah, Wadi Wahdah, and Wadi Dar'ah. These valleys pour into Abyan Al-Kawr between Yafi' and Madhhij. Al-Dabab belongs to the A'dud from Ja'dah. Hadar belongs to the A'dud from Ja'dah. Shar'ah belongs to Banu A'had from Ja'dah. Al-Huknah belongs to the A'dud. Al-Ja'diyah belongs to Banu al-Muhajir from Ja'dah. Thawbah belongs to Banu al-Muhajir. Al-Maqtan belongs to the A'dud. Shaka' and Akhlah belong to the A'dud and Banu Muhajir. Al-Thamra belongs to the A'dud. 'Amaq belongs to the Ahruth. Samih belongs to the A'dud. Harir and its mountain Hadar belong to the A'dud. Wadi Bakhal belongs to the Aknus from Banu Muhajir. Al-Suhayb is a village. Saba is the place of the Bahriyyin. Dhu Dahanah is a valley belonging to Banu Bahr and Banu Dhahban from Al-Sadaf. Dhu Yuhbash is a valley belonging to the Marathid. Wadi Tawnah belongs to the Asni'ah from the Ayzun. Asham belongs to the Sakasikah from Ja'dah. Al-Hubayl belongs to Yashham. And a well called...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Yazham. These Banu Ja'dah are said to go back to some Ru'ayf al-Kubar, but today they say they are from Banu Ja'dah ibn Ka'b. He begot Rabi'ah, nicknamed Barqan, Abdullah, Zuhayr, Mu'awiyah, and Mirdas. Rabi'ah begot Amr, Hayyan, Abdullah - nicknamed the Madman -, Jaz', Hisn, Amir, 'Awf, 'Adas, and Qiradah. Amr ibn Rabi'ah begot Al-Ruqad, Ward - the killer of Sharahil ibn al-As'hab al-Ju'fi, and he was a king over them -, Jaz' ibn Amr, and Suhayl ibn Amr. From the family of Al-Ward is Al-Hashraj ibn al-Ashhab ibn Ward, a house of honor, praised. 'Adas ibn Rabi'ah ibn Ja'dah begot Jaz', Qays, Abdullah, Hanak, Dirar, and Malik. From Banu 'Adas is Al-Nabigha al-Ja'di. Abdullah ibn Ja'dah begot Qays, Amir, Al-Musaffah the Poet, Ka'b, and Malik; all are clans. Such is the way of every tribe of the Bedouins that matches with its name the name of a more famous tribe than it; it almost leans towards it and is attributed to it. We have seen that often. Likewise Sarw Madhhij; Madhhij did not settle it except lately. It is from the homelands of Dhi Ru'ayn. Their market is in it, and the graves of their kings, their palaces, and their ruins. Most of its places and spots are named by the names of its settlers from the family of Dhi Ru'ayn.

Sarw Madhhij:
Its beginning is Al-Rabahah, Al-Salaf, Hamar, and Tana'im belonging to Ruha'. Al-Marawih belongs to Banu Sa'id, and they trace their lineage to Daws of Al-Azd. Al-Jazah belongs to Banu Amir, a clan from Masliyah. Al-Shi'b belongs to the family of Kutayf, and they are from Banu Masliyah, and they are their nobles. Al-Badah, Mayd, and Shabathan belong to Banu Masliyah. They have Nakhlan, a large valley. The land of Banu Za'id: its beginning is Al-Khazanah, Nisbah, and Al-Hujayrah, a pre-Islamic fortress. Al-Shahd, which is their fortress and around it are many properties. Al-Sirr, Nawas, and 'Abayah. They have a fortress known as Al-Hadmiyah. They have Dabban and Masr. All these places belong to Banu Za'id ibn Hayy ibn Awd. Wadi Na'wah belongs to Banu Munabbih, and they are brothers of Banu Kutayf and Banu Qays from Banu Awd. They are the clan of Al-Afwah...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Al-Awdi. In it are places for Ruha'. Khawdan is a valley belonging to Banu Af'a in Al-Sarw from Banu Awd, the clan of Muhammad ibn al-Sindid. Dhu Wathan is a valley belonging to Banu Af'a also. Hasamah and Shawkan are two valleys for the Aludhiyyin, and they are Banu Awd. Tarman belongs to Aludh. Al-'Atf, Al-Far', Al-'Affah, Sama', and Marhab belong to Al-Nakha', the clan of Al-Ashtar al-Nakha'i. Mash'abah and Sa'dan belong to the Asbahiyyin. Dhu 'Araf belongs to Sada', and they are with the Nakha'iyyin. Kuraysh belongs to the Awdiyyin and the Asbahiyyin. Sahab and Balas belong to the Awdiyyin. Wherever you find [places] for the Awdiyyin, they are mixed in it. Na'ma and 'Adw to the head of Al-Kawr. In it is a fortress known as Al-Qamar belonging to the Asbahiyyin from Himyar, and most of it belongs to Al-Du'am ibn Rizam al-Dihbali from Awd, and they are his maternal uncles. His maternal grandfather is Muhammad ibn Ubayd ibn Salim al-Asbahi, the peer of Muhammad ibn Abi al-'Ala. He fought Madhhij in Al-Sarw, and all of it was in his time.
Dathinah [Dathinah, Yemen]: Its beginning is 'Arran, and its name is Al-Ruqub, belonging to Banu Kutayf, and they are the clan of Rizam ibn Muhammad. They have Al-Mawshih, which is a large city. Al-Harr and Taran are two valleys belonging to Banu Qays from Banu Awd, and they are the two sons of Abdullah ibn Suhaytah, I mean Kutayf and Qays. They have a village known as Al-Zahirah. Yara is a large valley belonging to Banu Shakl ibn Hayy from Awd. Wadi Tharah belongs to Banu Hubab, and they are brothers of Banu Shabib, and their village is called Manha. 'Irfan is a valley belonging to Banu Af'a, and they are from Banu Rabi'ah ibn Awd, and they are the clan of Ibn al-Sindid. Al-Muqayq belongs to Banu Shihab ibn al-Arqam ibn Hayy ibn Awd. Al-Ghamr is a valley belonging to Thaqif. Ra'ish is a mountain inhabited by Banu Awd altogether. Yusqa belongs to Banu Amr, and they are brothers of Banu Shihab. Al-Ma'wran is a valley, and Al-Humayra' is a valley, both belonging to Banu Muzahim, and they are from the Dahabil, and they are among the nobles of Banu Awd and their masters. They are from Banu Rabi'ah ibn Awd, and they are the clan of Ibn Uthman al-Dahbali, who stayed at the frontier raiding for a long time then returned. Al-Sharafah is a great valley belonging to Banu 'Ada ibn Usama; they trace back to Rabi'ah al-Faras. Habl is a valley containing a village known as Al-Sawda' belonging to the Asbahiyyin from Himyar. Al-Hafah belongs to the Asbahiyyin. Al-Dubayyah belongs to Banu al-Hamas from Balharith ibn Ka'b. Maran, Kabran, Nazi'ah, Hajumah, Mallahah, and Al-Tayyib all belong to Al-Nakha'. In Wadi Maran, part of it belongs to Banu Qubath from them, and they are their masters and nobles. Among them is Muhammad ibn...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Qubath, the feeder of the wolf, and he has a strange story. Wahar belongs to Kindah. Dlarw'an Al-Jaza' belongs to Banu 'Aydh Allah ibn Sa'd. Al-Rawdah and Tabb are valleys belonging to Banu 'Aydh Allah ibn Sa'd. Al-Qarn, Al-'Aridah, and Mahar belong to Banu 'Ajib, and they are from Azd Shanu'ah. Al-Khaninah is a city belonging to Banu Suwayq from Banu Hayy ibn Awd. The plain of Dathinah adjacent to Yaramis is Dar al-Hufaynat, the fortress, and its inhabitants are Banu Shabib and Banu Hubab in three separate villages. And Akmah belongs to Banu Af'a. This is Dathinah.
Ahwar [Ahwar, Yemen] is a single valley containing many villages. Among them is Al-Jathwah, which belongs to the Sha'a'im from Banu 'Aydh Allah. Among them is Yahya ibn Harb who served the Caliph over the governorship of Yemen. And among them is Abu Yazid ibn Abd al-Aziz; Madhhij agreed on his leadership. He marched with them to Abyan and Al-Sarw. We will satisfy the mention of Ahwar later, Allah Almighty willing.

The roads that mix between Al-Sarw, Abyan, Radman, Rada', Dhamar, Qarn, then Bayhan and Ahwar, along with what was mentioned of the lands of Madhhij outside Al-Sarw.
The first land of Madhhij after you leave Dhamar [Dhamar, Yemen] heading towards the east by about two parasangs is the land of 'Ans. It is wide. Its boundaries from the north side are Al-Thaniyah which is in Yakla, Al-Taybar, and Jirah. From the south side, a mountain known as Maytam to Haql Shar'ah; they own half of it. From the east side, That. Today, among the clans of 'Ans in it are the Nahdiyon, the Qariyyon, the Lamisiyon, and the Yamiyon, and they are the clan of Abu al-'Ashirah al-Yami. In their land are many villages, including Al-Manshar, Al-Ahjar, Bashar, and Bawsan. The mountain known as Isbil is in the middle of their land, except that in it are people who are not of them, such as Banu 'Anam, Banu Tayyibah, and Banu Sarhah. Below that is Kuman; its origin is Himyari, but they call themselves Madhhij today, and Banu Fuja'ah. Below that are the valleys to Tanin and what adjoins it, Qa'ifah and Al-Ma'afir, and they are from Murad. As for Kuman and Fuja'ah, their count is in Zuwaf. As for Banu Sarhah, Banu Tayyibah, and Banu 'Anam, they are from Banu Julayhah ibn Aklab ibn Rabi'ah ibn 'Afris, and they are allies in Madhhij.

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text: I have omitted the descriptions of these places even if they are long, and started with the descriptions of the Mikhlaf of Banu Amir. The first of that is what is on the right side of that if the east is facing your face and you have left the borders of 'Ans: Wadi Yujaj belongs to Banu Salamah, and it was originally for the Qalhaniyyin from Al-Kala', and a small remnant of them remains in it. Aqsad, Mawar, and 'Azzan belong to Banu Salamah and the people of That. Al-Tannahub and Mallah belong to the Rummaniyyin from Al-Kala' and a people called Banu Asad who may claim sanctity (Taharrum), and to the Thatiyyin. Habban was originally for Kuman, then became for Banu Muhammad ibn Yunus al-Abrahi, then it is today for Banu al-Harith ibn Ka'b and the people of That and Rada' [Rada'a, Yemen]. Dhat Mithal, Dhat Kura', and Al-Kha'is belong to Banu Rabi'ah, and they are the Rabi'iyyun in Rada', and they are from Janb and their count is from Najiyah. Banu Amir are two houses: Zuwaf and Najiyah; then Najiyah are houses and Zuwaf are houses, you will see them Allah Almighty willing. Sawman and Al-Khabar belong to Banu 'Abs, and today people from Banu Rabi'ah and the people of Rada' have settled with them. Al-Far' and Al-Hajmah belong to Banu Sarif from Saba and to Banu Nashirah from Himyar, and their call (Da'wah) is all to the Rabi'iyyin from Janb. Bahrur belongs to Banu Ruha' from 'Ullah ibn Jald ibn Madhhij, and their call is in Banu Rabi'ah. 'Aqarib and Madawih belong to the people of Rada', and in them are mixtures of Banu Ziyad and Banu Rabi'ah, and they are the Ziyadiyyun who have Shatt Ziyad in Al-Jawf, and they are from Banu al-Harith. Dhu Hababah, Wihdan, and Al-Naq'ah belong to Banu Ziyad also, and their call is in Najiyah. Al-Mahjar al-A'la, Al-Mahjar al-Asfal, Al-Akrab, and Al-Matar belong to Banu Munabbih, and they are all from Khath'am, three houses: two houses from Shahran and a house from Julayhah, and they are in Najiyah. Walas, Sha'ban, and Al-Ghawl belong to Banu 'Abs from Zuwaf, and to the Saqa'ib allies of theirs from Hamdan. Al-Marun and Al-Jaruban belong to Banu Thumad from Saba, and they are allies to Banu 'Abs and their call is with them. They are 'Abs Zuwaf. Dhu Khayr, Dhu Kurash, Dhu Hasl, Al-Manharan, Al-Habash, and Radam to Salahlah eastward on Al-Sirr belong to Banu Salamah from Zuwaf, and they are the pillar of the Zuwafiyyin and the people of their horses and might. They are three houses: Banu Malik, and it is said their origin is from Zubayd, Banu Abd, and Banu Yasut. Haram is a citadel in a great valley. Adamah, Mallahah, and 'Afar belong to Sanabih,

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
and they are from Zuwaf. Dhat al-Quwah and Salam belong to Banu 'Asas from Sanabih, allies from some of Madhhij. Maras belongs to Banu Zafar, brothers of Banu 'Asas; Zafar and 'Asas are brothers from Dhi Maqar. Below these places are valleys, among them Hulayl, Sayd, and Dhu Kazzan belonging to Banu Hubaysh from Zubayd. They are in the middle of the land of Zuwaf, so we left the mention of their dwellings to the last thing. This is the land of Zuwaf on the right side. Hamrah and the adjacent lands to the borders of Yafi' and Al-Jarbatayn belong to Banu Ja'dah.

Return to the mention of the left side upon his exit from Rada' to the east: Fawd, Al-Nazim, Liqah, and Al-Harsabah belong to Banu Malik, and they are from Murad, then from Banu Ghatif, and their call is in Zuwaf. Dhu al-Hatab, Dhu al-Barar, Yakla, Dhu Qasad, Dhu Namir, Dhu Shuman, and Dhu al-Arakah all belong to Banu Wabish, and they are from Quda'a as they say, and their call and support is for Murad. Jabhan, Thumad, Al-Ahliyah, and Al-Naq'ah belong to Salman, and they are to Murad. Then the valleys after that to Wadi Adhanah.

Return to the mention of the middle road to Radman: Da'ah al-'Ulya belongs to Banu Wabish. Da'ah al-Sufla belongs to the A'far from Najiyah. 'Armah belongs to Banu Shabathan from Najiyah. Sari' belongs to Banu Shubrumah, and their call is in Najiyah. Wa'lan, which is the palace of Dhi Ma'ahir, and around it are great properties. In it today are people from Akil Khawlan, and people from Banu Urwah, and they are from Masliyah and their call is in the Jamaliyyin, and they are to Najiyah. Al-Mustalah, Al-Miftah, and Qatar belong to Banu Urwah also, and they are from Jamal ibn Kinanah to Najiyah. Dhu Harim belongs to Banu Urwah, and in it are people from Sanabih. Dhat al-Rihlayn, Al-Rawdah, to A'rab, to the heights of Bayhan belong to Murad.

Return to Radman: Naw'ah belongs to Juran, and they are from Himyar, and they are in Najiyah. Al-Mismaq al-A'la and Al-Mismaq al-Asfal belong to Banu Mulayk, and they are from Himyar in Najiyah. Hurriyah belongs to the Ramsiyyin. They have Dhu al-Qa'qa', and they are Shabathan from Najiyah; their support and call is in Jamal. 'Aqd, Al-Sadr, and Dhu Jazar belong to Banu Abd from Himyar, and their call is in Jamal ibn Kinanah from Murad. Hadnan are two valleys for the Murrabiyyin, and they are from the origin of Jamal. Atam belongs to Banu Sa'id from Al-Azd from the offspring of...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Daws, and their call is in Jamal. Al-Bad' are valleys, among them Dhu 'Arabil, Hawran, Rawaf, Qayinah, Dhu Hadid, Ramadah, and Dhu Halifan. All of them belong to Banu Murr, and among them are mixtures from Banu Ghaylan, and Banu Ghaylan are Nahik from Janb. Qarn: seven large valleys, among them Al-Ma'dhanah, Al-'Awlah, Al-Jahlah, Mahar, Dhu Zum, Dhu Jayshan, and Dhu 'Asb. Their inhabitants are all mixtures from Murad and Himyar, and their call and support are in An'am from Murad. After that are valleys to Harib in which are tribes from Murad: the Rabi'iyyun, the Khalafiyyun, and the 'Udhriyyun. The descriptions of Radman and Qarn are finished.

Return to the descriptions of the right side: The road of Al-Sarw, Al-Rabahah, and a mountain from which valleys branch out inhabited by Ruha' and Banu Ard from Banu Masliyah, and they are from 'Ullah. Hamar belongs to Ruha' and Masliyah. Dhu al-Dhuwayb is a large valley for Yafi' and Banu Masliyah. Dhu al-Qala' for Yafi' and Banu Masliyah. Asil for Ruha'. Qasas for Ruha' and Banu Za'id from Awd. Khazanah, and its name is Nisbah, for Banu Za'id also. Al-Shahd for Banu Za'id. Dhu al-Ajtha for Aludh from Awd, and they have Baram, Dhu Dam, Shawkan, then Al-Rahbah to Hasi, which is a city that belonged to Shamir Taran and in it is his grave, and it is today for the Awdiyyin. Dhu Sarim for Banu Zuhayr from Aludh. Hajlan for Banu Sa'd from Aludh. Dhu al-'Aybah for Banu Anas Allah from Aludh, the dwelling of the Ju'fiyyin, and they are in this place Nasr for Aludh. Al-Midmar is a large valley for Banu Zabyah, and they are from Banu Masliyah, and their support is in Aludh, and they are their allies. Dhat 'Ayn for Banu Sa'd from Aludh. Al-Hajar, which is the end of Al-Sarr, belongs to Sada' from Banu Harb ibn 'Ullah.
Markhah: Then Markhah, the first of it is 'Abrah, and it belongs to Banu Laqit from Sada'. Al-Bajbajah for Sada', a valley with many palm trees for Banu Shaddad from Sada', and among them is a clan called Banu Farat, intruders. Haza for Banu Sada', for Banu Shaddad from them. Lajyah is a valley with many palm trees and 'Ulub (Sidr trees) for Banu Shaddad. Al-Mashkan for Banu Shaddad. Al-Madid for Banu Sulaym from Sada'. Khawrah, Al-Hajar, and Al-Jarba' for Banu Dhi Ma'ahir from Himyar, and for a people from Sada' and Banu Mawiyah. This is Markhah.
And 'Abdan for Banu 'Aydh Allah from Sada', and their fortress in it is well-known, and Banu 'Aydh Allah ibn Sa'd al-'Ashirah. Jardan, a valley...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
great, containing many villages for Ju'f. Yashbam is a great valley for the Ayzun from Himyar. And Hajar Banu Wahb for Banu Amir from Kindah. This left precinct of Al-Sarw is completed.

Return to Al-Sarw intending for Dathinah: Sharjan from Al-Sarw for Banu Malik from Aludh. Nu'man for the Asbahiyyin from Himyar. 'Adw, a valley with many onions and grapes, in it is a fortress known as Al-Qamar for the Asbahiyyin, and most of it today is for Al-Du'am ibn Rizam al-Kutayfi, the master of Awd. And in Banu Ma'shar from Al-Asabih are his ancestors from his mother, and they are their nobles.
