His grandfather is Muhammad ibn Ubayd ibn Salim al-Asbahi, and he is the one who opposed Muhammad ibn Abi al-'Ala and settled Madhhij in Al-Sarw and Dathinah. Sahab is a valley for Al-Nakha' and Banu Awd. This is the end of Al-Sarr. And from the right road - then Al-Kawr to Dathinah has many roads, including Al-Ruqub, Damamah, Wisahah, Al-Buhayr, Taran, Tharah, 'Irfan, Mal'ah, Bara', and Hasrah.

And we repeat the description in Dathinah: So the beginning of Dathinah is Athrah for Banu Hubab from Awd. Dathinah is a lowland like the lowland of Ma'rib, in it are Banu Awd; for every clan (Banu Ab) of them is a village around which are their farms. In it is the village of Banu Shabib and Banu Qays, which is Al-Zahirah. And Al-Mawshih, which is the largest village in Dathinah, and it is a city for Banu Kutayf. And Al-Ma'wran for Banu Muzahim, and they have Al-Khadra'. And Al-Qarn for Banu Kulayb. Al-'Aridah for Saba. Al-Sawda' and its valleys for the Asbahiyyin. Dhu al-Khaninah for Banu Suwayq. The Black Mountain is the end of Dathinah, and it belongs to the 'Udiyyin and the Khamsiyyin from Himyar. This is Dathinah from this left precinct.

And we repeat the description in Ahwar: Ahwar, its beginning is Al-Jathwah, a village for Banu 'Aydh Allah ibn Sa'd. Al-Quway' for Banu Amir from Kindah. Al-Sharirah for Banu Amir also. Al-Muhdath, close to the sea, for Banu Amir from Sahil. 'Arqah for Banu Amir. Then I ended at Hajar Wahb from this road also, so the first road met there.

Then he returned to Al-Kawr intending the right road to Abyan: If you descend from...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Bara', there is Wadi Bara' containing Masliyah. Then Sana', a valley containing Banu Suraym from Awd, and they have traced lineage to Balharith ibn Ka'b, and there are mixtures from Banu Munabbih. Then Rubyan, Sanba, and Al-'Atf all belong to Murad. Then Yaramis, a great valley containing palm trees and cotton, and it belongs to a group from Al-Asabih from Himyar. Then Dhu Sukayr for Banu Masliyah.

Then after that Abyan [Abyan, Yemen]: The first of Abyan is Shawkan, a large village having valleys, and it belongs to the Asbahiyyin. The large city is Khanfar, and it also belongs to the Asbahiyyin and a people from Banu Majid called the Haramiyyin, and a people from Madhhij called the Zafriyyin. Al-Madari is a village inhabited by the Asbahiyyin. Al-Rawa' is inhabited by Banu Majid. Al-Milhah is inhabited by Banu Majid. Al-Masna'ah is inhabited by the Asbahiyyin. Al-Jashir is inhabited by the Asbahiyyin also. Al-Tariyyah is inhabited by the Amiriyyun from the offspring of Al-Ashras. Al-Baridah is inhabited by a people called the Rabi'iyyun from Kahlan. Al-Jathwah is inhabited by the Rabi'iyyun also. Al-Hujbur is inhabited by the Akhadir from Madhhij. Al-Faqq is inhabited by the Asbahiyyin. The villages of Abyan are many, between Banu Amir from Kindah and Al-Asabih from Himyar and Banu Majid, and those who mix all from Madhhij, which is little. Then to Al-Safal to the sea. Bawzan is inhabited by a people from Hadbar called Banu al-Hadbari, and their count is in Madhhij. Al-Sharirah is inhabited by the Asbahiyyin. Nakha' is inhabited by Banu Masliyah. Al-Rawdah is inhabited by the Asbahiyyin. Halmah is inhabited by the Asbahiyyin. Qahidah is inhabited by the Ahlul from Banu Majid. A village known by Yusuf ibn Kathir and his cousins, and they are Rabi'i people. A village known by Mahall Hamid is inhabited by people from Ahwar migrating, and they have settled it. A village on the sea coast whose name escaped me is inhabited by a people from Madhhij. The description of Abyan is completed.

Lahj [Lahij, Yemen] and its inhabitants: Al-Hayyib is inhabited by Banu Ahbal from the Asbahiyyin, and people from the Ayzun. Al-Ru'ayd is inhabited by Banu Hubayl from the Asbahiyyin. Al-Jawar is inhabited by the Asbahiyyin. Al-Dar is inhabited by the Waqidiyyun. Al-Ra'ari' is inhabited by the Waqidiyyun. Fawr is inhabited by the Asbahiyyin. Al-Ghabra', closer to Aden, is inhabited by the Asbahiyyin.

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Bani Abbah is inhabited only by Baqur from Yafi'. Banu al-Habl is inhabited by a people known as the A'dun, attributed to Aden, and Banu Tufayl from Banu al-Habl is inhabited by a people from Banu Majid. Al-Nashrahi is inhabited by the Asbahiyyin. Dhat al-Iqbal is inhabited by the Asbahiyyin. Tuban is inhabited by the Waqidiyyun, and it is the one mentioned by Al-Sayyid ibn Muhammad in his saying:
Did you not stand at the bends of Tuban?
Then he says in this poem:
I have two dwellings in Lahj, a dwelling in the middle ... of it, and I have a dwelling at Al-'Arr of Aden
Around me is Dhu Kula' in its dwellings ... and Dhu Ru'ayn, Hamdan, and Dhu Yazan
Thara is inhabited by the Waqidiyyun. Junayb is inhabited by the Waqidiyyun. Al-Rahbah is inhabited by the Waqidiyyun. Dar Banu Shu'ayb is inhabited by the Waqidiyyun. Al-Rahah is inhabited by the Asbahiyyin, and Al-Rawagh is inhabited by Al-Asabih.

Bayhan [Bayhan, Yemen]: As for Bayhan, it has two roads: Al-Sadarah, a valley pouring into Bayhan from which is their drink; its people are the Ridawiyyun from Tayy, and they are from Banu Abd Rida. The second is another valley. The inhabitants of Bayhan are Murad up to Al-'Atf. Below Bayhan and Al-'Atf is inhabited by the Ma'ajil from Saba. Then beyond that is the lowland (Al-Gha'it) to Markhah. The leaders of Murad of Bayhan are the family of Al-Makarman, and they are the Khasasat. It is said that the Khasasat are from the offspring of Al-Ashras ibn Kindah, and they are the house of Ibn Muljam. The family of Al-Makarman have honor, sovereignty, and standing in Madhhij.

Mikhlaf Shabwah: Inhabited by the Ashba' and the Ayzun, then Sada' and Ruha'.

We returned to west of the highway of Aden: Al-Sahl is the land of Banu Majid. Al-Shiqaq, Mawza', Wadi al-Hanna, and Al-Mandab. Al-'Umayrah, and its inhabitant is Banu Masih from Banu Majid. It is a wide land to what connects in the north to the land of Al-Rakb from Al-Ash'ar, and in the east to Al-Ma'afir and Dhabhan. A people from the Farsaniyyin, people of bravery, may mix with Banu Majid in their land. They are the ones who enter the land of the Abyssinians and protect the merchants. To them are attributed the Farsan Islands in the sea between Tihamah...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
...and the land of the Abyssinians. We will mention the watering places of Banu Majid between Zabid and Aden later, Allah Almighty willing.

Mikhlaf al-Ma'afir [Al-Ma'afir, Yemen]:
As for Al-Juwwah from the administration of Al-Ma'afir, the headship and authority over it belong to the family of Dhu al-Mughallas al-Hamdani, then Al-Marrani from the offspring of 'Umayr Dhu Marran, Qayl of Hamdan, to whom the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, wrote.
As for Jaba and its districts, which is the province of Al-Ma'afir, it is in a gap between Mount Sabr and Mount Dhakhar. Its road is in Wadi al-Dabab. From it are the valleys of Dhakhar and Tabashi'ah, inhabited by the Sakasik. And Rasyan, inhabited by Al-Rakb and Banu Majid and neighbors of theirs from Banu Waqid. From Al-Rakb are Al-Nushurah. The kings of Al-Ma'afir are the family of Al-Karandi from Saba the Lesser; they trace their lineage to the birth of Al-Abyad ibn Hammal. Their dwellings are at Al-Jubayl of Qa' Jaba. The drinking water of all is from a spring descending from the top of Mount Sabr, abundant, called Anf; the lightest and best water. Hair thrives on it, becoming beautiful and abundant. The people of Al-Ma'afir and its surroundings use the Sukkiniyyah (a type of perfume/dye?) on the head, and it is beautiful in their land. Qa' Jaba leads in the descent to the side of the land of Banu Majid to many of the villages of Al-Ma'afir like Harazah, where Harazi trays and clothes of Tajawuz are made. And Saharah, Ghazarah, Al-Dumaynah, and Bardad. The inhabitants of these places are from the clans of Himyar from the offspring of Al-Ma'afir ibn Yu'fir. Lower Al-Ma'afir are people of indistinctness in speech and people of incantations and magic, especially those of the Sakasik who are there.
The inhabitants of Sabr are Al-Rakb and the Hawashib from Himyar and Saksak. Their head and the one undertaking their affair is Abd al-Jabbar ibn al-Rabi' al-Hawshabi. The leaders before him were the family of Qar'ad al-Rakb. And Maknunah, in which are people from Al-Azd. And Al-Jazlah and Al-'Ushush. Sabr is a barrier between Jaba and Al-Janad, and it is an impregnable fortress, one of the humped mountains.
Al-Janad, Khadir, and Warzan belong to the Sakasik. Returning to Nakhlan, and east to the side of Warakh, and west to the borders of Al-Rakb, and south to the borders of Al-Asabih. Their land is a wide land. The Sakasik are five thousand. They are people of seriousness and bravery. They are among those who did not submit to the Qarmatians, but killed Ahmad ibn Fadl. They ceased not to be opposing the kings, defiant, not submitting.

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
They have camels, which are the Saksakiyah for carrying, and the Majidiyah, which are among the most noble and productive camels after the Mahri. The Sakasik possess the Khadiriyah cows; no cows match them in hugeness.

Mikhlaf al-Suhul:
Ibn Sawadah. Its inhabitant is the family of Shar'ab ibn Sahl and Wuhazah ibn Sa'd and the clans of Al-Kala'. They are clans from Himyar, among them Al-Suhul ibn Sawadah, Jisr al-Khabayir ibn Sawadah, Nu'aymah, Ghallas, 'Annah, Jaba to which Jaba al-Ma'afir is attributed, Zanja', Bahil, Al-Qafa'ah ibn Abd Shams, Dhu Manakh ibn Abd Shams, Ba'dan, Rayman, 'Arwan, Hamim, Al-Salaf ibn Zur'ah, Al-Saradif, Al-Mawajid, and Banu 'Alqan in it, and the Tuba'iyyun from Hamdan. - Al-Takallu', Al-Tabakkul, Al-Tahashshud, Al-Taqarrush, and Al-Tahabbush mean gathering. And Al-Tawazzu' means separation, and Al-Awza' means groups.
The dwellings of this Mikhlaf: Mount Ba'dan, Mount Adam, Saliyah, and Iryab, the place of Dhu Fa'ish whom Al-A'sha praised, saying about it:
In Ba'dan or Rayman or the top of Saliyah ... is a cure for one complaining of the hot winds, cool
And in the palace of Iryab, if you spent a night ... iced water, freezing, would come to you
And Al-Thujjah, Nakhlan, Batn al-Suhul, the branches of Zabid, Wadi al-Nuha, 'Alqan, Qaynan, Sayd, and Suq al-Humri (a new market, and there was the ancient city of Al-Mahrath). And Al-Zawahi, Al-Rabadi, Ta'kar, Al-Shawafi, Thuman, Milhah, Khulqah, Qaza'ah, Al-Jabjab, Raymah, Mudhaykhirah, Radajah, Wahfat, Madhnat, Shazzah, Qalamah, Al-Habr, Al-Dammadi, Al-Hayari, Zaba, Damt, Hamim in the west of Qalamah, Namar, the mountains of Shar'ab and their gathering place is Dukhkhan, Wadi Nakhlah, and Al-Wahsh from the land of Hashid between Hashid, Nu'man, and the land of Al-Kala' surrounding the flood path of Zabid. Among them are Al-Jafnah, Al-Malahiz, and Hajar Qamran. These lands are from Al-Sarat. Its head is at Ba'dan, Rayman, Adam, and Dalal. Its lower parts are the mountains of Nakhlah and the heights of Hays from Wadi al-Milh. The mountains of Al-Rakb, their east is Najd al-Makhrib, and from their north-east is Haql Qatab. The kings of the land of Al-Kala' are the Manakhiyyun from the Jahiliyyah. The last of the Ja'afir from them was Muhammad Dhu al-Muthlah. Ja'far ibn Ibrahim ruled for fifty years, and his father Ibrahim ibn Dhu al-Muthlah for thirty years.

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Al-Yahsiban: Connected to Al-Suhul from its north on the line of the middle of Al-Sarat is Lower Yahsub. From its Najd (highland) towards the north is Upper Yahsub. Its inhabitants are Banu Yahsub ibn Dahman, the Sakhtiyyun, and the Sufliyyun from Hamdan. The Lower [Yahsub] consists of the two valleys, Al-Sana' and Shi'an, the place of the precious Wars (dye plant), Suq 'Abdan, Manub, and Wadi Hamd. The people of Hamd are the sharpest and most skilled archers of Himyar. And Warf is high, then Lower 'Utmah. The Upper [Yahsub] includes Qitab, Mankath, Mawah, Yarim, Yakhar, to Sahmar, Al-Ahtut, Al-Samlal, the heights of Qarad, and Al-Hablah. In Upper Yahsub, according to what Abu al-Bas ibn Abi Ghalib al-Sufli told me, there are eighty dams, the largest of which we mentioned from him in the Book of Al-Iklil. About them Tubba' says:
And on the green hill of the land of Yahsub ... are eighty dams holding back the flowing water.
Mikhlaf al-'Ud and Dhi Ru'ayn: It is a Mikhlaf inhabited by the 'Adawiyyun from Dhi Ru'ayn and others from the tribes of Himyar. In it are Mount Habb, Sakhlan, and Warakh belonging to Banu Musa from Al-Kala'. Sakhlan and Al-'Ud belong to the 'Adawiyyun from Ru'ayn, and among them is Mujib al-Fakihi in Al-Masmatah which is called Al-Sahmaniyah.
Mikhlaf Dhi Ru'ayn: From it are Masani' Ru'ayn, Shakhb, and Kahal. From the valleys are Wadi Saban, Wadi Khaban, Dhu Balaq, Wadi Harad, Wadi Dhi Ya'zaz, and Tharid. From the Masani' (fortresses) are Hisn Kahlan, Hisn Mathwah, and Kahal. Among them are Al-Sawla', Labu, Al-Mawa'ilah, Malyan, Hayrah, and Silaf, to what borders Hayshan in Upper Yahsub from the direction of Zafar, then returning to Mikhlaf Maytam and the borders of Madhhij from Banu Habash, and Haql Salih from the land of the Rabi'iyyin and the Ziyadiyyin. Sometimes Al-Tarakhim like Bana, Sharad, Al-Khabar, Maytam, Shar'ah, and Mawah are counted from Mikhlaf Ru'ayn. They were the kings of Ru'ayn, and they are from the offspring of Dhi Tarakhum ibn Maryam Dhi al-Rumhayn ibn 'Ajrad from Saba the Lesser. All of Mikhlaf Ru'ayn is inhabited only by the family of Dhi Ru'ayn, such as Yahir, San, Al-Amluk, Al-Ahruth, and others. The clans of the family of Dhi Ru'ayn in this Mikhlaf are more numerous than in the south and east of the land of Ru'ayn, most of whom were overcome by Madhhij.

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Mikhlaf Jayshan: Jayshan is one of the cities of Yemen. There have always been scholars, jurists, and righteous merchants in it. One of its poets was Ibn Jubran, who is one of the poets of the Rafidah (Shi'a) and the author of the poem inciting against the Muslims. From Jayshan was the emergence of the Qarmatians in Yemen, and from Al-Janad. Mikhlaf Jayshan is inhabited by clans from Yarim Dhi Ru'ayn ibn Sahl ibn Zayd al-Jumhur. In it are the Sarariyyun, the Ra'diyyun, and the Raghamid, and its desert dwellers are Anjad. Counted from Mikhlaf Jayshan are Hajar, Badr, Sur, Hadar, Tharid, the land of Banu Habash, and the side of the land of Al-'Adw from Habb, Sakhlan, Al-'Ud, and Warakh.
Mikhlaf Rada' and That: The Mikhlaf of Rada' consists of the two villages Rada' and That, Al-'Urush, Bashran, Adhanah and its plain (Rahbah), and the land of Radman. Many names have entered into it which I adorned in the poem of Al-Rada'i at the end of the book. It and all its Mikhlifs are inhabited only by the clans of Madhhij and a few remnants of Himyar. In Rada' and That are the Aswadiyyun, the Rabi'iyyun, the Ziyadiyyun, and a mix of Arabs after that. Al-'Arsh and Hurriyah belong to Banu al-Harith ibn Ka'b, and they are the people of Kura' al-Qaryatayn. Their leaders are the family of Al-Dhamallaq, the family of Al-'Ayzar, and the family of Ilyas. Kuman is a wide land inhabited by Kuman, and they are from Zuwaf, Salamah, and Sanabih. Kuman connects to the land of Dhi Jurah, the land of Al-Hadd ibn Namirah ibn Madhhij. They and Kuman are among the best archers and sharpest of the Arabs. A predator hardly enters the land of Al-Hadd because they kill the predator with shooting.
Mikhlaf Ma'rib: The mountain belongs to Banu Malik from Murad, and to Banu Taliyah, Qa'ifah, and Fuja'ah. Its head is Mount Daqrar, which is one of the humped mountains. From it are Al-Suwayq and Tuhatim. From Adhanah is what is lower from Rahbah and Rahabah. There was a great palm grove there, and most of Sana'a's dates were from it. In it is a type called Al-Wansh. Then the Fitnah (strife) destroyed it. It used to be irrigated by the lower parts of Daqrar, then Al-Suwayq, then Habnun. These places are its slopes from the mountain in the south of Ma'rib. Its slopes in its north are to Nahj al-Jawf, Al-'Awahl, Haynan, Sirwah, and the valleys of Mawda'. Its east is the deep low ground (Al-Qa' al-Amaq) from Sayhad and Nahbiyah from Daghal to the Salt Mountain. It is not an upright mountain but a mountain in the ground

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
which is dug upon and one goes deep into the earth. Pillars remain from it that support what was lifted from those excavations. Sometimes it collapses on the group and they perish. It is a land with no vegetation, so water, provisions, firewood, and fodder are carried to it. Water is guarded against the crow lest it pecks the water-skin and its water is lost. It is three light stages or two slow stages from Ma'rib. Ma'rib is opposite Sana'a to the east. As for Qarn, it may be counted towards Ma'rib, Harib, and Bayhan, and it may be counted towards Radman.
The Mikhlifs between Al-Ma'afir and Sana'a to the west: The land of Al-Rakb and Hays, which is the land of the family of Abu al-Nimr al-Rakbiyyin, and their village in Hays is Al-Qanat. Jablan al-'Arkabah is a wide land, and Nu'man is a land. The inhabitant of Al-'Arkabah are the Sharahiyyun, among whom are the family of Yusuf, kings of Tihamah from the time of Al-Mu'asim to the days of Al-Mu'tamid. The Wasabiyyun are from Saba the Lesser, who is Wasab ibn Malik ibn Zayd ibn Sadad ibn Zur'ah, who is Himyar the Younger ibn Saba the Lesser. This Jablan is between Wadi Zabid and Wadi Rama'. Jablan Raymah is what separates Wadi Rama', Wadi Siham, Wadi Sayhan, and Al-'Arab to the land of Haraz. It is seven parts. From Jablan, the Jablaniyyah Arab cows, rough-skinned, are brought to Sana'a and elsewhere. It is a land with many cows, crops, and honey. Its market facing Tihamah is Qa'ar. The land is inhabited by clans from Himyar from the descendants of Jablan, from Al-Saradif, and from Banu Hayy ibn Khawlan, and it is its kings. Jablan Raymah is faced from the north by Wadi Siham, and from the north and west by Mount Bara', which is one of the humped mountains. It is wide, inhabited by the Sanabir from Himyar. In Raymah Jablan there are people from them also, a clan from Saba the Lesser, and groups from Hamdan. The market of Bara' is Al-Salli in the low ground to its east, and what faces Al-Zihar. Its sultan is Muhammad ibn Abdullah al-Bura'i, a noble generous Himyari. He is one of the bold ones of Yemen, its masters, and its brave men. He has power and equipment.
Wadi Sayr and Wadi al-'Arab separate Mount Bara' from Mount Dila' and Raymah. Then the land of Hazar and Hawzan separates Wadi Sardad from Wadi Siham. The branch of Sardad is Ahjar Shiyam, and that is what faces Sana'a.

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Mikhlaf Dhamar: Dhamar is a large comprehensive village with crops and nearby wells whose water is reached by hand. It is inhabited by clans from Himyar and individuals from Al-Abna'. The head of its Mikhlifs is the land of 'Ans, and its inhabitant today is some tribes of 'Ans ibn Madhhij. It is said that it is attributed to 'Ans ibn Zayd ibn Sadad ibn Zur'ah ibn Saba the Lesser. It is a precious Mikhlaf with much good, noble horses, many vineyards, farms, and monuments. In it are Baynun, Hakar, and palaces whose mention is included in the Book of Al-Iklil. Among them are Madaqqah, Bawsan, Rakhmah, and Mount Labu'ah ibn 'Ans. Mount Isbil is divided into two halves; half to Mikhlaf 'Ans and its northern [half] to Kuman. And Asi between Isbil and Dhamar is a black hill called Hammah, containing a cliff called Hammam Sulayman. People seek cure in it from pains, scabies, and other things. In Ayn Sharad also people spread out and are healed. Dhamar al-Qarn is an ancient ruined village. As for Dhamar al-Mukhaddar, it is different. Dhu Jazb, Dalan, and Sarbah are valleys with much water and mills. The valleys that have water mills are Sarbah, Sharad, Bana, Mawah, Al-Mawfad, Jam', Basid, the valleys of Ru'ayn, and Wadi Dahr.
As for the Mikhlifs of Dhamar from its west, they are Masna'at Afiq for the Mughithiyyin, Jam', Al-Mawfad, Sarbah, Wadi al-Qadab for Banu Abd Kilal, and Hamar. Wadi Hamar is attributed to Hamar ibn 'Adi. It faces Jablan, Wasiyah, Al-Jabjabah, Al-Jabjab, and Al-Salli. These places are inhabited by clans of Himyar from Awza'i, Mughithi, and others. In the north of these places are the land of Maqra, Mount Anas, and the land of Alhan. From the north of Dhamar is some of Haql Jahran. The people of Jahran are from Himyar, and among them are people from Wadi' Tubba'. Likewise in Qitab there are people from them. About that Tubba' says:
So I settled the best of my people in Iraq ... And settled the Nabit in the villages of Qitab
It is Haql Qitab ibn Malik ibn Zayd ibn Sadad ibn Zur'ah. Jahran is attributed to Jahran ibn Yahsub.
Mikhlaf Alhan and Maqra: It is a wide Mikhlaf to which the west of Haql Jahran is attributed, such as Dhu Khashran and Ma'bar. Alhan in itself is a wide land, and its gathering place is

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Al-Jubb, Jubb Alhan. It is inhabited by Alhan ibn Malik, brother of Hamdan, and clans from Himyar. Its villages are numerous. Maqra is inhabited by the family of Maqra ibn Sami'. From what faces Alhan to Wadi al-Shajbah which pours into Shajban then Rama': Mount Anas, containing Mahfar al-Baqar, Watih, Samh, and Raymah the Lesser, and Hada. From this region in the domain of Siham are it, Baqlan, and 'Ashar. Much of what we mentioned from the west of Dhamar is counted in Maqra Shajban: the market of the lowlands (Aghwar) of these Mikhlifs, and it is the border between these Mikhlifs and Jablan Raymah. Between Mount Anas and Haql Jahran are Dawran and Madhab, and in it are the Sabbaliyyun from Himyar.
Mikhlaf Haraz and Hawzan: It is seven sevenths, meaning seven lands. Haraz the fortified, Hawzan, Karar - to which the Karari cows are attributed -, Sa'fan, Masar, Lahab, Majih, and Shibam. The name Haraz and Hawzan gathers all. They are two clans from Himyar the Greater, and they are the two sons of Al-Ghawth ibn Sa'd ibn 'Awf ibn 'Adi. In Haraz are the Hanatilah, offspring of Hantal ibn 'Awf ibn 'Adi, La'af, Nashq from Hamdan, and other clans from Himyar. It is a land with much crops, Wars (dye), honey, and Arab cows like the Jablaniyah. Haraz is mixed from its west with the land of La'san from 'Akk. Among them are Al-Taym, Al-Adrub, 'Ajb, Al-'Abr, Al-'Arqayn, and Wadi Har. In Wadi Siham is hot water; eggs and rice are cooked by its heat. From Wadi Har are Al-'Aqil, Al-Hubayl, Al-Anghum - and Al-An'um is a clan from Himyar -, Shatt al-Hajal, Al-Ahass which is the watering place of Al-Zihar - Zihar ibn Bashir al-Nashqi from Hamdan -, Al-Dhanabat, Al-'Aridah, Al-Ma'shar, Al-Dirkham, Al-Jam', Al-Suq, Al-Hawraniyan, and Thawlanah and Al-Buwayyah are two fortresses.
The watering places of La'san: Al-Sananiyah, Dhu al-Kamah, Al-Maqtarah, Al-'Uqal, Al-Malihah, Dhu al-Khanasir, Dhu al-Qutb, Al-Miryas, Al-Hamatah, Al-Khilla, Al-Hassan, Al-Maslab with Al-Rukbatayn, Al-Malahi, Al-Fayyad, Wadi al-Numayl, Wadi al-Mathawi adjacent to Sardad, Al-Sa'ur, Tufyah, and Baram. These places are the lower parts of Haraz and the upper land of La'san. The market of these places and the upper parts of Haraz is Al-Mawzah. As for the land of La'san in the belly of Tihamah, it is Al-Ja'diyah, Al-Hindiyah, Al-Shaq'al, Marbal, Dhat al-'Izam, Dhat

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
al-Awtad, Al-'Amud, Al-Aman, Al-Nadaj, Dhu al-Rada', Al-Masil, Al-Jarib, Al-Hibal, Al-Tanam, Al-Fawwahah, Dhat al-Midhnabayn, Al-Muhtariqah, Al-Sa'id, and Al-Hanashat. The water sources of these places are lower Siham and lower Sardad. Their market is Al-Mahjam and Al-Kadra', Hima for Ghassan, and it is day by day, called Al-Masalah. Abu Muhammad said: We only investigated these places rather than other spots of Yemen to alert that these places were not dwellings for Rabi'ah ibn Nizar as those ignorant of ancient news in the days of the Arabs and their dwellings imagine. We will pass by the names of the dwellings of Rabi'ah in the description of the land of Najd, Allah willing.

Mikhlaf Hudur: It is Hudur ibn 'Adi ibn Malik. From his offspring is Shu'ayb the Prophet ibn Mahdam ibn Dhi Mahdam ibn al-Muqaddam ibn Hudur, peace be upon him. He is the one whom his people killed. It is said the people of Huduri and 'Aribaya killed him, and he was sent to them. Its lower part (Safilah) is Hudur Yana', Shamm, Mazikh, Sabih, Al-Aghyum, and Yaris. Among them are Bahza and 'Alsan. This is the lower part of Hudur. Connected to it is the land of Khuruj ibn al-Ghawth ibn Sa'd. It is said the land was attributed to Kharj from Hamdan. Khuruj is between Hudur and Hawzan. It is a wide land and the middle of Dhat Jardan. Upon it is the road to Naqil al-Shajjah, at whose head is Hawzan. In the land of Al-Akhruj today are the Sulayhiyyun from Hamdan. In Hudur Al-Sayd, they claim Hamdan lineage, and it is said they are from Himyar and are not Sayd of Hamdan. And the Jahadib from Himyar, and they may claim Hamdan lineage. The upper part of Hudur is Wadi', Al-Mu'allal, and Haql Sahman, lands attributed to Li, Wadi', Al-Mu'allal, and Sahman, sons of Al-Ghawth ibn Sa'd. These places are gathered by Mikhlaf al-Mu'allal, just as Dahr, Dila', and Ray'an are gathered by Mikhlaf Ma'dhin from the family of Dhi Ru'ayn. It is said Mikhlaf Ma'dhin and Hamlan, just as it is said Mikhlaf Dhi Jurah and Khawlan. As for Hamlan, it is Mikhlaf La'ah, and we will mention it Allah Almighty willing.

Mikhlaf Aqyan ibn Zur'ah ibn Saba the Lesser: Shibam Aqyan is a village containing the kingdom of Banu Hawal. Ya'fur ibn Abd al-Rahman al-Hawali fought in it

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
commanders of Al-Mu'tasim, Al-Wathiq, and Al-Mutawakkil: Mansur ibn Abd al-Rahman al-Tanukhi, Al-Shir (called Al-Shar by the non-Arabs) Bamiyan, and Ja'far ibn Dinar al-Khayyat. He repelled them and defeated them. It is said it was named after Shibam ibn Abdullah, a man from Hamdan who settled it. Its ancient name is Yahbis. It is inhabited with the Hawaliyyin by the family of Dhi Jadan and remnants of the Aqyaniyyin. Its precincts: Mount Dhakhar overlooking it, and it is at its base. In it are springs coming out of it running between the houses to the gardens. It is five... Al-Muthirah. At the top of the mountain overlooking it is the palace of Kawkaban. On the slopes of the mountain are running waters like Hablah, Al-Khaltab, and Wadi al-Ahjar, which has mills and is the head of Sardad, its waters coming from Mount Dhakhar. Thula is a fortress and village for the Marraniyyin from Hamdan. Najr for Hamdan. Hulamlum and Qarin for Hamdan. Hudur Bani Azad, Bayt Khiyam, and Bayt Aqra'. Bayt Aqra' and Hudur are distant from Al-Masani'. Al-Masani' are from the rowad [?] of Shibam. And Labakhah, Zaghban, Hababah, Ayfa'an, Hanzan, Al-Kamkh, Al-Rashh, Upper Sari', Al-Jaw'ar, and Al-Ma'inan. Haz is a great village with pre-Islamic ruins. Al-'Urr, Khulqah, 'Abarahza, Barish, Al-Badah, Bayt Rafah, Bayt Karab, Bayt Hayqar, and Al-Damum to Muhib and Musayb from the border of Hudur. Dahr and Dila', the two gardens of Yemen, from the border of Ma'dhin. From it are Al-Taraf, Al-Sharaf, and Upper Al-Jarib. Mikhlaf Shibam is known as Mikhlaf al-Sharaf al-A'la. Al-Sharaf al-Asfal is from the land of Banu 'Urayb ibn Jusham ibn Hashid of Hamdan. The west of Sana'a is finished, and we returned to its east.

Mikhlaf Dhi Jurah and Khawlan: As for the east of Sana'a which lies between it and Ma'rib, it is Mikhlaf Khawlan ibn Amr, and they are Khawlan Al-'Aliyah (The High) whom the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, mentioned saying: "O Allah, bless Al-Sakasik, Al-Sakun, Al-Amluk - Amluk Radman -, and Khawlan Al-'Aliyah." Connected to Mikhlaf Khawlan is Mikhlaf Al Dhi Jurah ibn Yakla ibn Amr ibn Malik ibn al-Harith ibn Murrah ibn Udad from its south to what borders the land of 'Ans and Al-Hada from Murad. Mikhlaf Dhi Jurah and Khawlan is called the Treasury of Yemen, and Dhamar, Ru'ayn, and Al-Suhul the Misr (metropolis/storehouse?) of Yemen,

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
because sorghum, wheat, and barley remain in these places for a long period. I saw in Mount Maswar wheat that was thirty years old which did not spoil or change. As for sorghum, it only exists in a hot land and is not stored in houses due to what quickly spoils it. Rather, it is dug for in the ground and buried in buried storages; one storage holds five thousand Qafiz to less than that. It is sealed until the naked tree (Al-'Ari) might grow on the seal. It stays for a lifetime and does not spoil (tanfakhish?), but its smell and taste change. If the storage is opened, it is left for days until it cools and its vapor settles. If someone entered it upon opening, he would perish from its heat. This Mikhlaf is wide, so let us mention its valleys in order.

The Valleys, the first of them from its north: Wadi al-Sirr, Sirr ibn al-Rawiyah, in it are springs and wells. It is one of the notable valleys of Yemen. In it are many villages and dwellings for the family of Al-Rawiyah for hospitality and for the wayfarer. In it from the mountains of Murad is Mount Barjam from Al-Sirr. The dwellings of the family of Al-Rawiyah are at A'faf and Hadhan from Al-Sirr. After that in it are many villages like Al-Ashariyyin, Al-Barakah, Al-Qarazah, and others. Its inhabitants are from Khawlan and whoever mixes from this Muradi mountain. Among the known mountains are Dhubab with Fatha on the Dhal, Sara', Samik, Al-Falkah, and Adhayr. Al-Sirr is the start of the highway to Basra from Sana'a. And Wadi Sa'wan, a valley that almost suffers drought for consecutive years, then if it comes forward (rains), it brings much fruit. Some of the ancients of Himyar mentioned it saying:
The darkest land is Maswar, and its sister is Batwa'ar, and Ahwar then Ahwar, and Sa'wan if it rains.
Wadi al-Tana'im, in it are valleys including Sahar, Sabr, Wadi 'Ashir, Wadi Ramak, Wadi Ghayman, Yafid, Yada', and Wadi Maswar. Its nearest part is Tharban and 'Asfan, and its furthest is Zabar, Al-Hajlah, and Al-Hasaf. Wadi Malaha, and Malaha is also in Al-Jawf, and to it is attributed the Day of Razm Malaha. Hamdan killed Bishr from Madhhij, and on that day the knights of Al-Arba', Banu Dhi al-Ghussah, were killed. Wadi Qarwa, Wadi Sayan, Wadi Maqulah, Wadi Khadar, Wa'lan, Wadi Samik, Wadi Dabrah, Wadi Marhab, Wadi Harub, Wadi Hababid, Wadi Yakla, and Wadi...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Al-Shazab, and Wadi 'Urqub. Al-Shazab and 'Urqub are the border between Dhi Jurah and Khawlan and between 'Ans. It borders from the direction of Al-Qahf Al-Hada ibn Namirah, and from the direction of Yakla Jirah, which is the border between it and 'Ans. The valleys of 'Ans, Bawsan and Al-Ahjar may mix with Al-Shazab and 'Urqub. From the valleys of Dhi Jurah to Harib 'Ans. As for the majority of the waters of this Mikhlaf, they go to three places: some to Ma'rib, some to Al-Jawf, and some to Tihamah. What pours into Kharid al-Jawf from them are Al-Sirr, Sa'wan, Al-Tana'im, Ghayman, Sayan, and Zabwah. It is met by the torrent of the western parts of Sana'a from Mikhlaf Ma'dhin, Al-Mu'allal, and Hudur to Hadaqan and Al-Bawariq. Then all coil into Al-Kharid to Al-Jawf. As for what pours into Siham from them then Tihamah to the sea, it is Wadi Khadar, Wa'lan, Samik, and 'Adward. The torrent of Al-Sahlayn, Al-Haqlayn, Hafid, and the torrent of A'shar and Baqlan gather to it to Siham. What pours from them to Ma'rib meets the waters of 'Ans, Dhamar, Mikhlaf Rada', Radman, the highland of the lands of Qarn, Al-Matar, Al-'Urush, the land of Banu Wabish, Tanin, Al-Shazab, 'Adhiqah, Naba', Ramak, Al-Qahf, and the rest of what was named previously.

Land of Hamdan: As for the land of Hamdan, it occupies what is between Al-Gha'it and Tihamah from Najd and Al-Sarat in the north of Sana'a, between it and Sa'dah from the land of Khawlan ibn Amr ibn al-Haf ibn Quda'a. It is divided by a latitudinal line between Sana'a and Sa'dah. Its east belongs to Bakil and its west to Hashid. In the division of Bakil are lands for Hashid, and in the division of Hashid are lands for Bakil. The first of the Bakil side is Al-Sama', Hadaqan, and Bir al-'Arm from the east of Al-Rahbah. These places are inhabited by Balharith and from Hamdan. Wadi Shara' and Matrah belong to 'Udhr ibn Sa'd ibn Asba. In Matrah are great valleys containing crops, grapes, and pomegranates, among them Thajir. All turn to Al-Kharid. 'Udhr Matrah are the sharpest of the Arabs and the best hunters. Maswarah, Milh, Barran, and Thajjat al-Kharid belong to Murhibah and Nihm. Mount Dhayban, the eastern side of Mahsam, Harmah, Itwah, and Al-Marfaq...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text: belong to Dhayban ibn 'Ulayan. It is a land with many vineyards. In Dhayban there is generosity, bravery, and sharpness. The Lower Nihm mountains to Ashhar Jabal Yam to Haylan to Harib al-Radrad to the slopes of Al-Jawf from the direction of Al-Manbaj. Baraqish, Hayna, and the slopes of Al-Radad and its highland belong to Nihm and Murhibah ibn al-Du'am. Sabarah may share in the east of Wadi Mahsam and its lower part with Dhayban. Then Upper Al-Jawf. In it from the villages are Shawabah, Harran, Al-Sufal, and Al-Manahi on the bank of Al-Kharid. In this Al-Jawf are the rivers Da'im, Al-Khuwayr, and Al-Musayrib; all these pour into Al-Kharid and pass by Al-Manahi. The branch of Upper Al-Jawf is Al-'Uqal, Warwar, Al-Razwah, Haynan, Mount Warwar, and Masham al-Nakhlah from the slopes of Akanit and Habashah, and a village in the lower part of Mahsam. What is between its branch from Al-'Uqal and Mahsam is Fajj al-Muwalladah and Sawlan. Above Al-'Uqal and Sawlan are Kharfan and Al-Kasad. These places are inhabited by Sufyan ibn Arhab. Al-Sabi' contains Banu Abd ibn Abbad al-Saql, Banu Harb, Al-Adahim, and a people from Al-Sabi' ibn al-Sab'. Hawatan, Rakhmat, Awjar, Ashhar, Bayhar, and Al-'Ablah. The inhabitant of these places is the outskirts of Diyaf and Makhlad ibn 'Ulayan. What rose to the Greater Mount Dhayban and Al-'Aylah, then the eastern half of Khaywan, then Al-Khadniyah, then 'Ayan. All the borders between Khaywan and the borders of Sa'dah all belong to Bakil, then to Sufyan ibn Arhab from Bakil. That is Al-Khadniyah, 'Ayan, Barkan, Al-Dark, Tali'in, Al-'Amashiyyah, all that Al-Rada'i mentioned on the road to Mecca, then Madhab, Shabhan, Qasran, Watran, Al-Hajar, then the land of Shakir which is Barat, Al-'Assatan, Jadrah, Talah, Aktaf, Nashur, Al-Ghalil, Halaf, Dadah, and Qadib, three valleys pouring into Al-Gha'it. The waters of the land of Shakir pour to Najran, Al-Jawf, and Al-Gha'it. In the upper parts of the valleys of Shakir pouring into Al-Gha'it between Najran and Al-Jawf are the places of wild donkeys in the likes of Qadib and Al-Masadir from Al-Aghbar to Rashahah to Najd al-Halab. We will mention Al-Jawf and the land of Shakir later, Allah Mighty and Majestic willing. From the place of the wild donkeys are the lower parts of the valleys between Al-Jawf and Ma'rib to Sirwah, Al-Ma'zimayn, and Al-Marashi belonging to Banu Abd ibn 'Ulayan and to Sabarah ibn Sufyan. We have...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
mentioned Al-Jawf and the land of Bakil from half of Al-Rahbah, Rahbat Sana'a, to Najran. Al-Hidhn from Najran belongs to Wathilah from Shakir and to Mir from Shakir. Al-Rahbah was named after its owner Al-Rahbah ibn al-Ghawth ibn Sa'd ibn 'Awf. The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, made it for the carrying and working [animals], then for sheep. It is narrated that he forbade cutting its thorny trees. The early Muslims used to avoid that, then people indulged in cutting it and gathering firewood, and the situation is not good about doing that. Bakil has no market other than Warwar, Gharaq, and Raydah, which is in the land of Hashid.

As for the beginning of the land of Hashid, it is Al-Juraf from Al-Rahbah, then Dhahban, then 'Ushar, then 'Alman, then Rahabah to the borders of Haz. Al-Khashab, most of its inhabitants are a mix from Wadi'ah and others from Hashid and Bakil also. It may be said: The beginning of the borders of Hashid is Rahabah, and what is behind it to Sana'a is Ma'dhini, and so it is, and upon it was the old [division].
Then Al-Bawn: It is one of the widest lowlands of Najd Yemen, it and Haql Jahran, Al-Rahbah, Haql Shar'ah, Haql Qitab, Qa' al-Janad, and Haql Sa'dah. As for Jahran, its villages are Daf, Tafadil, Karan, Al-Madarah, Al-Kharbah, Al-'Ulayb, Qarn 'Asam, Qurays, Qarn Yarahib, Qarn Qabatil, Dhu Khashran, Talhamah, Ma'bar, and Al-Wasitah.
As for Al-Bawn, its villages are Raydah for the 'Awiyyin and leaders from Bakil. In it is a house from Shawir, new, and a house from the family of Dhi al-'Athrab from Na'it, and a house Shahir for the Marraniyyin, and Bayt Dhanim for the 'Awiyyin. And Hamdah for the Shawali and Dhi al-Lub, the two sons of Al-Du'am, brothers of Arhab and Murhibah. And 'Athar for the 'Awiyyin. And Sayhah, Masak, Bayt al-Fawaqim, and Jub for Shakir and remnants from Jub ibn Shihab and a group from Al-Anba'. And Salit is a mix of all from Jalamidi, 'Athrabi, and Dabba'in. Likewise Al-Ghayl for Banu 'Ulayan ibn Arhab. Al-Jannat is mixed. Lughabah likewise. Nahirah likewise. Zirah for Banu Hatib from Al-Kharif. 'Aqar for Al-Abna'. Qa'ah is mixed. Arhaq, Qahal, and Al-Wark are mixed, except that the origin of Qahal is Himyari. These are the villages of Al-Bawn.
Al-Khashab: Its villages are numerous. Yana'ah, Dhu Bin, Al-Akhbab, and what is between the borders of Raydah to Warwar belong to Al-Sayd from the offspring of Amr ibn...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Jusham ibn Hashid. Akanit is a large village with a mix of Bakil and Hashid. Madar is a mix of Yam, Bakil, and Banu Hatib ibn Sa'd. In Akanit from them are Al-Mayh and Bayt al-Jalid. And Jurfah is Hashidi Bawsani, and in it are from the offspring of Al-Jalid. The east of the rest of the outer part of Hamdan is mostly Hashidi.
Sanam al-Zahir is the land of Wadi'ah ibn Amr ibn Amir ibn Nashij ibn Dafi' ibn Malik ibn Jusham ibn Hashid. It is from Jamdan to Tumu' and Al-Sirr. Between that are Al-'Ubayb, Bahman, Huth, Lakhuz, Nashir, and Madhak. In Al-Zahir are Al-Qashab from Wadi'ah, Banu Qa't, and Al-Shakak. It is from the tribes of Hashid and Bakil from 'Ind Athrat, Shakir, and Al-'Ulal. Al-Hafr and 'Usman for Al-Kharif. Khamir, the birthplace of As'ad Tubba', Nawdah, and Yashi' for Bakil and its brothers from Al-Fa'ish ibn Shihab. Bayt Thawb, Bayt al-Ward, Nughash, and Qasr al-Humaydi to Hind and Hunaydah in Qa'ah are Aqyani and Shawiri. Mount Sufyan in the furthest lands of Wadi'ah belongs to Wadi'ah and Ruhm from Bakil. Athafit for the Kabariyyin from Al-Sabi'. The two Hanakat: one Hashidi and the other Bakili for Shakir. Shawath and Al-Jabjab are Hashidi. Al-Faq', Rumayd, and Ras al-Sharwah are Wadi'i. The greatest district of Hashid is Khaywan; it is between the family of Mu'id and the family of Dhi Radwan, and they claim Bakil lineage, being allies of Bakil but their origin is from Hashid. Bawban for the family of Abu Hajr. Al-Hawariyyin for Wadi'ah and the people of Khaywan. Dhu Qayn for Hashid and Khawlan. Sirr Bakil for Bakil. Al-Santani for 'Akk and Hashid. Hulamlum and Qarin between Hashid and remnants of Himyar. This is the outer part of the land of Hashid.
As for the first of the land of Hashid, the first is La'ah. It enters towards the south in the west of Sana'a. The two mountains of La'ah, the southern of them is between it and Sardad, known as Mount Aktaf and Mount Al-Ahzam. In it are the homelands of Tays, Nidar, Al-Ma'iz, Shahidh, and Al-Baqir. These are tribes bordered by Himyar and Hamdan in lineage. The masters of Al-Habl are the Bahriyyun from the offspring of Dhi Khalil from Himyar. The village of this mountain is Al-Mudarrah. Wadi Bakil mixes with La'ah and Sardad for Aghshab ibn Qadam. In La'ah, Mount Jarabi at its bottom belongs to 'Akk, and it is the first of the land of 'Akk from this region. It connects from the land of 'Akk to Al-Fashiq, Al-Mansul,

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
and Al-Midhaqah. These places are a corner of Tihamah entering between the Sarat mountains of Hamdan and Himyar. As for the mountains of Himyar from the south of this corner, they are Rayshan, Mount Milhan, Mount Hufash Bani 'Awf, Mount Al-Madrib for 'Akk, and Qayhamah for 'Akk. As for the mountains of Hashid in the north of this corner, they are Al-Sharaf, Al-Wadrah, Al-Maw'il, 'Awli, and Wa'ilah. From it is the land of Hajur. Hajur is forty thousand. From it is Hajur al-Mahafir; its lands are Al-Jarib, Sahib, Hayran, Khadhlan, and the grave of 'Ulayan until Hakam ibn Sa'd al-'Ashirah aligns with the head of the land of Hajur. Al-Mahafir, Hajjah, and Mawtak belong to Hashid, their people are many. From it is Hajur Bayyinah and Akhraf, which is a wide land. From it is Hajur al-Batnah. Al-Batnah is a fertile land in the west of the land of Wadi'ah adjacent to 'Udhr, Hanum, and Zalimah. The land of 'Udhr is the west of Sha'b. Sha'b is a tribe from Hashid, and they are the people of precedence (Al-Sabq). This 'Udhr is called 'Udhr Sha'b. From this 'Udhr is 'Udhr Matrah. 'Udhr Sha'b borders the family of Rabi'ah from Khawlan. This is the land of Hamdan in summary; it is six days by six. It is the most impregnable of the lands of Yemen and the mightiest. As for the markets of the land of Hashid, the first and oldest is Suq Hamal. Hamal is from Al-Kharif; it is a pre-Islamic market. Al-Kalabih for the Marraniyyin from Al-Jabr. Bari for the Fa'ish from Al-Jabr. Suq Safir, Suq al-Faqi'ah, Suq al-Ahnum, Suq al-Zahr, Suq Qatabah, and Al-'Arqah for Wathan ibn Qadam. 'Ayyan is an ancient market for 'Ayyan from Hamdan, Adran, Hajjah, Naml, Qaylab, Sharas, Hamlan, and Yand. From them is Suq Tamam. And Al-'Arqah is in La'ah; it is for those on the two edges of Mount Maswar and for those in Mount Tays al-Jarabi. Al-Jarib is a market for the people of Tihamah, Mecca, 'Athr, and all the land of Hamdan. Al-Makhlifah is a market for Hajur, shopped in by the people of Tihamah and the people of the mountains. And Al-'Arqah for Wathan ibn Qadam. 'Ayyan is an ancient market for 'Ayyan from Hamdan, Adran, Hajjah, Naml, Qaylab, Sharas, Hamlan, and Yand. From them is Suq Tamam. And Al-'Arqah is in La'ah; it is for those on the two edges of Mount Maswar and for those in Mount Tays al-Jarabi. Al-Jarib is a market for the people of Tihamah, Mecca, 'Athr, and all the land of Hamdan. Al-Makhlifah is a market for Hajur, shopped in by the people of Tihamah and the people of the mountains.

Mikhlaf Sa'dah from Khawlan Quda'a: As for Haql Sa'dah, it is cut off from the land of Hamdan. For that, there is news in the Book of Days. The great city of Khawlan is Sa'dah. The village of Al-Ghayl was newly established near Sa'dah. Sa'dah was the land of tanning in the dark Jahiliyyah. It is in

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
the middle of the land of Qaraz (acacia used for tanning). Perhaps one thousand ratls to five hundred of Qaraz sold in it for a Mutawwaq Dinar on the weight of the Qafilah Dirham. As for the outer part of Khawlan, it is Asal. In it are villages, crops, and grapes. And Afqin and Mount Abthar, which is like Mount Dhakhar, among the mountains at whose peaks are water, pasture, crops, villages, and the Muwaqqar. And Farwah, which is a land of torrents and wells, and there is no river in it except at Al-'Ashshah and Al-Batnah. In it are streams. The valleys of Sa'dah: Dammaj, on which are vineyards, Al-Khaniq, Rahban, Al-Hawiyat, Qadan, and Al-Ghayl. It flows into Al-Batanat at the bottom of Al-'Ashshah. It is met from their valleys by Wadi 'Akwan. They are supplied from the west by Wadi Rabi' and Nisrin. The torrent of Al-Sahn and Wadi 'Alaf connect to them. 'Alaf is the best of the valleys of Khawlan, the noblest in vines, and the most abundant in good, crops, grapes, and livestock. It belongs to Banu Kulayb and the Sa'diyyin. The waters of these valleys gather at Al-Faqarah from the bottom of Al-Batnah, then to the land of Sabiqah from Hamdan, then to Najran.
Sa'dah: Its inhabitant are the Ukayliyyun from the family of Rabi'ah ibn Sa'd the Elder ibn Khawlan. It contains a gathering of tribes from Al-Kala', Hamdan, Sa'd ibn Sa'd, the rest of the clans of Khawlan, and others. In it is a house from Al-Abna'. Al-Batnah, Al-Ghayl, and Al-'Ashshah belong to Banu Sa'd ibn Sa'd. Surum Khawlan, Hadbar, and Al-Akhbab belong to Banu Sa'd. Al-Hadinah and Sabr belong to Wadi'ah. Al-Khabt belongs to Muslim and Sabaq from Banu Sa'd. Qaraz and Yasnam belong to Banu Sa'd Raghafah. Bawsan belongs to Banu Jama'ah from Khawlan. The Sarat of Banu Rashwan ibn Khawlan to Dafa belongs to Banu Thawr and Al-Abqur. Razih and Dafa belong to Banu Sahar ibn Khawlan. Qaywan and Anafiyah belong to them and to Banu Hudhayfah and Al-Abqur. Ghaylan belongs to Razih from Khawlan. 'Arash belongs to Banu Bahr from the family of Rabi'ah. The village of Wasakhah belongs to Banu Bishr and Banu Ya'nuq, and they are the Adim from Khawlan. Saqin belongs to Banu Sa'd ibn Sa'd and Banu Shihab. 'Afarah and Haydan belong to Banu Shihab ibn al-'Aqil from Kindah, allies of the family of Rabi'ah. Tadra' belongs to Banu Humrah. Mawtak belongs to Banu Humrah from Sa'd. Al-'Abla' and Kahlan belong to Banu Humrah as a nickname for Banu Sa'd. Al-'Ard belongs to Banu Thawr from Sa'd. Al-Qafa'ah is a market of a mine for Harrah. Al-Sarw and Harjab belong to Banu Hayy from Khawlan. 'Anmal and Badr belong to Banu Hayy. Al-Midhra, 'Arw,

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
and Kharr belong to Al-Ra'a. This is the land of Khawlan in summary. Its lowlands (Aghwar) entering Tihamah are Ibzan and Umm Jahdam. In the highest of Al-Sarat to Sarat Janb. In its Najd it connects to the land of Wadi'ah.
The Najdi Land of Wadi'ah: Buq'ah, 'Awdhan, Al-Thuwaylah, Ghayl Ali, Wadi 'Arad, and the upper part of Wadi Najran to Mount Shawk, Qadi Din, Al-Zabran, to Mahjarah, Al-Mandaj, Ghayl Ali, Aqawiyat, Araynib, and Jalajil. What went north in these lands and in Najran and mixed with Shakir are Al-Hanajir, Ya'ish, Sabiqah, Ka'b, and Hayf, sons of Anmar ibn Nashij from Wadi'ah ibn Amir ibn Nashij.
Land of Yam: Yam has a homeland in Najran, half of what is with Hamdan of it. Then it extends upon it towards the Hejaz to the borders of Zubayd and Nahd from the direction of Harah and what follows it. It is Harah, Mallah, and Samnan, to what borders Khalif Dukam from the heights of Habunan. At Khalif Dukam, Abdullah ibn al-Simmah, brother of Durayd, was killed. And Al-Hazirah, Badr, Sayhan, the opposite of Najran, Hadadah, and Al-Hazirah at the top of Habunan.
Dwellings of Janb, who is Munabbih: Al-Mukhtalaf and A'qaq. About it Amr ibn Ma'di Karib says:
Except that voices in A'qaq ceased not ... In it a friendly one from its people, not leaving
We found in it the two Amrs, Amr ibn 'Udiyah ... And Amr ibn Amr in Salatih dwellings
We found Banu Amr eighty horsemen ... For every morning, baring the fang, grim
The Ghadaniyyun were under their spears ... The spears of Banu Amr on the morning of the attack
Purified as in-laws, kin, and neighbors ... And there was no unruly horseman among them
Aswab Qaran is a town in Al-Humrah of Al-Mukhtalaf. Al-Mukhtalaf is called Al-Manshar. Among their dwellings are Sarum al-'Uqdah, Sarum al-'Ayn, and Sarum al-Fayd, which is Sarum al-Tarfa'. And Al-Safsaf with the two mountains, 'Ara'irayn, Al-Qarha', Al-Thajjah, and Dhat 'Ush. In it are the graves of the martyrs, wayfarers and pilgrims who were killed. The Black Mountain is the majority of the land of Janb. It is between the end of Sarat Khawlan opposite the land of Wadi'ah to Jurash. In it are villages, dwellings, and farms. It is likened to Al-Arid of the land of Al-Yamamah. From the land of

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Janb are Rahah and Mahlah, two valleys pouring from the Black Mountain to Najd eastward. It has Tihami and Najdi valleys, among them Jawf of the Khuzaymiyyin, which is Jawf Marzuq. He lived one hundred and thirty-eight years, and I met him when he was one hundred and thirty-five years old. The two villages of Janb are Al-Kubaybah for Banu Waqshah, and Al-Qurayha opposite it for Banu 'Ubaydah. And Sinan, other than Sinan Khath'am. 'Ubayd and 'Afarin for Banu Sharif and Banu Ranyah.
Land of Zubayd: Bala' is a valley with palm trees, and it is other than Bala' in the land of Khath'am below Al-Khanqah to Al-Warah and Al-A'dan, which are pastures for Ranyah. These lands are inhabited by tribes of Zubayd: Al-Aghluq, Banu Mazin, and Banu 'Asim.
Land of Banu Nahd: Tarib, Masabah from Dhat al-Qasas, Katnah, and Arak - a valley with Arak trees, and Arakah is in the lower land of Zubayd, and Arakah is in the direction of Al-Masamah from the dwellings of Khath'am ibn Amir ibn Rabi'ah. And Tathlith; Amr ibn Ma'di Karib had a fortress and palm trees in it. And Al-Qararah, Al-Rayyan, Jash, Dhu Bayda', Muray', 'Abalam, Gharb, Al-Hadarah, Al-'Ashtan, and Al-Baradan. Al-Baradan is a well in Tabalah and in Al-'Ard of Najran. And Dhat Ilah, which is the villages of Al-Dabil. And 'Ushar, and 'Ushar is in a valley from the direction of Sana'a. And 'Areban and Suqam, and their village is Al-Hujayrah. The ones inhabiting these lands from the tribes of Nahd are Ma'rraf and Haram, which is most of Nahd, Banu Zuhayr, Banu Duwayd, Banu Hazimah, Banu Murammid, Banu Sakhr, Banu Dinnah - and Dinnah is from 'Udhrah -, Banu Yarbu', Banu Qays, and Banu Zabyan.
Watering Places of Banu al-Harith ibn Ka'b: The numbers of waters of Balharith facing Al-Hujayrah are Hima, a water at the edges of the mountains of Ghadh between Muray' and Al-Gha'it and 'Abalam, which may be cut off. And a rock hollow (Qalt) called Yadamat. And Al-Malhat. And Lawzah and Shas'a, a Qalt also from the lower parts of Ghadh. And Al-Kawkab, a water lower than Hima in a detached mountain in Al-Gha'it before Al-Arid. And Khatmah, a well in the sand before Al-Arid dug by Abdullah ibn al-Rabi' al-Madani in the era of Abu al-Abbas al-Saffah. And Al-Barraq, a water at the top of Wadi Nar. And Al-Ziyyadiyah in Habunan. And Al-Husayniyah lower than it on the bank of the valley before Al-Nuhiyah, the end of Habunan. And Al-Rabi'iyah in the lower part of

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Najran. And Midhwad, Al-Harar, and Al-Batra'. These are the numbers of the north of the lands of Banu al-Harith. The first of the valleys between Najran and Al-Jawf is Qadib. In it from the waters of Balharith are Al-Aghbar, Al-Jamum, Mawah, and Khaliqa at its bottom. And Madrak Banu Hijnah in Qadib from Al-Fayfa from the land of Dahmah. Then Al-Khall between Qadib and Al-Yatimah, a valley from the land of Dahmah. At its top, from the waters of Balharith, is Fath 'Add. Then Madrak Banu Dahi, also 'Add Ghayl. At its top is Al-Shalilah, palm trees and water for Banu Da'ir. Then Wadi Khab. At its top are Tathr and Aswu'a, two 'Add waters, and Bi'r Dhi Bi'r. Then Sarhan, and there is no water in it. It is a valley between it and Al-Ahda' is Ramlat al-Udhn. In Al-Ahda' from the waters are Shatif and Al-Nakhl, which is the bottom of Awan. At the top of Awan are Khulays and Sharjan between Wadi Awan and the middle of Al-Bayad and Al-Majwi. Between them is Rahbah, a 'Add well that is not exhausted. Rubu', a 'Add well. At the bottom of Al-Jawf is a well called Lababah. And Al-Lisan, seeping waters (Ahsa') at the bottom of Hamd. And Al-Ghamariyah, waters including Al-Jafr and 'Ayna Dhi'b, two waters facing Najran on Al-Fart. What is between Al-Jawf and Najran is called Al-Afrat, singular Fart. Most of those in Al-Afrat from Balharith are Banu Mu'awiyah. Among them are Rawh ibn Zurarah and his son Khawwar, two masters killed by Hamdan. Balharith has increased between them. Al-Harith ibn Ziyad al-Mu'awi from Balharith said:
To Allah I complain that our party has become ... Like the breaking of a sound tooth, having no mender
For we raided with our own palms ... So everyone is a loser in what he hopes of glory
For whoever hopes for glory in killing his people ... Will not escape the fear of humiliation from what he cautions
The enemies obtain from his people what harms him ... And they walk in his detested things while he is present

Jurash and its Precincts
Jurash is the Upper District (Kurah) of Najd. It is from the dwellings of 'Anz. It is inhabited and headed by the 'Awasij from the nobles of Himyar. They are from the offspring of Yarim Dhi Maqar the Qayl. They have sovereignty. The horses and the Yemeni Jabbah (tax collection?) in the land of Najd are to them. They undertake the war of 'Anz with them. In the side of the village of Jurash are groups from the Nizaris called the Butchers (Al-Jazzarin) from the clients of Quraysh, and Al-Ghaz from Nizar from the strangers. They are a garrison for 'Anz

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text: against the 'Awasij. 'Anz dictates to them with its shout and help. Jurash is in a low ground (Qa'). It has distant western heights whose waters descend in a stream passing to its east, and between Hamumah, a forelock called the Black Hill, Hamumah, Hammah, and Kawlah. Then the valleys of the dwellings of 'Anz meet this stream until they pour into Bisha at 'Atan. Jurash is the head of Wadi Bisha. The district of Jurash is bordered by the homelands of Hazimah from 'Anz. Then Hazimah is inhabited from its north by 'Asir, tribes from 'Anz. 'Asir are Yemenis who became Nizaris and entered into 'Anz. The homelands of 'Asir are to the head of Tayyah, which is a pass from the heights of Tihamah. It is Abha, and in it is the grave of Dhu al-Qarnayn, as it is said it was found at the head of three hundred from the date of the Hijra. And Al-Darah, Al-Fatiha, Al-Lasbah, Al-Malhah, Tabab, Atanah, 'Abal, Al-Maghuth, Jarashah, and Al-Hadbah. These are all the valleys of 'Asir. From the Najdi part, its homelands are Al-Rafid, a land of fortresses and crops for 'Anz. And Wadi Hadha and Sa'ya, inhabited by the Bishriyyun from Al-Azd, and it may be said they are from Balharith. Then connects to it 'Anqah, inhabited by Banu Abdullah ibn Amir from 'Anz. Then Tanduhah, which is Al-Ayn from the valleys of Jurash. In it are vineyards and wells. Its inhabitant is Banu Usama from Al-Azd, and I saw some of them drawn to Shahran Al-'Aridah. And Al-'Ayba, a land of farms for Banu Abi Asim from 'Anz. Followed by Wadi Tal'an, with many farms for Banu Asad from 'Anz. And Al-Qar'a for Shaybah from 'Anz. They have a large village with a congregational mosque called Al-Masqi, and they are peaceful with the 'Awasij. What borders Janb from the dwellings of 'Anz is Al-Rafid, Al-Ghawth, Aday, 'Anqah, Al-Rakis, Al-Ayn (Ayn Al-Rafid), Tamniyah, and Al-'Aqqalah. Al-Rafid is inhabited by Hazimah from 'Anz. Al-Ghawth is inhabited by Banu Hadid from 'Anz. Al-Rakis is inhabited by Banu Ghanm from 'Anz. Al-Ayn is inhabited by Banu al-'Arras from 'Anz. Tamniyah is inhabited by Banu Malik from 'Anz. Al-Masqi is for Shaybah from 'Anz. Tal'an is for Banu Asad from 'Anz. Al-'Ayba is for Banu Abi Asim from 'Anz. Dhu al-Yanim is inhabited by Banu Dirar. Al-Darah, Abha, Al-Halalah, Al-Fatiha, then Hamrah, Tabab, then Atanah, Al-Maghuth, then Jarashah by depositing are the homelands of 'Asir from 'Anz. This is called the land of Tawd. As for its lowlands (Aghwar) towards Umm Jahdam

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
they are Al-Dhibah and Al-Saqah for Banu Jabirah from Shaybah. The head of the Pass (Al-'Aqabah) is for Banu al-Nu'man, and it is 'Aqabat Dila'. From Jurash to the head of the Pass, then to the bottom of 'Aqabat Dila', then to Yasbin, then to Sabtayn, then to 'Afranin, then to Al-Qawa'im, then to Umm Jahdam. From Jurash to the land of Banu Nahd and Khath'am eastward and northward: Tandahah, then Dhat al-Sihar for Kawd from 'Anz, then Al-Shaqrah for Banu Quhafah, then Banat Harb for Julayhah, then Hasad for Banu al-Hazar. Then the land of Nahd from Jurash to Katnah: Al-Hujayrah. Then follows Sarat 'Anz and Sarat Al-Hajar ibn al-Hanu ibn al-Azd. Its cities are Al-Jahwah, and from it are Tanumah and Al-Shar' from Bachan. Then follows it Sarat Ghamid, then Sarat Daws, then Sarat Fahm and 'Adwan, then Sarat Al-Ta'if.
Land of Khath'am: The valleys (A'rad) of Najd: Bisha, Turabah, Tabalah, and Al-Maraghah. Most of the inhabitants of Al-Maraghah are Quraysh. It has two fortresses: one is Al-Qarn (Makhzumi) and the second is Al-Barqah (Sahmi).
Land of Hilal: The two valleys Ranyah and Abidah. Among the villages are Al-Qurayha, which is ruined, and Al-'Abla' and Al-Fatq, which is ruined. Najd and Hadramawt are finished.

Tihamah of Yemen
The land of Banu Majid and the land of Al-Farsan. It is on the highway of Aden to Zabid. Then the dwellings of the Ash'aris from the borders of Banu Majid in the land of Al-Shiqaq to Hays. Zabid was attributed to the valley. It is Al-Husayb, and it is the homeland of Al-Husayb ibn Abd Shams. It is the district (Kurah) of Tihamah. Its coasts are Ghalafiqah, Al-Mandab, and Al-Makha, the two coasts of Banu Majid. And Al-Farsan, and Kamaran Island. The villages of Zabid: Al-Mu'aqqar, Al-Qahmah, and the villages of Dhu'al. The Ash'ar mix in these lands with a small group from Banu Waqid from Thaqif. Then Siham, and it is 'Akkite. From its deserts is Waqir. Then Al-Mahjam; its upper part is for Khawlan and its lower part for 'Akk. On every valley of these valleys are small villages and houses that cannot be fully grasped. Every valley of them is a Mikhlaf having a sultan who undertakes its revenues. Mawr is 'Akkite also, and it is a Mikhlaf. Then the land of Hakam, which is five days. In it are valleys of the land of Hamdan and Khawlan. Its kings from Hakam are the family of Abd al-Jadd. In it are cities like Al-Hajar, Al-Khasuf, Al-Sa'id,

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
and Al-Saqifatayn. Al-Sharjah is its coast. Al-Hardah and 'Atnah are the two coasts of Al-Mahjam and Al-Kadra'. In the land of Hakam are many villages like Al-'Adayah, Al-Rakub, Al-Makharif, and Al-Qaliq. In it are Wadi Harad, Hayran, Khadhlan, the two valleys of Banu 'Abs, Wadi al-Hayd, Wadi Ta'shar, Wadi Jahfan, Wadi Liyah, Wadi Khulab, Wadi Za'irah, Wadi al-Hayd, Wadi Ta'shar, Wadi Liyah, Wadi Khulab, Wadi Za'irah [repetition in text], Wadi Shabah, Damad, Jazan, and Sabya. Its kings are those we mentioned from the Hakamiyyin, then from the family of Abd al-Jadd. In Mawr is the family of Rawq from Banu Shihab. In Al-Mahjam is the family of Al-Najm. In Al-Kadra' is the family of Ali. In Zabid are the Sharahiyyun, and they are the head of all. In Al-Shiqaq and Mawza' is the family of Abu al-Gharat.
Then Mikhlaf 'Athr: 'Athr is a majestic coast. The city is Baysh and Hasbat Abraq. In it from the valleys are Al-Aman, Wadi Baysh, Wadi 'Atud, Wadi Bayd, Wadi Rim, 'Aramram, Wadi Zanif, and Wadi al-'Amud. It belongs to Khawlan, Kinanah, and Al-Azd. Its kings are from Banu Makhzum and their slaves.
Then the land of Haram from Kinanah: It is Wadi Atmah and Dhankan, which is an abundant mine and its gold dust is not bad. The Harrah is Harrat Kinanah. And Al-Mu'aqqad and Hali, which is a Mikhlaf and its capital is Al-Sahariyah, the place of the leaders of Banu Haram. And Al-Jaw, Wadi Talumah, Wadi al-Farasah, Al-Jawniyah, Wadi al-Muharram, Da'naj, and 'Asham, a mine and a village. And Upper Hali. Al-Sirrin is the coast of Kinanah, it and Hamdah. Al-Lith and Markub are two valleys with springs. Yalamlam, Al-Khayal, Tubyah, Mulkan, Al-Bayda', Al-Madarij, Wadi Rahmah, and lower 'Uranah. Mecca, its precincts belong to Quraysh and Khuza'ah. From it are Marr al-Zahran, Al-Tan'im, Al-Ji'ranah, Saraf, Fakh, Al-'Asm, Usfan, and Qudayd, which belongs to Khuza'ah. Al-Juhfah and Khumm to what connects to that of the land of Juhaynah and the dwellings of Banu Harb, which we have mentioned. Then Ta'if, an ancient Jahili city. It is the land of tanning; the rubbed Ta'ifi hides are tanned there. The city is also called Al-Ta'if, and the meaning is the City of Al-Ta'if. The inhabitant of Ta'if is Thaqif. East of Ta'if lives a people from the offspring of Amr ibn al-Aas. A valley near Ta'if is called Bard; in it are two great gardens for Zubaida; their place is called Wajj. East of Ta'if is a valley...

It is called Liyyah, inhabited by Banu Nasr from Hawazin. From the southern part of Ta'if is a valley called Jafn belonging to Thaqif, which is between Ta'if and Ma'din al-Baram (Mine of Stone Pots). Ma'din al-Baram is inhabited by Quraysh and Thaqif. From the Qibla (south/facing direction) of Ta'if also is a valley called Mashriq belonging to Banu Umayya from Quraysh, and Wadi Jaldhan turning to Najd in the east of Ta'if, inhabited by Banu Hilal. In the Qibla of Ta'if is the wall/garden of Umm al-Muqtadir called Salamah. Between Ta'if and Arafah is Wadi Nu'man, containing the shortcut road of Ta'if to Mecca; as for the main road (Mahajja), it is via Qarn al-Manazil (Qarn al-Muharram). The Land of Sarat: Then follows Ma'din al-Baram and Matar, ascending towards Yemen: the Sarat of Banu Ali and Fahm, then the Sarat of Bajila and Al-Azd ibn Salaman ibn Mufarrij, Alma', Bariq, Daws, Ghamid, and Al-Hajr to Jurash. Clans of Azd: Following Anz descending to Mecca is Al-Hajr; its interior is in the Tihama (Tahmah). Alma' and Yarfa ibn Uthman are in the upper parts of Haly and Asham, and that is the wasteland of Al-Hajr. And Tanumah, Al-Ashjan, and Nahyan, then Al-Jahwah, villages of Banu Rabi'a ibn Al-Hajr. And Ashirat al-Irq, Ayd, and Hadar. Beyond it are villages of Banu Rabi'a from the farthest Al-Hajr also. And Halaba, a village of Banu Malik ibn Shahr. South of Al-Hajr on this is abutting Anz. From its north is the land of Alus and Al-Faza' from Khath'am. Its east is what neighbors Bisha from the land of Khath'am and Aklub. Its Ghaur (lowland) is the land of Bariq, so the family of Ubaydah from Azd; their settling partner (Halal) is Haram ibn Kinanah. The first of the lands of Al-Hajr from its south is Abal, a valley containing Al-Habl, inhabited by Banu Malik ibn Shahr. And Bahan, containing villages and agriculture, inhabited by Banu Malik, Banu Tha'labah, and Banu Nazilah from Banu Malik ibn Shahr ibn Al-Hajr. And Dhubub, a valley of Banu Al-Asmar from Shahr. Then Al-Rahwah, the Rahwah of Banu Qa'id from the Adamiyyin from the lands of Shahr, a village on a peak (Sha'afiyyah) at the top of the Sarat. Then Sadwan, a valley containing a village called Rahb belonging to Banu Malik ibn Shahr. Tanumah [Tanumah, Saudi Arabia], a valley containing sixty villages; its lower part belongs to Banu Yasar and its upper part to Balharith ibn Shahr. Then Al-Ashjan, a large village; there is no village in the Sarat larger than it after Al-Jahwah, and its inhabitants are Banu Abd...

...from Banu Amir ibn Al-Hajr. Then Nahyan, a valley facing the Qibla (south), containing apples, almonds, and fruits. Its owner is Ali ibn Al-Husayn Al-Abdi from Banu Abd ibn Amir and his cousin Al-Husayn ibn Duhaym; they are the rulers over Nahyan, Al-Ashjan, and Al-Hara. Beyond that is Al-Jahwah, the city of the Sarat, larger than Jurash. Its owner is Al-Jabir ibn Al-Dahhak Al-Rab'i from Nasr ibn Rabi'a ibn Al-Hajr. Beyond Al-Jahwah is Zanamat al-Irq, which belongs to Jabir ibn Al-Dahhak, a village with crops. Then after it is Ayd, a valley containing scattered villages and crops. The people of Ayd and the neighbors of Al-Hajr are from Quraysh mixed with Hadar (settled people). Behind it is a valley containing the Qurashi neighbors. Then Al-Bahah and Al-Khadra, two villages belonging to Malik ibn Shahr and Banu Al-Ghamrah. And Halaba, a village belonging to Banu Marwan from Banu Malik ibn Shahr. The villages of Al-Hajr ended. Then Rima, a valley with many springs; it is from the sources of Turj. Then Yamah, and it is the farthest border of Al-Hajr, and its people are Al-Harith ibn Rabi'a. Then cutting between Al-Hajr and the land of Shukr are two clans from Khath'am called Alus and Al-Faza'; they cut it off to Tihama. And Sa'd al-Humam are Nizaris. Then the land of Shukr is Sarari (of Sarat). Then Ghamid. Then the land of Al-Namir. Then the land of Daws beyond that, from the land of Bajila. Then the land of Adwan and Fahm and Nabt ibn Ukl in the sources of Abidah. Opposite the land of Al-Hajr is the upper Turj and the sides of Bisha which adjoin the Sarat. In it is a village adjoining Bisha called Naddah belonging to Banu Al-Asbagh from Al-Hajr. And Al-Sahn are pastures for Banu Shahr. Its two Najds (highlands) adjoin Bisha where it spreads out, it and Khath'am. Its two Ghaurs (lowlands): the northern is Tirah, and the southern is Anzi. That which follows Tiyyah from the lowlands of Al-Hajr is Murrah, a valley descending to Al-Kufayrah and Haly. And Al-Shara in the east of Dhankan is Asadi belonging to Yarfa ibn Uthman. Among its lowland valleys is Farshat; its sources are Hajri and its lower parts are Ubaydi from Kinanah. And Qarab, a valley whose people are from Al-Hajr, Zayd ibn Al-Hajr, inhabiting it to Tihama. And Wadi Saqin to Tihama; in it is the Tihami highway of Al-Hajr, and its inhabitants from Al-Hajr are Jubayhah, the front of Al-Hajr. Al-Udayf is a pass (Aqaba) whose waters descend to Khat, a valley whose inhabitants...

...are Banu Amir the Ghauris (lowlanders) from Al-Hajr. In Khat are palm trees. In Sarat Al-Hajr are wheat, barley, lentils (balas), 'itr (a plant), cowpeas, almonds, apples, peaches, pears, plums, and honey. In its west are cattle and hunters. Its east, from Najd, has people of sheep and camels, and horses belonging to the Asabigha, no others. From Jurash to Sa'dah: You go out from Jurash intending Sa'dah via the land of Janb in Sa'ya, the valley of Banu Bishr possessing vineyards and crops, and lower Anis, then Wadi Tartar, then Wadi Man', then you cross from it into Wadi Nahyan—which is Al-Khanqah—then Zalamah, then the Sarat of Janb, and from it Al-Kubaybah and Al-Jabal Al-Aswad; from it is a place called Al-Qurayha—and Al-Qurayha is also Ranyah—then you ascend into Wadi Al-Nahy to Sarum and Al-Hamrah, and you fall into the highway of Mecca. Land of Adwan: From the Sarat: Yasa', Al-Suwar, Batn Qut, Al-Najar, and Baqran. Dhu al-Isba' said: 'We drove the horses from Baqran, lean... Traversing the earth, valley after valley.' And Al-Bayda, Marhab, Sa'ar, and Ma'rab. Dhu al-Isba' said mentioning several of their dwellings: 'Indeed my home is in Marhab, then in Sa'ar... Then Ma'urah, then Wakhdah, then Al-Marar. And we have a dwelling in Raqbah wherein... no raving of news is heard. A dwelling where the brooding women are protected... by every crowned, mighty chief. Then in Al-Far' we settled a while ago... a home of truth with little filth. Possessing protection, might, and safety... and impregnability from a dragging army. Our water is the overflowing (Fayd), the heat does not torture us... Nor the pulling with the rope of the deep well.' And Asla', Al-Sirrayn, and Al-Arad—two valleys from the ridge of Al-Hazn—to Al-Kufrayn, from Najl to Darah to Al-Bard. From the land of Daws: Athla, Sahbah, and Dhanab Farajil. Dwellings of Rabi'a: Al-Dhana'ib, Waridat, Dhu Husam, Uwayrid, Shurayb, Aban, Dhat al-Talah, Katirah, Al-Sallan, Khazaz, Qarar 'Umq, and Al-Lisaf—and Al-Lisaf also belongs to Banu Murra—and Wadi al-Hadh from Maris, Al-Aqiq, Dhat Riyam, and Al-Qaratan. From the dwellings of Bakr specifically: Nabad, Qaww, Al-Raja, Al-Nawa'is, Al-Shaytan, the water of Al-Hinu from Qaddah, Al-Qadibah, Al-Hunaynah, Thimad, Najd al-Khal, Al-Asjadiyyah, Al-Abwa, Khanzir...

...and Rajlah, Rawd al-Qata, Darna, Kathib al-Ghaylah, and 'Aba'ib—where a battle took place—and Manfuhah [Manfuha, Saudi Arabia], Batn al-Ghamis, Badula, Al-Sakhal, Dhu Qar [Dhi Qar, Iraq], Dhat al-Ri'al, Al-Badi, Dahidah, Thahmad, Jabal al-Amrar, Rimm, Janba, Itar, and Tala'. Falaj specifically for 'Ijl, which is Falaj al-Madar. Al-Thani and Hath for 'Ijl also. La'la', a water place in the dwellings of Bakr. And Al-Nata'il, Tabal, Al-Rukhayl (a well), Niqa' al-Sufr, Matar (with Fatha on Mim) and Matar (with Damma on Mim) in the land of Ta'if. And Hadan, Dhat al-Ham, Al-Shatb, Marjam, Al-Hadm, Al-Rakham, Wajrah, Shabakah, Anbatah, and Al-Baqqar; these are places of wild beasts, Jinn, and others. From their dwellings in Al-Jazira [Upper Mesopotamia]: Al-Murr, Shaytar, and Al-Ahwalayn. Land of Yathrib: Al-Madinah [Medina, Saudi Arabia], Quba [Quba, Saudi Arabia], Al-Fada, Uhud [Mount Uhud], Al-Aqiq, Buthan, Sal' [Mount Sela], Al-Harrah, the two Labahs (lava fields), Sabkhah, Al-Rahabah, and Al-Rahibah—and Rahabah is in Marib. And Al-Khushub, and Al-Khashab from the land of Hamdan. And Al-Dahyan (a fortress/Utum), Al-Qababah, Tudari' (a mountain), Al-Dakhshanah, and Dhat Ashra' from what adjoins the dwellings of Nasr from Hawazin. And Al-Munhana, Jadhman, Thamgh, Arthad, Qura, Al-Urayd, Al-A'was, Al-Darak, Al-Jarr, and Bu'ath. Al-Jarr is also the foot of Al-Watih in Khaybar. Al-Watih and Al-Natat are from Khaybar, exemplified by Hima al-Natat and Hima al-Qatif in Bahrain. The fortresses (Atam) among them: Al-Dahyan, Muzahim, Ajam, Al-Khassi, Nasih, Kanas, Al-Mustazill, Fari', Atud, Yuqawim, Al-Shar'abi, Ratij, and Al-Rayyan. From its areas: Baqi' al-Gharqad [Al-Baqi Cemetery], Sarar, and Al-Sararah. Names of Villages whose Inhabitants are Two Opposing Parts: Aden Abyan [Aden, Yemen] between the Maribiyyin, Hamahimiyyin, and Malahiyyin. Lahj [Lahj, Yemen] and Abyan between the Asalih and Banu Amir. Sana'a [Sana'a, Yemen] between the Shihabiyyin and the Abna; those who claim Nizar lineage there enter with the Abna, and the people of the land and those who claim Qahtan lineage there enter with Banu Shihab. Khaywan [Khaywan, Yemen] between the Ridwaniyyin and the family of Abu Mu'id; Bakil enters with the Ridwaniyyin and Hashid with the Mu'idiyyin. Sa'dah [Sa'dah, Yemen] between Akil and Yarsum. Washah from the villages of Khawlan between the Bishriyyin and the Nisfiyyin. They said: Its name in the Jahiliyyah was Wasakhah (Dirty). When the Zakat of its people reached the Prophet, peace be upon him, in the first Zakat, he said: 'Where is this from?' It was said: 'From Wasakhah.' He said: 'Rather, from Washah.' Bawsan between Banu Jama'ah...

...and Banu Rashwan. Najran [Najran, Saudi Arabia] between Balharith and Hamdan. Al-Jawf [Al-Jawf, Yemen] between Hamdan and Madhhij. Marib [Marib, Yemen] between Saba and Madhhij. Jurash [Jurash, Saudi Arabia] between Al-Awasij and Anz. Turj between Al-Mutayr and Nasa'. Mecca [Mecca, Saudi Arabia] between the wheat merchants and the butchers. Land of Oman [Oman]: its greatest district is Sohar [Sohar, Oman]. As for its villages, most of their gatherings are Harud from its valleys. Famous Mountains: Al-Kawr, the mountain of Dathinah, and Al-Kawr in Jurash. Sabir and Dhakhir, the two mountains of Al-Ma'afir. Ta'kar, Sayd, Ba'dan, and Rayman, the mountains of Al-Sahul. Jabal Hubb. Jabal al-Ud, between it and Jabal Nu'man. Sana' and Al-Qamar in Al-Sarw. From Jabalan Al-Arkaba: Jabal al-Dala' from Jabalan. Bura': Jabal al-Sannabir. Rishan, Hufash, and Al-Sharaf. Shibam and Masar, the two mountains of Haraz. Ans: Jabal Dawran. Isbil, Sahmar, Jabal al-Diqrar for Murad. Sharafat Jurah and Kanan, Tan'imah. Ayban and Nuqum, the two mountains of Sana'a. Mahnun for Upper Khawlan, it and Tan'imah. Jabal Tays, Jabal Takhalla, and Sara'. Jabal Hajjah, Mawtak. Jabal Dhakhar, Hadur, Dayn, Muda', Shazab. Haylan, Jabal Milh, Jabal Yam. Jabal Sufyan, Dhayban al-Kabir, Barat. Hanum and Suhayb. 'Arr Bawsan, Arash, Ghaylan. Al-Jabal Al-Aswad for Janb. Shann and Bariq in Al-Sarat. Al-Hadn in the land of Najd. Arid al-Yamama (Jabal Tuwaiq). The two mountains of Tayy: Aja and Salma. Aqra', Ta'ar, Laban, Abah, Shamam from the mountain of Tayy. 'Asib, 'Arwan, Yalamlam, Quds, Radwa, A'far, Afra', Yasum, Arah, Al-Ash'ar. Those with Nab' trees among them, especially from the land of Khawlan: Fawt, 'Arami, Gharabiq, Al-Dabr, Jabal al-Ra'a, Jabal al-Aswaq (its name is Dalani), Arash, 'Anmal, Badr, Al-Madhra, Wakhar, 'Arw, and Hanum from the lands of Hamdan, Suhayb, and Al-Sharaf. Famous Fortresses among them: Sana', Al-Qamar, Jabal Hubb, Warakh, Al-Ud, Ta'kar, Sabir, Al-Juwwah, Qar'ad, Khalqah, Rimah al-Kila', Kahlan, Mathwah, Dala', Rimah, Bura', Shibam Haraz, Masar Haraz Al-Mustahrizah, Dawran, Nu'man, Ras Hadur (called Bayt Khawlan), Jabal Takhalla (it and Hanum are the head of it), Hajjah, Mawtak, Shazab, Madhrah, Muda', Hadur Banu Azad, Na'it, Tan'imah, Dhubab, Sara', Qal'at Dahr, Yakla, Hakar, Talfum, Dharwah, Awli...

...and Wa'ilah, Rishan, Muhib, Muda', Shaharah, Al-Abla', Hisn al-Ushshah, Abudhar, Arash, Ghaylan, Al-Ghara, Barran, Dafa, Anam, and Al-Khanfa'arr from the land of Khawlan. Lofty Mountains on whose peaks are Noble Mosques and mosque sites: Ta'kar, Adam, Hadur, Sahmar, Shibam Haraz, Bayt Fa'is from the top of Jabal Takhalla, Upper Rishan (which is Jabal Milhan ibn Awf ibn Malik), Sharafat Jurah, Sabir, Kanan, and Hanum. Mountains with mound-like height and conical peaks: Al-Mutawwaq, Khatarir, Qasran, Watran, Shajjan, Sharafat Jurah, Dayn, Sarar, Khatfah, and Shakhab. Humped Mountains without peaks: Sabir, Dhakhir, Bura', Suhayb, Haraz al-Mustahrizah, Shazab, Mawtak, Jabal Nahm, Milhan, Shaharah, 'Ayshan, Al-Sharaf, and 'Arwan. Those on whose peaks are Wells and Cisterns: As for those on whose peaks are cisterns and wells, they are Barat, Asal, and Tan'imah. Those on whose peaks are streams and springs: Hanum, Jabal Takhalla, Rishan (Jabal Milhan), Al-'Arw, Arash, Ghaylan, Hadur, Masar, Dawran, and Jabal Dhakhar. This is from those with layered strata and gates. As for the mountains that are not encircled by strata, and most of them are what remains of fortresses, such as Sabir, Dhakhir, Bura', Rimah, Shazab, Hufash, Haraz al-Mustahrizah, Suhayb, and countless others. Mountains Famous among the Arabs mentioned in their poetry: Aja and Salma (the two mountains of Tayy), Aban, Ta'ar, Laban, Hadn, Quds, Radwa, 'Arwan, Yasum, Hira [Jabal al-Nour], Thabir, Al-Arid, Al-Qinan, and Afra'. Amr ibn Ma'adi Yakrub said: 'And your fortune is castrated on the face, miserable... The riders point it out as long as Afra' stands.' And Al-Nir and 'Asib. Imru' al-Qays said: 'For I am residing as long as 'Asib remains.' And Yadhbul, Al-Mujaymir, Lubnan [Lebanon], and Al-Lukkam. The beginning of the Sarat of the Arabian Peninsula is from the land of Dhubhan and Al-Ma'afir, and its end is Jabal al-Qabq from the farthest Sham.

Places of Worship: Mecca, Aelia [Jerusalem], Al-Lat in Upper Nakhla, Dhu al-Khalasa in the region of Tabalah, the Kaaba of Najran, Riyam in the land of Hamdan, and the Church of Al-Baghutah in Al-Hirah. Shores of the Arabian Sea: Such as Safwan, Kazima [Kazima, Kuwait], the gulfs of Mahra, Lower Hadhramaut [Hadhramaut, Yemen], Al-Ahqaf, Tih Abyan, the desert of Farasan and Banu Majid, the shore of the Ash'aris, the plain of Akk, the date groves of Hakam, the land of Kinana and Azd, the coasts of Al-Sirrayn, Al-Haram, the plains of Hijaz, and Tih Tayma. Headlands of this Sea known for danger and difficulty: Al-Fartak [Ras Fartak], Ras al-Jamjamah, Bab al-Mandab [Bab el-Mandeb], Munfahiq Jabir, Bahat Jazan, Ras Athr, Shaqan, Taran, and Jabalat. Places of Wild Animals used in proverbs: Wajrah, Harbah, Asnamah, Dhu Qar, Tawdah, Sharab, Rumah, Al-Dabil, Wahbin, Zarud, Anbatah, and Talah. It is said 'Sheep of Al-Rakhami' just as it is said 'Sheep of Al-Aran', 'Goat of the Sand', 'Eye of the Sand', 'Al-Halab', 'Wolf of the Khamar', 'Wolf of the Ghada', 'Wolf of the Ghamlul', and 'Sheep of the Waql' for ibexes. Places of Lions in this Peninsula used in proverbs: Lion of Khaffan, Lion of Al-Shara from the lands of Lakhm, Lion of Athr (Athr with light pronunciation, sometimes heavy), Lion of Hamilah, Lion of Al-Malahit, Lion of Al-Muqayda, Lion of Al-Lata, Lion of Ta'shar, Lion of Liyyah, Lion of Halyah, Lion of Al-Sahul, Lion of Tabalah, Lion of Turj and Bisha, and Lion of Atud. As for Tabalah, Turj, and Bisha, they are among the valleys of Najd, and there are no lions in this, nor were there ever. Rather, the Arabs mean the Lions of Baysh, and they add the Ha to it, saying Bisha (with Fatha on Ba), which are the places of lions. Bisha Ba'tan is with Kasra on Ba. It was said: Rather, they meant Bisha of Najd, and that the heads of these valleys from the Upper Sarat, some descend to Najd and some descend to Tihama. What descends to Tihama has lions in it, and they have proximity. They attributed them to these valleys. Perhaps one of them ascended to the land of Najd, crossing from his land, and wreaked havoc there. So perhaps the first who attributed lions to these places saw one of them...

...and a pair in some of these valleys. And Wadi al-Siba' (Valley of Beasts) in the land of Iyad; in it is meant for Abu Duwad and his son Duwad. Places of Jinn used in proverbs: Jannat Abqar. Zuhayr said: 'On horses upon which are Jinns of Abqar.' And Jinn of Al-Badi. Labid said: 'Jinn of Al-Badi, their feet firmly planted.' And Jinn of Al-Baqqar. Al-Nabigha said: 'Under the armor are Jinn of Al-Baqqar.' And Jinn of Dhu Simar, Ghul of Al-Rabdhat, 'Udar of Lahj and Mulh, Jinn of Hud and Qawwar in Al-Ma'afir, and Jayham. Humayd ibn Thawr said: 'Tales of Jinn visiting Jinn in Jayham.' And Abraq al-Hannan, wherein the humming of Jinn is heard. The poet said: 'May Allah water waters whose location I knew... Jurab, Malkum, Badhdhar, and Al-Ghamr.' The Ancient Watering Places: Among the ancient waters are Tawdah, which is between Raml al-Shihah and Sharj in Dhat al-Talh. And Al-Saminah in the region of Raml al-Saminah, which is the red [sand] belonging to the goldsmiths. And Za'aq between Al-Nibah and Al-Yansu'ah. Rabad between Bi'r al-Jawa and Nazirah. Tuwayli' between Al-Samman and Al-Dahna. Some Arabs were asked about Tuwayli' at the overlooking height: 'By Allah, it has a long rope, distant supper, overlooking enemies.' Some of Banu Tamim say about it: 'Even if I were at war, I would not come to Tuwayli'... Nor its hollow except with a mighty army.' And Al-Ja'b; Al-Aswad ibn Ya'fur says about it: 'And it was as if my colt remained there imagining... covering the spearheads with the red ochre of Al-Ja'b.' And Unayzah [Unaizah, Saudi Arabia]. Muhalhil said: 'It was as if we, in the morning, and the sons of our father... at the side of Unayzah were the millstones of a manager.' And Al-Murayrah in some of the clefts of Al-Dahna. And Lisaf in Al-Iyad. And Barhut, a well in Lower Hadhramaut, ancient. The oldest wells of the earth are the Well of Shem son of Noah in Sana'a and the Well of...

...Maymun in Mecca. It is in some interpretations the meaning of the saying of Allah, Mighty and Majestic: 'Say, have you considered: if your water was to become sunken.'
