He is Maymun ibn Qahtan al-Sadafi from the children of Abad ibn Abyad ibn Malik ibn Al-Sadaf. Places of Wine: Wine of Anat [Anah, Iraq], Wine of Baysan [Beit She'an, Israel/Palestine], Wine of Al-Khuss—a village in the lower Euphrates. Imru' al-Qays said: 'As if the merchants ascended with wine... from Al-Khuss until they brought it down at Yasr.' The Palestinian from Palestine. Wine of That. Wine of Dahr. The Hiriyah attributed to Al-Hirah [Al-Hirah, Iraq]. Bayt Ras is a place for wine in Jordan. Dwellings of those who went North (Tasha'ama) from the Arabs: As for the dwellings of Lakhm, they are scattered; most of them are between Ramla [Ramla, Israel/Palestine] and Egypt in Al-Jifar. Some are in Golan [Golan Heights], some in Hauran [Hauran, Syria] and Al-Bathaniyyah and the city of Nawa [Nawa, Syria]; in it are Khalaf ibn Jabala al-Qusayri and Ibn Aziz al-Lakhmi, his dwelling is the edge of the Shara mountains. As for Judham, it is between Midian [Al-Bad', Saudi Arabia] to Tabuk [Tabuk, Saudi Arabia] to Adhruh [Adhruh, Jordan]. A branch of it is near Tiberias [Tiberias, Israel] from the land of Jordan to Lajjun [Lajjun, Israel] and Yamun to the region of Acre [Acre, Israel]. As for Amilah, it is in its mountain overlooking Tiberias towards the sea. As for Dhubyan, it is from the border of Al-Bayad—Bayad Qarqarah—which is a lowland between Tayma and Hauran; no one mixes with them except Tayy, and their settled area is Al-Sawad, Marw, and Al-Hayyaniyyat. As for Kalb, its dwellings are Al-Samawah, and no one mixes with its clans in Al-Samawah. From Kalb in the land of Al-Ghouta [Ghouta, Syria] are Amir ibn al-Husayn ibn Ulaym and Ibn Rabab al-Ma'qili. As for Hisma [Hisma Desert, Jordan/Saudi Arabia], it is between Fazara and Judham, and it is from the borders of Judham. In Hisma is the Well of Iram, one of the known Arab watering places. And Qaraqir between Kalb and Dhubyan, which is a watering place. And Ara'ir; the Day of Qaraqir and Ara'ir was between Kalb and Abs. From the dwellings of Ghatafan is Yathqub; in Yathqub is Rawdat al-Ajdad which Al-Nabigha mentioned saying: 'Rawdat al-Ajdad from it in Yathqub has been effaced.' From Husham ibn Judham is a clan called Banu Jara living in the sand from Al-Farama. Banu Bayadah from Judham and Banu Rashidah from Lakhm live in Al-Baqqarah...

...and Al-Warradah and Al-Arish [Arish, Egypt]. Banu al-Tha'l from Banu Jara dominate Al-Arish. From Banu al-Tha'l is Ba'bsan, a village in Darum Gaza. Banu Jara have the Islands of Banu Jara in the land of Egypt, which are white sands. As for Banu Ubayr, the clan of Hudbah ibn Khashram from Udhrah, their home is at Tall Qarsis and Al-Mahab. Some of Udhrah live in Jazirat al-Sawami' on white sands from the district (Kura) of Dayyan. Some of them are at Zankalum, and some in the Sa'id (Upper Egypt) of Egypt. From Banu al-Harith ibn Ka'b is a house living in Al-Faljah in the land of Damascus; among them is Abd al-Malik ibn al-Rahim al-Harithi. Dwellings of the Arabs beyond Medina: Between Medina and Wadi al-Qura [AlUla, Saudi Arabia] are five stages on the road of Al-Marwah. It has another road to the right of that in the land of Najd via the Fortress of Banu Uthman; its distance is four days. Khaybar [Khaybar, Saudi Arabia] has two roads to Medina: one is direct from Medina, and the second turns right from the Fortress of Banu Uthman. In Khaybar are a people of Jews, Mawali, and a mixture of Arabs. The dwellings of Banu Harb between these places are Juhaynah, Bali, and Muzaynah. These tribes anciently encroached on the land of Tayy below Banu Harb. From Al-Marwah to Medina is two stages: Al-Suwayda, where there is water, then Medina. Awal of Hijaz is to the right of Al-Suwayda. If the pilgrim of Egypt and Sham comes from Al-Suwayda to Medina, he turns to Awal, then they exit from it to Al-Sayyalah. In this Awal are the palms of Al-Marwah, inhabited by the Ja'afir, Mawali, and a mixture. Al-Is: Juhaynah and Muzaynah are in it. The abode of Juhaynah is separate from the borders of Radwa and Al-Ash'ar to a valley between Najd and the sea. Then from the end of the abode of Juhaynah is the abode of Bali to the border of the abode of Judham at Al-Nabk on the seashore, then Aynuna behind it. Then it has the right sides of the land to the border of Tabuk, then to the mountains of Al-Shara, then to Ma'an [Ma'an, Jordan], returning to Ayla [Aqaba, Jordan], until Al-Maghar says: 'Here I am'. Al-Maghar is a stop for Lakhm. Then you fall into the dwellings of Lakhm from the border of Al-Maghar, then Al-Darum, then Al-Jifar. Al-Jifar are sands to the border of Al-Farama...

...and what is behind Al-Farama to Egypt belongs to the Copts. As for what turns left towards the sea from the land of the Copts, it is Yemeni; in it are Bali, Lakhm, some of Qays, and mixtures of people. Then to Lakhm and those who mix with them from Kinana is what is around Ramla to Nablus [Nablus, Palestine]. They also have what passed Tabuk to Zoar (Zughar), which is a land of palms, and from it comes the Zughari dates. Then the Dead Lake [Dead Sea] into which Wadi Yarmouk and Jordan throw. Lakhm also has Golan and the lands following it: Nawa, Al-Bathaniyyah, and a portion of the land of Hauran. Juhaynah, Dhubyan, and some of Al-Qayn mix with them in these places. To the left of the mountains of Al-Shara are the cities of the people of Lot; among them is the stop Dhu Khashab and Al-Ghamr, which is Ghamrah. This region is finished. We return to classifying what remains of the dwellings of the Arabs east and north from Wadi al-Qura. From Wadi al-Qura to Khaybar to the east of Medina to the border of the Two Mountains (Aja and Salma) to what ends at the Harrah are the dwellings of Sulaym. No one mixes with them except a section of the Ansar who are travelers, and they may neighbor Tayy. As for the Najd between Mecca and Medina from Dhat Irq to the Two Mountains, then the Mine—the Mine of Sulaym [Mahd adh Dhahab, Saudi Arabia]—returning to Wadi al-Qura to Al-Hijr [Mada'in Saleh], the place of Thamud and the She-Camel, is one stage, and in it are great ruins. Between them is Al-Is, to which Al-Isi dates are attributed. Then from Al-Hijr to Tayma [Tayma, Saudi Arabia], the place of Al-Samaw'al in the Dahna, is three stages (Butan). Inhabiting what is between that from Tayy are Banu Sakhr and their brothers Banu Amr and a clan from Buhtur. The settlement of Tayma today belongs to Tayy, then to Banu Zurayq, Banu Mirdas, Banu Juwayn, and Al-Ghushah, who are Mawali. If you go out from Tayma intending Kufa [Kufa, Iraq] secondly, you are in the dwellings of Buhtur from Tayy until you fall into the dwellings of Banu Asad five [days] before Kufa. This road is between Al-Qurayyat to the left next to Al-Bayad, and Al-Manhab is to their right. Al-Qurayyat belongs to Dhubyan, Buhtur from Tayy, and a mixture. If he passes Tayma returning to the highway to Kufa, he goes out to Fayd if he wishes, or if he wishes to the Two Mountains, until he sticks to the highway. Travel on these two roads is with protection (Khafara). If you turn left, you fall from Tayma into the dwellings of Dhubyan and Al-Bayad until Hauran says 'Here I am'. Some of Kalb mix with them at Ara'ir and what follows it. Then from Hauran into the dwellings of Kalb on your right in...

...Al-Samawah then Al-Dahna until you see the palms of the Euphrates. No one mixes with Kalb other than it. If you take the left, you fall into Al-Hayyaniyyat and what follows it, the dwellings of Al-Qayn where the remnant of Jadis, the brothers of Tasm, were. If you turn left from that also, you fall into the dwellings of Amilah, which neighbors Jordan. The mountain of Amilah overlooks Acre from the sea side following it, and overlooks Jordan and Al-Faljah. In it is a group from Akk, Hamdan, and Madhhij from Balharith then Banu Malik; they are the group of Ibn Abd al-Rahim al-Harithi. If you pass the mountain of Amilah intending Damascus, Homs, and what follows it, it is the dwellings of Ghassan from the family of Jafna and others. If you turn left from Homs from the Great Sea, which is the Sea of the Romans, you fall into the land of Bahra, a free tribe who do not submit; they are people of sovereignty and might. Then to their left adjoining the sea is Tanukh; it is the dwellings of Al-Fadid, the masters of Tanukh. Their stronghold from it is Latakia [Latakia, Syria] on the seashore. Then you fall into Christians and others to the border of the Euphrates to Balis [Balis, Syria] in the desert of Khasaf, which is part of Al-Dahna. From there you go out to Tadmur (Palmyra) [Palmyra, Syria] of the right (Yemen), which is ancient Palmyra. It is the side of Al-Samawah. Among the villages falling in the dwellings of Kalb are Tadmur, Salamiyah [Salamiyah, Syria], Al-Asimiyyah, and Homs [Homs, Syria], which is Himyarite. Behind it towards Iraq are Hama [Hama, Syria], Shayzar [Shaizar, Syria], and Kafr Tab belonging to Kinana of Kalb. Then you return with Kinana of Kalb from these dwellings of theirs to the region of Al-Samawah and the Euphrates. Of the cities are Tall Mannas, Haras, Za'raya, and Manbij [Manbij, Syria]. Manbij is shared between them and Banu Kilab to the border of Wadi Butnan. Then you come to the Euphrates from the land of the Romans cutting through the edge of Sham twisting to Iraq. Its west is the dwellings of Kalb and its east is the dwellings of Mudar. Among the cities are Al-Raqqa (Al-Rafiqah) [Raqqa, Syria] on the bank of the Euphrates, inhabited by mixtures of Mudar. And Harran [Harran, Turkey], the place of measuring instruments like astrolabes and others; Harrani camel halters made of linen and hair are made there for Banu Tamim and those who mix from Banu Sulaym. And Edessa (Al-Raha) [Sanliurfa, Turkey] for Banu Sulaym, and the Church of Edessa which is used in proverbs. And Marba'a. And Al-Khabur for Banu Uqayl; its upper part for Banu Malik and Banu Habib, and clans of Taghlib the rest. Then the last of the dwellings of Mudar is Ras al-Ayn [Ras al-Ayn, Syria] for Al-Namir ibn Qasit.

Dwellings of Rabi'a and what is behind them: The first of them and the last of the dwellings of Mudar is Ras al-Ayn. Then Kafr Tutha for Jusham to its left, passing by the place of snakes used in proverbs, and it overlooks Darin. Then Nisibis [Nusaybin, Turkey], the place of scorpions; it is the abode of the family of Hamdan ibn Hamdun, clients of Taghlib. From Nisibis to Adhramah and Al-Sumay'iyyah is a day's journey. To the right of that is Mount Sinjar [Sinjar Mountains, Iraq], the mountain of the Shurat of Banu Taghlib. Of the Shurat are Banu Zuhayr and Banu Amr. Then to the right of that is Dahna to Rahbat Malik ibn Tawq and Circesium (Qarqisiya) [Busayrah, Syria]. Then you return to Adhramah to Barqa'id, which is the dwellings of Banu Abd from Taghlib. The sayer says about them: 'Let not Barqa'id and its plaster deceive you... And secure for yourself a living by day.' Then from there to Balad, and in it are Shurat and others, to the border of Mosul [Mosul, Iraq]. If you want after the land of Mosul, you pass by Tikrit [Tikrit, Iraq], and Al-Tharthar is on your right. Most of the people of Mosul are Madhhij, and it is Rabi'a. If you turn left from it, you fall to the mountain named Al-Judi [Mount Judi], inhabited by Rabi'a, and behind it are the Kurds, and behind the Kurds are the Armenians. If you turn right from Mosul wanting Baghdad, Al-Hadithah meets you, and Mount Barimma, called today Hamrin [Hamrin Mountains]; it is said it is a mountain never free of a slain person for a day. Then Al-Sinn and Al-Bawazij, lands of the Shurat from Rabi'a. Then one falls into Mount Tur al-Barri, which is the first of the borders of the dwellings of Bakr for Banu Shayban and their kin. No one mixes with them to the region of Khorasan except the Kurds. As for what is between Baghdad [Baghdad, Iraq] and Basra towards the North and Khorasan, it is the dwellings of Banu Rasib al-Jarmiyyah, then Basra. The dwellings of the Arabs there connected to the coasts of the sea and Kazima. Much may exit from the seashore away from the Peninsula, such as those in Giza of the land of Egypt, Aswan, the Maghreb, the Sa'id, and what bordered the west of the Sea of Qulzum [Red Sea] from Aswan to the region of Badi, Suakin, and the Mines. Chapter: Plants of Yemen. The plants of Yemen are between meadows, trees of Ar' (Arak?), grafted acacia (Idah), thorny acacia, herbs, flowers, and blossoms. As for herbs, in it are most of the medicinal herbs (Aqqar), but its Bedouin people do not know them; rather, the wise among people from the medical profession know them. Every genus of these types has uncountable varieties...

...except that the Arabs incline in the names of men towards thorny and grazing acacias due to the roughness, sharpness, hardness, and endurance of water scarcity and lack of irrigation in them. Among their names are Talha, Samra, Awsaja, 'Arfata, Qatada, Alqama, Hadaqa, Shubruma, Buqayla, Qaraza, Arta'a, Athba, 'Araba, Salamah (plural Salam), Juma' Salamah Salam, Salamah with the name of the stone (plural Salam), 'Athraba, Dandana, Qatara, 'Allafa, Ja'dana, 'Ankatha, Ghadura, Ghada, 'Alatha, Khalila, Hamza, Sahma, Araka, Ja'thana, Thaghama, Alqama, Habaqa, 'Ajrama, Sabra, Dabra, Murra, Sharkha, Sharkh, Shabta, and Jarhada. From women: Karma, Ja'than, 'Arada, 'Arama, Mazza, Ghalaqa (and Al-Aghluq from Zabid), 'Alaqa, 'Alqa, Sakhbara, Bashama, Halaza, Tanzaba, Markha, Harama, Busra, Sharza, Sharya, 'Alafa, and Jarjah (the fruit of the Talh, different from it). The poet said: 'With the neck of a dark-lipped [camel] reaching for the 'Allaf.' And Hamdah (from it Al-Mundhir ibn Abi Hamdah al-Wadi'i) and Mazza ibn al-Jamjum from Hakam, and Harmala, Khamkhama, and other than that for whoever tracks it. As for the names of fruits: like Busr, Busra, Rutba, Zabiba, 'Anjada, Shu'ayra, Dukhna, Tahfa, 'Adasa, and others. Dialects of the People of this Peninsula: The people of Al-Shihr and Al-As'aa are not eloquent. Mahra are barbarous (Ghutm) resembling the Persians (Ajam). Hadhramaut are not eloquent, though the eloquent may be among them; the most eloquent of them are Kinda, Hamdan, and some of Al-Sadaf. The Sarw of Madhhij, Marib, Bayhan, and Harib are eloquent; bad language among them is rare. The Sarw of Himyar and Ja'da are not eloquent; in their speech is something of Tahmir (Himyaritic traits). They drag in their speech and delete, saying 'Ya bna Ma'am' for 'Ya bna al-Amm' (O cousin) and 'Sama'' for 'Asma'' (Listen). Lahj, Abyan, and Dathinah are more eloquent. The Amiris from Kinda and the Odis are the most eloquent of them. Aden: their language is mixed (Muwallada), bad; in some of them is foolishness and stupidity except for those who are educated. Banu Majid, Banu Waqid, and Al-Ash'ar: there is no harm in their language. Lower Al-Ma'afir is barbarous, and its upper part is better. Al-Sakasik is middle. The land of Al-Kara' is Najdi, exemplary, with difficulty from...

...the Himyaritic tongue. Their Sarat has complexity (Ta'qid). Sakhlan, Jayshan, Warakh, Hadar, Al-Suhayb, and Badr are close to the language of the Sarw of Himyar. Yahsub and Ru'ayn are more eloquent than Jabalan. Jabalan has complexity in their language. Haql Qitab to Dhamar is pure complex Himyaritic. The Sarat of Madhhij like Radman and Qaran, and its Najd like Rada', Isbil, Kuman, Al-Hada, Qa'ifa, and Diqrar are eloquent. Upper Khawlan is close to that. Sahmar, Qard, Al-Hablah, Mulh, Lahj, Hamd, Utmah, Watih, Samh, Ans, and Alhan are middle, closer to accent (Luknah). Haraz, Al-Khuruj, Shamm, Mazikh, Al-Ahbub, Al-Jahadib, Sharaf Aqyan, Al-Taraf, Wadih, and Al-Mu'allal are a mixture between eloquence and accent, and among them is what is deeper in complex Himyaritic, especially the Haduris of these tribes. The land of Al-Ash'ar, the land of Akk, and Hakam ibn Sa'd from the bottom of Tihama and its surroundings: there is no harm in their language except those of them who inhabited villages. Hamdan who were in its Sarat from Hashid are a mixture of eloquent like 'Udhar, Hanum, and Hajur, and barbarous like some of Qadam and some of Al-Jabar. Najdi is a land; he had inhabited these places, migrated to them, grazed in them, traveled in them, and was expert in them. The Great City of Bahrain is Hajar; it is the market of Banu Muharib from Abd al-Qays. Its dwellings are what surrounded it of the villages of Bahrain. Al-Qatif is a place of palms and a city of great importance; it is a coast, and its inhabitants are Jadhimah from Abd al-Qays, their master is Ibn Mismar and his clan. Then Al-Uqayr below it; it is a coast and a village below Al-Qatif from the bend ('Atf), having palms and inhabited by Arabs from Banu Muharib. Then Al-Sayf, the coast of the sea; it is a day from Awal. Awal is an island in the middle of the sea, a journey of a day; in it are all animals except predatory beasts. Then Al-Sittar, known as Bahrain; it is the Munada (calling place?) of Banu Tamim. Al-Bayda is connected to it, and it had palms and habitation. Al-Fatah is a road between Al-Sittar and the sea to Basra. Among the connected waters are Mu'aqqalat, then Khams, then Ma'qala Tuwayli', which is to the right of Sanam. Then Kazimat al-Buhur is a coast; Farwa al-Asadi says in it: 'Fears diverted them from Sunayh... and from Raml al-Niqar, so they are visitors. It is Al-Niqar, Al-Jifar, and Al-Haza'ir, the Haza'ir of Mudrik. I guaranteed for them that they abandon Najd... and settle in Kazimat al-Buhur.' Then Rahliyyah to Basra. From the waters of Sittar of Bahrain are Thaytal, Al-Nibaj, and Al-Nibak; all have many palms and water called Qatar. And Al-Sabaj is a land of many villages. It is called Nibaj of Banu Amir; they are springs gushing with water, palms, and crops. Its highest part connects the two mountains Aja and Salma; between them is a journey of two days. Al-Na'f, the slope of Muhajjar in the region of Al-Armah. As for Al-Sulliyy, it is a great valley, which Al-A'sha mentioned saying: 'An old woman seeks sustenance in Al-Sulliyy for her dependents.' The branch of Al-Sulliyy is below the hills (Qarat) of Al-Habl on the right of Hajar from the direction of sunrise. Khanzir is adjacent to it, between it and Barqat al-Sakhal. In it are Al-Hafira Al-Ulya and Al-Hafira Al-Sufla, which are two buried waters. In the middle of Al-Sulliyy below Khanzir is Hit of Najd. Then the valley pushes below Al-Barashi', Hamdan, Al-Bawn—the eastern part of it—and Al-Khashab is Arab mixed with Himyarite. The Najdi exterior of Hamdan varies from eloquent to less than that. Khaywan are eloquent and they have much Himyaritic. In Sa'dah and the land of Sufyan ibn Arhab, they are eloquent except in the like of their saying 'Am-Rajul' (The Man - using Am for Al) and 'Qayyad Ba'irak' (Tie your camel) and 'Ra'aytu Akhwak' (I saw your brother - nominative for accusative). Sharing with them in substituting Mim for Lam in 'Al-Rajul' and 'Al-Ba'ir' and the like are Al-Ash'ar, Akk, and some of Hakam from the people of Tihama. 'Udhar, Matrah, Nihm, Marhabah, Dhayban, and the inhabitants of Al-Rahbah from Balharith are eloquent. Diyaf in Upper Jawf is less than that. Kharfan and Athafit: no harm in their eloquence. The inhabitants of Al-Jawf are eloquent except those mixed with neighbors from Tihama. Qabil of Northern Nihm, Nu'man of Marhabah, the exterior of Banu 'Ulyan, and the exterior of Sufyan and Shakir are eloquent. The land of Wada'ah, Banu Harb are people of Imala in all their speech. Banu Sa'd are more eloquent. From Dhamar to Sana'a is intermediate; it is the land of Dhu Jurrah. Sana'a has in its people remnants of pure Arabic and parts of the speech of Himyar. The city of Sana'a has different languages and dialects; for every spot of them is a language. And whoever...

...adjoins Shu'ub differs from everyone. Shibam Aqyan, Al-Masani', and Takhalla are pure Himyaritic. Khawlan of Sa'dah: its Najdi people are eloquent, and the people of its Qadd and Ghaur are barbarous. Then eloquence from Al-Arad is in Wada'ah, then Janb, then Yam, then Zabid, then Banu al-Harith, then what connects to the land of Shakir from Najran to the land of Yam, then the land of Sinhan, then the land of Nahd and Banu Usamah, then Anz, then Khath'am, then Hilal, then Amir ibn Rabi'a, then Sarat al-Hajr, then Daws, then Ghamid, then Shukr, then Fahm, then Thaqif, then Bajila, then Banu Ali; except that the lower parts of the Sarats of these tribes between Sarat Khawlan and Ta'if are below their upper parts in eloquence. As for Al-Arud, eloquence is in it except for its villages. Likewise Hijaz, then Lower Najd to Sham, and to the dwellings of Mudar and the dwellings of Rabi'a; eloquence is in them except in their villages. These are the languages of the Peninsula in general, without partiality or detailed categorization. Description of Al-Arud, Bahrain, Lower Najd, the edge of Upper Najd, the pastures of these lands, the numbers of their waters, their Dahuls (caverns), mountains, villages, and deserts to the edges of Hijaz and the heights of Sham and the Sawad of Iraq: Bahrain and its regions from Abu Malik Ahmad ibn Muhammad ibn Sahl ibn Sabah al-Yashkuri.

...and it is Shibak, and to Rawdat al-Qarah. Then Al-Arad opposes from the middle of the open space to its left, Al-Farzah. Facing Al-Armah is Ghar al-Maghrah (Cave of Red Ochre) and Ghar al-Tin (Cave of Clay) which people eat. Facing them from the sunrise is Raha Ibil and Raha Ghanam. Al-A'sha has mentioned most of these places, saying: 'They said Namar, then Batn al-Khal watered them... Then Al-Asjadiyyah, then Al-Abla', then Al-Rijl. Then Al-Safh flows, then Khanzir, then its Barqah... Until Al-Watar and Al-Habl followed in it.' Al-Watar is a valley entering Wadi Hajar. Al-A'sha's home was in the two Manfuhas in Darna. These places in Al-Yamama are addressed by our description from the region of Bahrain. Then you return to Bahrain. Al-Ahsa [Al-Ahsa, Saudi Arabia] are dwellings and houses for Banu Tamim, then for Sa'd from Banu Tamim. Its market was on a dune called Al-Jar'a where Arabs trade. To the right of Bahrain and below it is Yabrin [Yabrin, Saudi Arabia] and Al-Khann, a place with many palms belonging to Banu Wada'ah. Yabrin has palms, fortresses, flowing springs, and non-flowing ones...

...and salt flats. Bahrain was named Bahrain only because of its river Muhallam and for the river of Ayn al-Jurayb. Then you ascend from it intending Al-Yamama. On your right will be Kharshim, which are hills and a desert cast towards Al-Hafrayn and Al-Silhayn. Al-Hafran are the Hafar of the two Rummanahs, and they are from the waters of Al-Armah. In front of your face, while you are facing the sunset, your ascent is from Al-Jaysh, then Al-Habisiyyah, then Mazlaqqah Mufa''alah, then Al-Mawarid, then Al-Faruq Al-Adna (The Nearer Faruq), then Al-Faruq Al-Thani (The Second Faruq). Then you ascend from Al-Faruq into Al-Khawar, Khawar al-Thul', then Al-Salib. On your right is Al-Sulb, Sulb al-Ma'a, and the Barqah, Barqat al-Thawr. Then Al-Samman and its waters, which are Dahuls (caverns) under the earth piercing the skin of the earth. Some of them are seventy fathoms and a hundred fathoms under the earth, less and more. Among them is Dahl al-Ayd, and among them is Dahl Arikah in Al-Sahsahan, and among them is Dahl al-Samurat, and among them is Dahl al-Dabbi. Their water is from the rain water, fresh. In Al-Samman are Al-Masani', which are pools made from the earth paved with rocks on their sides. There is no permanent spring water (Add) in Al-Samman except what was of the waters of Al-Armah near it. Then you return to the road of Zara intending Al-Yamama. From your left is Al-Dabib, a water called Al-Dabib, while you are passing Al-Sahsahan. From your right is a water called Al-Dahradi. Antara says about it: 'I drank from the water of Al-Dahradayni and became...' Then you cross Batn Qaww, then Al-Samra', which is a plain land. Then you take into Al-Dahna, and it is there a journey of a day. You turn from the road of Zara and take towards Al-Shajarah, which is the tree of Dhu al-Rummah under which he died and wrote his poetry. Then you exit from the mountains and clefts to Al-Atha'ith, which are the sand dunes (Salasil). While in that, you take a road called Al-Khall, Khall al-Raml. The first water you reach from Al-Armah from your left is Qalt Habal; it empties and recovers quickly. From your right are Qilal (rock pools) called Al-Nazim, Nazim al-Jafnah. From the right of that on...

...the left of Al-Shibak is Shibak al-Armah and Al-Gharabat. Then you cross Al-Armah and reach Washi', which is from the waters of Al-Armah, except that it empties into the side of the bottom (Qa'). The Rajiz says about it: 'As if, when they reached Washi'... Strings of Nab' tree concealing cracks.' Then you travel in Al-Sahba', then you cross a small mountain called Anqad, then Al-Rawdah. Then you reach Al-Khadramah, Jaww al-Khadarim, a city, villages, and a market containing Banu al-Ukhaydir ibn Yusuf. It is the abode of Banu Adi ibn Hanifa, the abode of Banu Amir ibn Hanifa, the abode of Ijl ibn Lujaym, and the dwellings of Hawdha ibn Ali al-Suhaymi al-Hanafi. It is the first of Al-Yamama from the direction of Bahrain. To the right of that is a valley from Al-Dam called Al-Rawhan. Al-Dam is a rough hill (Quff) with whiteness on its back. In it are waters, among them Al-Khuwayrat, Al-Thalma', and Al-Akbisha. Then it descends into the palm groves of Jaww and its fortresses, among them Al-Ghabib, Dhu al-Arakah, Al-Aq'as, Al-Rayyan, Al-Uyun, and Al-Zabyah. From the left of that is the spring from which Al-Sayh Al-Kabir flows. From its right is Al-Munsif, a fortress for Banu Amir ibn Hanifa, then Al-Munaysif, watered by Al-Munkhariq, Munkhariq Nisah. Then lower than that are the villages of Al-Yamama: Al-Dabi'ah, Al-Malha, and Al-Kharj [Al-Kharj, Saudi Arabia]. It is in the Qan' of the sand—and Al-Qan' is the outlet of the bottom—and the sands. The sands are at the base of Al-Dam, and they are called Ramlat al-Mughassil. Between Al-Dam and the sands is Al-Liwa, a strip between the Quff and the sand. In Al-Liwa is a water called Al-Suwaydiyah in the flow of Wadi al-Mughassil, which is a valley flowing from Qatman, Jawjan, and Al-Sha'nah below the cemetery, the cemetery of Al-Kharj. This Al-Yamama has scattered fortresses, palms, and gardens. A Quff to its right between it and Nisah is called Aklub; it is the dwellings of Banu Qays ibn Tha'labah. It formerly belonged to Banu Sa'd ibn Zayd Manat, but they were overcome for it. Al-Kharj is a bottom like your hand (flat), with fortresses. Valleys pouring into it are Ni'am, Birk, and Wadi al-Majazah. These valleys have one outlet into Batn al-Sawt, Al-Abrak al-Ni'am, for it empties into Dhat Nusub. It is from the dwellings of Jarm and Ijlah in lower Al-Majazah and Al-Armah and lower Wadi Ni'am; both are Jarmi. All these valleys have palms, crops, and dwellings...

...and they are called Al-Thanaya, Thanaya al-Arid. It is a long Quff (rough hill/escarpment); its nearest part is at Hadhramaut and its farthest at Al-Jaza'ir. In its west is Al-Dahna, and in its east it runs parallel to it. The Quff of Al-Arid [Jabal Tuwaiq] is sometimes mounted by sands so it lowers, and sometimes it lengthens and rises. These 'Arads' (valleys) come from it, and they all pour into their settling place at Al-Rawdah from Jaww al-Khadarim. Then they exit from Jaww and split Al-Armah a splitting, then Al-Dahna a splitting, then they exit until they pour into the sea. Birk: Batn al-Raka' descends into it. The journey of Ras al-Raka' from the dwellings of Banu Uqayl is five or six [days]. From the southern valleys of Al-Yamama are Nisah, Milk, Liha, and Al-Arad. In all of them are dead and living villages. From its branches are Qurqara, Al-Hazmah, Al-Nahy, the waters of Al-Siba'a, Al-Mahdah and its villages, and Al-Burthayn. All the dwellings are Rab'i. They are between the belly of Quff al-Arid and Ramlat al-Warakah to the farthest Al-Washum. So it is from 'Uwaynid Banu Khadij, then Al-Rugham, then Ramlat al-Hasadah, then Manfuh [Manfuha], then Al-Bardan, then Tharmada [Tharmada, Saudi Arabia], then Dhat Ghisl, then Al-Shaqra [Shaqra, Saudi Arabia], and Ushayqir [Ushaiger, Saudi Arabia], returning towards Al-Furu', to Marah [Marat, Saudi Arabia], to Batn al-Azraqah, to Tawdah. What repelled their west—which is a small interrupted Quff extended like a rope—is the land of Banu Tamim; in it are palms, villages, crops, and wells. Then you return to Batn al-Arad, Arad Banu Adi. The first of it is Al-Qurayy, Qurayy Banu Yashkur, then Al-Qalatayn for Banu Yashkur. To the left of that are Al-Shu'batan, belonging to Banu Dawr from Qays ibn Tha'labah. To their left is Wadi Liha; its lower part for Banu Yashkur and its upper part for Dawr from Qays ibn Tha'labah, then ascending. Then you return to Batn al-Arad, then Al-Fari'ah, then Al-Mawsil for Banu Yashkur, then Al-Masani' for Dawr, then Manfuhatan—which are Al-Manafiuh—for Banu Qays ibn Tha'labah. Then Muhraqah for Banu Zayd ibn Yarbu'; they are the Bedouins. Their master on that day was the leader of Al-Jarba', Umayr ibn Sulmi; he is the one who came as a delegate to the Prophet, peace be upon him, from Banu Yarbu' and dominated Al-Yamama in the days of the Fitna between Banu Hashim and Banu Abd Shams. Then Al-Qaryah Al-Khadra (The Green Village), Khadra Hajar, which Ubayd ibn Tha'labah ibn al-Du'l picked up and shared with no one. It consists of the fortresses of Tasm and Jadis, and in it are their ruins, fortresses, and their Batals—singular Batil, which is a square thing like a silo, tall in the sky, made of clay. Abu [Muhammad?] said...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text: Malik: I reached a building whose height was two hundred cubits in the sky. He said: It was said that there was one among them whose height was five hundred cubits. From one of them, Zarqa' al-Yamama looked at those who descended from Jaww Jan from the top of Al-Dam, a journey of two days and two nights. Jadis used to inhabit Al-Khadramah, and Tasm used to inhabit Al-Khadra'. Then you leave Hajr ascending in Al-Arid. The first valley of Al-Arid - and it is a valley that gathers three hundred valleys - the first thing that meets you on your right is Fayshan, and Al-Rawdah called Haznah. Then you go out to the village of Banu Adi, Al-Naqb, then Abad, Al-Ji'ad, and Aqrabah. At Aqrabah, the army of Khalid ibn al-Walid was killed on the Day of Musaylimah ibn Habib al-Hanafi. Then Khalid was victorious and destroyed it at the end of the day. It is also Adawiyyah. Then Al-Haddar, and it is Dhuhliyyah from Dhuhl ibn al-Dul. Al-Haddar has fortresses, palm trees, and ancient palaces. Then you proceed to the branch of Al-Arid and Al-'Uyaynah, which belongs to Banu Amir. To its left is Thaniyat al-Ahis. Then you proceed to the top of Al-Arid, and Al-Arid is blocked from you, so you come to the village from behind Al-Abakkayn - which are two peaks, two small mountains - the village of Banu Sadus ibn Dhuhl ibn Tha'labah. It is a good village, and in it is the palace of Solomon son of David, peace be upon him, built with wondrous hewn rock, ruined, and the citadel remains. Then you ascend from it to Naqil Qarran and Rayman, a place and valleys, and Watar. Qarran and Rayman belong to Banu Suhaym ibn al-Dul ibn Hanifah, and Watar belongs to Banu Ghubar. It has palm trees and ancient and non-ancient fortresses. Then you ascend a pass from the Naqil, and you descend upon the well of Banu Suhaym. In it are palm trees and fortresses, and below it are watercourses in the front of Al-Armah. From there to Al-Ghamim, to Ra'n al-Sawabah, to Al-Baqa'i', to Sari', to Ramlat Katlah, to Khinzir, to Al-Sikhal. All of that is behind Hajr, and before it to Jaww. Then you descend from Naqil Tahbal to the belly of Al-'Atk and to Al-Bakrat. From the right of the belly of Al-'Atk is Tamr, Tumayr, Mubayid, and Rawdat al-'Arqubah. Dahik faces you, and it is a pass in Al-Armah leading to the left sides of Al-Dahna' from the right of Falaj. At its top is Al-Halqah and Al-Thamad. All the waters of Al-'Atk and its villages you counted belong to Al-Rabab from Banu Tamim. Then you jump from Al-'Atk into the belly of Dhu Arat. Then you ascend in 'Arid al-Faqi. Its first village is Jammaz, which is Rababiyyah, Malkaniyyah, Adawiyyah...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
from the clan of Dhu al-Rummah. Then you proceed in the belly of Al-Faqi, which is a valley with many palm trees and wells. You meet Qarat Bel'anbar, which is unknown. Al-Qarah is a hill, a detached mountain, at its top is a well at one hundred fathoms, and around it are estates and palm trees. Their Rajiz poet said:
We built a Qarah in the middle of Al-Faqi ... From the crawling ones and from the pouring of the mounts
And from an unjust prince who does not refrain ... Does not fear Allah nor pity a wretched one
Then you ascend in the belly of Al-Faqi and come to Al-Ha'it, the wall of Banu Ghubar, a great village with a market. Likewise Jammaz is a market in a great village also. Then you leave it to Al-Rawdah, Rawdat al-Hazimi, and it has palm trees and an impregnable fortress. Then you proceed to Qarat al-Hazimi, and it is before Qarat al-Anbar. You are in palm trees, crops, and wells throughout that. Then Tuwam, then Ashiy, then Al-Khays. Then Al-Faqi ends, and you turn right as if you want Basra, so you come to Munaykhayn, then Al-Hanbali, which are two waters. At Munaykhayn are few palm trees, and there are no palm trees at Al-Hanbali. Then Al-Firdaws in the middle of Al-Hazn. Then you cross Falaj, a valley splitting Al-Hazn, and in it are waters from its right and from its left. They are deep-bottomed; some of them are many fathoms deep. Hafr Abi Musa is closer than that. Then you fall into Al-Daww, which is a journey of three [days]. There is no water or tree in it except Nasi and Silyan. The people bake in it with the roots of Silyan, dung, and dry Naqd. Al-Naqdah is a lowly tree. Then they cross it to Sanam. Then if they turn right at Al-Mas'udiyah, a ruined village to the right of Al-Naddah, it has many seeping waters (Ahsa'). If you turn left from Falaj, you fall into Al-Barit, which is a place where thyme grows. To its left is the main road to Iraq to Kufa. Behind the road is the road of Al-Bark, and it turns from the road, the road of Iraq, left from behind Al-Hubayr at a stage and two stages. So you take to Al-Bark. To the left of it are Al-Akhyas, Akhyas Kalb. And Hawran, which is a mountain in the right sides of Harrat Layla the Farther, and it is the nearest landmark of Sham. He said: It is my limit from this direction.
The Watering Places of the Road: Al-Aqabah, Sumayra, Fayd, Al-Naqrah, Al-Hajir, Al-Rabadhah, Al-Umq, Ufay'ah, Al-Maslah, and Ghamrah. To its left is Wajrah on the Basra road...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
...passing through Falaj and Al-Muwahhadah, and there is no water in it. Then Kharman, called Umm Kharman. Then Dhat Irq. Then Batn Nakhlah. And from your left in Batn Nakhlah comes a mountain pass, then Dar al-Barmaki, then Al-Zaymah, then Al-Ha'it. Then you return on the Basran road and drink at Wajrah, which is a well and a plastered pool. Then you descend Al-Sayy, which is a misleading land. Below it is Basyan, where Kharqa' bint Fatimah al-Amiriyah used to camp and pitch [tent], about whom Dhu al-Rummah says:
The completion of Hajj is that the mounts stand ... at Kharqa' while she unveils the mask
And about her he says, having stolen a visit but not seeing her:
When a night passed after the second ones ... and four added to ten of the month
I lived from Mina at the darkness of night, so I became ... at Basyan, her hands shining with the east
When a lean she-camel led them as if she were ... black-backed, bare-shanked, bald
Below Basyan are Al-Nathrawat, which are three hills. Then Al-Shabakah, Shabakat al-Kura'. Then Quba, and on it are Bahshan and palm trees and ruins; it belongs to Amir from Rabi'ah. To its right at the slope of the Harrah is Dharqan, two waters that are sipped. Then you exit the Harrah, and on your left is Al-Ghadir, Ghadir al-Harrah, which is the Near Harrah. Behind it is the Far Harrah, Harrat Layla. Between them are Al-Ashrat, the two ponds Adma' and Mutraq. They are at the end of the Harrah. At the end of the Harrah from the left of the Iraqi road is Zarud and the sand of Zarud. Then before that, towards sunrise, is Al-Sharabbah and its waters, which are Dhu Talal, Dhu al-Qaddah, Al-Athbajah, Al-Af'alah, and Sha'ba. In it is Wadi al-Miyah. It is the nearest of Al-Sharabbah to Dariyah. Sha'ba is the border of the Hima. These are the dwellings of Amir ibn Rabi'ah. Then we returned to the description of the road. From it is Marran, palm trees, Bahsh, and Husayn, which is between Quba and Al-Shubaykah, deviating in the Harrah. Then you emerge into the desert of Zulm, a long black mountain in the belly of the lowland (Al-Qa'). Between Dahr and Rahabah in Yemen is a high black mountain with a hump...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
...also called Zulm. Then Al-Dathinah, a water. Then Al-Sakhkhah. Then Al-Murayt, in it is a rock hollow (Qaltah) called Al-Udhirah Fi'lah, and in it is a well called Al-Midya'ah. Then if you turn left to the waters of Al-Sharabah, there are Al-Thu'al, Al-Baqarah, and Al-Yanufah, Yanufat Khanthal, which is a solitary mountain peak. To its left are Al-Muhdath, Buraq Namla, Al-Haw'ab, and Matlub. To the left of that in the left parts of Al-Sharabah for one intending the left road to Qarn al-Yamaniyah are Al-Nakhliyah, Nasihah, Al-Baghra, and Buraym. A fortress appears to him from the east of Qarn al-Yamaniyah. Then you return and take the outskirts of Al-Ubra, then Al-Athbajah, then Dariyah, which are dwellings and land that is cultivated, two fortresses, and a comprehensive market. It falls in the Hima, Hima Dariyah. Around it are landmarks, among them 'As'as, and Hadb al-Hajar, which is a fresh water rock hollow entered from under the hill, and around it are scattered hills. Also a landmark called Wasat like 'As'as. Then Al-Dil', Dil' al-Wakar. Then it ascends in Al-Haziz, which is the head of the Hima, Hima Dariyah. The Hima is a pole with what revolves around it to the furthest footsteps of Abu Malik. From the left of Dariyah adjacent to the north of the watering places, resources, and pastures are Dhalfa', hills and a desert grazed by camels. The Rajiz said:
O camels, do you know Saq ... and Dhalfa'an, the thin pasture?
And Fawzah overlooking the ranges
Then Saq al-Farwayn, then Abanan: Aban the Black and Aban the White, two mountains between which passes the belly of Al-Rummah. Before them is 'Ushayrah, which is Ta'iyyah. At its heights are Aja and Salma, the two mountains of Tayy. Then behind that is Al-Qassim, which is a wide land with many palm trees and sand. The palm trees are in the fold of the sand. It has much water and many fortresses. To its side is Khaybar from the direction of Hejaz and Hadb al-Qinan. Al-Qinan has a black peak. And Sarah, and Dhu 'Aj, which is a water. Then Al-Khabra' to the right of that, and Al-Yansu'ah, which are waters of the Basran road. And Birkat Takhfah before them to Birkat Dariyah. Al-Qassim, below it is Raml al-Shaqiq to Haza'ir Madrak. To the left of that towards Hejaz is Rakham, which is a water, Qarat al-Zunabi, and the two Bajalis. All that is before Ubla, then the head of Al-Sharabbah.

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Then Dariyah towards sunrise: Kabshan are hills, and Al-Bakrat are hills in which is a well called Al-Bakrah. Then to the left of that are the waters of Al-Dabab. Among them are Al-Mawjaniyah, Ghawl, Al-Khasafah, and Wadi Dhi Ajrad. To the left of Dhi Ajrad is a water called Munyah and a huge red hill. To its left is a hill. To the right of that is Thahmad, which is a black mountain with a spring at its top. And Dhat Firqayn, which is a hill whose head is split in two halves like Mount Shajan. All those landmarks are in a discarded desert wilderness. Then follows it Hallit, which is a long black mountain without width. To its left in the inclination of the Hima is a water called Nafi, quenching four thousand houses and five thousand houses, seeping waters sipped from the gravel. Behind it is Wariyat, which are red peaks overlooking the belly of Al-Sarir. And A'shash which Al-Farazdaq mentions:
You played music at A'shash and almost did not play
And Qunwan, which are two mountain peaks. About them Al-Kilabi says:
Oh, would that I knew, has there changed after us ... landmarks between the Hima and Aban?
And has Al-Rayyan departed after its place ... and Ghawl, and is it remaining against the accidents of time?
And the Talh tree of A'shash whose shade was pleasant ... when two branches from it leaned in the forenoon
And passion had died a death due to distance ... but passion lived when Qunwan appeared
Al-Rayyan is one of the waters of Al-Dabab. To the right of Qunwan and below it is Al-Fariyah - with Fa' - a well and a thicket. And Al-Hasah, Hasat Jabalah, a great hill. In a ravine of it Banu Amir from Tamim entered in their known war, the Day of Jabalah. It has many waters. It is bordered on its left by Batn al-Sarir, which is the bottom of Wadi al-Rummah. It is cut from behind by Batn al-Sirr and its waters. It is a valley containing the waters 'Ukash, Khuff, and Al-Nataf. In its lower part are the nearest waters of Ha'il, Al-'Uwaynid, Al-A'bidah, and Makinag. Its lower part pours into Al-Qaryatayn in the middle of Al-Shawr, which is Fayf Mutayrih, its length is five miles. Then you return from Batn al-Sarir, bordered by the sand of Al-Sha'afiq on your left while you face sunrise. And Shawl. These waters are in Ghawl Talh. Between Al-Sirr and Al-Sarir is a rocky tract called Al-Khallah containing many waters, and its length is about half a day.

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Among its waters are Al-Masluq and Al-Saliyah. At its end is Al-Thabr, which is an 'Ath'athah of small disconnected sands. And a Ghawl called 'Aqil. From the waters of Al-Sarsali and Sajir, which are two waters. From the east of the Hima of waters are Al-Saqqah and Al-Khanuqah to Batn al-Rasha', which is between Al-Khanuqah and Thahlan and Ibn Dukhan. Thahlan is a mountain, and Ibn Dukhan is a mountain cut off from Thahlan. Then from the right of that are Al-Haramiyah, Al-Aswadah, Al-Hurayjah, Kunayfah, and Al-'Uwaynid. From the south of Dariyah in the Hima is Al-Kawd, a well, and it has a peak called Al-Kawd. And Madh'a and Zaqa, two waters. The poet said:
You will not reach Madh'a nor will you reach Zaqa ... nor Al-Kawd unless you wish wishes
And Dhu 'Athath, a valley. All these places are between Al-Nir and Dariyah. Al-Nir is a mountain. He said:
You will not hear the voice of the caller in the evening ... at Dhu Ghathath calling the heavy trailing ones
Al-Khuwan is a pass, and Al-Shatwan is a well. From the waters of Al-Nir are Al-Hanabij, Dhu Bahar, Al-Jathjanah, and Jafna; it has palm trees and a fortress for Banu Amr ibn Kilab. Below Jafna is Al-Ansur, which are small discarded mountains in a depression of the earth, black leaning towards redness. At the back of Al-Nir between it and the south is Batn al-'Ubra, the seeping waters of Banu Huthah, and Halaqim, a water. At the head of Al-'Ubra are Sawaj and Al-Akhraj. In Al-Akhraj is a water called Al-Dhimakh. And Batn al-Jarib, Sawqa', and Al-Mudan, Madan al-Gha'it, which is a water. And Al-Hadb, Hadb al-Qalib. And Al-Hafir, Hafir al-Dabib, and Ma'din al-Hasan. Below that is Zarba'in. We have mentioned the villages from the Hima on the road to the Highway such as Al-Athbajah and Dhu 'Aj. Among them is Al-'Ubamah, which is the old well of Al-Harith ibn 'Abbad. To its left are Al-Hadhayat and Al-Dhana'ib overlooking Al-Dathinah. And Al-Khal is a discarded black peak in front of Al-Sannajah. And Thaniyat Qadah in the Hima overlooking the head of Al-Haziz. The Hima is finished, and its end from the south is Hadb Shabib.

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Adjacent to the Hima: Batn al-Rasha', which is at the back of Thahlan to Dhat al-Nitaq. From the waters of Thahlan are Dhu Yaqn, Dhu Qalha, Al-Rayyan, Al-Kala, and Al-Shi'ra. Below that are Dhura al-Sharif, its ravines and waters. From its left are Al-Burqa'ah. Kha'i' and Al-Nashash are two waters facing Jamran, which is a small discarded mountain. Before it are Al-Samnat, Tazid, and 'Ukash, two waters. Al-Burqa'ah and Al-Nashash are two waters. Kha'i' is a water. Al-Khanfas and Khallas overlook Al-Rahat and Wadi Dhi Khashab, which is the branch of Al-'Arid into which the two Ajra's pour. Mention of Al-Khanfas from the waters of Al-Sharif, and it is from the waters of Ma'sil Jihwah. From the waters of Al-Sharif are Dhu Saqif, Al-Ja'ur - which is Al-Ja'mushah -, Tawilat al-Khatam, 'Usayr, Tahi, 'Asansar, and Tahiyah. Then Sitar al-Sharif which is at the end of Dhi Khashab. Behind it are Al-'Abla' and Al-Za'abah; they are cultivated and livestock is watered there. Then Ma'sil Jihwah, which is two fortresses, palm trees, and crops. On the left bank of Al-'Arid is the water of Tayshar in the direction of Al-Baram. Then Ma'sil al-Jumh. In its branch is a desert called Jarad and the Sand. Behind them are small red hills called Mujayrat. To their right is a hill called Hadb al-Samnat. In Al-Sharif are ravines of Talh, many beyond counting. In it are palm trees and a water called Al-Tarifah to the left of that towards the south. Whoever intends sunrise: Saliyah, Burqat al-Amhar, Al-Ghaydah, and Damkh. The waters of Damkh are Al-Kahilah and Al-Fadrah. Then the lower parts of Al-'Ubra, Al-Bayda' a water, Wara' a well, seeping waters, and Dhu Sumayr. Then Yadhbul; its first waters are Al-Qarad, Halimah, Al-'Ata'iyah a water in Batn al-Surrah, Al-Bijadah, and Al-Yatimah facing Zabn 'Amayah. 
Savad Bahilah: Its beginning is Al-Khasirah from the north, a water. Between it and the west is Al-Baram, Baram Dinnah, and Al-Mushaqqariyah, palm trees for Dinnah below that. Shamam was a great village; it is from the left bank of Al-'Arid to the descent. The two sons of Shamam are two very tall mountains overlooking Sakhin and Sukhaynah, two villages and palm trees for Bahilah. On 'Arwan and the bank, all that is villages, farms, and palm trees. Then from the villages of Bahilah are Murayfaq, 'Usayyan, Wasit, 'Uwaysijah, Al-'Awsajah, Al-Abtah, and Dhu Tuluh, at its top...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text: is the fortress of Banu 'Isam, the companion of Al-Nu'man ibn al-Mundhir. And Al-Quway' in a pass. And Juzala, Al-Thurayya, and Al-Jawza' in a valley to the right of Dhu Tuluh containing palm trees and villages. In Thaniyat al-Hafir are palm trees, and below it are Al-Muqtarib and Al-Thakhr. Then Tahfat al-Baydah, a white rocky tract containing waters, palm trees, and farms. From its waters are 'Ushayrah, Al-Kufafah, Al-Ghadiriyah, and Al-Khala'iq. To its left is Sha'b'ab, which was a village for Banu Tufayl ibn Qurrah, it and Hajir al-Milh. To the right of Savad Bahilah to Qayyah and Saqab is Batn Ha'il, which is a land like the hand of a shaker; the rider is seen in it from a distance of half a day. In its middle is a small sand dune called Ramlat al-Athar. At its top are two Sawfahs. It is bordered by the sand of Jarad, which is cut off alone between Al-Marut and Jarad. It is below the sand of Al-Sha'afiq. In it are palm trees and Nakhlah, two waters for Banu Tamim. In it is a water called Al-Suhamah. At its end is a water called Al-Hafirah, Hafirat al-Nasram, and that is when Jarad ends. Then Ramlat al-Hawamid arises following the end of the sand by a mile or more. In Ramlat al-Hamidah is a water, Al-Hamidah, salty, causing camels to have diarrhea. Then Wasit, then Al-Hajir, other than Hajir of the Highway. In it is fresh water, and in it is salt, Milh al-Hajir, a depression between dunes. In the middle of the depression is a salt marsh and hewn salt, white and red. In the middle of that is a long pool, Qrarat al-Milh; light white foam seeps from it, which is the freshest salt, so it is dried and becomes salt. Between the edges of this salt marsh and the slopes of the dunes are palm trees. Then below that in Kha'il is Sayh Ibn Murabba', which was an abundant stream then cut off due to the weakness of its people. And Batn Munaym. In Batn Munaym are salty waters, among them Al-Jad'a' at the cut of the sand opposite Quff al-Wahi. In Batn Munaym are many salty waters, among them Sawqa', Al-Dubayb, Qani, and Al-Huwwah. They are bitter waters (Ma'j), neither salty nor fresh. They are opposite Quff Marid intercepting between the passes, the passes of the valleys Hunayzilah, Ni'am, and Birk, and between Batn Ha'il and Al-'Arid, which is a weak small rocky tract, wide at the tops. We returned to the rest of Al-Baydah; it borders Al-Rayb, which is a spacious, huge valley.

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text: In it are clans from Qushayr: Murayh in Al-Kadid, which is the bottom of Wadi al-Rayb. In its middle are Banu Haydah. In its top are Al-'Ubaydat and a part of Banu Qurrah. In its top is a valley called 'Anan and Al-'Udhayb, palm trees and a village. Between it and Savad Bahilah is a water called Al-Ghabah, palm trees. Al-Rayb is bordered on its left by a mountain called Mount 'Ariqah and Safa Umm Sabbar. Behind that in the area of Al-Baydah is a water called Al-Shatur. Then Batn al-'Amq, in it are the seeping waters of Ibn Ba'ja' and Al-Mabhalah, which are filthy salty waters. And Qarn Zabi and Zarrah, two hills, one black and the other red. To the left of that is Al-Qatad, which is a black mountain containing fresh waters: Dhimakh and 'Anzah. And villages opposite it from Al-Hadb, Al-Ajribah, Sudayrat Qasas, and Al-Dhimakh. These four waters are fresh and the rest are salty. Al-Mabhalah was named so because whoever drinks from it defecates in his trousers or loincloth, passing through it. Then above that, bordering Al-Rayb to the lands of Bahilah, Al-Dawahi, which is a spacious land with no pairings. Then Al-Qara', which pours into Batn al-Siradah opposite Al-Qihad. Between Shatt al-Siradah and Al-Qihad is a plain called Al-Malatit, singular Al-Miltat, a plain cut between it and its like by the conjunction of mountains. At the branch of the pass, Thaniyat al-Sud, Sud Bahilah. To its right before the pass is a water called Al-Mughayra, and a great village called Al-'Awsajah, which is a mine. Likewise Shamam is a silver mine and a copper mine. There were thousands of Magians working the mine, and there were two Fire Temples worshiped. The pass, Thaniyat Hisn Ibn 'Isam, is a gold mine. Al-Falaj is a pole and what is around it is a circle. From sunrise of it is Al-Bayad, then the sand, Raml al-Kadid. It is between it and Yabrin, and there is no water between them for three days and nights in Al-Dahna'. Behind Yabrin and Al-Khunn is sand to Oman, continuous, not trodden by Abu Malik. The highway of Oman in this sand takes to Yabrin and to Al-Khunn. From the north of Al-Falaj is a valley called Shatab, between it and Al-Yamamah. Whoever takes Al-Bayad and Al-Barq arrives at a pond of water called...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text: ...Al-Hazmah. Then Al-Hayfanah, a water. Then he descends into Hawjan. His path is on Al-Thadyayn, two peaks white at the bottom, black at the top, as if they were a woman's breasts. And Kabid, a black overlooking hill called Kabid al-Bayad between Najaf al-Aghwarah and Al-Bayad. Whoever takes from Al-Falaj to Al-Yamamah traverses the high ground (intajafa), so he drinks only at a water called Al-'Uqaymah in Batn al-Najaf, or Mukhamisah, which is a water at the edge of Fatman at the branch of Al-Mughsil. To its left are Buraq Shi'ara leading to Qa' al-Dahiyah to Hisn Sayh al-Ghamr. Whoever takes Al-Thafn from Al-Falaj to Al-Yamamah takes the lower parts of the valleys of Ja'dah. The valleys, the first of them is Akamah pouring onto Al-Falaj. So the morning traveler takes the lower part of Al-Ghayl from Al-Thafn, which is a spacious valley with many palm trees and many fortresses. Its branch is Al-Sudarah. Then he crosses Ghulghul, Al-Thujjah, and Al-Nash. If he wishes, he drinks at Dalamis, then Naslah, then Al-Kharj. If he wishes, he drinks at Al-Mira', then Birk, then Burak. Then he takes to Al-Majazah and Ijlah in those lands. Among the valleys that pour into Al-Kharj are Dhu Arwal, Ma'wan, Tamr, and Qilab. All that descends into Al-Kharj gathering into one valley. Wadi al-Mughsil covers it from below. The sand borders it in which is Naqa al-'Azzaf overlooking Al-Kharj. Between Al-Majazah and Al-Kharj is a small sand dune called Sulaysilah, its width is a mile. Al-Salasil of sand are small dunes with no gap between them. From the Qibla of Al-Falaj is the branch of Wadi Akamah, and in it are Banu Abdullah ibn Ja'dah. The first part of it is Al-Rawqiyah, the second is Al-Bahah, then the part of Al-Zahirah, then Al-Far'ah, then Karaz to the right of the pass. Then you descend from the pass; at its base is a water called Al-Nabjah on your right while you intend the west. Then below that in the hollow, Jawf al-Thaniyah, is a water called Wahah. Then in the lining of Al-'Arid on its right are two close waters called Awan and Al-Hayyaniyah between Al-'Arid and Al-Dabil. Al-Dabil is a compacted sand; on its back are waters we have mentioned. In its middle are waters, among them Al-Hudhayqah and two other waters, Al-Ra'ighah and Taraf, and at Taraf another small water. Then you proceed as if you want Mecca, so straight in front of your face is a salty water called: Al-Dahiyah. Then on the belly of the Mecca road, Al-Nadariyah, fresh water...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
...then Al-Ukhrabah, which is in the hollows of 'Amayah. Then you go out into a hot desert after having crossed 'Amayah the Left and Right on your right and crossed gaps of small black reeds facing each other. In the 'Amayat are waters, among them Al-Shakul, Tarif, and Ahsa' al-Thumam. Then you come to Al-Ahsa', Ahsa' Murtafaq. Then you enter into crests belonging to Banu Hayal, ridges in which is a water called Al-'Usayr. Then Al-Muhdath, Muhdath Namla. We returned to the other road. You take to Al-Haddar, Haddar Banu al-Harish. The first part in it is Al-Qatniyah for Banu Khaldah from Al-Harish. Then Al-Aqtan for Banu Khalid. Then Al-Far'ah for Banu Rabi'ah. And Al-Hashraj for Banu al-Mujarr, whom Antara means:
And the last of them, I dragged my spear [in him]
Then Al-Nutaj, which are hills in the front of the mouth of Al-Haddar for one intending Al-Dabil. Then you cross Al-Dabil, crossing the rope (Habl), which is the sand. The first drinking place on this highway is a water for Jarm called Mumkin. Then they take to Qarn Uhamir and face Al-Saqib, Saqib al-Dakhul. On their right are the peaks of Ghamrat and Batn al-Raka'. In its middle is Al-Dakhul, a water near Safa al-Atit and Hadb Dhi Iqdam. The head of Suham appears to you. These are the places about which Imru' al-Qays says:
To whom belong the dwellings I recognized at Suham ... then the two 'Amayahs, then Hadb Dhi Iqdam
Then Safa al-Atit, then the two Sahahs, then 'Asim ... the ewes walk in them with the gazelles
At the bank of Ghamrah next to Al-Raka' are bound seeping waters. You come to Al-Dakhul, and it has a landmark called Mankhar Hadbah. Then you fall into the sand of Abdullah ibn Kilab. Then you come to Al-Akhdar at the bottom of Wadi Turabah. Then Bisha if you turn left. If you turn right, then to Buraym and its waters which we named previously: Al-Baqarah, Nasihah, Dhat al-Riqa', Dhawat al-Far'a', Hadb al-Himarah - which are two waters -, and Hadb al-Awqab, Awqab Banu al-A'lam. All that is deviating from the road, descending from Mecca, between Ghamrah and Batn al-Aqiq. In the middle of Al-Surrah from the land of Banu Kilab and from the dwellings of Lubayna from Qushayr: Al-Yankir, which is a smooth peak with no path in it. In it are spring waters and a 'Add water called...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
...Hanjran. To the right of Al-Yankir are waters leading to Al-Yankir, among them Al-Risal, Risal Tayas, which is a huge black peak. And the sand of Batn al-Surrah behind Bijad, which is the attributed sand of Tayas. In it is the well of Al-'Ala' ibn al-Hadrami, the companion of the Messenger of Allah "peace be upon him". And a water called Al-Nahiqah. And Al-Laqitah, a water. And Al-Qa'nabiyah. Then Batn al-Siradah. Below Tayas is Al-Dariyah to the end of Al-Qatad. At Al-Qatad is a water called Al-Akbad. We returned to Al-Falaj: The blowing of the South wind from it are Al-Madhar' [farms?]. From it is Al-Midhra', Midhra' Banu Qushayr for Banu Abdullah ibn Salamah and Sudayy ibn Iyad from Banu al-Harish. Then Al-Shatbatan, which are palm trees and waters for Banu al-Harish. Then a well on the bank of Al-Bayad from the back of Al-Bayad. Then you pass Qurun, which is a weak water. Then Hammam, a water. Then the bank of Banu al-Karrawsh from Banu Qurt from Al-Muqtarib. To its right is Tamrah and Al-Haliqah, which is in the middle of Al-Ghada between Al-'Aqiq and Al-Muqtarib. Then Al-'Aqiq, a city with two hundred Jews, many palm trees, flowing streams, and wells. Then Al-Ghada. Then Al-Khall, Khall al-Qaswah. Then the Mine, Ma'din al-'Aqiq. Then what took to Al-Hujayrah. Before that are Al-Hathbariyah and Al-Rakhmah, two waters in the channels of Jash. Then you returned to the road from Al-Muqtarib wanting Yemen intending Najran, so you drink at Hisy Kabab, about which Marwan ibn Abi Hafsah says:
The white camels have ascended Al-Dabil and left behind ... Batn al-'Aqiq with us and Hisy Kabab
If you turn right, you drink ancient water called Qaryah; beside it are ancient wells and a church carved in the rock. Then you come to Thajr, a water about which Al-Majnun says:
My two friends, if my death comes, raise ... the bier with me until you bury me at Thajr
Then Hima, Al-Wihaf, Bi'r al-Rabi', then Midhwad from the bottom of Najran. If you turn left, you ascend Al-Bayad then drink at Al-Hafar, Hafar al-Tharba'. On both roads you cross the sand of Hafil. If there is water in Ghadir al-Tanahi, you drink it; otherwise, there is no drink except at Bi'r al-Rabi'. As for Al-An'am, Al-Ana'im, and Sulaymanin, they are in the middle of Al-Hamadah. And Nawa'im is in Damkh. Al-An'am is also a valley pouring from...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
...Hadbat 'Arwa to Bi'r al-Muntahabah. The two small reeds (Al-Qusaybatan) mentioned in the news of Banu Wa'il are Qasabat al-Ragham. Al-Ragham is a collection, from it are Sufuh, Arta'ah, Al-Baradan, and Al-Tawil; all this has many palm trees. Rumaylah is Ramlat al-Ragham overlooking Tharmada'. And Qasabat Ibn Khawli in Al-Hamadah. And Batn Nu'man in Al-Yankir. And Batn Nu'man between Ta'if and Arafah. Nu'man is also a valley pouring onto Sa'ifayn from the left of the mouth of Nisah; they are two waters. In the mouth of Nisah is a water called Al-Wakhra'. And Qarar al-Na'am, Ramlat al-Yatimah, Al-Rakhimah, Al-Nahiyah, and Washal al-Dhi'b are waters surrounding a meadow called Rawdat Umm al-Mahal to Far' Malak to Thaniyat al-Najd to Qararat al-Mudhnib from Ramlat al-Warkah. In Ramlat al-Warkah is a fold of many palm trees. And Qarat al-Ma'aniq; the road takes upon them from Mecca to Hajr. From Al-Arid is a valley called Tawlab, and Wadi Hunayzilah pours into the branch of Ni'am. Tawlab pours into Nisah. The branch of Ma'wan which pours onto Al-Kharj is named Al-'Alah. In Al-'Alah are springs to which the ibexes, the Thaytal, and the Thaytalah flood. 'Aqil opposite Al-Nir. From Al-Dahna' is Al-Wahid, a disconnected dune overlooking the two excavations of Banu Sa'd. And Raml Wahhabin to the right of the two excavations leading to Al-Samman. Hazwa is a disconnected solitary long dune. And Al-Hasan is a beautiful blackish disconnected dune. And Utum and Al-Karazim are tall facing dunes. And Armah are tall sharp dunes. And Liwa Rimah below them. All this is from Al-Dahna'. Al-Marrut is between Ha'il and Al-Warkah. It is a flattened rocky tract. At its top are the depression and waters. From the first of its waters are Tibrak and Munbih, then Ahwa, then Al-'Uwaynid, and waters called Al-Abat, Abtah and Abt al-Ramlah. In it are a depression of plants and salty plants.
Mines of Al-Yamamah and the dwellings of Rabi'ah which Uqayl ibn Ka'b has settled today: Ma'din al-Hasan. Al-Hasan is a beautiful black peak, and it is an abundant gold mine. Ma'din al-Hafir in the area of 'Amayah, an abundant gold mine. Ma'din al-Dabib to the left of Hadb al-Qalib. Ma'din al-Thaniyah, Thaniyat Ibn 'Isam al-Bahili, a gold mine. Ma'din al-'Awsajah from the land of Ghani above Al-Mughira in Batn...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
...Al-Siradah. Al-Mughira is the water where it is said Sha's ibn Zuhayr ibn Tha'labah ibn al-A'raj al-Ghanawi was shot. Opposite Al-Mughira is a peak called Al-Watidah in the belly of the valley. Ma'din Shamam of silver and copper. Ma'din Tayas, gold hidden in Tayas. Ma'din al-'Aqiq. Ma'din al-Mahajjah between Al-'Amq and Ufay'iyah. Ma'din Bisha. Ma'din al-Hujayrah. And Ma'din Banu Sulaym. These are the mines of Najd.

Rains of these Lands
The Wasmi (early spring rain) is the first of them. Its Anwa' (stars/periods) are Pisces (Al-Hut), Cancer (Al-Saratan), Al-Butayn, Pleiades (Al-Thurayya), Aldebaran (Al-Dabaran), Al-Haq'ah, and Al-Han'ah, if they rise at nightfall or their opposites rise in the morning. Then follows it the Rabi' (spring rain) from Al-Dhira' to Al-Simak. Then the Sayf (summer rain) from Al-Simak to Al-Na'a'im. Then the Kharif (autumn rain) from Al-Na'a'im to Pisces. There is no rain there after that.

Musical Sounds (Ma'azif) of the Jinn in this Earth
Raml Hawda, Raml al-Mughsil, and Al-Sumayriyah - and it is said at the two dogs overlooking Al-Kharj. Dil' al-Kharijah is one of the known places of Jinn music. And Jinn of Al-Badi - and Al-Badi is one of the waters of Al-Dabab. And Al-Baqqar and 'Abqar. And most of the land of Wabar. And Dhi Simar; the Jinn of Dhi Simar are used as a proverb. And Ghul al-Rabadat. And Ba'dar Milh and Lahj.

Places of Winds
The most windy of these places are Al-Khadramah in Al-Yamamah and at Al-Falaj. And at Hali in the land of Kinanah. And at Al-Bawn in the land of Hamdan and lower Al-Jawf. Al-Dahna' is fasting (calm) forever; there are no winds in it except the breathing of the hot wind (Samum) at middays, with the stagnant mirage and the glowing haze in all these places, which is what aligns with Taurus and Gemini.
Description of the Winds of the Directions and Corners: The winds of the East are Al-Qabul, which is Al-Saba. Opposite it from the West is Al-Dabur. The South (Al-Janub) blows from Yemen, and the North (Al-Shamal) faces it from the direction of Sham. The domain of the South is called Al-Taymana, and the domain of the North Al-Jarbiya. What blows between the South and Al-Qabul is Al-Nakba'. What is between the South and Al-Dabur is Al-Dajin. What is between the North and Al-Dabur, facing Al-Nakba', is Azyab. What is between the North and Al-Qabul, facing Al-Dajin, is Al-Harjaf. Between Al-Qabul and Al-Nakba' is Al-Badhakhsh, which is the dead wind. Between Al-Dajin and Al-Dabur... Between Al-Dabur and Azyab...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
...Al-Saruf. Between the North and Al-Harjaf is the Barren Wind (Al-Rih al-'Aqim). Twelve winds for twelve signs.

The Salty Waters
Al-Dabil is salty from beginning to end. Al-Hudhayqah, Al-Rabighah, Sabib, Al-Huwwah, and the waters of Al-Sharabah. About them Al-Harith ibn Zalim says:
If you had obeyed your 'Amr (life/command), you would be among them ... and I would not have found myself seeking clouds
Nor would I have been a guest of Al-Sharrabah every year ... cutting off the flies at its wells
Salty wells in a bad rocky ground ... their drinkers spend the night thirsty, hungry
From the salty waters of Al-'Aqiq are Al-Manhalah and Al-Na'jawi. From the salty ones are Al-'Ubamah, Al-Thu'al, Al-Baghra, Ahsa' Banu Juwayyah, Yanufat Khanthal, Nadihah, Al-Baqarah, Al-Najliyah, Al-Naqrah, and Al-Majazah - the crossing of the road other than Majazat al-Yamamah - between Ijlah and Al-Far'ah. The waters of Al-Hamadah are salty: Najil, Najlah, Al-Abat, Al-Hafirah, Al-Hamidah, and Sha'b'ab. The waters of Munaym except Al-Jad'a'. And Ma' Yafa', Birk, Awan, Al-Khayaniyah, Al-Nahiqah, Al-Laqitah, and what Badhran possessed. Then Qubbat Aram to Khalafah. 'Amayah is all fresh. Al-Qataniyah is salty in Batn al-Surrah.
As for the salt that is mined, it is Sabah al-Hajir, Milh al-Mutlafiyah, Milh al-Qusaybah, Milh Yabrin, and salt in the region of Bahrain. In the tops of mountains is hewn red salt in veins. These are the salts of the people of Najd. As for the salt of Yemen, it is from the Salt Mountain in Ma'rib, and salt at Al-Qammah of Tihamah in the area of Mawr and Al-Mahjam. Many of the waters of Tihamah are salty, including Al-Ma'jar, Al-Jibal, Al-Hutiyyah, and Jaww Hali. Everything near the coast is entirely salty except a little.

Vegetation of the Land of Najd
Of all trees, if the Samr gathers in a place, it is Al-Harajah. If the Salam gathers in a place, it is Darib al-Salam, and it is Al-Darib. If the Talh gathers in a place, it is Al-Ghawl, and its plural is Al-Ghilan, and it is said singular Ghal. If the 'Urfut gathers in a place, it is Sahb al-'Urfut. If it is mixed from all that in a place...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
...it is Al-Khalitah. If the Sarh gathers in a place, it is called Wadi al-Sarh. If the Sidr - which is Dum and 'Ilb - gathers in a place, it is called Al-Mari'. The Rajiz said:
As if they were at Al-Mari' of the Dum ... ostriches upon which the people performed Hajj
If the Thumam and Da'ah gather in a place, it is Al-'Uqdah, 'Uqdat al-Thumam and 'Uqdat al-Da'ah. If the 'Arfaj gathers in a place, it is Al-Hajir, and its plural is Al-Hujran. Al-Tandub is similar to Shawhat; it only grows on mountain tops. If the Nasi gathers in a place, it is called Hajir al-Nasi. Safhat al-Nasi if it is in a place. Hajl al-Nasi is what is of the growing places of Nasi in the sand and lowlands (Hajul). If Athl gathers in a place, it is Maghrin. If Ghaf gathers in a place, it is Makan al-Ghaf. If Arak gathers in a spot, it is Al-Gharif. What gathers of Arak and others is Aykah. If the thorny trees ('Idah) intertwine so what is under them does not see sun, it is 'Ishshah.

Names of Herbs until that which dries and breaks in Najd
Al-'Arqasan, Al-Baql, Al-Dharaq, Al-Ya'did, Al-Maknan, Al-Shaqara, Al-Khamkham, Al-Yanamah, Al-Zubad, Al-Safra', Al-Qaf'a', Al-Harbath, Al-Saql, Al-Hafnah, Al-Ghurayra, Al-Uqhuwan (Chamomile), Al-Khuzama (Lavender). Al-Rafraf is what is close of herb plants and connected to each other. Al-Hanwah, Al-Karish, Al-Sam'a', then it dries so it is Al-Bahma, and it is also Al-'Arab. Al-Rabbah, Al-Habbah, Al-Da'a', Al-Qatt. Al-Riqqa is from the pasture that its root does not perish and revives every year with rain and sprouts in the cold parts of the earth without rain (yatarabbal) - meaning it flourishes as if it rained. Most of it is in the sand. Al-Thada', Al-Makr, Al-Khatrah, Al-Nasi, Al-Sabat, Al-Qasba, Al-Kiryah, Al-Jalab, Al-Rukhama, Al-Da'ah, Al-Nasi, Al-Thagham, Al-Saham, Al-Ghadur, Al-Tanum, Al-Thumam - which is Al-Jalil -, Al-'Arfaj, Al-Siha, Al-Hayshar. These things exclude Nashir al-Riqqa, and the first is the Herbs (Al-'Ushb). From the herbs also: Al-Hawwa', Al-Qatbah, Al-Ham'ah, Al-Thaghr. From Al-Riqqa...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
...also: Al-Shih (Mugwort), Al-Qasis, Al-Qaysum (Southernwood), Al-Khallah, Al-Haj, Al-Hadh, Al-Sulh. The Salty Plants (Al-Humud): Al-Ghada, Al-Rimth, Al-'Arad, Al-'Asal, Al-Fassah, Al-Tahmah, Al-Sahmah, Al-Qarmal, Al-Ukhrit, Al-'Anzuwan, Al-Hurud - which is Al-Ushnan (Potash) -, Al-Qasqas, Al-Rughl - which is the best salty plant. If camels graze on salty plants, they are called Hawamid. If they graze on pasture whatever it may be, they are called Mukhillah. The best camel milk is if they graze on salty plants: Rughl, 'Arad, and Rimth. Milk from salty plants tends to be thin. The thickest camel milk is if they graze on herbs or Siha. The bitterest is if they graze on Murar, and Murar is of the herbs.

Descriptions of the Spots of the Land of Najd and Others
Al-Ard al-Qawa' (The Desolate Land) which has no people in it, and likewise the Manzil al-Qawa' (Desolate Dwelling). Aqwat al-Bilad (The lands became desolate), and it is Al-Qayy, and its inhabitant is Muqwi. Al-Qull, which rain has not hit. Al-Khasibah (The Fertile), which has pasture. It is called Jadub (Barren), Mumhilah (Drought-stricken), and Musnitah (Famine-stricken) if it has no pasture. Ard Sanah (Year/Drought Land) and Ard Sunun. Ard Murti'ah (Grazing Land) if it has pasture. Ard Muhyiya if it has life (rain/growth). Mujdibah if it is barren of pasture. Among the names of the land: Al-Sahb, which is the land [Al-Sanawi?] and has little diverse vegetation. Al-Hazm is what rose above the ground. Al-Hazn is what is rough of the ground. Al-Nafanif is what is far-flung of the land with elevation and depression. Al-Qaradid are the heads of the rough grounds. Al-Fadafid is what rose from the ground. Al-Sabasib is what extended from the ground and leveled. Al-Basabis is like it, reversed, and they are the Qifar (Wastelands). Al-Qifar are those with no people, and it is Qafr. Al-Madhanib are what was of the valleys of the depression that are in the sand because it is the path of the water of the depression exiting from it. Al-Tanahi is what the water ends at from the sand and becomes confused without a passage. Shiqaq al-Raml is what separated from the leveled sands (Dakadik) between the rope (Habl). They are Al-Dakadik and Al-Hujul also. Al-Jiwa' are hollows in the middle of the ropes of sand, collapsed in the sand; nothing falls into them but perishes. They remain so forever, and there are no outlets for their water. We have mentioned Al-'Atha'ith and Al-Salasil. Al-Sahra' (Desert) is the level land. Ashara al-Qawm means they emerged into the Qa' (open plain). Al-'Ara' is what is bared...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
...from the land of the coast from the sea water. Al-'Ara' in the sea is the place with little water. Al-Suhun and Al-Sahasih are what leveled of the ground and rounded. Al-Damath are the soft parts of the ground mixed with easy sand. Al-Jarathim are what the winds wrapped around the roots of trees of dust. Al-Sahlah, Al-Jar'a', and Al-Ajra' are level land of pure ease without gravel (Barq). 'Ajamat al-Raml, plural 'Ajam al-Raml and 'Ijam, is what rose in the sky and did not grow trees. If it grew trees and it is 'Ajmah, it is called Al-'Ajmah al-Sha'ra' (Hairy 'Ajmah). Al-Da's is the red dune that does not grow, plural Di'as, Da'sah, and Ad'as. Al-Naqa is the pure sand. Al-'Aqd is what was tall of sand and had no path or gaps. Al-Fawz and Al-Qizan are what was tall of sand with a gap between them. Al-Wa'as, singular Wa'sa', and the lower parts of the ropes (Hibal) are the Ahayl Al-Amayl (loose shifting sand) in which feet and hooves of beasts sink. Al-Dahas is what struck from the lower parts of sand to the black ground. Al-Faf is what was of a wide-fronted valley and [Al-Laqam?]. Of the land, Al-Samra' and Al-Sal'a' is that which does not grow, and it is Al-Hassa. Al-Ama'iz, singular Am'az and Am'uz, is what had pebbles in it. Al-Marwah, which is Al-A'abil also, singular A'bal, and it is Al-'Abla' also. Al-Hizabi is what rose and lowered like the hills (Akam). The Rajiz said:
If I do not task you with the ruggedness of the hills ... and the night journey, then single me out for blame
Al-Tall, plural Al-Tulul, is what rose of transported dust. Al-Jabnun and Al-Jamhur are what rose from the ground and whitened. Al-Thawr is the peak that has whiteness in its head. Al-Thawr is a piece of dried yogurt (Aqit). Al-Barqah is the easy mixed with stones, plural Baraq. Al-Abariq are the Abariq of pure sand; they were named Abariq for the flashing of their heat, their purity, and height. The single Abraq is what its bottom is easy, its middle is rock, and its top is easy. Al-Gha'it of the land is what has no water. Al-Ruba is what rose from the easy land, singular Rabwah and Rabiyah. Al-Fand is a piece of the mountain. Al-Ru'n is its body. The roots of the mountains are Al-Mana. Al-Hadid, Al-Hadn, Al-Jarr, and Al-Jalam are the edges of the mountains, Al-Na'ifah, where the length is cut off and ends.

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Description of Al-Arud from the Arabian Peninsula

Al-Falaj is from Al-Arud regarding the composition of the inhabitant. It is a country whose lords are Ja'dah, Qushayr, and Al-Harish Banu Ka'b; Al-Harish are the least of the groups. It is called Falaj for its splitting (Infilaj) by water, meaning its opening. The Falajan are two mountains in Ma'rib with a path between them. From that, the gap-toothed mouth is called Muflaj and Aflaj. 'Falajtu bi-hujjati' means I made it clear and cut off my right with it. Like the two Falajs in Ma'rib are the Ma'ziman at Jam' between Mina and Arafat, which are two mountains with a strait between them. Therefore, biting is called Azm, and the biting year for wealth is Al-Azum, which is the Crisis (Azmah). Azm is restriction and closing the mouth on the molars. Al-Harish is in a valley of Al-Falaj called Al-Haddar, containing palm trees and crops on wells and camels drawing water. Al-Harish has decreased in it and dispersed, and many of them neighbored in Yemen. In Al-Haddar is the fortress of Musa ibn Numayr al-Harishi, the fortress of Abu Samrah, and a fortress whose name slipped my mind.

As for Qushayr, it is in Al-Madhar', and in it are fortresses, palm trees, crops, and the stream (Sayh) runs under the palm trees, and wells also. The first of the fortresses of Banu Qushayr in Al-Midhra' is the fortress of Al-'Aqidah of Banu Farash; its people are the Jafnah (Bowl/Generous) of Al-Falaj, noble faces, numerous. And the fortress of the Samariyyin, who are Banu Abi Samrah from Ja'dah. And the fortress of the Farashiyyin from Banu Farash. And the fortress of Banu Iyad - and Iyad is from Al-Harish - in Sada' of Al-Madhar'. And the fortress of Banu Yabit from Banu Qurrah in Sada' of Al-Madhar'. And the fortress of Al-'Adiyah in Al-Safiyah for Banu Sawadah from Qushayr, and they are of rising lineages. And the fortress of the family of Shibl in Al-Safiyah also from Banu Huraym. And the fortress of Banu al-Najwa from Banu Huraym. And the fortress of Umm al-Hajjal al-Huraymi. And the fortress of Al-Hajjal ibn al-Anbar al-Huraymi. And the fortress of the family of Dirar from Banu Huraym. And the fortresses of Banu Thawr. And the fortress of Banu Suhayb in Akamah. And the fortress of Banu Qurt from Qushayr. In Al-Madhar' and others are citadels (Qasab) smaller than fortresses, small, called Al-Thunayya. From them is a citadel fought over. And from them is the citadel of Al-Sha'ami, the citadel of the family of Rukayz, the fortress of Banu Abdullah from the family of Hayyan, and the citadel of 'Umaythal. All this is in Al-Madhar'.

As for the land of Ja'dah ibn Ka'b, from it on the side of the fortress...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
...of Al-Ahabish from Qushayr and Al-Haysamiyah for Banu Suhayb from Banu Qushayr, which is a fortified city; four horses can gallop on its wall, and the high shooter with an arrow struggles to reach its top.

As for what is obtained from the abode of Ja'dah, it is Suq al-Falaj (Market of Falaj), which Nizar and Yemen market in. It belongs to Banu Abi Samrah from Ja'dah. Then following it from the two streams of Ja'dah is a fortress called Murghim, meaning it humiliates (Yurghim) the enemy by its impregnability against him. It belongs to Banu Abi Samrah. And the Ancient Palace (Al-Qasr al-'Adi) from the era of Tasm and Jadis. Its description is that its builder built a fortress of clay thirty cubits [high], packed it, then built the fortress upon it. Around it are dwellings for the retinue of the chief who is in it, and tamarisk and palm trees. Its inhabitant today is Banu Abi Shamsah. Suq al-Falaj has iron gates upon it. The thickness of its wall is thirty cubits, and the trench surrounds it. It is belted with plaster, stones, and mortar a fathom and a span, for fear that it be besieged or the streams be released upon it by the enemy. Inside the market are two hundred and sixty wells, their water is sweet fresh resembling rain water and does not recede, and four hundred shops. Banu Ja'dah have two streams called: one Al-Raqqadi and the other Al-Atlas. As for the stream of Qushayr, its name is Sayh Ishaq. As for Al-Raqqadi, its outlet is from a spring called Ayn Ibn Asma' and from a spring called Ayn al-Zabba', mixed together. As for Al-Atlas, its outlet is from a spring called Ayn al-Naqah. The people of Al-Falaj say regarding the derivation of this name that a woman passed by it on a she-camel of hers, and the she-camel plunged with her into the hollow of the spring. It emerged after her bracelet in the river Muhallim in Hajar of Bahrain. Muhallim is a great river; it is said that Tubba' descended upon it and it awed him. It is said that it is in the land of the Arabs like the river of Balkh in the land of the non-Arabs. The rest of Banu Ja'dah are in a land called Akamah, having palm trees, crops, wells, and fortresses. The remaining of Banu Ja'dah are in a land called Al-Ghayl, having crops, wells, and fortresses. And in Ghulghul. And Al-Thujjah in the land of Najd mentioned by Al-Rada'i, and Al-Thujjah is in Al-Suhul of Yemen. And in Haradah. Then beyond that are paths and lands such as Bark and Burayk without Alif and Lam. In Harrat Kinanah of Tihamah are Al-Bark and Al-Burayk. The Rajiz said:
Go away, you have crossed the land ... Al-Bark, Al-Burayk, and Al-Mu'aqqad

and Al-Majazah and Ijlah. Al-Jarmi said: Ijlah belongs to Jarm below Burayk, and Al-Majazah belongs to Banu Hazzan. He said: And Upper Burayk belongs to Banu Nufay', who are from Banu Shayban, and to the family of Al-Mugharrab and the family of Abu Qurrah. And Akamah belongs to Banu Abdullah ibn Ja'dah. And Al-Ghayl belongs to Abdullah ibn Ja'dah. And Ni'am is known to belong to the family of Rashid from the Bedouins of Banu Ubayd. And Al-Qusur and Al-Shuwayq belong to the Samarat. And Al-Haysamiyyah belongs to Qushayr, and Al-Jadwal, higher than it, belongs to Banu Qushayr. And Al-Faqi belongs to the family of Hammad from Tamim. Al-Ha'it belongs to Banu Tamim. Ahmad ibn al-Hasan al-Adi al-Falaji said: The sand of Al-Da'bil is behind Al-Arid, the Arid of Al-Yamama [Jabal Tuwaiq], and Al-Dabil borders what is between Al-Yamama and Najran. Ibn Abi Hafsa said on the day he came to Ma'n in Yemen from Al-Yamama: 'Were it not for hope in you, my she-camel would not have crossed... The breadth of Al-Dabil nor the villages of Najran.'
