He said: And the sand of Al-Dahna is between Al-Yamama and Basra, coming from Oman and going towards the west aiming for Egypt. As for the sand called Raml Haqqan, it is between Najran and Al-Aqiq. Names of the dates of Al-Falaj: Al-Sufri is the master of dates, because it is immersed in the sea (water), so all dates dissolve except Al-Sufri. Then Al-Sarri, then Al-Lasaf, then Al-Fahahil, then Al-Mujtana, then Al-Ja'adi, then Al-Shamarihk, then Al-Mushamrakh, then Al-Sarfan, then Al-Bayad, then Al-Sawad—and they are many colors. Then Al-Barni, and it has fat (ihalah) and grease (jamil) like the grease of a fat ram, and wine is not made from the like of it. Al-Falaj has good food, no harmful things in it, and no epidemic. Some of their poets say about it: 'Greet the land of Al-Aqiq and Al-Falaj... The eye, and in the eye is what prolongs my living. A land where no gnat harms you... Scratching the face, nor the difference of the rumen (stomach ailment).' Al-Yamama: The land of Al-Yamama is Hajar [Riyadh area], which is its metropolis and center, and the residence of the emirs from it, and to it things are brought. Then Jaww, which is Al-Khadramah, which is Al-Yamama; it is a day and a night from Hajar. In it are Banu Suhaym, Banu Thumamah, Banu Amir ibn Hanifa, and Banu Ijl. And Al-Arad, which is a valley in Al-Yamama from its top to its bottom, and in it are villages...

...inhabited by Banu Hanifa. Its lowest part is Al-Karsh, a village with Banu Adi ibn Hanifa. Next to it is a village called Manfuhah [Manfuha, Saudi Arabia], belonging to Banu Qays ibn Tha'labah. Above that is a village called Wabrah, with people from the Bedouins. Above that is a village called Al-Awqah, with people from Banu Adi ibn Hanifa. Above that is a village called Ghabra', with Banu al-Harith ibn Maslamah ibn Ubayd. Above that is a village called Mahshamah and Al-Ammariyyah joined to it, belonging to Banu Abdullah ibn al-Du'l. Above that is a village called Fayshan, with Banu Amir ibn Hanifa. Above that is a village called Abad, where the battle of Khalid ibn al-Walid and Musaylimah took place, belonging to Banu Adi ibn Hanifa. Above that is a village called Al-Haddar, with Banu Haffan ibn al-Harith ibn al-Du'l. Above that is another valley called Wadi Qarran, and in it is a village called Qarran [Al-Qarah/Al-Ghat?], which Alqama ibn Abadah means by his saying: 'A thorn like the staff of the Nahdi, inserted for it... Possessing return from the kernels of Qarran, chewed.' In this village Qarran are Banu Suhaym. Below it is a village called Malham [Malham, Saudi Arabia]. Muraqqish said: 'Or did the litter-borne women grieve you... Coming early like the palm trees of Malham.' Tarafa said: 'And the women of the tribe circling around him... Saying: Is Asib from the best part of Malham?' In it are Banu Ghubbar from Yashkur. Above that is a village called Al-Qurrayah, with Banu Sadus ibn Shayban ibn Dhuhl ibn Tha'labah. On the other side of Al-Yamama is a village called Al-Majazah, with Banu Hazzan from Anazah. Next to it is a village called Mawan, with Banu Hazzan and Banu Rabi'a, people from Al-Namir ibn Qasit. The nearest part of Al-Yamama for one intending it from Iraq is a village called Banban [Banban, Saudi Arabia], with people from Banu Sa'd ibn Zayd Manat ibn Tamim. Among those who inhabited Al-Haddar are Banu Dhuhl. In Aqraba' [Aqraba, Saudi Arabia] of Al-Arad are the graves of the martyrs; Aqraba' today belongs to Banu Bakr from Banu Zalim from Numayr. Al-Naqb belongs to Banu Adi ibn Hanifa, and Tal'at ibn Ata', which belongs to Banu Amir ibn Hanifa. Al-Sadusiyyah belongs to Banu Sa'd, and it is Hazwa, and I think it is the one...

...meant by Dhu al-Rummah in his saying: 'My soul heaved [at] the depression of Mushrif... And the day of the bend of Hazwa, so I said to it: Patience.' Al-Khadramah was ruled after Banu Ubayd of Hanifa by the family of Abu Hafsa, then Al-Ukhaydir ibn Yusuf the Alawite overcame it and inhabited it. Al-Dabi'ah belongs to Banu Qays. Al-Malha' belongs to Banu Qays. Al-Kharj belongs to Banu Qays. Al-Nuqayrah and Al-Uwaynid from Ala al-Jabih of Al-Yamama belong to Banu Khadij from Tamim. The Well of Al-Nuqayr in the region of Bahrain also has ten pulleys (qiyam), never exhausted, and many of the Arab water-seekers gather at it; perhaps ten thousand camels are watered at it, then they all depart from it quenched, and it is a abundant, old well (Hasif Qalaydham). Arid al-Yamama is a mountain, a journey of days; from it is Qaddah of Banu Bakr and Taghlib, which is today Al-Tahaliq. Al-Jarmi said: Al-Majazah from the land of Al-Yamama belongs to Banu Sali, Banu Subayh, and Banu Kabir from Jarm. As for Sali, he is the son of Jarm Kabr (Great Jarm?); Banu Kabir are from Al-Hun; and Subayh is a clan of Sali. The dwellings of Jarm among the Arabs are scattered; some in Al-Yamama, some in Basra, some in Al-Aqiq, and some in Hadhramaut. It had a dwelling in Sa'dah in Wadi Nushur, and a dwelling between Sana'a and Marib, and in Dathinah and Ahwar. It is Muslim, especially Banu Dinar and Banu Sabilah. They sometimes fight some of Madhhij and raid them. Regarding that, some poets of Balharith say: 'As for Kabir and Dinar, they have been caught... In the loop of the rope, their hands tied in the snare. And Tariq and all the clans of Al-Hun... And if you leave me alone, I will not harm Banu Al-Birk.' 'Ghayat al-Habl' is its noose; 'Mydiyayn' means their hands fell into the noose; 'Yadaytuhu' means I hit his hands. Al-Jarmi said: Al-Washm [Al-Washm, Saudi Arabia] is from the land of Al-Yamama, and it belongs to the Qarawishah from Banu Numayr. The first of Al-Washm is Tharmada' [Tharmada, Saudi Arabia] and Uthayfiyah [Uthayfiyah, Saudi Arabia], which belongs to the kinsfolk of Umara ibn Aqil. And Dhat Ghisl; the poet said: 'O Dhat Ghisl, Allah knows that I am... To your valley (Jaww) among the lands a friend.'

And Ushayqir [Ushaiger, Saudi Arabia] and Al-Shaqra' [Shaqra, Saudi Arabia], both belonging to Banu Tamim. And Bulbul; Umara says about it where his son was buried: 'May Allah water Bulbul and its sandy hillock where... my son resided for summer and spring. As if I never defended a relative (Rajmah) from a sanctuary... against an enemy, nor repelled injustice with him a repelling.' He said: From it and what is counted as its domain is the Sawad of Bahila. Its beginning from its east is a land called Al-Quway' known for Banu Ziyad from Bahila. Then higher than it is the fortress of the family of Isam, who is from the descendants of Isam, the servant of Al-Nu'man. Among them is Abu al-Mani', a poet of our time. Regarding Isam, Al-Nabigha says: 'The soul of Isam ennobled Isam... So tell what is behind you, O Isam.' And Jazala to the right of that. Regarding it, the poet says: 'O Banu Isam, indeed Jazala and Hannah... Are damp places harvesting war for you every year. When the early dates ripen in them, they provoke... the chests of men for whom you have not startled a flock.' He says: You are envied for them. They belong to Banu Isam from Bahila and their clients. And Murtafaq belongs to Banu Hisn, and Al-Shatt to the clients of Isam. And Ma'sal and Hadn—other than Hadn of Ukaz—from the land of Bahila. And Al-Far'ah, a valley of palms for Balharith from Bahila. Then to the right of that is Al-Rayb; it belongs to Banu Murayh, Banu Ubaydah, and Lahidah; these clans are from Mu'awiyah ibn Qushayr. And Qurqara from Al-Yamama, and Al-Hazmah, and in it today are Banu Shihab ibn Zalim from Numayr. Al-Dakhul is the region of Al-Hazmah and Qurqara and Tawdah. Imru' al-Qays meant them: 'At the edge of the winding sand between Al-Dakhul, then Hawmal... And Tawdah, then Al-Miqrat; its trace has not been effaced.' Hadn of Bahila is a valley of palms like Hadn of Najran. Hadn of Ukaz is a mountain; regarding it, the poet says: 'Like a smooth rock from the hills of Al-Hadn.' The Rajiz said: 'When peaks appeared at the top of Al-Sayy... And Hadn like the back of the Zanj (Negro).'

And Ma'sal Jalah belongs to Bahila, and Ma'sal al-Jamh belongs to Banu Dinnah from Banu Numayr. And Dhu Sudayr is the valley of Dinnah from Numayr. And Batn al-Mu'arras and Batn al-Jawf are a border between Dinnah and Bahila. And Ibna Shamam belongs to Bahila. Yabrin [Yabrin, Saudi Arabia]: Yabrin is in the east of Al-Yamama. It is on the highway from Oman to Mecca. It seems more entered into alignment with Al-Yamama towards the south somewhat. Between it and Hadhramaut of the non-Arabs is a vast land that cannot be crossed. Its view from Al-Yamama is between the East and the South. Between Yabrin and the sea are the sands. It has a road to Al-Yamama and to Bahrain in sand. It is a land cut off between the sands. It has many palms of Al-Sufri and Al-Barni, and little cultivation. It has large breaches (Bathq) in the form of some Bahrah. Its inhabitant is from the Lakhums of the Arabs—meaning the clans of the Arabs; it is said Takhum like Luhum. Then Qushayr extracted it from their hands, then the Qarmatians expelled Banu Qushayr from it. Al-Arid [Jabal Tuwaiq] is a mountain extending for ten days; it opposes one going out from Najran for four stages, so it continues to accompany the person until he crosses Al-Faqi', which is the farthest Al-Yamama. From Al-Faqi' to Basra is the obstruction of Al-Dahna, Al-Samman, Al-Duqay'an, rugged grounds (Hazun), and other things. The road of Yabrin to Al-Yamama is in the valleys of Al-Arid. In what adjoins Al-Yamama are villages of Al-Yamama. In Al-Arid is the game we mentioned. From the homelands of Al-Yamama are Al-Qassim [Al-Qassim, Saudi Arabia] for Abs, Al-Nibaj for Banu Majid from Quraysh, Al-Niqar for Banu Qatan from Numayr, Al-Yaram for Dinnah from Numayr, and Al-Sirr for Banu Sala'ah from Numayr. Al-Abras al-Sala'i said: 'The doctors said, "What cures you?" I said to them... "A Rumth plant from Al-Ramad and Al-Sirran cures me."' Ramad is counted as part of Al-Falaj from the land of Al-Yamama. It is in a Daww of the land, meaning a bottom (Qa'). The floods of Al-Arid pass by its edges; it is a day from it. Its floods appear from a gush (Jashsh) from sinks (Maghayid) from Al-Arid eastward and from the land of Najd and its Arads (valleys) westward, and from the direction of Al-Akhdar in the terminus (Nuhiyya) of Bisha Ba'tan, Turj, Tabalah, Ranyah, and Turabah. It is sand cutting through the earth, surrounding, containing a coil like the letter Nun, so water settles in it for years. Likewise Tawdah in Al-Yamama is in a terminus between sand. The terminus of Al-Mudhanib is like that...

...its source is Al-Arid and the sand borders it. The road of Al-Aqiq to Al-Yamama is on the west of Al-Falaj on Amayah, and it is safe (Muslim) for Banu Uqayl. At its top is Ghamrah, a valley of palms and wells for Jarm. And Mat'am is a water for them. The Jarmi woman said: 'I love the folds of Mat'am and their settling... And the livestock of Jarm where its Salib (hard ground) appeared'—meaning its cave and its top. Whoever wishes may take the road to Al-Falaj to Al-Yamama from Al-Aqiq. As for the stages from Najran to Al-Aqiq, the first is Al-Kawkab, which is a rock pool (Qalt), then Al-Hafar, then three stages, then Al-Aqiq [Al-Aqiq, Saudi Arabia]. It was named Aqiq because it is a mine split (Ya'uqq) for gold. It belongs to Jarm and Kinda; in it now are the Kanadirah from Kinda, and in it are properties for the family of Al-Hasah from the Ja'awim (with Jim)—and in Himyar Al-Kha'awim (with Kha)—which passed to them from a mother of theirs who was Jarmi, called Umm Zayd from Banu Harb from Al-Hun ibn Jarm. And Al-Muqtarab is between Al-Aqiq and Al-Falaj; it belongs to Banu Qart from Numayr, then to Banu Hamam, and it is a stage from Al-Aqiq. From Najran to Al-Aqiq is four stages. From Al-Aqiq to Al-Falaj is seven light ones. From Al-Falaj to Al-Kharj is three light stages. From Al-Kharj to Al-Khadramah is a stage. Between Al-Khadramah and Al-Faqi', which is the edge of Al-Yamama, is four stages. Between Al-Faqi' and Basra is ten stages in a bottom (Qa') where the camel pad meets neither hill nor rock. He recited: 'It departed from Al-Samman between the mountains... Raising the tail of the hanging Sabul (rain/tail?).' Al-Jarmi said, and his father told him, that he heard a Rajiz chanting in the desert, his person unseen, coming in some of his travels, saying: 'She came from Sham intending Ta'if... Scattering the pebbles of the Ma'za, having dust trails. Her forelegs rustle like the throwing of the thrower... Until the high, new star appeared. So bring near the saddles and ornaments... And hang the swords and velvet garments. From every reddish-white [camel] and old fat she-camel... With hard kidneys, the mangers have dispersed. Driving them is every noble youth... Expert in the unknown desert, knowing. Girded with sheets and embroidered garments.' Abu Muhammad said: He must have heard him at night while he was traveling alongside him, because hearing him...

...by day without a person is impossible according to people of intellect. Malik ibn Harim al-Hamdani said, mentioning the broad valleys (A'rad) of Al-Yamama and Jarad: 'If your soul asks that you see us... In the possession of Al-Jawf, then become a stranger to the highlands (Najad). You will see us in Al-Qararah without doubt... Leading them, branded steeds. Upon us is every ample, smooth coat of mail... And swords we inherited from Ad. We will protect Al-Jawf as long as Ma'in remains... At its bottom facing Arad. And we will attach those who crowd us over it... To the Arads of Al-Yamama or Jarad. We spend the night with foxes where they spent the night... And make the gum of their acacia our provision.' Since we mentioned Ma'in in this place, we will mention what is in Al-Jawf [Al-Jawf, Yemen] of ruins and habitation, and mention what the homelands of Al-Jawf and its country and exterior are, and the land of Shakir. Description of Al-Jawf: Amran, which belongs to Nashq. Bayt Namran and the White Ruin (Al-Kharbah Al-Bayda) Al-Hashashiyyah belong to Banu Dalan. The Black Ruin (Al-Kharbah Al-Sawda) is in Al-Shakiriyyah. Then Ma'in [Ma'in, Yemen] and Baraqish [Baraqish, Yemen]. Then Kamna and Rathan belong to Nashq. We have mentioned its large streams: Madhab, Khabash, Al-Kharid, Al-Manbaj, and Ham; then the lower land of Banu Dalan. Among the small ones are Sa'bah, Al-Falaqah, and Ayn. Homelands of Nihm from Al-Jawf: Awban, Ar'arayn, Sarum, Dhu al-Dawm, Al-Aql, Khulays (a well of theirs), Hamin, Kaba, Sadna, Haraba, Gharaz, Al-Matalah, Wasat, Al-Mulayyah, Thayb, Al-Bayad, Nuhas, Tibb, the two valleys of Banu al-Ajda', Wadi al-Shuwar, Sarat, Asharah, Khabban (each of them is a Khabb - depression), the two valleys of Banu Munabbih, Thamar, then Qadib, then Khalaf. These are valleys pouring from the northern facing of Nihm to Al-Fart and the Gha'it (lowland). And what is between Nihm and Banu Abd in Al-Marashi: the border of Rahnah, Uqnah, Rahb, Ar'arayn, Nasam, Malil, Qudat Nu'man—which belongs to Marhabah—Haltan, Sarum, Al-Aql, Dhu al-Dawm, Salbah, Al-Qa'if, and Jabal al-Zahr. Homelands of Al-Marashi: Al-Barud for Sabbar, Al-Hallaf for Al-Humaydat, Al-Salal, Atan, Tafhan, and Marqab—in it is Al-Malaliyyah, a land and valley for Malalah ibn Arhab—and Al-Nil, 'Umq, Al-Aftul, and Al-Shaqra', which belongs to Sabbarah. Then the land of Dahmah: Barat, Habl, 'Adalah, Al-Sama', and Al-Jafrah (three valleys flowing into the Gha'it), and Gharir. Their division...

...is from Al-Hajr. For Wa'ilah, from what adjoins Dahmah and Arhab: Al-Qaww and Tila' for Wa'ilah, and Al-Ushshah and Al-Sarir to Watran; all this is Shu'ara' (wooded land) between Shakir and Al-Shi'r Al-Hamat to the head of Al-Muhtabiyah for Al-Hanajir and Al-Matamah for Wa'ilah. Valleys of Wa'ilah: Amlah and Rahub (their flow is to Ribaq), Marin (two valleys ending in the Gha'it), Kitaf (flows to Al-Aqiq, and Al-Aqiq pours into the Gha'it), Al-Fahluwayn (land of Hawqaf, not a valley), Al-Atf and Al-Faqarah (two valleys flowing into Dadah, a valley for Amir ending in the Gha'it), Halaf (overflows to Al-Takim in Hawah). Then Al-Gha'it and Al-Hadn in Najran for it and for Amir. And Sidra, Al-Sadah, Harab, and Arad—which Malik ibn Harim mentioned in his saying: 'We will protect Al-Jawf as long as Ma'in remains... At its bottom facing Arad.' And Awban, Mataran (Matarah of the Najdat from Nihm and Matarah of Ajram, a clan in Nihm from Ajram), Yahir, Al-Hafr from the land of Banu Shahr ibn Nihm, Ar'aran, Al-Manharah, Abalan, and Al-Futul in streams and places surrounding Awban. This is what is between Yemen, Najd, Al-Arud, Iraq, Al-Asab, Bahrain, and its environs: If we summarize the land of Bahrain, which is the land of Al-Mushaqqar, it is Hajar [Al-Hasa], its great city, Al-Uqayr, Al-Qatif [Qatif], Al-Ahsa [Al-Ahsa], and Muhallam their river. And what surrounds it and falls between it and Basra, and between it and Al-Yamama, and between it and Fasfwan. The Rajiz says in it: 'A girl whose home is in Safwan... She knew neither Al-Dahna nor its Niqar. Nor Al-Dujani nor its Ta'shar.' Al-Niqar are holes in the sand. And Kazima [Kazima, Kuwait]. And Maslahah, a well that was salty causing diarrhea, then its water became sweet and fresh. And Al-Nuqayrah, in which is the spring well (Bi'r 'Add) which we mentioned. And Al-Sudah, Wadi Abi Jami', Al-Jashiriyyah, Al-Qarantan for Banu Tamim, and Al-Rusafah. The land of Bahrain ended. We will mention the famous places between Yemen, Najd, Al-Arud, Iraq, and Sham, and the mention of the highway of Iraq in these. Abu Muhammad said: If we detailed Bahrain in the manner we detailed Al-Falaj, it would be much; however, we have mentioned edges of it. Likewise, much of Yemen, Najd, and Al-Sarat, if we thoroughly investigated them...

...the description would be much. The proof of that is that we mention the best parts (Sarar) of Wadi Najran and the small streams of Al-Jawf without its broad valleys (A'rad), so many places spread from them. The Sarar of Najran are Shawkan, Al-Jawz, Al-Darran, Al-Hamdah, Al-Jalaliyan, Nafhah, Nu'aman, Al-Biran, and Al-Hadn. Wada'ah from Hamdan inhabits these places, except Al-Hadn, for it is an abode for Wa'ilah ibn Shakir ibn Bakil and neighbors of theirs from Thaqif. Qabil Yam are Ra'ash, Rahah, Labakhah Al-Ulya, Labakhah Al-Sufla, and Lubaynan. The section of Hamdan ended. From the homelands of Balharith: Sawhan and Minan—in it Banu al-Harith fortified themselves against the Alawite in the days he rallied Hamdan and Khawlan against them, so he could not dislodge anything from them—and Al-Muwaffajah, Dhat Ibar, Akman, Al-Ghayl, Sirr Banu Mazin from Zabid, Saghir, Hadn Bali, Rajla, Dhubyan, Mahdar, Ara'is, Al-Yata'im, Al-Arbat, Adwar Hudayr, Qarqar, Yanqam, Al-Hajar—which is the modern village—and Al-Hajar Al-Qadima (Old Hajar), the place of Al-Ukhdud (The Trench). As for the streams of Jawf Hamdan, we have mentioned its large A'rad (broad valleys) and the small ones like Dharar pouring into Al-Kharid at Al-Manahi, Harar descending to Al-Kharid, Al-Sud descending to Al-Kharid to Ashar al-Muqaylid to Al-Kharid before Amran, Wadi al-Kharbah, Al-Rawdatan, Ghubbar, Nuhama, Dhu Qarr, Abr, 'Anasan, Dhu Salif, Majzar, Aya, Mulaha, Al-Uyaynah, Rahnah, Waqah (pours into Qabal Nu'man then to Madhab), Dafrah, Adir, Ayn Ibn Abi Uyaynah, Ayn Banu Rabi', Al-Qa'a', Al-Lahjah, Upper Ham, Kina, and Sha'b al-Dhi'b. Mention of the Famous Places between Yemen, Najd, Al-Arud, Iraq, and Sham, and mention of the highway of Iraq in these. Al-Jarmi said: Al-Sharif, to which the eagles of Al-Sharif are attributed, belongs to Banu Tamim. Shu'ba is from the environs of Al-Sharif. Tarafa said: 'Hind has ruins in the rough grounds of Al-Sharif... gleaming, and the nearest of their era is old.' Dariyya belongs to Banu Kilab. Al-Ghamr is Ghamr Dhi Kinda; they succeeded to it after the evacuation of Kinda to Hadhramaut. He said: The dwellings of Bakr ibn Wa'il are from Al-Yamama to Bahrain to the coast of Kazima to the sea to the edges of the Sawad of Iraq to Ubulla to Hit. The dwellings of Taghlib are Al-Jazira (Upper Mesopotamia) between the land of Bakr and the land of Quda'a. It is said that Ghamr Dhi Kinda and what adjoins it used to be inhabited by Banu Junadah ibn Ma'add. Umar ibn Abi Rabi'a said: 'Hind has ruins in the rough grounds of Al-Sharif... gleaming, and the nearest of their era is old.' Dariyya belongs to Banu Kilab. Al-Ghamr is Ghamr Dhi Kinda; they succeeded to it after the evacuation of Kinda to Hadhramaut. He said: The dwellings of Bakr ibn Wa'il are from Al-Yamama to Bahrain to the coast of Kazima to the sea to the edges of the Sawad of Iraq to Ubulla to Hit...

...and the dwellings of Taghlib are Al-Jazira between the land of Bakr and the land of Quda'a. It is said that Ghamr Dhi Kinda and what adjoins it used to be inhabited by Banu Junadah ibn Ma'add. Umar ibn Abi Rabi'a said: 'When you traverse Ghamr Dhi Kinda... With the caravan, aiming for it, is Al-Farqad (Star). There, either love is consoled... Or one is saddened by their traces.' Ghamrah is a land other than Ghamr Dhi Kinda, belonging to Ghani. Tufayl said: 'We avoided the heights, the heights of Ghamrah... And the manes of the horses' sons, oh what a distance of avoidance!' Hadn and Al-Sayy belong to Bahila. We have mentioned the dwellings of the Daja'im from Salih: Al-Balqa [Balqa, Jordan], Salamiyah [Salamiyah, Syria], Hawwarin [Hawwarin, Syria], and Al-Zaytun. Dwellings of Bali: Amaj and Gharran, two valleys taking from the Harrah of Banu Sulaym and ending in the sea. And Hajshan, Al-Jazl, Al-Suqya, and Al-Ruhbah. As for Ma'din Faran, it is attributed to Faran ibn Bali ibn Amr, just as it is said regarding the mountains of the Haram 'Mountains of Faran' and they were mentioned as such in the Torah; but they were attributed to Faran ibn Amr ibn Amliq. Bali has a dwelling in Shaghb and Bada between Tayma and Medina. In the land of Uqayl: Sahbal, a place where Ja'far ibn Ulbah al-Harithi killed a slaughter of Banu Uqayl; he says about it: 'They have the chest of my sword on the day of the valley of Sahbal... And I have from it what the fingers grasped.' And Jarad in the region of Al-Yamama; Malik ibn Harim al-Hamdani says in a raid he launched against it: 'And the tribe of Zabid on the day of Habis were killed... And on the day of Banu Sa'd I healed my thirst. And Khath'am, I quenched the spears with their blood... In Shafan until every stream flowed. And the tribe of Tamim, when we met them and their Sa'd... In the sand of Jarad, were destroyed for revenges.' And Za'bal in Hijaz from the direction of Tayma. Abu al-Dhayyal al-Balawi said: 'And my eye did not see the like of a day I saw... In Za'bal, as long as the Arak tree turned green and bore fruit.' Land of Juhaynah: Taydad, Math'ar, and Wadi Ghawa. It is changed to be called Wadi Rashd. Likewise, changed...

...the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, among Banu Ghayyan, so he said: 'Banu Rashdan'. And Al-Ash'ar, Al-Ajrad, Quds, Arah, Radwa, Sandid, and Idam. Idam is a great valley fed by many valleys; it is one of the large A'rad (broad valleys) of Hijaz like Nakhal and others. Umayyah ibn Abi al-Salt says in it: 'Our fathers manured Tihama in time... And Idam flowed with their army.' And Al-Safra, Sayah, Dhu Khashab, Al-Hadir, Thaqba, Na'f, Buwat, Al-Musalla, Badr, Jafjaf, Rahat, Waddan, Yanbu, Al-Hawra, Al-Arj, Al-Athayah, Al-Ruwaythah, Al-Mujannabatan, Al-Rawha, Haql (coast of Tayma), Dhu al-Marwah, Al-Is, Fayf al-Fahlatayn, Fayf al-Rih in the land of Hawazin, Khaybar, Fadak, Harrat al-Nar, and Yayn to Al-Rabadhah to Al-Naqrah to Iran to Sufaynah to Al-Suwariqiyyah, the village of Banu Sulaym. Dwellings of Iyad: Sindad. Al-Aswad ibn Ya'fur said: 'What do I hope for after the family of Muharriq... They left their dwellings, and after Iyad. The people of Al-Khawarnaq and Al-Sadir and Bariq... And the palace with balconies in Sindad. They settled in Anqara, the water of the Euphrates flows upon them... flowing from Atwad. A land chosen for the goodness of its resting place... by Ka'b ibn Mamah and Ibn Umm Duwad.' They used to worship a house called Dhu al-Ka'bat (Possessor of Cubes), and the Ka'bat are the letters of Tarabi' (fours). To Bariq in Al-Khawarnaq to Al-Jazira in the west to Kazima in the east and south. Abu al-Mundhir al-Iyadi said: 'My she-camel yearns for the land of Al-Mughammas... And below it are the back of Al-Jarib and Rakis. In it its women cut the straps from us... And the dumb sons rooted among us. Every she-camel traverses Al-Bawbah with us... When the barren deserts turn away from it. O how lovely are the landmarks of Bisha and Al-Liwa... And O how lovely are its fawns and humming bees.' Qarn, the Miqat for the people of Najd, is called Qarn al-Manazil. Dwellings of Rabi'a from Al-Arud and Najd: Al-Dhana'ib, Waridat, Al-Ahass, Shabith, Batn al-Jarib, and Al-Taghlamayn...

...and Al-Shaytan. He mentions in it the war of Madhhij against Rabi'a: 'We prevented Al-Ghayl from those who settled in it... To Batn al-Jarib to Al-Kathib. With straightened, hard spears... On the morning of stabbing in the gloomy day. And they blocked Batn Najd against you... And the udders of Al-Jababah and Al-Hadib.' And Khazaz. One of those who witnessed it from Khawlan says about it: 'We had at Khazaz a wondrous battle... When we met while the driver of death drove it.' It is called Khazaza. Regarding that, Aws ibn Haritha ibn La'm reminds Khawlan of the help of Madhhij to Quda'a against Banu Rabi'a: 'And we struck the ram from the branch of Wa'il... With our swords until it complained of the pain of the edge. The morning we met them at the foot of Unayzah... With every led [horse] on foot and dusty, tawny one. Because of what Quda'a committed against us and dragged... Upon us, so we marched with the army and the banner.' He means what Hazimah ibn Nahd dragged; he was in love with Fatima bint Yadhkur ibn Anazah ibn Asad ibn Rabi'a. Umara ibn Aqil ibn Bilal ibn Jarir said: 'O night of obscure lightning, and below it... From Batn Takhfah or Sawaj is a shoulder. It watered Al-Jarib, so the harm of its clouds passed the night... In Hima Dariyya pouring and spilling. At times it illuminates, and its clouds fly... Forward, and the dark fresh water pushes it. So the fortress of Dhu Marakh, it spent the night overturning it... Leaping away from what was low of the dune. And it ascended Lughat, so its flood spent the night clamoring... In Qurqara, the valley of Al-Yamama, it branched out. And it stayed in Al-Qamman most of its night... As if the halo of every atmosphere was a star. And it knelt at Al-Dahna, and split its waterskins... In its soft ground and hard ground, seeking to pour.' They said: Hima Dariyya is the Hima of Kulayb. Between the Hima and Dariyya is Jabal al-Nir. Some ignorant people think that the dwellings of Rabi'a ibn Nizar were in Tihama at Surdud and the land of La'san from Akk, and that Tubba' granted them these lands when they allied with him. This...

...is from fabricated news, because kings are too great to ally with subjects. They only built this report on illusion and fancy. So they said for Al-Mahjam—which is Khazzah—Khazaza; and for Al-An'um—Al-An'umayn; and for Al-Dhaybat—Al-Dhana'ib; and for Al-Aridah—Uwayrid. Muhalhil only meant by his saying: 'Our home Tihama was inhabited for a time... And in it Banu Ma'add were settlers.' Mecca and what adjoins it: Dwellings of Hudhayl: Urnah, Arafah, Batn Nu'man, Nakhla, Rahil, Kabkab, Al-Bawbah, Awtas, and Ghazwan. Banu Sa'd expelled them from it; they expelled them in our time with the help of Ajj ibn Shakh, the Sultan of Mecca. Ghazwan is one of the most impregnable mountains of Hijaz and the most abundant in game and honey. It resembles Shann and Jabal Bariq among the mountains of Al-Sarat. Chapter: Containing verses from poets mentioning places in Najd. Tarafa said regarding Tabalah: 'He saw a view of it in Wadi Tabalah... So the provision upon him was like bitter aloe or bitter. She stayed at Al-Za'ra' a day and a night... The winds alternating upon her with watering and rain.' Al-Maqr: Aloe. Tarafa said mentioning Al-Sharif: 'Hind has ruins in the rough grounds of Al-Sharif.' Some Arabs said: 'Whoever spent the summer in Al-Sharif, the spring in... and the winter in Al-Samman has hit the pasture.' Tufayl al-Ghanawi said: 'Its men spend the night like the eagles of Al-Sharif... Whenever they intend a new matter, following up.' Waqr and Dhat al-Hadh are two places; Al-Hadh is a plant. Tarafa said: 'Around Dhat al-Hadh from Thanniy and Waqr.' Al-Nir is a mountain for Ghadirah. Al-Ajjaj said: 'If the ibexes of the peaks of Al-Nir... heard him, they would rejoice at the glad tidings.' Tarafa said: 'I stayed at Dhu al-Arta above Mithqab... With an evil kunya (nickname/condition?), perishing or like perishing.' Kunya is like Dirat Adir (Dropsy/Hernia) in Dirah. Mithqab is a place. Yathqub is in the land of...

...Dhubyan. Al-Nabigha said: 'Rawdat al-Ajdad from it in Yathqub has been effaced.' Thuqban is in Yemen. Tarafa said: 'Khawla has ruins in Barqat Thahmad.' Thahmad is a water in Haziz Adakh for Ghani. Asad in Najd. Dad is a place on the coast of Kazima. Tarafa said: 'Empty ships in the middle parts of Dad.' Ghamrah from the lands of Ghani. Tufayl said: 'We avoided the heights, the heights of Ghamrah... And the manes of the horses' sons, oh what a distance of avoidance!' Al-Qinan is a mountain for Banu Asad. Tufayl said: 'And when the hills of Al-Qinan and Sarah appeared.' Sarah is a place. Sand of Alij cuts between the two mountains of Tayy and the land of Fazara in Al-Dahna. Sharj and Ayhab are from the land of Ghani. Muhajjar is between Ghani and Banu Asad. Rumman and Huqayl are two lands between Ghani and Tayy. Idam is from the environs of Mecca. Al-Dam is between Al-Yamama and the land of Khath'am. Al-Yazm is in the land of Al-Kila'. Al-Damum in Ma'dhin and Mudam belonging to Hamdan. Al-Janab and Ayhab from the land of Ghatafan. Arik al-Abyad from the land of Banu Asad and Uwarah. As for Arik with Damma on the Alif, it is in the region of Nakhla. And Aw'al and Adhri'at and Batn Dhi Aaj. Matalai' for Ghani. Tufayl said about the horses: 'They stayed, so they cease not around Matalai'... Having a playground like the traces of the cattle.' Haras is a water for Ghani. Tufayl said—and he mentioned Yabambam from Upper Najd—: 'Did litter-borne women at Hafar Yabambam excite you... They left early before the covered palms.' Then he mentioned Samsam from the land of Al-Falaj: 'It approached Al-Aflaj, the right of its rain... And its left surmounts the passes of Samsam.' Tibnan from the land of Ghani. Tibn in the land of Murad. Tibn also in Yemen. Al-Sayyid Al-Himyari said: 'Did you not stand at the ruins of Tibn... And what is the standing of an old man at the dung?'

Yalamlam is the Miqat of the people of Tihama. In some Hadith, Al-Alam occurs with Hamza instead of Ya. Tufayl said: 'And a tall mare outstripping the horses as if she were... A boulder that tumbled from the branches of Yalamlam.' It is also called Lamlam. Mina in Mecca is Munawwana (tan-able?) from 'Manna al-Adim' (he tanned the leather) [or 'Muna al-Adim' - place of blood/slaughter?]. Mina Munawwan is from the dwellings of Ghani near Takhfah, which is Hima Dariyya. In the Hima is Al-Rukham, a small mountain. Al-Rayyan is a valley in the Hima. Dhu Tuluh in the dwellings of Tamim towards Kazima. Jarir said: 'When were the tents at Dhu Tuluh?' Dhu Talh is a place. Al-Hutay'ah said: 'What do you say to chicks at Dhu Talh... Red-cropped, no water and no trees.' Nazirah is a place. Mas-hulan and Hamir are two places. Al-Hutay'ah said: 'Mas-hulan and its Hamir have been effaced of Sulayma.' Humr in Yemen. Qurqara from Al-Yamama. Qaraqir is a place. Suwa is a place. The Rajiz said: 'He crossed the desert from Qaraqir to Suwa.' Al-Nabigha said describing Al-Daww: 'And how was she guided, while Al-Daww is between me and her... And the night traveler in Al-Daww was not guided. In a land where you see the chick of the bustard as if it were... A star in it overlooking the back of a ruggid hill.' Saham is a place. Imru' al-Qays said: 'Whose are the dwellings I knew in Saham... Then the two Amayas, then the hills of Dhu Iqdam?' Darij is a place. Al-Hutay'ah said: 'And at Al-Atwa, the Atwa of Darij, almost... The hoopoe's voice made me and the saddle fall.' He also said mentioning Yabrin: 'Indeed a man whose kin is in Sham, his dwelling... In the sand of Yabrin is a neighbor, how strange he is!' He also said about Tawd: 'It stepped with him from the land of Al-Tawd, descending him... A dusty [wind] leaving no branch on the Ghada tree.' It is said 'Bilad Tawd' and not 'Bilad Al-Tawd' except for one who means the land of the mountain, just as it is said...

...'Land of the Plain' (Ard al-Sahl), 'Land of the Plains' (Ard al-Suhul), and 'Land of the Mountains' (Ard al-Jibal). It may be narrated 'from the land of Al-Tur'. Al-Shaytan is a water for Banu Bakr ibn Wa'il. Al-A'sha said: 'At Al-Shaytanayn my oryx seek pasture.' Al-A'sha said: 'Like a lagging gazelle grazing the middle parts of... Tathlith, empty, with smooth tracts between them.' Abu al-Najm said: 'A home effaced after Umm al-Ghamr... Between Al-Rahil and the spots of Al-Saqr.' Tarafa said: 'At Tathlith or Najran or where meet... From Al-Najd in the bottoms of Jash its streams.' He also said: 'Then Dhu al-Nir, then Al-A'lam from the side of the Hima... And a Quff (rough hill) like the back of a shield whose Asajil flow'—meaning its Sarat (back/ridge). Al-Hutay'ah said: 'Like the gazelles of Harbah driven... To the shades of the lote tree by a driver.' He exemplifies with the wild animals of Harbah, Wajrah, Al-Nahar, Dhu Qar, Tabalah, Hawmal, the gazelles of Salam, and the oryx of Al-Habil Al-Dabil. Chapter on the Mixed Dwellings of Arabs between Iraq, Sham, and Yemen: Arik al-Abyad in the land of Banu Asad, and Arik in Mecca. Ras al-Kalb, a mountain in Al-Yamama. Nita', a water for Banu Dinnah. Suwwat al-Ajdad, then Shibak Ba'ijah, then Ja'iz from the dwellings of Iyad. Waqr, Al-Ghamr, and Qatan for Tamim. Wabbar today belongs to Banu Sa'd from Tamim, and they are sands. Sanam and Al-Raqam for Tamim. Al-Hakkakat and Aqil from Bahrain. Al-Sittar for Banu Tamim. Al-Anbar, Al-Hirah, Al-Qasr Al-Abyad, Al-Baqqah, Sindad, Al-Khawarnaq, Al-Sadir, and Bariq are ancient Arab settlements from the region of Iraq. Mithqab from the dwellings of Bakr. Yathqub from the dwellings of Murra. Idam, a valley for Ashja' and Juhaynah. Qaww, a mountain. Al-Qaww in the land of Hamdan. Jurthum for Muzaynah. Yasr, Waqr, Dhat al-Hadh, Jafaf, and Dhu Khaym are valleys. Dhu Khaym is a mountain. Thahmad, a water at Haziz Adakh for Ghani. Darma, the desert of Bahrain. Al-Quffayn: one for Ghadirah and the second for Banu...

...Yarbu'. Dharghad, a Harrah (lava field) in the land of Ghatafan. In Upper Najd, it is called 'Al-Najd', and in Lower, 'Land of Najd'. Tarafa said: 'From Al-Najd in the bottoms of Jash its streams.' The Hima is Hima Dariyya to Sawaj. Al-Akhraj and Al-Nir are the farthest Hima Dariyya. Al-Nir is a mountain for Ghadirah. Al-Aqr in Al-Aliyah. Al-Sharif is its east and Al-Sharaf is its west, and it is among the valleys of Najd. Ghamrah and A'raf Ghamrah. Lubna, an unknown mountain, feminine like that. Ta'ar for Ghani. Al-Qinan, a mountain for Banu Asad. Al-Khall and Sarah. Alij, a sand land passing between Tayy and Fazara for Kalb. Sharj and Ayhab from the land of Ghani. Muhajjar between Ghani and Tayy. Rumman and Huqayl between Tayy and Ghani also. Al-Dam in the dwellings of Banu Amir ibn Rabi'a ibn Uqayl between Turj and Al-Yamama. Idam in Mecca. Al-Janab from the land of Ghatafan. Batn Dhi Aaj, Mutali', and Qura between Asad and Tamim. Al-Aqiq are two Aqiqs: The Upper Aqiq for Al-Muntafiq, and with it is the Mine of Si'ad a day or two away; it is the most abundant mine in the Arabian Peninsula, and it is the one mentioned by the Prophet, peace be upon him, in his saying: 'The land of Uqayl rained gold.' The Lower is in Tayy. Haras, a water for Ghani. Al-Falaj, Samsam, and Jadud, a water for Ghani. Tabna, a water for them also. Qurqara, where Al-Zabarqan met Al-Hutay'ah. Tarim from the dwellings of Tamim. Tarim and Taris in Hadhramaut. Dhu Talh is Dhu Tuluh. Jadud, Mas-hulan, and Hamir Ubaydan. Wadi al-Hayyah (Valley of the Snake), and it has a story. Dhu Tuwala, a place. Darij, Al-Watar, and Hajir for Banu Bakr. Qata'idah, a place, and Qasa'irah, and like them 'Ata'id. Sha'ab'ab and Ghabghab. Kabkab, a red mountain at the head of Arafah. Dhu Tuwa, Al-Ir, Al-Irah, Kada, Kuda, Al-Farsh, Al-Birk, and Azwar from the environs of Mecca. Region of Bahrain and Al-Yamama to Najd: Khaym, Huffaf, and Yasr are valleys we have mentioned. Dhu al-Khal, a mountain adjoining Najd from the direction of Bahrain. Wadi al-Khuzama, Aw'al, and Dhat Aw'al, a hill with a trickle of water. Adhri'at from the region of Sham. Al-Unay'im which is Al-An'am, Awal, Al-Dakhul, Hawmal, Tawdah, Al-Miqrat...

...Ma'sal, and Darat Juljul (a water). Unayzah, Wajrah, and Zaby are waters for Kalb also. Ar'ar, a valley for Tayy. Darij, Al-Udhayb, Qatan, Thaytal, Al-Sittar, Yadhbul, and Ma'sal are mountains. Katifah and Tayma; there is Tayma, a stop with many palms diverging from the highway of Iraq, and it is other than Tayma of Al-Samaw'al. Aban, a mountain in the dwellings of Bakr and Taghlib. Al-Mujaymir, a mountain for Banu Nizarah. Al-Ghabit, a land for Fazara. Taymar, a place. Al-Mushaqqar in Bahrain towards Hajar, having palms where water never leaves their roots. Shabah, Al-Amim, Ghadur, and Al-Ghamim (with Ghayn) between Marr and Usfan. Al-Ghadur is a grass. Hamal and A'far, two mountains towards Alij. Taziq, Tartar, Barr Ba'is, and Maysir are places in the land of Tayy. Tartar is in the land of Hakam also. Shawt and Hayyah from the lands of Tayy. Zaymar, a mountain. Dafar in lower Najran. Daqar (with Qaf) in the region of Yadhbul Mutali' Shaman. Yanuf and Al-Qawa'il are two mountains; it is said 'Eagle of Yanuf' and 'Eagle of Mila'', so it is attributed to Yanuf and to its Mila', just as it is said 'Eagles of Al-Sharif', 'Old woman of Al-Sulliyy', and 'Anqa Mughrib' (Western Phoenix/Griffin) meaning distant. Jaww and Mustah in the land of Tayy. Shatan 'Asal for Tayy. Mukhattat, a place. Al-Lajj also a place. Khu'ayi in the land of Yarbu'. Athal and Dhu Awal, a place. 'As'as and Ghul. Al-'Ass is the places of Kinda. Al-Ithmid, a place. Al-Ghul, a place with separate groups. Al-Awda', a water for Dabba towards Nita'. Limas for Tayy. Usays and Haqqah between Bahrain and Banu Asad. Amayah, Juwatha, Sahatan, Thu'alah, Akhrab, and Saha; all these are places in Bahrain. Ir, a mountain. Shurayb, Matraq, and Madhiq in the dwellings of Rabi'a. Athal and Al-Ashab, two waters in Al-Sittar. Al-Dhanabat are hills there, and Adamat and Umm Aw'al, a hill there. Dwellings of Iyad: Ayn Ubagh and what adjoins it. Al-Raqmatan, Dhu Shu'ab, Baydan al-Ghada, Khabbah, and Urayan are places. Akhrab, Ja'iz, Harad, Umayr, Al-Ghamr, Ghamrah, Ghamr Dhi Kinda, Marjah, and Qadib where Amr ibn Umamah was killed. Al-Sirr and Aqil, and in it is the grave of Al-Harith the King, son of Amr Al-Maqsur Al-Kindi. Da'an, Al-Dabil, Al-Hajur, Dhu Husa, Ya'jaj, Damr, Dajj, Al-Nibaj, Al-Kab, Rahrahan, and Al-Khu'. Wadi al-Qa'ah from the land of Tamim. Al-Qa'ah in Al-Janad. Dhat...

...Al-Hawsal for Abs. Al-Ashja'an, a land. Muzlim, a mountain land near Al-Nisar; a battle took place at Al-Nisar. And at Al-Furuq, Uwarah, Malzaq, and Al-Musamarah from the dwellings of Bakr. Tharmada', Shu'ba, Dhu al-Gha'it, and Thabir. Hira, Thabir Ghayna, Thabir Al-Ahdath, and Thabir Al-Akhraj. 'Ayham on the road of Al-Yamama to Najd. Al-Ma'iy, Hawda, Rahba, and Hazwa. Al-Ta'ar, a mountain. As-haman, a mountain. Jabal al-Umara, Al-Yathuban, and Dhu Harad. Al-Kadid, and a battle took place there. Damkh, a mountain. Al-Samman. Hawmal for Tamim. Al-Waqit also, and a battle took place there between them and Bakr. Maghamir, a water. Ara'ir, a water between Kalb and Dhubyan, and we have mentioned it. Marut and Dhu Dawm. Adam in the dwellings of Muzaynah, and Adam in Al-Sahul are two mountains. Dhu al-Jalil from the places of wild animals, and Dhu al-Jalil on the highway of Najd containing Thumam (grass), which is Al-Jalil. Wa'al from the land of Dhubyan. Al-Danna, and to it are attributed the waters of Al-Danna, a group of water. Uwayridat. Rudaynah, a place to which spears are attributed; it is a village on the seashore in the East. Likewise Al-Khatt in Bahrain; Khatti spears are attributed to it. As for Qana Marran, they said Marran is on the highway of Basra, four stages between it and Mecca. If 'Al-Qana Al-Marran' is said, it is the plural of Marin (pliable/spear). Marr al-Zahran below Mecca, and we have mentioned it. Al-Dhahyut, a land in the region of Sham between Judham and Kalb. Batn al-Ayyim, a valley there. Hisma, Sayda, Harib, and Jilliq are dwellings of Ghassan. And Aelia (Jerusalem). Therefore Al-Nabigha said: 'Their code (Majallah) is Dhat al-Ilah (Possessor of the God) and their religion...' It is narrated: 'Their place (Mahallah) is Dhat al-Ilah' meaning Mecca from the dwellings of Khuza'a. It is narrated: 'Their place is Dar al-Ilah (House of God) and their religion... Is upright, so they hope for nothing but the consequences (Hereafter).' Meaning they fear nothing but the Hereafter. Their Majallah is their scriptures/sermons regarding Allah, Mighty and Majestic. Harith al-Julan is a mountain for them also. From the land of Kalb: Khalah. The water of Al-Dhunabah, Suwa, the waters of Al-Manazir, and Qaraqir are waters for them also. And Dhu Aral. From the land of Bali and Juhaynah: Al-Shar', Al-Khabin, and Idam. Al-Tin, a mountain in Sham. Ancient Arab Markets, and we have mentioned them: Aden, Mecca, Al-Janad...

...Najran, Dhu al-Majaz, Ukaz, Badr, Majanna, Hajar al-Yamama, and Hajar Bahrain. Al-Rawd (Meadows): Rawdat Da'ma, Rawdat al-Ajdad, Rawd al-Qata, Rawd al-Ajawil, and Riyad al-Khayl in Tabalah. Abir, Al-Kawathil, and Al-Amrar for Fazara. Al-Atwa, Al-Lub, and Aqil of Bahrain. Aqil also for Bahila. Al-Jamumayn and Hamir for Dhubyan. Sadir, a place. Wadi al-Qura for Udhrah. Al-Nabigha said: 'Great of gifts, the sons of Udhrah, indeed they are... Chieftains, they swallow it easily in the throats. They protected Wadi al-Qura from their enemy... With a strong gathering against the arrogant enemy.' Al-Ghumaysa for Kinana in the Tihama of Hijaz. Al-Rumaytha for the family of Murra. Al-Ruwaythah on the road to Medina. Kanib, a water for Fazara. Al-Dathinah, a water for Banu Sayyar; Al-Dathinah is in Yemen also. Aqr, a place other than Waqr. Jawsh, a land for Balqayn. Hudad, a land for Kalb. Al-Lisaf and Harrat al-Nar for Banu Murra from Juhaynah. Husam, and it is said Dhu Husam. Rakis and Al-Dawaji'. Ilal, the mountain of the standing place (Mawqif) at Arafah. Lisaf and Thabrah, two places other than Al-Lisaf. Arashat and Al-Qaryatayn; a battle took place there between Wabrah ibn Rumans al-Kalbi and Banu Amir ibn Sa'sa'ah; other than Al-Qaryatayn of Al-Sha'i. Al-Luhaym for Murra. Al-Dimakh and Azlam, two places. Al-Kilab, Thahlan, and Al-Nir for Dhubyan. Uwal, a place. Sharh, a place in the region of Al-Hirah. Al-Ghumayr in the region of Yanbu. Habud, a mountain. Munawwar, a mountain. Quzah, a place. Batn Nakhl, a place on the highway of Iraq. Hayyiz Nakhl. 'Abarat al-Shiqaq, a place. Al-Adahim, ends of water. Al-Ahass and Shabith for Rabi'a. Dhu Salaman, a place. Al-Jawfa and Al-Umud. Dhu al-Radm, Halal, Asnamah, and Inbatah are places of wild animals. Arsad, a place. Atha'ith, a battle took place there. Shahib, a Day (battle) was there. Tikrit for Iyad. Dwellings of Tamim: Sulb Rahbi and Mughanni al-Muthanna. Fataq, Ablaq, Hudabayn, Barmara, Ashmas, Suqman, Talh, Al-Falaj, Barqat al-Thawr, Al-Zurq, Ma'qalah, Al-Khalsa, Al-Fawdajan, Wahif, Wahbin, and Dhu al-Fawaris; all these are from the dwellings of Tamim. Al-Sayy—and in Yemen Asiyy. Al-Ashyamayn. Dhat al-Mawa'is. Qawayn, Al-Quffayn, Jar'a Malik, Al-Dahl, and Duhul Habala—which are deep cracks in the earth that are...

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text: In it is water, and at Habalah there was a battle. Shari', Aslab, Shanzab, Wa'j, and Muta'li' are two waters; all these belong to Tamim. And Qasa, Al-Masani', Al-Jifar, Jufayr, Al-Ashyam, Al-'Uruq, Al-Dahna', Jar'a' al-'Ajuz, Ghamazah, Mushrif, Qararqu, Ma'an, Wa'j, Suwayqah, Humayt, Al-'Adanayn, Khashba' al-Qarin, and Athal, a mountain. 'Ubayd said: As if its withers are Athal. Dhat Ghisl, Fatakh, Al-Subayyah, then Rimah, which is one of the places of wild animals. Safwan, Al-Aharim - a water, and Al-Hadr. Al-Hadr is also in the land of the Jaramqah. Al-Qusaybah and Mar'ah are two villages belonging to Banu Imru' al-Qays from Tamim. Al-Shamalil, Al-Jalsa', Wahif al-Ramad - and Al-Ramadah in Al-Jawf -, Sarimat Hawda, Al-Sibal, Al-Washij, Al-Muntasaf, Al-Afrahan, Al-Qan', 'Anaq, Fataq, Ajmad al-Zujaj, Ma'n, Wahif, Bustan, Al-Firniyah, Al-Namit, Jalajil - and Jalajil belongs to Wadi'ah. Arik al-Fawaris, other than Arik al-Abyad. Al-Fawaris are mountains. Al-Shaba. Barada is a river in the region of Damascus. Al-Bazwa' is between Mecca and Medina, and Khabt al-Bazwa' is in the region of 'Alib. 'Alib is a valley between the two Khabts: Khabt al-Bazwa' and Khabt Udhn. It is in the slopes of the land of Bariq from the Ghor of Al-Sarat. It is Baqarah, Al-Malsah, Yasran, Dhat A'shar, and Tarban, a mountain of theirs from the direction of Dhat A'shar and Upper Qanuna. Among the Hejazi stations are Nakhlah, 'Azwar, Tufayl, Nas', Al-Buwayb, Yalil, Sharawah, Al-Niya', Yanbu' and what is around it, Hammah, Suwayqah, and Dhat al-Talh, which leads to the road of Kufa. And Al-Maqarib, Far'an, Al-Shatan, Shawtan, Das, Da'an, Hadma, Yanbu' al-Nukhayl below Yanbu', and Al-Nujayl. Al-Karim between Zanif and Tadurru' - and in the land of Al-Sakasik is Batn Tadurru' -, Rihab, the rivers of Al-Badi', Jasim, Rim - other than Rim 'Aramram -, and Dhu Yadum in the dwellings of Kinanah. Ajam Shawti - and it is Shawtan as I imagine -, Taghlam, Al-Bada'id, Shatb, Marjam, Waddan, A'zam, Azbam, 'Unayz, Faradim, and Al-Bulayd next to Tadurru'. Al-Uthayl is a place. And Al-Dahalik, Dhu Dam, Dhu Wajma, Al-Duwanik, Busaq, Shafil - a village of Al-Ruwayshah -, Shanuktan which pour into Al-Rawha', Arthad, Al-Murayh, Dhu Rit, and Baysan. And Farsh al-Jaba, Al-Masarib, Ghayqah, Aral, Sarma, Qadim, Tanadub, Barq al-Jaba, Sandad, and Busaq are two mountains. Kabkab and Nu'man, and we have mentioned them.

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
And Al-Rakiy. Majalikh is one of the valleys of Tihamah of Hejaz. Al-Rusaysan. Das is a mountain next to Radwa. Ayla is also a mountain. Al-Dhi'ab, other than the wolves (Dhi'ab) of the dwellings of Rabi'ah. Ray'an al-Madhahib and Al-Balqa'. Al-Muwaqqar is from the dwellings of Salih. Burmah, leading to Sham. Haqrah leads to the borders of Egypt. Balakith between Al-Marwah and Shabakat al-Dawm near Burmah. Burmah is a village above Hunayn on the road to Egypt. Shabakat al-Dawm is one of the valleys of Medina. The other Balakith is between Ghamrah and (Madyan). And Al-'Unnab, which is 'Unnabah. The other Hunayn is between Mecca and Qarn, and in it was the Day of Hunayn. Baydah and Tarmim are among the places of 'Azzah Kuthayyir. Shabah is Najdi. Al-Mahw and 'Amarat are in Hejaz and in Najd from the dwellings of Janb. Wadi al-'Ushayrah in Al-Jar, and Raml al-'Ushayrah in the region of Al-Sirrayn. Kabj. Al-Dunakayn is a water. Al-'Anaqayn, Balyin, and Baram are two mountains. Ramlat Lajjah leading to Sham. Katanah, Fa'ra, and Mayasir. From the dwellings of Iyad: Al-'Adnah, Al-Sull, Tahh, and Jaww Tarif where a battle for Banu Murrah took place. Zulm from the land of Tayy. Bahwah is Jabal al-Hawd. The land of Al-Mahdar is from the dwellings of Dinnah and Fazarah, and a Mahdar in Najran. Ha'il. And Al-Marrut from the Hima. The Rajiz said:
If we cross Ha'il and Al-Marrut ... May Allah distance Al-Suwayq Al-Maltut
Al-Shara: A mountain. Al-Qushayri said:
He saw, while he was at the top of Al-Shara inaccessible ... the sources of Najd and the space, so he returned
Sa'a'id, Kitman - a water, Al-Tathallum, 'Awq, Al-Makhadah, and Al-Ta'ma' in the dwellings of Dhubyan. Atidah, Dhu Waqt from the dwellings of Hawazin. Shamt, Al-Waddah, Wadi al-Mustabah, Dhu Khashab, Ma'shar, 'A'irah, and Al-Badi' from the land of Banu Amir. Dhu Bali and Al-Qarma'an. Then Majdal, then Dihan, then Al-Mathal, then Radam, then Al-Ajawil, then Shalal from the places of wild animals. It is said: The gazelle of Al-Shalil. And Kashr - and Kashr is in the land of Hamdan. Dhu Suways, Ghusnan, Allah, Al-Sulayb, 'Amayah, Qalah, Al-Abatir, and Jawad. Jarad is a place of sand. Al-'Arja', Shuwan, and Kafaf from the dwellings of Sulaym. Al-Sal'a' from the dwellings of Juhaynah. Shuhnat al-'Ulayyah, and it is from the places of wild animals. Al-Muntada from the dwellings of Hudhayl. Amsilat al-Rasha' from the land of Tamim. Suwayqat al-Hejaz, Al-Mutatabbal, Sajir, and Sahuq from the dwellings of Banu

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Amir. Mawthib and Khadar from the land of Iyad. Baninah from the land of Rabi'ah. Halyah and Mash'al from Al-Sarat. Anif is a branch for Hudhayl. Al-Ranqa' and Buzakhah for Banu Asad.

The Highway (Mahajjah) of Iraq in this Peninsula to Mecca:
Every road that is frequented often is called Mahajjah because the place of buildings and passing of things is Mahjuj (frequented/intended). From it is: 'Hajajtu al-shajjah' (I probed the head wound), meaning I inserted the probe into it and measured it with it, and that is its Hajj. The Hajjaj (orbit/bone) of the eye was called Hajjaj from Al-Akhda' because it surrounds the eye. The trodden road is called Al-Itar Al-Maliki because its dust is trampled as dough is kneaded (yumlaku). Whatever of the road is in the property of a valley or otherwise, the Arabs do not say it except in diminutive form, and the analogy is Malaki. The narrow road is called Al-Habl (rope) and Sharak (snare/strip), and the ropes of the road are its Itars (tracks). A Jaddah (main) road means cut (Majdudah) by treading. Qari'at al-Tariq (middle of the road) is in the meaning of Maqru'ah (struck) because of striking it with hooves and camel feet. Al-Ray' is the road.

The latitude of Baghdad is thirty-three degrees and half a tenth. Between it and Qasr Ibn Hubayrah is thirty-six miles. The latitude of Al-Qasr is thirty-two degrees and a half. Between it and Al-Qanatir is twenty-four miles. The latitude of Al-Qanatir is thirty-two degrees and a sixth. Between it and Kufa is twenty-two miles. The latitude of Kufa is thirty-two degrees. Between it and Al-Qadisiyyah is fourteen miles. The latitude of Al-Qadisiyyah is thirty-two degrees also. Between it and Al-Mughithah is thirty-six miles. The latitude of Al-Mughithah is thirty-one degrees and a third and a fifth. Between it and Al-Qar'a' is twenty-five miles. The latitude of Al-Qar'a' is thirty-one degrees. From there to Waqisah is twenty-two miles. The latitude of Waqisah is thirty degrees and a half. From there to Al-'Aqabah is twenty-five miles. The latitude of Al-'Aqabah is thirty degrees. From there to Al-Qa' is twenty miles - and in Al-Jawf is a place called Al-Qa' where a battle took place between Hamdan and Murad - and the latitude of Al-Qa' is twenty-nine degrees and two-thirds of a degree. From there to Zubalah is eighteen miles. The latitude of Zubalah is twenty-nine degrees and a quarter. From there to Al-Shuquq is nineteen miles. The latitude of Al-Shuquq is twenty-nine parts. Al-Jarmi recited to me for Ibn Shiryan

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Al-Quray'i from Numayr satirizing Al-Mukhtar al-'Uqayli:
I bent the loops of the rope to his hamstrings ... so he persisted in the malicious and increased in doing
So I brought him to Al-Shuquq and did not let him taste ... water therein, though he descended into the wells
And I brought him to Zubalah every year ... he gathers the jewelry onto his forelock
And I brought him to Nibaj Bani Majid ... if only the slave were strong there
From Al-Shuquq to Al-Bitan is twenty-two miles. The latitude of Al-Bitan is twenty-eight parts. From there to Al-Khuzaymiyah is twenty-eight miles. The latitude of Al-Khuzaymiyah is twenty-seven parts and two-thirds of a part. From there to Al-Ajfar is twenty miles. The latitude of Al-Ajfar is twenty-seven degrees and a third. From there to Fayd is twenty-eight miles. The latitude of Fayd is twenty-seven parts. From there to Tuz is twenty-four miles. The latitude of Tuz is twenty-six parts and three-quarters of a part. From there to Sumayra' is twenty-five miles. The latitude of Sumayra' is twenty-six parts and a half. From there to Al-Hajir is twenty-three miles. [Note: Text repeats Tuz latitude and Sumayra distance erroneously]. The latitude of Al-Hajir is twenty-six parts and a quarter. From there to Ma'din al-Naqrah is twenty-eight miles. The latitude of Al-Ma'din is twenty-six parts. From there to Al-'Usaylah is twenty-six miles. The latitude of Al-'Usaylah is twenty-five parts and a half. From there to Batn Nakhl is twenty-eight miles. The latitude of Batn Nakhl is twenty-five degrees. From there to Al-Taraf is twenty miles. The latitude of Al-Taraf is twenty-four parts and a half. From there to Medina is twenty-four miles. From there to Al-Sayyalah is twenty-three miles. The latitude of Al-Sayyalah is twenty-three parts and two-thirds of a part. From there to Al-Rawha' is twenty-four miles. The latitude of Al-Rawha' is twenty-three parts and a third. From Al-Rawha' to Al-Ruwaythah is thirteen miles. The latitude of Al-Ruwaythah is twenty-three parts and a sixth. From there to Al-'Arj is twenty-four miles. The latitude of Al-'Arj is twenty-three parts. From there to Al-Suqya is twenty-four miles. The latitude of Al-Suqya is twenty-two parts and three-quarters. From there to Al-Abwa' is nineteen miles. The latitude of Al-Abwa' is twenty-two and a half.

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
From there to Al-Juhfah is twenty-three miles. The latitude of Al-Juhfah is twenty-two and a sixth. From there to Qudayd is twenty-four miles. The latitude of Qudayd is twenty-two parts. From Qudayd to 'Usfan is twenty-three miles. The latitude of 'Usfan is twenty-one parts and two-thirds of a part. From there to Marr al-Zahran is twenty-three miles. The latitude of Marr is twenty-one parts and a tenth. From Marr to Mecca is thirteen miles. The latitude of Mecca is twenty-one parts.
Whoever takes the main road from Mecca to Ma'din al-Naqrah: From Mecca to Al-Bustan is twenty-nine miles. The latitude of Al-Bustan is twenty-one parts and a quarter. From there to Dhat 'Irq is twenty-four miles. The latitude of Dhat 'Irq is twenty-one parts and two-thirds of a part. From there to Al-Ghamrah is twenty miles. The latitude of Al-Ghamrah is twenty-two parts. From there to Al-Maslah is seventeen miles. The latitude of Al-Maslah is twenty-two parts and a half. From there to Al-Afay'iyah is twenty-eight miles and a half. The latitude of Al-Afay'iyah is twenty-three parts. From there to Harrat Bani Sulaym is twenty-six miles. The latitude of Harrat Bani Sulaym is twenty-three parts and a half. From there to Al-'Umq is twenty-two miles. The latitude of Al-'Umq is twenty-four degrees. From there to Al-Salilah is thirteen miles. The latitude of Al-Salilah is twenty-four parts and a half. From there to Al-Rabadhah is twenty-three miles. The latitude of Al-Rabadhah is twenty-five parts. From there to Al-Mawan is twenty-six miles. The latitude of Al-Mawan is twenty-five parts and a half. From there to Ma'din al-Naqrah is twenty miles, and it is the meeting point of the two roads. This is the estimation of the road of Iraq in Al-Arud according to what some scholars of Iraq worked out.

The Highway of Sana'a according to the estimation of Al-Arud:
What is between Sana'a and Mecca on the road of Najd is twenty-two stages, and of post-stages (Barid) thirty-five posts, which in miles is four hundred and twenty miles. What is between Sana'a and Sa'dah is on the direction of what is between the rising of Ursa Major and its setting. And to Katnah on the direction of

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
the setting of the first of them. And to Bisha on the direction of the setting of the middle of them, next to which is Al-Suha (Alcor), which is a small star that only the eyesight of a young person can perceive. And to Al-Manaqib on the direction of the setting of the last of them, whose last rises and whose last also sets. From the top of Al-Manaqib to Mecca taking towards the west towards the south because Mecca is to the west of Al-Fatq, and between Al-Fatq and Al-Manaqib is a stage, so know this meaning.
From Sana'a to Raydah is twenty miles, and its latitude is fourteen degrees and four-fifths of a degree. From there to Athafit is sixteen miles, and its latitude is fifteen degrees and half a tenth. From there to Khaywan is fifteen miles, and its latitude is fifteen degrees and a fifth and a sixth of a tenth of a degree. From there to Al-'Amashiyah is seventeen miles, and its latitude is fifteen degrees and a quarter and a fifth of a degree. From there to Sa'dah is twenty-two miles, and the latitude of Sa'dah is fifteen degrees and four-fifths of a degree. From there to Al-'Arqah on the old Sura highway and to Buq'ah on the new right highway is twenty-two miles, and the latitude of Al-'Arqah is sixteen degrees and an eighth of a degree. From there to Mahjarah is twelve miles, and it may be made a stage, and most of that is traversed to Araynib. From Al-'Arqah to Araynib is twenty-five miles, and its latitude is sixteen parts and a third and a fifth of a part. From there to Sarum al-Fayd is fourteen miles, and its latitude is sixteen parts and a half and a fifth of a part. From there to Al-Thajjah is sixteen miles, and its latitude is sixteen parts and two-thirds of a part and a quarter of a part. From there to Katnah is twenty miles, and it is at the completion of fifteen posts from Sana'a and one hundred and eighty miles. Katnah is the first border of Hejaz, and its latitude is seventeen parts and a sixth and half a tenth. Its latitude and the latitude of Jurash are one because it is from it on the line of longitude from East to West at a distance of less than a day, and from Al-Hujayrah and Tathlith about a day in its east. Then from there to Yabambam is twenty miles, and that is two hundred miles from Sana'a, and its latitude is seventeen parts and a half, and a sixth of a tenth of a part. From there to Banat Harb is twenty

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text: miles, and its latitude is seventeen degrees and four-fifths of a degree. From there to Al-Jasda' is twenty-two miles, and its latitude is eighteen degrees and a tenth and half a tenth. From there to Bisha Ba'tan is twenty-one miles, and its latitude is eighteen degrees and a third and an eighth. From there to Tabalah is eleven miles, and it is from Sana'a at twenty-three posts and two hundred and seventy-six miles, and its latitude is eighteen parts and a third and three-tenths of a part. From there to Al-Qurayha is twenty-two miles, and its latitude is nineteen parts. From there to Kara is sixteen miles, and the latitude of Kara is nineteen parts and a sixth and two-thirds of a tenth. From Kara to Turabah, which is Abidah, is fifteen miles, and its latitude is nineteen degrees and a third of a degree, and an eighth of a degree. From there to Al-Safn is twenty-two miles, and the latitude of Al-Safn is nineteen degrees and three hundred [?] and an eighth. From there to Al-Fatq is twenty-three miles, and it is from Sana'a at thirty posts and three hundred and sixty miles. Al-Fatq, Ta'if, and Mecca are on the line of longitude from East to West. If you pray in Al-Fatq you face the West, so Ta'if falls between you and Mecca, and the latitude of Al-Fatq is twenty degrees and a tenth of a degree. In the stage of Safn to Al-Fatq is the post of Jaldan, which is the amount of a post and a half. Al-Faddal the guide used to say: Three things allow only seriousness and contraction without relaxation and languor. It was said to him: And what are they, O Abu Yusuf? He would say: Copulation with an old woman, eating Lahuh with milk, and the post of Jaldan. Al-Lahuh, also called Al-Salih, is sorghum bread on the baking plate (Tabiq) which is as thin as cloth; it cannot be carried. If it falls into milk, it goes limp and cannot be carried except with most of the fingers, and with the right hand, etiquette dictates using all of it. From there to Ras al-Manaqib is twelve miles, and it is the end of the road towards the North, then you return towards the West and South. The latitude of Ras al-Manaqib is twenty degrees and a quarter and a third of a tenth. It is not a dwelling (Manzil); the dwelling is Qarn, called Qarn al-Manazil. From Ras al-Manaqib to Qarn is six miles. From Qarn to Rimah is eighteen miles, and its latitude is twenty parts and a sixth of a tenth. Then Al-Zaymah to Mecca, and its latitude is twenty degrees and a tenth.

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Highway of Sana'a to Mecca, Road of Tihamah:
From Sana'a you pray from Al-Bawn, then Al-Muwabbad, then lower Al-'Arqah and Akhraf, then Al-Sarhah, then the head of Al-Shaqiqah, then Harad, then Al-Khasuf of the land of Hakam, then Al-Hajar, then 'Athr, then Bayd, then Zanif, then Dhankan, then Al-Mu'aqqad, then Hali, then Al-Jaww, then Al-Juwayniyah of Qanuna - and it is called Al-Qanat -, then Dawqah which belongs to the 'Abdiyyin from the remnants of Jurhum, then to Al-Sirrayn, then Lam'ajz, then Al-Khayal, then to Yalamlam, then Mulkan, then Mecca. This is the coastal road. The ancient highway rises to Upper Hali and is called Halyah. To it are attributed the lions of Halyah, and it is what Al-Shanfara means by his saying:
With a basil from the belly of Halyah she blossomed ... It has a fragrance around it not stagnant
Then to 'Asham, then on Al-Lith and Markub to Yalamlam. This Sana'a road has a shortcut in the land of Hamdan from Sana'a to Raydah then to the head of Al-Shurwah from the land of Wadi'ah then Al-Batnah then Kharj.

Highway of Aden:
From Aden to Al-Makhnaq, and from Al-Makhnaq [to] Al-Hajjar, and from Al-Hajjar [to] Al-Masil, and from Al-Masil [to] 'Abrah, and from 'Abrah to Kahalah, the well of Dhi Yazan lined with black stones from its top to the water, long. From Kahalah [to] Al-Majiliyah, then Al-Maq'adiyah, then to Zabid, then to Al-Mu'aqqar, then Al-Kadra', then Al-Mahjam. At Al-Mahjam, the highway of Sana'a leads to Wadi Siham, and it is far except that it follows safety. Then Balahah from Wadi Mawr, then Al-Hasarah, then Al-'Abayah, then Al-Sharjah, then Al-'Arsh, then 'Athr.

Highway of Hadramawt:
From Al-'Abr to Al-Jawf then Sa'dah. The people of Ma'rib, Bayhan, Al-Sarwayn, and Markhah join them on this road. This is the Upper Highway of Hadramawt. As for its Lower Highway, it is from Al-'Abr in Shi'iz Sayhad to Najran, about eight days. Then from Najran [to] Habunan, which is a valley disappearing from the land of Yam from the direction of Samnan. It has much Arta (Calligonum). In it is the well of Ziyad al-Harithi, pre-Islamic. Habunan with Kasra on the Ha is one of the famous watering places of the Arabs,

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
as well as the well of Al-Rabi' ibn Abdullah from Najran at a stage for one intending it from Hadramawt and Ma'rib. Abdullah ibn al-Simmah, brother of Durayd, was killed at Khalif Dukam from the top of Habunan; Banu al-Harith ibn Ka'b killed him. About him the sayer says: Braver than the walker in Turaj. About him Durayd says:
They called out and said, "Did you want the horses [to have] a knight?" ... So I said, "Is it Abdullah? That is destruction."
In Balharith is the sword of Durayd, Dhu al-Jamr, which Hubayrah ibn Malik al-Hamasi took. About him Durayd says:
Decreed for him from his earth and his sky ... Hubayrah, the one who arrives at death upon rebuke
It was called Dhu al-Jamr for a notch in one year of it [like] a ember. It is today with the family of Bistam of them. Then Al-Malhat, then Lawzah, then 'Abalam, then Muray', then Al-Hujayrah, then Tathlith, then Jash, then Al-Masamah, then Majma'ah Tarj, and it met the highway of Sana'a at Tabalah. The highway of Sana'a meets the highway of Iraq, Al-Yamamah, and Bahrain at Al-Mashash between Hunayn and Al-'Awarah.

Highway of Aden on the road of Sana'a from it:
From Aden [to] Lahj, the land of the Asabih. Then Al-Suhayb, and in it are Saba Al-Suhayb, a tribe of Saba. Then Al-Hubayl, and it is not a village but a hill Tuzkham like simple grains. Then lower Al-Ardam, which is Wadi al-Aj'ud. Then Sur. Then Tharid from Ru'ayn. Then Dhu Balaq from the land of Ru'ayn. Then Sharad from the land of Ru'ayn. Then upper Shar'ah from the direction of 'Abasir. Then Yakla. Then Sana'a. Then the highway of Sana'a. Perhaps they took the White Dune between Lahj and Al-Suhayb. Perhaps they took from Tharid [to] Akhtam 'Uhan then Badr then Al-Suhayb.

Upper Highway of Aden to Al-Janad, then the Highway of Al-Janad with it to Sana'a:
From Aden to Lahj, then Thu'ubah, then Warzan, then Al-Janad Al-Suhul, then Haql Qitab, then Dhamar, then Khadar, then Sana'a. It is more direct and more rugged. In it is Naqil Sayd; it is traveled by litters for two stages. This is the left road

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
to Al-Janad. Whoever takes the right [road], then via 'Alsan. In this road of the passes (Naql) are Yaslah, Sayd, Nakhlan, and Hazar. As for what is below these passes, it is not counted.

Wonders of Yemen that have no equal in any country:
Among them is Bab Aden (Gate of Aden), which is a cut cleft in a mountain that surrounded the place of Aden from the coast, so it had no way to the mainland except for a man on foot who climbed the back of the mountain. So a gate was cut in the mountain reaching the width of the mountain until beasts, camels, litters, and palanquins traversed it.
And the Cut of Baynun, a mountain cut by some kings of Himyar until a torrent was brought out in it from a land behind it to the land of Baynun.
And the Citadel of Al-Ju'ah belonging to Abu al-Mughallas in the land of Al-Ma'afir, and he is Marrani from Hamdan. It is ascended by a ladder; if removed, it cannot be ascended.
And among them is Mount Takhla, which is a mountain with a wide top, having a vein ('Arqah - ledge/terrace) surrounding it where the hyrax and monkey slip. Under the vein is a vein, and in places of it are consecutive veins. It does not encompass all of it except the upper vein and the one below it. Its top is very wide, containing three citadels (fortresses). The first of them is Bayt Fa'is, which is one of the highest things in it, and in it is a standing mosque which people used to visit. And Al-Midmar is like it in height. And Bayt Rayb is a fortress with a disconnected vein upon which are the palaces of the family of Al-Mansur, their harems, and their wealth; it has no path other than one gate. And Al-Aras is a fortress between it and Fa'is, and it is a wide fortress. In it from the villages are the village of Bayt Rayb, which is the market village where the merchants are, the village of Al-Jawsh, Maydan, Bayt Zuwad, Bayt al-Buri, Sama', Bayt Fa'is, and Al-Midmar; all these are villages. It has gates that are not entered except with permission: Bab al-Suruj, which is the gate of Sana'a and the land of Hamdan; Bab al-Barar for the land of Qadam, Naml, and Sharas; Bab al-Makahil for 'Ayyan, Al-Makhlifah, the land of Hajur, Al-Sharaf, the land of Hakam, and Mecca; Bab Adam for Tamam, the land of 'Akk, Milhan, Al-Mahjam, Al-Kadra', Zabid, and Aden; Bab al-'Ashshah, not a highway; Bab Ghabqan, not a highway; and Bab al-'Adn. These gates are closed upon these fortresses and these villages upon estates yielding five thousand [dinars?] gold of wheat or barley, which is seven thousand five hundred Qafiz. Of the pools and streams: on Ghayl 'Ablah,

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text: Birkat Sama', Birkat Maydan, Birkat Halah, Birkat al-Suq, and Birkat Bayt Fa'is. On a stream are 'Ayn Bayadah, 'Ayn al-'Ashshah, 'Ayn Bayt al-Hatl, and 'Ayn al-Wa'rayn. It is closed upon its Maydan (field/square), its pastures, its slaughterhouse, its mosques, its grazing lands, its sheep, its cows, and its horses, except for camels, for they do not ascend it. With that, it has many predators at its top. There are no harmful creatures of the vermin of the earth in it; no large snake, viper, scorpion, Dafrah (insect), Qa'as, mosquito, cockroaches (Banat Wardan) - which are Al-Dawamir -, beetle, nor Kattan - which is the bedbug - have been seen in it. Bedbugs may enter in the luggage of travelers to it, so they die when they become in it. It has few flies and spiders, many crows and kites. As for its atmosphere and air, it is moderate in winter especially because it is clear in winter. By winter I mean the season of Autumn according to the calculators, which is the time of Libra, Scorpio, and Sagittarius. The time of Capricorn, Aquarius, and Pisces may resemble it. Most of that [rain/clouds?] magnifies in the Nawa' (period) of Pleiades (Al-Thurayya), which is the time of Capricorn and half of Aquarius, and the Nawa' of Al-Sawab in Pisces. The time of Aries, Taurus, and Gemini, which is Spring according to the calculators, has screeching, much rain, hail, and storms. If Al-Thurayya connects with Al-Sawab in Spring, the sun is almost not seen on it for a period due to the fog that wraps it, so the dogs lose it. When the time of clearness comes and the sun appears. And Autumn, which is according to the calculators Summer, which is the time of Cancer, Leo, and Virgo, has many rains and thunderbolts are frequent in it due to its height. They may occur in it and snatch from its people. Thunder is only from the strength of the striker of lightning and the beginnings of its movement. Every thundercloud is a thunderbolt because if it rises in the atmosphere, that movement reaches the end of its range in the atmosphere before reaching the earth. If the flash approaches the earth, its sound and movement fall to the earth and do not reach their range, so it causes in what it meets of bodies like the arrow that meets the body from close range, so it pierces it with the intensity of its drive. If it hits a body at the furthest of its range, it falls into it while it is high, its drive gone. The controller of much of its natures was the Moon, so it remains in the clear days

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text: clear until the sun declines from the part of the middle of the sky and the moon is visible from it. Then vapor erupts from the bellies of the valleys around it and from the bellies of its ravines as dense white clouds. It appears, thickens, and rises quickly. Two or three parts of the sphere do not rotate until that vapor has covered the head of the mountain from all its sides, masking it. You see it rising upon you, coming between you and looking at your beast if it is in front of you, or between you and your companion if he precedes you. If you are in a time of Nawa' (rain star), that cloud you are in pours down abundant drizzle. Then it rises and thickens, and the flash of lightning falls in it, followed by the sound of thunder quickly or slowly according to the distance of the lightning bolt from the lightning. An example of that is if you are in some plains and someone is within your eyesight striking a stone with a pickaxe or a tree with an axe; you look at the fall of the axe, but its sound does not reach you except at the fall of the second blow, and the sound of the second blow at the fall of the third blow. Perhaps it is slower according to the distance. Likewise lightning; perhaps it flashes three consecutive flashes, but the thunder of the first is not heard except after the end of the third flash. Perhaps that cloud thickens when it appears from the bellies of the valleys below the ravines, wraps, and presses on the middle of the base of the mountain, so the flash of lightning falls in it, so it flashes beneath you. You look at the valleys split by clouds, and above it is the sun. If the cloud clears, you look at the rain water flowing in the bellies of the valleys. If the morning comes on its head clear, the rain having passed and the air cleared, you look from any of its lookouts you wish and from any of its heights. You see the land of Tihamah beneath you from the middle of the land of Hakam to Al-Mahjam and from Sardad. You see the flood of Mawr like white old age between the velvet of Tihamah, its down, and its crests. Then you see the sea as a ruby chased game. As for the sharp-sighted, he sees from behind the sea the islands of Al-Farsan. As for what is seen from it of mountains: 'Arr Khawlan from its north, the hill of Khatarir, the head of Watran at a journey of seven days, six, and five, and Suhayb the mountain of Banu Amir in Harad. From its west, the mountains of Al-Sharaf and Rayshan Mount Milhan from close like the closeness of Hanum to it from its north. From its south, Bara', Shibam Haraz, Masar, Dila' Jablan, Harf Anas, Dawran, Ras Sahammar, and Yakhar. It is seen from these places. Were it not that its base is in the valleys instead of being on the back of a highland, it would be seen from the land of Najd. As for from its east, no land is seen because the mountains of Al-Masani' rise above it, such as Mount Dhakhar, Muda', and Hudur Bani Azad, which are in the highest line of Al-Sarat while it is in its middle. Therefore its air became moderate because it rose from the heat of Tihamah and its hot wind (Samum), and lowered from the Najd of Yemen and its cold and dryness. As for the width of its head which the vein ('Arqah) contains and the gates surround, it is for one who surveys it a mile and a half by the like of it, or increases to two miles less a third. If an ignorant person sees it, he judges it to be two miles and an increase in their like. It is surrounded by valleys: Wadi La'ah which is Tamam, its two branches 'Atwah and its head Bayadah and Al-'Ashshah from the head of the mountain, and Al-Tiham which is from Mount Dhakhar, Al-Shawariq, Maswar, and Al-Hatr. Other valleys pour into it like Al-Ya'mul, Dila' al-Jannat, and others, and Wadi 'Ayyan, Wadi Naml, and Wadi Qaylab. All these valleys are streams (Ghuyul) whose outlets are from its slopes. On them are bananas and reeds, I mean the reeds of Shirin - and it is said Al-Shiri -, which is the reed of Al-Maddar, and sugar cane. The reed of Al-Maddar was named so because it becomes sour (yamduru) in the mouth, meaning it is chewed and its water swallowed. Its slopes are clothed with farms and huts which are pastures for cows. Whoever is born on its head is ugly, not beautiful, especially women. Whoever is born on its slope is beautiful, not ugly. The nature of its inhabitants and people differs from the nature of those on its slopes in intellect, bravery, height, perfection, eloquence, and openness of tongues. Its head grows Barzaghah, Athbah, and Thyme. Of crops: wheat, emmer, barley, and Ja'rah. The name of this mountain is Wafit. It is attributed to Takhla ibn Amr al-Himyari from the offspring of Shamir Dhi al-Janah ibn al-'Attaf. The news of Takhla is much. sun. Among them is Mount Hanum. Its people are Al-Ahnum from Hamdan, then from Hashid. In them is

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
a clan from Khawlan ibn Amr ibn al-Haf, then from the offspring of Ya'la ibn Sa'd ibn Amr ibn Zayd ibn Malik ibn Zayd ibn Usama. It is opposite Takhla from its north, and on its description among the mountains of Al-Sarat. It is more fortified, taller, and wider. Its base is on a land with no valleys, so it is clear for most of its time except in the days of rains. Therefore, it differed from Mount Takhla in what is on its head of grapes, peaches, pomegranates, figs, and other things. In it is a plant resembling white sandalwood, approaching it in scent; it may be mixed with Indian sandalwood. The crops of its head in quantity are close to the crops of Mount Takhla, except that wheat in Hanum is more. It has a disconnected vein and has no more than two paths which only men can ascend. No beast ascends it like Mount Takhla due to the ruggedness of its path. If they want a beast to use on its head like cows for plowing and donkeys for carrying, men carry them as calves and young foals. The nature of the inhabitants of its head is like the nature of the inhabitants of the head of Mount Takhla... stupidity is upon them, safety of side, chastity, dullness of tongue, baseness of character, and its ruggedness are predominant. In the slopes of Hanum are five thousand fighters from the clan of Hashid. The crops of its slopes are sorghum. Its slopes are the most abundant land of Allah in bees and honey; a man may have fifty hives and more. Honey there is six Baghdadi ratls, and seven and eight for a Qaflah dirham. Those on its slopes are people of bravery, beauty, and beautiful women, in the manner of those on the slopes of Takhla, except that these are manlier and sharper. In its head are abundant springs and a raised peak with a mosque on it and a stream below it. Its news is much.
Among them is Mount Barat. Its inhabitant is Dahmah from Shakir ibn Bakil. Its head is wide, counted as a land among lands. Its crops are many, rain-fed and on irrigation systems (Masani) which are the water-drawing camels (Nawadih). One who collected the tithes of the Alawid told me five thousand Faraq. Its people are the bravest of Hamdan, protectors of the vulnerable, and defenders of the neighbor. They are called the Quraysh of Hamdan. The killing between Dahmah and its sister Wa'ilah, the two sons of Shakir, reached in this age of ours three hundred men from all. Al-Khayyar then Al-Khayyar regarding a neighbor that belonged to Wa'ilah whom Dahmah killed. They are

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
at the strongest they have been. The head of Barat is among the healthiest of Yemen, the best, and the most moderate in air. It is between Al-Gha'it and Najd.
Among them is Mount Tan'amah for Khawlan Al-'Aliyah. It is an impregnable fortress but not like Barat in width. In its head are rain-fed crops and on wells. These are the fortresses which have their water, pasture, and all their facilities.
Among them is Mount Dhakhar. In it are villages, waters, springs, and two fortresses: one of them is Kawkaban from one side, and Shurabab the second from its other side.
Among the wonders of Yemen is Haql Sana'a. The first to seek it after the Flood was Shem son of Noah after the transcendental drowning. He found it to be among the best of the First Clime. It was said - and the scholars of Sana'a mention it from elder to elder - that he placed his measuring line, which is the thread by which building is estimated, on the place of Al-Zabbir (with Za'). Al-Zabbir is a mountain near Sana'a as they say, and it is the edge of the mountain and the edge of the building. They do not go to Tadbir from Al-Asawah and Tadbir al-Naqah (making the she-camel firm), a firm she-camel. He built Al-Zabbir.
