When he was serious in building, a bird came skimming over the pool (Miqrah), snatched it, and flew with it. He followed it with his sight until it dropped it on Jabubat al-Nu'aym. He placed [it] to build with it. That bird skimmed for the pool, carried it, until it dropped it on Harrat Ghumdan. So Shem founded Ghumdan and dug his well in it, which is today known as Bir Sam (Well of Shem).
As for the nature of Sana'a, it is healthy, although cold is predominant over it. Due to its healthiness, a person wears in it in winter, when water freezes, clothes of silk, linen, and thin fabrics, and cold does not enter them because it is dry cold. The evidence of its dryness is that it cracks the extremities of workers and craftsmen and dries them with blood. A person wears wool, padded clothes, and fox furs in its summer, and it does not harm him. Umar al-Shihabi told me from Ahmad ibn Yusuf al-Hadhaqi that he looked at frozen water in the area of Bayt Baws in the beginning of June, and it was clear [with] a little [ice?]. A person does not move winter and summer from his place. If the summer and heat intensify on him, and the man enters to nap on his bed, he must cover himself because its houses in the summer are cool

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
due to the Qassah (plaster) of Al-Khiyar with which the interiors of the houses are coated. He enters the cabinet on his bed, closes the door on himself, and lowers the two curtains and the veil. The light of the room does not change due to the marble that is in the walls and the ceiling. Rather, if there is a clear piece of marble in the ceiling, he sees the swimming of the bird by its shadow on it if it aligns with it. The marble transmits the shine of the sun to the Qassah, so it accepts it with its substance and luster. Some of the Iraqis who entered Sana'a said: It is amazing that a room of Qassah in Sana'a is for two dinars! He means the Mukhayyarah Qassah. Al-Khiyar is a thorny tree like aloe, in it is glue with which arrow shafts are glued and the blade is attached. This thorny tree is cooked until it melts its water, and that glue is seized. Then Al-Ghurrah - and it is said gypsum - is mixed with it. It does not set (die) with Al-Khiyar except after a time after the plasterer holds its patching and managing as he wishes. When it solidifies, hands are applied and it is wiped, so a substantial luster appears for it like the luster of polished gems. Then whiteness enters it with that polish until polished silver resembles it. Other gypsum in the lands stains clothes with its whiteness and has no substance. From the quality of the Qassah of Yemen is that if it is mixed with water, then struck on a rough place, then a man's hand is stuck to it while he is over something carrying him, then something of it is struck on his hand, then left until it sets (dies); if what is under the man is removed and he is left, that Qassah hangs him by his hand due to the intensity of its grip and cohesion, so he stays fixed. It sets broken bones by this grip of hers, her casing, and her trick.
All fruits are in it: of grapes Al-Malahi, Al-Dawali, Al-Ashhab, Al-Darbaj, Al-Nawasi, Al-Ziyadi, Al-Atraf, Al-'Uyun, Al-Qawarir, Al-Jarashi, Al-Nashani, Al-Tabiki, Al-Raziqi, and Al-Duru'. Al-Rumi is brought to it from Khaywan, and Al-Wadi from Al-Jawf. In it are sweet, sour, mixed, and Mulaysi pomegranates. And quince, and the quince of the lands does not catch up to it because it has some acidity and astringency. And plums, apricots, sweet apples, sour and mixed apples, Himyari peaches, Persian peaches, Nahdi peaches, Farak walnuts,

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text: Farak almonds, sweet and bitter ones, and pears. Qudamah had come to Sana'a. In it are roses, green fava beans - and they do not let it mature -, all types of legumes, and all grains. The pot in it has a scent, and the bread in it has a wondrous appetizing scent smelled from afar. Likewise, pots and mugs of water made of pottery have, upon contacting water while new, a good scent strengthening the spirit and returning to the fainting one his breath. These three scents, no land shares with it in them. Then if meat is cooked with vinegar and the pot is taken down with it covered for a month or two months, then you come after this period and find it solid, and you heat it, the scent of its day appears in it. This only happens in Sana'a. A group reported that, among them Ibrahim ibn al-Salt. He cooked a pot of his, and he was a bachelor. When it was finished and its fire consumed it, he resolved to have lunch. He was like that until the messenger of Abu Yu'fir Ibrahim ibn Muhammad ibn Yu'fir came to him. He followed him immediately to Shibam. When he reached him, he ordered him to proceed to Mecca - and he was one of the Tarradin (couriers?) - and ordered a she-camel and provisions for him, and gave him letters to deliver to the governor of Mecca. He proceeded to Mecca and stayed until his answer came out, and returned to Shibam. He delivered his answer then was dismissed to his home. He said: I entered and I was hungry. I looked at that pot on the trivets and at that bread which had dried in its napkin. He said: I broke some of the bread into a bowl, heated that pot, and poured it onto that bread until it soaked it up. It was like a pot I heated on the third day, and that was after a month and a fraction. The pilgrims used to eat their travel food, soft bread and dry, unchanged, from Sana'a to Katnah, and further. I used to look at the merchants when we carried them to Mecca from Sa'dah eating their travel food soft to half the way, and dry, crushed and softened to Mecca. We used to use in our travels Mullah bread, Sann, meat, Kashk, and Mahhad. We see that travel food bread if crumbled from the ruggedness of travel. My father, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, said to me: A man in Baghdad asked me: With what do you season [food] in your travels? I said: With Samn (clarified butter). He said: With Samn?! He said: I said: And what is wrong with Samn? He said: It is a type of poison. He said: I said: By Allah, if you tasted the Barti

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
of it, and the Maghribi, the Kulaybi, and the Junaybi, you would know that almond oil is dirty compared to it. Therefore, the people of Yemen do not make their sweets except with it, because it is better and finer than peeled sesame oil and than walnut and almond oil. Due to its goodness, people drink it as a drink. It has an appetizing scent that invites the soul with it to drink it and increase seasoning with it. It has delicacy, so it hardly solidifies due to its thinness, delicacy, and lightness. Samn is among what distinguishes Yemen. You find that likewise in the delicacy of sheep meat and beef. As for the Janadi of it, the bull of it may reach thirty Mutawwaq dinars. It is better than the meat of the six-month-old lamb in other lands due to its thinness, delicacy, and fattiness, and it has no [bad] smell. The people of Sana'a have thin bread (Ruqaq) which is not in any country in thinness, width, and whiteness due to the suitability of the durability of the wheat. The wheats of Yemen are the ancient Arab [wheat]. And Al-Nasul is emmer wheat; it is the most delicate of them in bread and the lightest in lightness. The loaf in Sana'a does not break, but bends and rolls up like a scroll, and the traveler breaks it into pieces. Bread in it is of many types. Their Madir (dishes cooked with sour milk) have superiority due to the condition of the milk. Curdled milk in Sana'a, the land of Hamdan, the east of Khawlan, Haziz, and Jahran is thicker than butter in other than Yemen, with nutrition, pleasure, and goodness. Its butter is like soft cheese in other [places] and stronger, and you carry the piece, so not much of it sticks to your hand. They have with that types of food, sweets, and soups that are preferred over the utmost types of cookery books: Sama'id, types of Baqt, Sari Kashk, types of Hilbah (fenugreek), preserves of citron, pumpkin, carrots, dried peaches, Ranij, and Layy, and other things that if an ignorant person hears of, he scorns, but if he starts in it, he bites some of his fingers over its goodness. In it is the Huduri Madi solid honey which is cut with knives. Imru' al-Qays mentioned it by his saying:
As if musk and camphor ... in the Yemeni wine on her canine teeth
Here ... with the Huduri honey
It is gifted to Iraq, Mecca, and other countries in reeds. The description of its making is that it is heated in the sun and put into the nodes of reed pens. That reed is set up

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text: for days in a cool room until it returns to its solidity. Then the mouths of the reeds are sealed with Qassah, and it is carried. When he wants to present it on tables, he strikes the ground with the reed, and it splits revealing a standing reed of honey. It is cut with a knife onto a tray or a loaf. In Yemen are strange grains, then of the Arab wheat which is not Hintah (common wheat). If it is kneaded into dough, then you want to cut a piece of it, a follower follows the piece, extending like the follower of Qabbi?t (nougat). Al-Maysani, Al-Nasul, and Al-Halba' do not exist except in Najran. From it are the smooth Adra' and the rough red. And cowpeas, 'Itr, cotton, and Tahf. And colors of sorghum: white, yellow, red, and dusty. And sesame which no follower catches up to, especially the Ma'ribi and Jawfi; it has much light, pure, and good. Chickpeas, fava beans, cumin, and other things may be planted in it. Among the wonders of Yemen is that most of its crops are rain-fed ('Aqar). Therefore, its dough is firm, and its bread is soft. That is that the field (Jarbah) drinks in late Tammuz and early Ab, then it is plowed in Aylul when it heats up, meaning it drank its water and its face dried. Then it is plowed in Tishrin another time, then in the other Tishrin a third time. Then it was sown in Kanun al-Awwal, so the crop stayed in it until Ayyar and was harvested, and no water hit it. As for the low ground (Qararah) in Al-Hujayrah, it is harvested hastily in Nisan and late Adhar. The Jarbah in it is much from its heat, so it is plowed and sown a second time, so it brings hasty food due to the heat of the time, harvested in Haziran. As for Ma'rib, Al-Jawf, and Bayhan, the Wadan - which is the Jarbah and the Zahab in the language of the people of Tihamah - fills from the torrent. When it fills, Tahf and millet are scattered in it. When the water recedes, its plant rises. The Jarbah does not heat up for a month and days until it is harvested and plowed for the crop we mentioned. Perhaps sesame, cowpeas, 'Itr, cucumbers, melons, and pumpkins are thrown into the Wadan with the sorghum seed. All that matures first by first. This happens in the extremities of Al-Juruz, like the valleys of Najd, Najran, Al-Jawf, Ma'rib, Bayhan, and Tihamah in its entirety. Of that is the sorghum in Najran in front of Yam from the direction of Ri'ash and Rahah; there is

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text: in the stalk of sorghum two Mutwahs (cobs?) and three and more. It is not in it in the place on this [manner?]. Of that is the citron in Najran; there is no sourness in it. Large ones are sweeter than honey; one reaches a quarter of a dinar and five and a sixth. It has no equal in any country. Of that is the sugar of Al-'Ushar; it does not exist except in Najran, and it is not from it except the side of Balharith between Al-Hajar and Sirr Bani Mazin. It is sugar that descends from the air onto the leaf of Al-'Ushar in their saying and my imagination. So it is by the power of Allah Mighty and Majestic from Al-'Ushar. Some of it may be found in the place on other than Al-'Ushar. It is a type of Manna, and its form is like pieces of frankincense and mastic. It may be carried and large sugar made from it imprinted in molds. I was gifted some of it to a brother of mine in Iraq, and whoever saw it marveled at it. From it is Al-Mahatt, and it is called Al-Qassas. It is a shaver for hemorrhoids. This illness does not afflict anyone in Khaywan because of their use of it in pots and thickening it with honey. It is gifted. Some sultans of Tihamah gifted some of it to Iraq. Letters came to him: "Preserve the enclosures of this tree." So he informed them that it is a plant of the mountains of the tribes of Wadi'ah and Arhab. From it are Wars and Frankincense (Luban), which do not exist in other than Yemen and go to all the earth. In it is the Ba'l palm tree which does not drink except from the torrent. Perhaps it suffered drought, so it brought dates for the irrigation of a year and two. In it is the Qasb of dates which is pounded and sweetens with Sawiq like Qand (sugar candy); that is in Najran. In it is the Mudabbas which the Burdi of Khaybar does not catch up to. My father, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, said to me: I have entered Kufa, Baghdad, Basra, Oman, Egypt, Mecca, and most of the lands of palm trees and tasted the two dates. I have not seen the like of the Mudabbas of Najran in quality and size of its date specifically; the date fills the palm. In it are large Jarbahs (fields) that bring twenty thousand gold [dinars/measures?]; that is thirty thousand Qafiz. Saywan in the side of Sana'a, Jarbat Harran in Sharad, Al-Hadar, the land of Al-Rzam in Al-Jawf, and Al-Harajah in Ma'rib. Among the wondrous wells: The Disabled Well in Raydah. And of them the Well of Suraqah for Murad in lower Al-Jawf. Its depth is fifty fathoms. Its water is sweet fresh; it is not muddied

buckets. And the Well of Sam ibn Nuh in Sana'a [Sana'a, Yemen], and Kahala—the Well of Dhu Yazan—between Zabid and Aden, and Barhut in lower Hadhramaut [Hadhramaut, Yemen], and the Well of Maymun mentioned in the Quran. And the places where vipers do not harm: Na'it, no one is bitten in it nor in a place overlooking it, being within sight of it; and Sana'a due to a talisman that was in it at the Masra' Gate; and likewise Zafar. It has soil that, if a plastered house is painted with it, no flea enters it; it is carried and sold. In Al-Ma'afir, there are many acacia trees that repel its harm. In it is the Mountain of Salt in the land of Marib [Marib, Yemen], which has no equal; it is salt mentioned as having a gem-like quality and clarity like crystal, and it is rock salt. The Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, had allotted it to Al-Abyad ibn Hammal al-Saba'i on the day he came to him as a delegate. When he turned away, it was said: 'You have allotted him the ever-flowing water, O Messenger of Allah.' So he asked him to return it, and he returned it. In Al-Sharraf of Hamdan are the wild bananas (Mawz al-Ari), meaning they do not drink from a spring but from rain. In Yemen, among the noble camels are the Arhabiyya, attributed to Arhab ibn al-Du'am of Hamdan; the Mahriyya; then from the Mahriyya, the 'Idiyya, attributed to Al-Eid, a tribe of Mahra; the Sadafiyya; the Jarmiyya; the Da'iriyya, attributed to Da'ir from Balharith; and the Majidiyya. From them are the Mahriyya camels smelling of ambergris. Among the cows are the Janadiyya [from Al-Janad] and Khadiriyya [from Khadir] in body, strength, and goodness of meat; they reach a great size in body. And the Jabalaniyya [from Jabal Raymah/Jabalans], the black, rough ones whose hides are tanned for sandals; a hide from them reaches ten mithqals and more, up to twenty. Among them are the Shar'a, the coin-spotted (Mudrahama), the 'Arsiyya, and the Simsimiyya. The skin of the rough Namir reaches dinars. These cows have aggressiveness, sharpness in their horns, and valor; they kill predators. They are the 'Irab (purebred) of cows; the others are the Durr (trained/mixed?) and the humped Durba. Among the donkeys for saddles: the Hadhramiyya, then the Ma'afiriyya, and those with exuberance, lightness, speed, gallantry, and wooden roughness. Among the horses: the Ansiyya, the Jawfiyya, and the Hajijiyya. They are horses with spirit (breath), distinctive gaits, and swerving. They are not like the Egyptian and Jaziran horses in body, but they have endurance...

...and beauty, although they are not massive. They are more gallant and collected in heart. They trample the killed, carry heavy weapons, maneuver with them, and run, and the weight decreases nothing from their running. And the Shawafiyya [leopards], in it are precious leopard skins, pitch black and pure white. A skin reaches [a price of] dinars. Precious bedding is made from them along with saddles. Likewise, in it are precious colored Abaa rugs; they serve as coverings for horses and are of the finest things. They are felted (Mulabban); like the felting of brocade, a white square (labnah), and next to it a black, hairless, un-napped square. In it is precious royal silk equipment, and robust leather mats (Anta' Sutt) which do not leak in the rain of days, and wind-bedding from this silk, which is wondrous. In it are vessels of Haysami, which is a stone resembling marble except it is whiter; many vessels are turned from it. In it is the Kadhi [Pandanus], which has no equal in any land; it resembles the scent of the spikenard in the garment; its abundance and oil are precious. In it is the Du'bab, which is the Liy; it is a grain for libido and its oil is precious. It is among the best things a wine drinker eats with drink. It may be dried and ground, serving in place of bread. As for the herbs of Yemen, they are many for one who inspects them. Gem Mines: We have mentioned the gold mines. As for the silver mine in Radrad, it has no equal. In it are iron mines not worked, such as Nuqum and Ghumdan. In it are Baqran gems (stones); a triangular one fetches money there, which is that its face is red above a white vein above a black vein. Baqran comes in colors, and its mine is in Jabal Ans, attributed to Ans ibn Alhan ibn Malik. The Sa'waniyya, from Sa'wan, a valley next to Sana'a; it is a black gem with a white vein, and its mine is in Shaharah. 'Ayshan from the land of Hashid next to Hanum and Zulayma. And Al-Jamsh from Shamr Hamdan. And Al-'Ushari, which is the celestial stone 'Ashar near Sana'a. Crystal is found in places there. Al-Musanna, from which knife handles are made, is found in places there. Red Agate and Yellow Agate; the two Agates of Alhan. In it is the Onyx (Jaz'), variegated and striped (Musayyar), found in places there. Of it is the Nuqmi, which is the best (Fahl al-'Urf), the Sa'wani, and the Dasri...

...of it is Ajash, the Khawlani, and the Jarti from 'Adhiqa. And Shazb; boards, plates, hilts, swords, knife handles, oil containers, bowls, and other things are made from it. There is nothing else like it except in the land of India, and the Indian has one vein. Places of Wailing for the Dead: Khaywan, Najran, Al-Jawf, Sa'dah, the broad valleys (A'rad) of Najd, Marib, and all the land of Madhhij. As for Khaywan, the prominent man among them is wailed over continuously when he dies until his like dies, so the wailing for the first connects to the wailing for the last. The wailing is with light poetry chanted by the women, snatching it between them while they scream. The men of the clients (Mawali) have other melodies with wondrous reiterations between men and women. We have mentioned the announcements of death in the Book of the Bow from Al-Ya'sub. The Famous Mahafid (Fortresses/Palaces) of Yemen and its Ancient Castles mentioned by the Arabs in poetry and proverbs: The Mahafid of Yemen are many; what is in poetry about them is a wide chapter, and the Eighth Book of Al-Iklil has collected it all for you. We now mention the famous ones among them in a passing mention. The first and oldest is Ghumdan [in Sana'a], then Talfum, Na'it, Sirwah, Salhin in Marib, Zafar, Hakar, Dahr, Shibam, Ghayman, Baynun, Riyam, Baraqish, Ma'in, Rawthan, Iryab, Hind, Hunayda, Amran, and Al-Najir in Hadhramaut. Places used in Proverbs from this Peninsula regarding farness: They say: 'You are not impossible for us even if you reached Al-Shihr, and even if Yabrin stood between us, and you reached Hadhramaut.' Al-Shamardal ibn Sharik said describing the winds: 'Where it is said to the winds: Blow upon us... Violent winds coming in the morning, they do not wake us. And every direction for the night journey, they take us... They reached the farthest sand of Yabrina. And Hadhramaut, and they reached China.' He joined China to these places due to its distance in his view. And they say: 'May Allah crush him and distance him and join his soul with the souls of the disbelievers in Barhut.' They say: 'We will reach him, even if he were further than Anaf al-Lawdh.' They say: 'There must be [a trip to] Sana'a, even if the journey is long.' They say: 'Even if he reached Sana'a the Qasbah (Metropolis), and even if he reached Birk al-Ghimad.' In the Hadith...

...that Sa'd ibn Mu'adh or Al-Miqdad ibn Amr said to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, while he was heading to Badr: 'We will not say to you, O Messenger of Allah, as the Children of Israel said to their Prophet, peace be upon him: "Go, you and your Lord, and fight; indeed, we are sitting here." Rather, go, you and your Lord, and fight; indeed, we are fighting with you. By Allah, if you marched us into the water of the sea, we would wade into it, or if you intended with us Birk al-Ghimad, we would intend it.' And in the Hadith, Abu Darda' said: 'If a verse from the Book of Allah, Mighty and Majestic, exhausted me and I found no one to open it for me except a man at Birk al-Ghimad, I would travel to him.' It is the farthest stone (Hajar) in Yemen. Mention of Birk al-Ghimad, then mention of its location among the palaces of Yemen. Abu Muhammad said: Muhammad ibn Aban ibn Hariz al-Khanfari mentioned Birk al-Ghimad while he was in the land of the Khanfariyyin in the area of Hanaway Mun'ij, saying: 'So leave alone the one whose dwelling in the evening is in Ghaur... At Birk al-Ghimad above the hill of Barih.' These are places at the end of Al-Dumayna and Azzaza from lower Ma'afir. 'Al-Birk' are stones like the stones of the Harrah (lava field), rough, decaying, compact, difficult to traverse. Mention of poetry that came collecting many of the dwellings of the Arabs and their paths which reached us and we heard, and that is little of much of what the Arabs know because it is regarding specific properties of places. As for poetry that came individually regarding parts of this Peninsula, and generally about it, no one can encompass it nor is able to collect and comprehend it, because every poet has mentioned places of ruins, traces, rainfalls, and pastures what others have not mentioned, except for mistakes. Of that is the saying of Al-Akhnas ibn Shihab al-Taghlibi mentioning some dwellings of the Arabs of this Peninsula: 'For every people of Ma'add there is an architecture... A breadth to which they resort, and a side. Lakiz has the Bahrain(s) and the entire coast (Sayf)... And if a calamitous might comes to it from India.' Al-Sayf is the bank of Bahrain. Lakiz is Ibn Afsa ibn Abd al-Qays. By India here he means Sindh, and it is said Basra; its region was called by this name by the Arabs of old.

It flies, and upon the rumps of wild camels as if they are... A waterless cloud that shed its water so it is pouring. And Bakr has the land of Iraq, and if it wishes... A barrier from Al-Yamama intervenes before it. And Tamim came to be between a rugged hill (Quff) and sand... It has ropes of distancing and ways. And Kalb has a low ground (Khabt), then the sand of Alij... To the Harrah Rajla where it fights. It was named Harrah Rajla because it forces its traveler to walk (tarjul), and one cannot ride in it. Hijaz has many Harras (lava fields). The Harrah is Al-Luba, plural Lub. Salamah ibn Jandal said: 'Until we left, and our litter-borne women did not turn... Taking the way between the Sawad of Al-Khatt and the Lub.' It is Laba, plural Lab. It has been said that Hijaz was named Hijaz because of the abundance of Harras in it and the seeking of protection (Ihtijaz) by its people from the enemy. Therefore, Al-Nabigha said, mentioning his fortification in Harrat al-Nar: 'If I am disobeyed, then I will not return... From Al-Lisab at the two sides of Harrat al-Nar. So the place of water is from a deaf, dark [rock]... That shackles the caravan; the night traveler does not travel in it.' And from the first Qasida is his saying: 'And Ghassan is a tribe whose might is in others... A troop and battalions fight on their behalf. And Bahra is a people whose place we have known... They have a road (Sharak) around Rusafa, clear.' Al-Sharak is the rope of the road in waters and others. 'And Iyad raided into the Sawad, and before them... Are groups of non-Arabs seeking who to fight. And Lakhm are kings of people; tax is collected for them... If a sayer among them says [something], it is obligatory. And we are a people, there is no barrier in our land... From the rain, what we receive and who is overcoming.' Abu Qays ibn al-Aslat said, rebuking Ghatafan from fighting Al-Khazraj: 'To the flanks of Al-Jarib, then the slope of Salma... Then the aquifers of Al-Asahil, then Al-Janab. To the meadows of Layla, fertile... Effaced, where the flies have made noise. As if the mikr (plant) and the hawdhan (plant) in it... And the sorrel of the watercourses, the mature, is a forest. Do your youth deserve the war of a people... Who have character, a side (protection), and a habit? And if you refuse, then Banu Sulaym... And their brothers Hawazin have returned. To the numbers of waters to attend them... And in Golan are Kalb and Al-Rabab. And below you Bakr are settlers... On Ta'shar the domes were anchored.'

And of that is the saying of one of the family of As'ad ibn Malkikarib Tubba', describing the dwellings of those who went out from Yemen into the rest of the Arabian Peninsula and elsewhere: 'And kings of it separated from its lands... So they came to be in a land of Bedouin and settled life. And Khuza'a from us settled a place... Noble, at the Ancient House, the Veiled. And in Yathrib [Medina] are tribes from us; if they are called... They come as a swarm of armored and unarmored men. They drove the Jews from it, so they became... In isolation from it in the courtyard of Khaybar. And Ghassan is a tribe whose might is in their swords... Noble of endeavors, they have possessed the land of Caesar. And Quda'a settled a place from us... Distant, so they spent the evening in the lands of the Pine. And Kalb has what is between the sand of Alij... To the Harrah Rajla of the land of Tadmur [Palmyra]. And Lakhm, its kings were in Iraq... And it has cast Adnan into every cast-off place. And Judham settled where it settled and shared... There with Lakhm in height and tyranny. And Azd has the Bahrain(s) and the entire coast (Sayf)... And the land of Oman after the land of Al-Mushaqqar. And from us in the land of the West (Maghreb) is an army that clung... To Barbar until they came to the land of Barbar.' Abdullah ibn Abd al-Rahman al-Azdi said in his Qasida in which he mentions the dispersion of Azd:

'And before meeting her is the valley of Oman... And Najran, and a guiding road of Najd. And you passed it hoping a hope... But you returned from hope without provision. She may approach and join the one who draws near... And distance the one who descends to distance. The excitement of the grieving one for beautiful women... At the heel of gray hair is not of correctness. Is there anyone to convey a message from me... Carried, urging to Murad? And Ghassan, who have established... Their tribes in the extremities of the lands. And a clan of them settled in Oman... I see them not intending apostasy. So march towards your people all together... And do not distance yourselves [to be] others among the enemies. For you are the best of people anciently... And the most enduring of men after Ad. And the most of them youth among middle-aged men... Like the lions of Tabalah, the gray, the drinking ones. Are you distancing the tribe of Imran ibn Amr... And distancing the noble ones, Banu Ziyad? And distancing Shanu'ah, the heroes, whose... Houses became raised with pillars?' When Amr Muzayqiya ibn Amir al-Sama'—who is Malik ibn al-Yaman—went out from Marib with a group of Azd and they appeared to the Mikhlaf of Khawlan, the land of Ans, and the field of Sana'a, they advanced passing no water but exhausting it, nor pasture but crushing it, due to their numbers and equipment, horses, camels, sheep, cows, and other types of livestock. In that, the scouts were sent out for them in the lands seeking water and pasture for them. One of their scouts was a man from Banu Amr ibn al-Ghauth; he went out as a scout for them to the lands of their brothers Hamdan. He saw lands whose pastures could not sustain its people and them. So he returned coming back until he met them and stood among them reciting these verses: 'Will you not wonder at us and at what... The uncertainty of nights has arbitrarily done to us? We left Marib and in it we grew up... And we were in it in a good state. We rested our grazing livestock every day... Upon the trees and the cool water. And we used to dwell in its two gardens... Kings in the orchards and shadows. Then our Lord whispered a saying to Amr... To his soothsayer persisting in error. So we came driving the weak camels from it... To the land of famine and emaciation.'

'O men! You have been afflicted... With a dilemma. O men! Is there a settling place for us after the two gardens... In Raydah or Athafit or Azal [Sana'a]? Indeed Al-Jawf is a valley in which is nothing... Except the protruding Arak trees (Rabad) and the Sayal trees. And in Gharaq you have no settlement... Nor is it a refuge for family and wealth. And the land of Al-Bawn, your intending it... To graze it is a huge impossibility. And in Al-Khashab the Empty, there is nothing... For you, O people, of "it was said" and "he said". And this Tawd, the Tawd of the Ghaur (Lowland) is yours... And before the Tawd are the pillars of the mountains.' He means by Al-Tawd what cuts through Yemen of the Sarat Mountain which is between its Najd and its Tihama; it was named Tawd. In some writings of Dhu Ma'dhin a writing in Musnad script was found: 'From Karib Dhu Ma'dhinam to the people of Tihamat and Tawdam' in speech we have mentioned in the Book of Al-Iklil. 'And your horses, if you burden them... With the tops of the lofty ones of the mountains. I fear a hoof-soreness that hobbles them against you... So they become unable to march from fatigue. While you, O Banu Ghauth ibn Nabt... Are the masters of horses and the brown high spears. When war shows its molars... And the chiefs roll up [sleeves] for fighting.' One of their scouts was a man called A'idh ibn Abdullah from Banu Malik ibn Nasr ibn al-Azd. He went out as a scout for them to the land of their brothers Himyar. He saw rugged lands that would not bear them along with its people. So he returned coming back until he met them, stood among them reciting, and began to say: 'Why the departure of the tribe from the land of Marib... While Marib is the shelter of every content and blaming one? Is it not that in it are the two gardens, and in them... For us and for those in them are varieties of good things? Did not our weak camels used to go early, heavy... Upon the tangled thicket between the drinking places? If a soothsayer said a saying to our king... Then he is not, in what he said, the first liar.'

'We leave them and the two gardens and seek... In Jahran or in Yahsub the like of Marib? But alas, nay alas! And the truth is the best of what... Is said, and some speech is the revealing of faults. I have frequented Sayd and Al-Sahulayn after it... And Annah and Al-Sayyal between Al-Dhana'ib. And I went to the Ghaur until I circled Abyan after... I tested for you Lahj of the hills and the deserts. I did not see in what I circled of the land of Himyar... For our Marib any likeness or approximation. And these lofty mountains are a barrier to the Ghaur... Before you, and in them you have no purposes (Ma'arib). And your horses are horses that grazed in a plain... Of the land; they are not accustomed to ascending the high peaks. I fear for them that fatigue will reach them... While you are the masters of the marked battalions. And how many, then how many a group after a group... Did you make their sanctuary permissible with the long swift horses?' Then they stayed in Azal and the side of the land of Hamdan in the neighborhood of the King of Himyar in that era until their horses, livestock, and cattle became strong (stony-hoofed?), and ascending the mountains became suitable for them. So they ascended them from the direction of Siham and Rima' and descended from them upon Dhuwal and overcame Ghafiq for it. They stayed in Tihama as long as they stayed until division occurred between them and all of Akk. So they marched to Hijaz in groups. Each clan of them went to a land. Some of them settled the Sarawat, some remained in Mecca and around it, some went out to Iraq, some marched to Sham, and some aimed for the direction of Oman, Yamama, and Bahrain. Regarding that, Jama'ah al-Bariqi says:

'Azd settled, after its Marib, the Ghaur... Then the land of Hijaz, then the Sarawat. And battalions of truth from them proceeded... Helping, wading through the breadth of the desert. So they came to the courtyard of Yamama with the thirsty [camels]... And the horses, the spears, and the archers. So they overlooked the swords of Tasm... And Jadis at the decaying bones. And they went straight intending the Qafiyah (nape/back) of Bahrain... With the weak camels between the hands of the shepherds. Then they settled their settlement in Oman... For Oman is the place of those protectors. And lions from them came to Al-Khawarnaq... So they possessed its kingdom and the kingdom of the Euphrates. And kings from them rose to Sham... On the lean trained horses. So they possessed it and built the kingdom in it... For to them belongs the kingdom of the courtyard of the Shams. Those are the most noble of the children of Azd... Belonging to Ghassan, the masters of masters. And the residents in the two Hijazs from them... Rubbed the noses of the enemies in the dust away from them. They possessed the Tawd from Sarum to Ta'if... With the might from them and the steadfastness. And their Khuza'a possessed the Kaaba... Possessor of signs and verses. It expelled Jurhum ibn Yashjub from it... By force with the marked battalions. So the governors of the pilgrims are from it, and from it... Is leadership in Mina and Arafat. And to it belongs the feeding of the House (Rifada) and the quarter-share of spoils (Mirba')... Collected for it from the raids. And the children of Qayla [Aws and Khazraj] who possessed Yathrib... With the led horses and the fierce lions. They marched to the Jews, and they were thousands... Of the cunning of the Jews, what cunning! So they exterminated the tyrants from it and did not... Fail in meeting those tyrants. And they humiliated the Jews from it and emptied... Of them the two Harrahs and the Labas (lava fields). The water and the palm shoots became belonging to a people... Under its fortresses along with the fruits. And shepherds of theirs pasturing meadows... And watering women approaching, and cooks. They captured it from the Jews at their dispersion... In the villages and in the open lands. O you who asks about us... How is the light of the guides hidden from you? We are the people of pride from the children of Azd... And the people of light and darkness. Do you see today in lands other than us... Any kings, masters, and governors?'

As for the inhabitants of Oman from Azd, they are Yahmad, Haddan, Malik, Al-Harith, Atik, and Jadid. As for who dwelt in Al-Hirah and Iraq, it is Daws. As for who dwelt in Sham, they are the family of Al-Harith Muharriq and the family of Jafna, the two sons of Amr. As for who dwelt in Medina, they are Al-Aws and Al-Khazraj. As for who dwelt in Mecca and its environs, it is Khuza'a. As for who dwelt in the Sarawat, they are Al-Hajr ibn Al-Hanu, Lahb, Nah, Ghamid, and from Daws, Shukr, Bariq, Al-Sawda', Ha', Ali ibn Uthman, Al-Namir, Hawalah, Thumalah, Salaman, Al-Buqum, Shamran, and Amr. And many of the children of Nasr ibn al-Azd joined the regions of Al-Shihr, Raysut, the edges of the land of Fars, Al-Juwaym, then the place of the family of Al-Julanda. Account of the dispute of Murad ibn Madhhij and Qasi ibn Mu'awiyah—who are Thaqif—regarding the land of Wajj before the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and what he judged regarding it. This is what came from Amir ibn Sharahil al-Sha'bi regarding the claim of the delegation of Murad to extract Wajj before the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. Al-Sha'bi said: Dhabian ibn Kadadah al-Muradi came to the Prophet, peace be upon him, while he was in his mosque in Medina. He greeted him then said: 'Indeed the Sovereign is Allah, and the Guide to good. We have believed in Him and testified that there is no god but He. We are from the marrow of Madhhij, from Yahabir ibn Malik. We have monuments, purposes, foods, and drinks. The clouds of the sky flashed for us, and the showers of the Anwa' (stars) poured upon us. So the young camels climbed with us from the lower parts of Al-Jawf and the tops of the hills. The hard grounds of the highlands raised them, the darknesses of the night covered them, and the bellies of the soft grounds and the ends of the deep valleys lowered them, until they settled in your land and your sky. We befriend whoever you befriend, and we oppose whoever you oppose. Allah is our Master and your Master. Indeed Wajj and the overlooks of Ta'if belonged to Banu Mahla'il ibn Qaynan. They planted its valleys, tamed its rugged grounds, and grazed its watercourses. When they disobeyed the Merciful, the Flood blew upon them, so no one of them remained on the face of the earth except who was in the ship of Noah. When the sky withheld [rain] and the water subsided, Allah brought down Noah and those with him to the ruggid and plain ground of the earth, and its rough terrain and mountains. The most established of his sons and the fastest in growth after him were Ad and Thamud. They were in...

...transgression like two betting horses. As for Ad, Allah, Mighty and Majestic, destroyed them with the barren wind and the painful punishment. As for Thamud, He struck them with smooth stones (Dumaliq) and destroyed them with thunderbolts. Banu Hani ibn Hadhlul ibn Hawdhala ibn Thamud used to inhabit it. They are the ones who planned its drinking places, came to its streams, revived its courtyards, and raised its trellises. Then Himyar possessed the strongholds of the earth and its settlements, and the mature people and the young, until they reached its nearest and farthest, and possessed its last and first. They had the White and the Black, Fars the Red, and the Treasury the Yellow. But they were ungrateful for the blessings and deserved the vengeance. So Allah, Exalted is He, struck some of them with others and destroyed them in the world through treachery. They were as our poet said: "Treachery destroyed Ad in their dwellings... And oppression annihilated generations whose home was Al-Janad. From Himyar when oppression was public... From them against the event of days, so they were stripped away." Then tribes from Azd settled it during the time of Amr ibn Amir. They opened watering paths in it and built fortresses/cisterns (Masani') in it. So they had its inhabitant, its builder, its boatman(?), and its night-talker, until Madhhij exiled them with its weapons and carved them with its spears. So they evacuated from it reluctantly and left it visibly, and tried for it for a time. Then Madhhij shot with its spearheads and flowed with its reins, so the mighty conquered its humblest and the many ate its fewest. We, the assembly of Yahabir, were the pegs of its anchor, the arrangement of its first ones, and the rock of its course. Then droughts struck us in it, and despair drove us out of it, after we had planted trees in it and eaten fruits in it. Banu Amr ibn Khalid ibn Jadhimah used to beat its pruned branches, eat its harvested grain, and sip its broken branches until we departed from it. Then Qasi ibn Mu'awiyah and Iyad ibn Nizar settled in it. They did not join a rope in it...!, nor did they make food for it, nor were they satisfied last or first. When their children became wealthy and their number increased, they forgot the good trial between them and cut the knot of loyalty among them. War flew between them until some of them annihilated others. So return our land to us, O Messenger of Allah.' He said: Al-Akhnas ibn Shariq and Aswad ibn Mas'ud al-Thaqafi were present with the Messenger of Allah. So Al-Aswad ibn Mas'ud ibn Mughith said, answering him: 'O Messenger of Allah...

...indeed Banu Hani ibn Hadhlul ibn Hawdhala ibn Thamud were the inhabitants of Batn Wajj after the perishing of Mahla'il ibn Qaynan. Their dwellings were emptied and their residences left as ruins, and its buildings. So the Arabs avoided it with avoidance and shunned it with shunning, fearing that there might befall them what befell Ad and Thamud of the exposures to calamity and causes of misery. When Qahtan increased and its ravines became narrow for them, some of them drove others, so they migrated land by land. Banu Amr ibn Khalid ibn Jadhimah stayed. Then Qasi ibn Mu'awiyah and Iyad ibn Nizar marched to them and drove poison to them and led them to death. So they vacated it and headed from it to Yemen. Iyad sought half of the spoil, but Qasi refused them. Qasi was more numerous than Iyad and faster in the land. They caught up until war ignited in its hills, and they waded in its floods and expelled them from its highlands. They knelt upon Iyad with the chest and watered them with the cloud of death/destruction (Naytal) until its soft grounds, rugged grounds, backs, bellies, hills, and springs were empty for them. Iyad departed to Iraq, and Qasi stayed in Batn Wajj having no partner, eating its mallow, grazing its Sarh trees, beating its Talh trees, pollinating its palms, and possessing its plain and mountain.' The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: 'Indeed, the bliss of the world is less and smaller than a Khirbasisah (a tiny bead/thing). If it equaled a gnat's wing with Allah, Mighty and Majestic, a Muslim would not have need (Lihah) nor a disbeliever have a way out (Barah) in it. If the created being knew the extent of his day, it would narrow upon him despite its vastness, and neither joy nor ease would benefit him. But the term (death) was obscured for him, and hope was extended for him. It was named Jahiliyyah only because of the weakness of its deeds and the ignorance of its people. Whoever Islam overtakes while in his hand is ruin or cultivation, it is his, subject to the duty of his Zakat, for every pure believer or covenanted Dhimmi. Indeed the people of Jahiliyyah worshipped other than Allah, Mighty and Majestic. They have deeds they reach the term of, and ends they arrive at. The punishment is delayed from them until the Day of Reckoning. He gave them respite by His power, Majesty, and Might. So the mightier of them conquered the humbler, and the many of them ate the few. And Allah is the Highest, the Most Majestic. Whatever was in the Jahiliyyah is dropped (annulled), of shedding blood and violating a sacred thing. Allah has pardoned what is past...

...and whoever returns, Allah will take retribution from him. And Allah is Mighty, Owner of Retribution.' So the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, did not return it to Murad and judged it for Thaqif. Dhabian ibn Kadadah was satisfied and began to say: 'I testify by the Ancient House and Al-Safa... A testimony from whose excellence is accepted. That you are praised upon us, blessed... Loyal, trustworthy, truthful in speech, sent. You came with a light by whose like light is sought... And there is no fault in the saying that is sifted. Upon you is the acceptance of the One who is my God and Creator... And the mark of truth whose endeavor is accepted. I swore an oath by the One whose House is veiled... The oath of a man who does not plagiarize in speech. That you are the balance (Qistas) of all creation... And a scale of justice as long as Al-Mushallal stands.' A mountain. This speech entered the Book of Al-Iklil explained, so we neglected its explanation in this place. Mention of the Upper Parts of the Arabian Peninsula which are from Yemen and Hijaz along with the borders of Yamama and its Arud. Abu al-Hasan al-Khuza'i said—and he used to live in the land of Upper Najd, settled in its Arud, mixed with the people of Al-Sarat, and heard from everyone a portion of ancient news—they said: A severe crisis struck the people. They remained for a barren year, and they named it the Year of Al-Jumud (Freezing/Stagnation) due to the stagnation of winds in it, the cessation of rains, the loss and emaciation of livestock, the stability of high prices, the lack of foods, and the cutting off of waters in valleys and wells. The like of this year is called Al-Hutamah, Al-Azmah, Al-Lazbah, Al-Maja'ah, Al-Ramad, Kuhl, Al-Qasr, Al-Shiddah, and Al-Hajiz. So the people came with clamor, howling, and supplication to the Sacred House of Allah from the land of Najd, the sides of Hijaz, the land of Tihama, and the Sarawat, calling upon Allah, Mighty and Majestic, for relief for them and praying for rain. Among the delegation praying for rain from the people of Najd was a poet called Al-Hazazah al-Amiri. He recited poetry mentioning the blessings of Allah, Mighty and Majestic, in it and His mercy which encompassed them and encompassed their land, country by country, valley by valley, and mountain by mountain. He said: 'Lord, we call You, so answer. Forever... You uncover the distress from the creation. Indeed Job, when he called You, was not screened... Job had a Lord for whom the call is not [screened].'

'Harm touched him, so You answered the call for him... When the affliction harmed him. Indeed this Jumud is for the gray year... And the calamitous misfortune. So aid us, our God, and to You... is praise, with rain dragged by the Anwa' (stars). It revives the people in the settlements and the wild... And the dusty new earth comes to life. How many, then how many rains have I seen... Which the soft winds drive for You. It watered Al-Shihr, then Al-Mazun [Oman], then what... The possessors of Al-Qatif [Qatif] held, then Al-Ahsa. Then the Yamamas, then Al-Kilab, then Bahrain... Then Hazwa of Tamim, then Al-Wa'sa. Then the Nammars, then Al-Liwa from Athal... Then the two Aqiqs, Upper then Al-Jawa. Then Kathab al-Dabil, then the Upper... Humrah, then Qahr al-Wahaf and Al-Qawfa. Then upon Marib [Marib], then Najran [Najran], then Al-Jawf... Then Sana'a [Sana'a], a pouring, copious rain. Then the villages of Al-Hinu, then the Manadij from it... Then Sarum al-Kurum, then Al-Tarfa. Quenched, so for the descending of the rain... Upon it is a green gloom. It was cast to the clouds from the land of... Tathlith, then the land of Al-Hajirah, the fatigues. Then the Shu'aybat from Yabambam... Came to life, then their river bends, then Al-Maytha. The Kawr became grassy, the Kawr of Amir Taym... Where Harjab is, then Al-Madha. And the floods of Bisha flowed straight in... Its broad valleys (A'rad), so it is a dark abyss. And as if the palms from the belly of Turj... And it is Hawm, are dark darknesses. And in Hawran for the Awarik (camels eating Arak) and the sheep... And in the fertility of Athr is a clamor. The two bottoms of Tabala were quenched with rain... Then Dhuwat al-Asad, then Al-Abla. Then its Qurayha, then Ranyah has flowed... Then the valley of its Kilakh, then Al-Kura. Then Ukaz, then Dhu al-Majaz with the Harrah... Then Al-Abraqat, then Al-Jarda. Then its Kharida with Al-Hadn... The Exposed, then Al-Qarn, that one, and Al-Bawba. And upon Dhat Irq, then Al-Sayy, then Al-Rakba... From it is the persistent, heavy rain. And the two Harrahs of Sulaym were quenched and flowed... The ravine of the two Ma'dins, then Al-Ahma. Then its Dariyat, then Yarqat Thahlan... To its fortress the shepherds inclined. There flowed in Hajiz then the valleys of Al-Tawz... Floods for which the open space was too narrow.'

'Then Samira had a surge, and was watered... Like it, Al-Tha'labiyya the ash-colored. Then the two Hama's, Qarn Najd, then Rumman... Al-Hubayr, then Al-Dahna. Then the hills of Yahmad, then Aja and Salma [Ha'il]... The gazelles graze in their share. Fayd resembled Zubala in fertility... And likewise Al-Shuquq then Al-Qar'a. And the rain rose where Barqat Shamma is... And where Al-Ladhidh is, then Al-Khalsa. Then Mahyat, then Al-Safah, then Upper... Dhi Fataq, then Adhib, then Al-Wafa. Then Riyad al-Qata and the valleys of Sharabb... Then Al-Shu'batan, then Al-Abla.' These last two verses are included (Muddamman), and they belong to Al-Harith ibn Hilliza. These are the names of the lands of the Arabs and the known, famous, mentioned Najdi watering places which the Arabs of the people of Najd occupy and reside at their waters and pastures with caravans and livestock. Al-Hazazah mentioned them in order, so he enumerated them well and organized them masterfully. They said: The delegation praying for rain from the people of Tihama and its Sarawat heard this poem. Among them was a poet called Abu al-Hayyash al-Hajari from Al-Hajr ibn al-Hanu. They asked him to say poetry like what Al-Hazazah said. So Abu al-Hayyash began to say: 'Lord, he is not disappointed who called You, nor is... Supplication veiled from You, O Possessor of Majesty. The Prophet Jacob was not disappointed, O Possessor of... The Throne, in what hope called for with You. Lord, You are the One who returned to him... Sight which weeping had effaced. And his son Joseph, You gathered to him... After adversity had touched Joseph. Loneliness from him in the darkness of the pit... And in the prison when the stay was long. A mercy from You, grant us, for we are... To You, O Allah, slaves and bondmaids. Indeed this is a crisis that has encompassed the people... And misery has touched them because of it. And how many, then how many rains You have watered the earth for us... Brought by the Anwa'. Hadhramaut was watered from it... Along with Al-Ahqaf, a quenching, and Al-As'a was watered. It covered Abyan with floods up to... Its Lahj, and it and the sky were equal. That is Ahwar, and those are the Dathinas... Along with Al-Sarw, a green garden. And for Dhubhan, then Al-Ma'afir, then the coast... From its lowland is mist and clouds.'

'Then the villages of Shar'ab along with Upper Janad... Then what Al-Rabadi occupied, behind. Then the two Sahuls, then Al-Mudhaykhira the leafy... Were watered, then its Hays, the large. And it rained continuously pouring over Zabid [Zabid, Yemen]... Like what poured into the troughs, the buckets. And for Jabalan the flood flowed in Rima'... And the sky poured generously upon Dhuwal. And upon Surdud is a low cloud of generosity... With its watering it revived Al-Kadra. And for its La'san, then the land of Tamam... Then for Ayyan, a pouring continuous rain. It watered the Tawd of Haraz, then from Hawzan... A rain, for its two Haydas is cloud. Then the villages of Mawr, then Al-Quraydah, then Al-Sharjah... Then Al-Wadiya, then Al-Sal'a. And a black cloud darkened upon the villages of Harad... For two days with pouring rain. It watered for a while the villages of Khulab from it... Then that Jazan, then Al-Sabya. Then the villages of Baysh, then Al-Duwaymat, then Al-Birk... Then Haly, rained upon, leafy. And from the Tawd, then Al-Zaqamat are green... Quenched, then Al-Tanumah, the blooming. Then the villages of Al-Hajr, Jahwat of crops and udder... Then its Ashjan, Al-Hana, then Al-Jaba. Then the mountains of Al-Sarat, then the Middle Far'... Hakin, Al-Janan, then Al-Hayfa. Then the two Shadawans from Saqamah, then the stage... The broad, wide-eyed. Then the villages of Mughasil, then the valleys of the Nahbiyyin... Then the valley possessing wholesome springs. Then the peaks from Sarat Ghamid, then Al-Namir... Then the mountains of its Daws are dark. Then the villages of the two Darahs, a land upon... Its plain and the mountains is water. Then the Shababats, then the Ma'adin, then Ta'if... Then Al-Wayl, their land is a sky. Then Qanuha, then it crashed at Dawqah, then Al-Layth... Then Asham, Al-Sirrayn, then Al-Sara'ir.' These are the names of the lands of the Arabs, the watering places, and the Tihami and Sarawi valleys, known, famous, and mentioned, which the Arabs, the people of Tihama and its Sarawat, Bedouin and settled, occupy. Abu al-Hayyash al-Hajari enumerated them well and described them excellently in poetry. They said: And among the petitioners for rain from the people of Hijaz was a poet known as Al-Ajlani. His Hijazi companions said to him: 'Say for us poetry with which we oppose these two poets, and mention in your saying a likeness.' So he began to say:

'Lord, You alone we call and hope... And in You, O Possessor of Majesty, is the hope. So answer, our Lord, for indeed the supplication... Of the askers is not veiled from You. Give us rain so that the drought may leave us... And the hard years, the distress. Lord, indeed Hijaz, since the earth existed... Is a land where high prices persist. Except that Hijaz did not used to be missed... By the sky with the pouring of rains. It revives the destitute provider in fertility... And the dumb beast lives. Lord, indeed the crisis has swept away Hijaz... And evacuation has befallen its people. Lord, indeed the sky becomes morning and evening... Above it, weak, rosy, carrying [no rain?]. Its wind has frozen, so no pouring cloud... Has been seen in it for a year. And how much have I seen the water overflowing upon the plain... Along with the rugged ground in Hijaz. From rains following rains... Moving slowly, the Anwa' flowed with them. The mountains of Mecca drank from it until... They are like meadows, green, quenched. It resembled Al-Zayma, Al-Mughammas... And Al-Nakhla, then the two Mawqifs, then Al-Bathaa. Then its Madarij, Yalamlam, then Al-Amq... Then those coasts, Ilayhima (?). Then the two Fuqqas from Khadhariq, then Al-Farsh... Then that Jeddah, the large. Then Judaydat, then Al-Hawa'it, then Al-Barqa... That black Ghamimah. Then the two Kura's, then Al-Ghamim, aids... Then that Usfan, then Al-Barqa. The moistening covered the outskirts of Amaj... And its Fayha' Qudayd was revived. Then Al-Kulliyat, then Al-Sitara, then Al-Juhfa... Then Al-Quds all, then Al-Abwa. Then the outskirts of Batn Waddan, then Al-Jar... Then Badr, Yakayn (?), then Al-Safra. They were quenched by floods, a watering, and were watered... Along with that aiding Al-Rawha. Yanbu' was watered, so that courtyard of it... Then those estates, then Al-Sha'tha. And it flowed straight pouring from above Radwa... Then Buwat, bucket-like, heavy-hanging. From its bulk, Al-Is was quenched, then Al-Rass... Floods, then Al-Marwah, the white. And it continued pouring in Al-Hijr and Al-Wudd... Just as the buckets poured into the troughs. Khaybar was watered by it, then Yadi'... A continuous rain whose star (Naw') was Gemini.'

'Al-Qaa' became grassy, then the gardens of Yathrib [Medina]... From the rain, then the thirsty outskirts. The two Labas were watered, then the bloody Harrah... Then Wadi al-Aqiq, then Al-Hama. Then Al-Khulay'at, then Al-Sayyala, then Al-Far'... Then those dark caravans.' These are names. Al-Ash'ath al-Janbi describing the desert of Sayhad, and its path was from Wadi Najran: 'Will you not stay awake for a night-vigil lightning... A lightning fond of my love, Najdi (highland). A lightning reminding you of the maiden, that she... Hung her necklaces, tall of the neck (Musnad). She hung her necklaces, so there is nothing after her... With me diminishing her if I do not increase. And I remembered you then reviewed the passion... On the day of Al-Shara, and I prayed that you not be distant. And in the evening before the road, facing south... Al-Ara'is settled, returning from a manger. My diviners guessed in my soul that I would see... What I was threatened with of the desert of Sayhad. And lo, the desert of Sayhad is a wilderness... A maze whose winds remain unguided. And the murky ones of its sandgrouse remain confused... And go at evening without water and go at morning. A land where you imagine the crow when it appears... A king draped in sheets and wearing a cloak. So I asked when our landmarks disappeared... From Hadhramaut, by which star do we ransom ourselves? They said the Galaxy or Canopus appearing... Then they were guided in their return by the Farqad (Star). We swallow the terrors seeking Amir... Grieving for him if he is not found.' Al-Harith ibn Hilliza said mentioning places of their dwellings and the dwellings of their settling partners: 'Asma' announced her separation to us... Many a stayer of whom staying is wearied. After a covenant of ours at Barqat Shamma... Then its nearest dwellings, Al-Khalsa. Then Mahyat, then Al-Safah, then A'naq... Then Fataq, then Adhib, then Al-Wafa. I do not see whom I knew in it... So I weep today, lost in love, and what does weeping return? And with your eyes Hind kindled the fire... Finally, the high ground twists with it. She kindled it between Al-Aqiq and Shakhsayn... With wood, just as the light shines.'

'So I viewed her fire from afar... At Khazaza; how far is the warming fire from you.' Khazaza is a mountain in Najd, and Aqiq and Shakhsan are places. Al-A'sha has gathered places of their dwellings in two verses of poetry, saying: 'My family settled in Batn al-Ghamis, then Baduli... And Alawiyya settled in the plains. Grazing Al-Safh, then Al-Kathib, then Dhu Qar... Then Rawd al-Qata, then Dhat al-Ri'al.' Alqama ibn Zayd ibn Bishr, the brother of Banu Suhar ibn Khawlan ibn Amr ibn al-Haf ibn Quda'a, said seeking reinforcement against Hawazin and Banu Sulaym, and he described the lands he traversed from his country to Sa'dah, then from Sa'dah to Sana'a in the middle of the land of Hamdan: 'May thunderers water a ruin at Al-Jalhatayn... And white clouds whose flow is copious rain. Dwellings of Umm al-Husayn I knew... The time of which has become old while it is new. And anciently I see it, while it gathers passion... The era of youth sways in it and roams. She says—she from whose house we departed... With sad [camels] like the bows, generous. I see you have folded the flank in abandonment against the one... Whom you were fond of, and the heart of you is lovesick. So I said to her: I am hoping for a journey... To a pure king whom ancestors produced. To you, son of Dhu al-Tajayn, we marched with riding camels... Saddle-sore, as if they were soldiers. When they were sent forth, they left for the lion (Sab') a year... A meal, and their meal is the lands and the trot. To a cheerful one whose palm meanness did not tie... And whose fire-stick in noble deeds is not failing (Salud). A proud soul raised him to the heights... And valor, on the morning of valor from him is generosity. So when we entered the plain from under Buhtur... And a pillar of the morning light shone. We traveled the plain with them, the plain of Sahama... They have a rapid pace under us and a constant run. It vied with us like ghouls, wide... And a possessor of fluttering above the saddles sways. They folded Jamil al-Khaniqin in the early morning... And passed by the water of Al-Habt while it was Jewish (?). And she bid farewell to the two hills of Thaqif with Al-Ama... In the middle of the night while the worshippers were asleep. She crossed the water of Al-Amaysh when there appeared... From the shade, a swaying wing, still. To a king who gives the creation his wealth... And said to them: Return, and I will return.'

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Then the riders did not bypass, the swift camels marched ... whether the plains or the highlands were equal to them
If their hooves wiped the ground in steps ... you would think there were palms beneath them, cheeks
Come to the door of a man of standing ... in whom intellect was perfected while he was a child
Lean-bellied, long-armed, from the house of Aslam ... patient over the calamity of time, sturdy
They threw themselves at Bawban in the beginning of their night ... and the water of Athaf, while the Arabs were asleep
So Dhaqin greeted them in the morning, and our delegation magnified ... and stars and good fortunes met us
Heading for a youth from the best of whom ... the noble women of Dhuhl bore, and the glorious one is glorious
Khawlan says: The name of Dhi Yazan the Elder is Dhuhl, and Himyar says: Amir.
Perfection was completed in him, a position he did not attain by twist ... and a kingdom raised by new and old wealth
And he extended on the Day of Ghayman when he called ... from the sons of Amr, cubs and lions
And our mounts leaned towards the two corners of 'Ajib ... lowered and raised by a lowering for him and an ascent
They hope for victory from you, O best master ... and you are a reacher of the relative, loving
And a protector of the neighbor's grazing livestock from the distance of his house ... for fear of you over it where there was deviation
You protected more protectively than enemies settled by ... the horsemen of Qays, and the fleeing one defends
When we leveled the head of a towering mountain ... we traversed it, and the belly of the plain was far from it
To Al-Ghulaha the spacious, falling with youths ... their drink from us is night travel and sleeplessness
And I have left my house, Jama', and its people ... to you, and in it are wealth and number
And a house surrounded by vineyards and crops ... and between it a lofty built fortress
And lean camels leaned towards the parts of Hayfah ... lean, in their marching is slowness
When we saw who removed its palaces ... a bringer of news and a messenger raced
And we saw nothing but the follower of the earth, a journey ... to its greatest house, and we are servants
O Abu al-Mundhir the Overflowing, O best of Himyar ... and best of Banu Dhuhl, it wants you
It wants a gift from abundant buckets ... for you are useful to it in calamities
Lean camels that have folded a mountain pass and a plain ... and went in the evening in a night whose cold was severe
And cut the wilderness of the earth from the two dung-hills of Dafa ... to you, and you give wishes and increase
I turned the people to you, their wounds bleeding ... so that ulcers and wounds from them might heal

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
And an arrow from them, hairless, is feathered ... and one day it misses you while it is straight
And we return from you with what leaves the enemies ... scattered, among them fearful and fugitive
By your life, I do not offer other than my affection ... and for my wealth, other than what you knew, there are witnesses

Tarafa said, gathering parts of the land of Madhhij in a verse:
Do you know the trace of the house, its dwellings desolate ... like the sheath of the Yemeni sword, the decoration of embroidery resembles it
At Tathlith or Najran or where meet ... from the Najd in the lowlands of Jash, flowing waters

Labid gathered much of Najd and Hejaz in his Great Poem, saying:
The dwellings have been effaced, their place so their station ... at Mina, its Ghul then its Rjam became eternal
Mina Manun is a place near Takhfah in the Hima in the lands of Ghani. Mina of Mecca is other than Manun. From Mina, leather (Adim) was taken, and it is 'Atanah. In the tradition, Adam, peace be upon him, wished (tamanna) to see Eve at Mina, so it was named Mina for that, and she came from Jeddah, so they recognized each other (ta'arafa) at Arafat. Al-Rajmah, Al-Rajamat, and Al-Rijam are mountains in the plain, small like subtle hills. Al-Ghawl, Al-Waghl, and Al-Ghulaha are one, and it is what curved of the earth.
Traces that passed after the era of their intimate companion ... years passed, their lawful and their forbidden
It was pushed and the mirage separated from it as if it were ... the parts of Bisha, its tamarisk and its rocks
A Murri woman settled in Fayd and neighbored ... the people of Hejaz, so where is her destination from you?
At the eastern parts of the two mountains or at Mahjar ... then Fardah then its Rukham contained her
Places of Banu Asad and Ghani. So Sawa'iq, if she became widowed, then a place of thought ... from it, and the sides of Al-Qahr or its Talkham
At the rugged grounds of Al-Thalbut, above it watches ... the desolation of the watchtowers, its markers are its fears
She was distracted, remaining confused in the ends of Sa'a'id ... seven complete twins, their days
And it is narrated: In the clefts of 'Alij. Al-Shaqiqah is a land split between two sands. And from it:
Thick-necked lions threatening with vengeance as if they were ... the Jinn of Al-Badi, their feet firmly fixed

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Al-Badi is a place to which the abundance of Jinn is attributed, and it is hardly known, just as the Jinn of 'Abqar and the Jinn of Dhi Simar are said. Dhi Simar is a known place. They say Ghul al-Rabadat is a known place in Najd. And the Jinn of Wabar, which is a land where nations of the original Arabs were, and I have not met anyone who knows it. Tashadhdhar: he likened them to the she-camel when she threatens (tashadhdharat), which is to raise her tail when goaded, tying her tail, sprinkling with her urine.

Abu Dawud said, mentioning several places of the localities of Iyad:
Ta'ar has become desolate of the herds of my people ... then Arum, then Shabah, then Al-Sitar
After the herd of my people was for a time ... theirs were all the palm trees and the seas
Then to Al-Dur, then the deserts from them ... then Hafir, then Na'im, then the houses
For their dwellings have become the belly of Falaj ... and a destination for their summer is Ta'shar
Al-Dur are gaps opening in the sand. And by Falaj he means ropes of sand. He also said:
The monastery and the sandy hills have become desolate of my people ... then Gharaq, then Ramih, then Khafiyah
Then the watercourses of Al-Mala to the bank of Sindad ... then Qaww, to the slopes of Tumayyah
Al-Ajjaj said about Al-Dur while describing a bull:
From Al-Dabil spreading to Al-Dur ... he rides every barren sand dune

Zuhayr said, mentioning eight places:
The cupbearers mixed in its bowl a cold [water] ... from the water of Linah, neither muddy nor turbid
I continued to watch them until the hands of the camels ... descended with them from Rakis into a cleft
Near to Sharura or the stand of Adam ... the drivers striving to their traces in groups
And from it also:
So he traveled from it on a nature intending with it ... the two sides of 'Amayah, then Al-Raka', then Al-'Umq
This Adam is a mountain in Hejaz, and Adam is a mountain in Yemen. And Al-Dimm and Al-Dawm are in Yemen. He said mentioning others:
They sacrificed a little at the dunes of Asnimah ... and from them at Al-Qasumiyat is a battlefield
Then they continued and said: Indeed your drinking place ... is water at the east of Salma, Fayd or Rakak

Al-A'sha said:

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
And I toured for wealth its horizons ... Oman and Homs, then Urishalam
I came to the Negus in his house ... and the land of the Nabit and the land of the Persians
Then Najran, then Al-Sarw of Himyar ... so which destination for it did I not aim for?
And after that to Hadramawt ... so I fulfilled my concern and at times I intend
Urishalam is Iliya (Jerusalem). Al-A'sha also said:
Did you not see me tour what is between Ma'rib ... to Aden, then Al-Sham, and Al-Sham is deviating
And Dha Fa'ish I visited in a prohibited place ... from the peak, in it for the ibexes are watering places
In Ba'dan or Rayman or the head of Saliyah ... is a cure for one who complains of the hot winds, cool
And in the palace of Iryab, if you spent a night ... iced water, freezing, would come to you
And I drank with Fahd in Al-Ma'afir for an era ... and Fahd is generous, promises do not resemble him
And Qays at the top of Hadramawt, I sought his pasture ... for excellent is the father of guests while the night is stagnant

Tarafa said, and it is said to be for Al-Khirniq:
The Sahb has been effaced of the family of Layla ... then Al-Amlah, then Al-Ghamr, then 'Irq
Then Al-Rimah, then Al-Liwa is empty of its people ... and Ubli to Al-Gharra'
Then Al-Mawan, then Al-Hajar ... then the waters of Al-Duna, then Al-Najd
Then the desert, then Al-Nasr ... a wilderness grazed by the wild cows, then Al-Zalman, then Al-'Afr

Abu Dawud said describing rain:
And a rain from which the winds carry ... dark heavy clouds and heavy laden clouds
When the winds of the south drive it back ... they impregnate from it lean, barren clouds
And if it goes to rise the rising of the broken one ... the water pushes its chest until it flows
So its chest settled at Dhi Sal' ... you think the lightning flashes in it are wicks
So it quenched Al-Darafa from La'la' ... pouring buckets and cutting buckets
You think the sandgrouse in the forenoon ... settled at Al-Daqari, drinking remnants

Imru' al-Qays said and mentioned ten places of the land of Bahrain:
I covered the dwellings of the tribe at Al-Bakrat ... then 'Arimah, then Burqat al-'Ayrat

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Then Ghawl, then Hullit, then Nif', then Min'aj ... to 'Aqil, then the well of Dhu al-Amrat
And he said and mentioned ten places of the land of Bahrain:
To whom belong the dwellings I knew at Suham ... then the two 'Amamahs, then Hadb Dhi Iqdam
Then Safa al-Atit, then the two Sahahs, then 'Asim ... the ostriches walk in them with the gazelles
Do you not see their litters at 'Aqil ... like the palm trees of Shawkan at the time of harvest?
He also said:
Shatb has been effaced of its people, then Gharur ... then Mawbulah; indeed the dwellings revolve
Then the bend of Muhayyah, as if Salamah ... did not stay in it for a full year, nor Qadhur

Dhu al-Rummah said:
The days pass for us while not a glimpse ... of an eye from other than us has glanced at us to Shafar
They passed from the crests of Lubn and Ghamrah ... then when they recognized Al-Yamama from 'Afr
They turned away from Qarran deliberately and who was in it ... of people, and their night travel turned away from Hajar
And they became at Al-Hawman making a direction ... for their necks the Capricorn or the rising of dawn
So they resolved in the desert of Al-Daww after ... they met what is after the calamity of leanness
And they became crossing Al-Kawadim to the right ... and their middles were agitated from whistling
I say, and poetry and the brides are between us ... and the brown peaks of the hills of Nasifat al-Humr
If people are mentioned, then mention with praise ... Bilal your brother, Al-Ash'ari Abu Amr

And for Kuthayyir:
Squadrons of horses still dark ... against them, they worked every day its fighting
Pushing at Al-Rawha' at times, and at times ... the passes of Radwa, its low ground, then its sands
They approach at Al-Bazwa' while the army is standing ... the waterskins of the camels, they pour their remnants
And they faced from it Thara, seeking crossing ... scalpels from the face of Thara, then its Thughal
And horses at 'Anat, then the tooth of Sumayrah ... for him, the defenders do not repel their thirst
Thara is the bottom of Wadi al-Ji. And he said:
The soft grounds of Kalfa have been effaced after us, then Al-Ajawil ... then the water holes of Husna, then the facing stony grounds

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
As if Su'da was not at the sides of Ghayqah ... and no dwellings of Su'da were seen in them
And she did not summer at Al-Sarir, and for him ... the summer was not the tents of Al-'Udhayb, the shading ones
To you, Ibn Layla, the white camels mount my companionship ... throwing us from two kneeling places, Al-Munaqil
Penetrating the hot stones of Al-Khabib as if they were ... sandgrouse approaching the water numbers of Hulwan, drinking
And you, Abu Shiblayn, sharp of his weapon ... Khufyah is a familiar place for him, then Al-Ghayatil
He has at the south of Al-Qadisiyyah, then Al-Shara ... places where pedestrians do not walk
And he said, mentioning much of the places between Mecca and Yathrib:
O my two friends, in the morning my tears ... preceded the glance of her eye by pouring
Stand and reflect, and you are more seeing than me ... do you see at Al-Ghamim any camels?
Fulfilling a need from a kneeling place ... and circumambulation and a standing at the mountains
The Arabs say "We stood at the mountains" and we know they meant Arafat:
They were shown to me at the rugged ground of Faydah trotting ... like the Jew from Nata'ah, the jumping ones
They said 'Usfan, then went quickly ... rising in the evening from Ghazal
Gnawing Al-Kadid, crossing ... every valley of Al-Juhuf with loads
Intending Lift while they are arranged ... like the heavy ships, joining the followers
When they leaned their hips on Dawwah on the right ... and the bed of Al-Badi' on the left
They crossed Wadi al-Miyah attending ... the path of Al-'Arj, traveling the gaps
And Al-'Ubayla' was on their left ... and they left Al-'Aqiq, the possessor of arrowheads
Rising from Al-Ghamis from the side of 'Abud ... striking Al-Khuwayy from Amlal
He also said:

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
And what reminder is the dust of Khasilah after ... she departed by the middles of Al-Marad, then Taghlam
So they became at Al-La'ba' throwing pebbles ... the extent of every wild one to them and seeking
Parallel to the hills of Al-Mudayyah and avoided ... the mountains of the Hima and the two Akhshabs at Akhram
To you she vies after I said the mountains of ... Al-Shaba had appeared or she veered from the hills of Tarim
The white camels traverse the desert with us as if they were ... sandgrouse of Al-Kadr which became near a drying well of Damdam
Complaining at the top of Dhu Jarawil at midnight ... soles of them dyeing the flint with blood
The noble Himyari mounts surpass my companionship ... with a white camel rising over fatigue, stoning
As if the mounts fear from Zabanah ... the shoulders of a corner from Nidad, gathered
Come, and they have veered from the landmarks of 'Abid ... with their left corners the hills of Al-Muqattam

He said describing rain over much of Hejaz:
The black dark clouds watered Umm Kulthum at the distance of her house ... and her women, early
Black, trembling, its white clouds pouring ... it has partitions, rushing, returning
The arrogant one ascended in the bends ... black, heavy, thundering, raining together
And turned away from Dhahban, its peaks drowned ... the Hajirs summered from it with the dripping waters
And Dhahban is in Rahbat Sana'a.
It stayed on Jamdan a day and a night ... so Jamdan from it is standing, shortened
And camped at Al-Sakran two days and leaned ... and dragged as the staying traveler drags

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
With a fringe, black, the east wind accomplishes it ... and pushes it the push of the young gazelle while it is weary
And it flooded the sides of Al-Marabid in the morning ... and Dahik and Al-'Awaqir flooded from it
And from it in the desert of Al-Mahw, blue are its clouds ... it has flowing rain, and Al-Ghafa'ir became desolate from it
And it covered from the direction of Al-Najil as if it were ... at Yalil when it left the palm trees behind, roaring
And it passed and quenched Yanbu', then its south ... and Jaydah was watered from it, then 'Abathir
It has branches, of them Yemeni and pouring ... Levantine and Najdi, and another lowland (Gha'ir)
When it approached the two Labahs (lava fields), leading it were ... sweeping black clouds with white clouds, billowings
It anchored between Sal' and Al-'Aqiq and Fari' ... to Uhud, the rain clouds have violence in it
With black creeping clouds as if its thunder ... threatens camels that have rumblings
So it became pouring water over Wa'irah ... it has at Al-Liwa and the two valleys confusions
Then it ceased from 'Ush and became a cloud ... recovering, and the horizons of the sky are revealing
So every stream from Tihamah is good ... wide streams flow in it, uprooting
Uprooting the ancient thorny trees as if they were ... in its middles lions having roaring
Leaving fallen Arak and Tandub ... and leaving blue [water] in the middles of the seas
And every stream over which the sun set ... the irrigation of Pleiades between it is neighboring
And no mother of a fawn in Al-'Ulayah, a gazelle ... for whom a fresh Ban tree from Al-Mard obeyed
She grazes the two Burdains with it, then her resting place is ... the peaks of Salam trees to which the gazelles retreat
Is better than the mother of Al-Hurayth in age ... in the evening, my tear is flowing, rushing

He also said:
As if the litters of her howdahs ... at Ghayqah when they descended Al-Baratha
Soft white women on a Maitheb ... great of trunks, they settled at Bu'atha
Like the blackness of the mounts with their loads ... they left early from Samahij or from Juwatha
When my family settled at the two Abraqs ... the Abraq of Dhi Jadad or Du'atha
And a nature came from its land ... hills growing clover, soft grounds
Juwatha is from Bahrain and Du'atha in Tihamah.

'Ubayd said:
Malhub has become desolate of its people ... then Al-Qutbiyat, then Al-Dhanub

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Then Rakis, then Thu'aybat ... then Dhat Firqayn, then Al-Qalib
Then 'Ardah, then Qafa Hibr ... so there is no dweller of its people

Imru' al-Qays said:
O friend, do you see lightning, I show you its flash ... like the flashing of hands in a crowned cloud?
Its light shines, or the lamps of a monk ... who tilted the oil on the twisted wicks
I sat for it with my companions between Darij ... and Al-'Udhayb, after what I contemplated
It ascended Qatan with the shower, the right of its downpour ... and its left on Al-Sitar then Yadhbul
So it became pouring water over Kutayfah ... overturning the great Kanahbul trees on their chins
And passed over Al-Qinan from its spray ... so it brought down the mountain goats from every dwelling
And Tayma, it left not a palm trunk within it ... nor a fortress except built with stones, destroying
As if Thabir in the noses of its rain ... was a chief of people wrapped in a striped garment
As if the peak of the head of Al-Mujaymir in the morning ... from the torrent and scum was the whorl of a spindle
And it threw its chest on the desert of Al-Ghabit ... the descending of the Yemeni, possessor of bags, the loaded one
And he said in the like of it:
I sat for it with my companions between Darij ... and between the watercourses of Tathlith, then Al-'Arid
It hit Qutayyat, so Al-Liwa flowed for it ... then Wadi al-Badi', so it ended to flourish

Al-A'sha said describing a cloud:
So I said to the drinkers in Darna while they were drunk ... Look, and how does the drunk drinker look?
At lightning whose falling place shines on the bends ... and at Al-Habiyyah from it is a cloud appearing
They said Namar, then Najd al-Khal, it watered them ... then Al-'Asjadiyah, then Al-Abwa', then Al-Rijl
