Then Al-Safh flows, then Khinzir, then its sandy ground ... until Al-Rabw and Al-Habl pushed from it
Then it carried the water from it, burdening it ... Warad al-Qata, then the soft dune of Al-Ghaynah

Al-Shammakh said describing the watering places of donkeys:
And she remained at A'raf as if her eyes ... to the sun, do dry wells approach?
And she intended them in the belly of Ghab and Ha'ir ... and before her from Rahrahan are the deserts
Upon her are the clouds originating as if they were ... howdahs upon which fleece is tied

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
She runs when it blazes over her and protects herself ... as the stallion protects himself from the pregnant camels, the fast ones
So he passed with her over Al-Hubayl, so she crossed ... 'Asha', and she almost did not cross at Sharaf
And she intended to drink at Al-Qattain, but blocked her ... the strait of Al-Kura' and Al-Qinan, the pushing ones
And she turned away a turning from Wadi'at 'Athlab ... and no Banu 'Iyad in the chests are slaughtered camels
And Amir drove her away from Dhu al-Arakah ... the brother of Al-Khadr, shooting where the hunting archers shoot

Shabib ibn al-Barsa' said:
To whom belong the dwellings I covered at Sanam ... then the two Abraqs, then the peak of Al-Arjam?
Then Al-Saykaran to Dajuj as if they were ... leaves of scriptures written with pens
Kalbi dwellings, the drought cast them away ... the sanctities of Jawsh and the courtyard of Islam

Al-Mutalammis said:
Do you have Al-Sadir and Bariq ... and Mubayid, and do you have Al-Khawarnaq?
And the palace of Sindad possessor of ... the cubic chambers and the pollinated palm trees?
And Al-Ghamr and Al-Ahsa' and the pleasures ... from Sa' and Daysaq?
And Al-Qadisiyyah, all of it ... and Al-Jawf from 'An and Talq?

Al-Qutami said describing rain on places:
I stayed awake, while the exposure of lightning was before me ... for lightning that spent the night blazing a blaze
It lowered at Al-Sahah from Munaym ... and watered Al-'Ayn and spread over Al-Ghamar
And spent the night bringing down from the two mountains of Nawar ... the crests of its torrent, huge rocks
It pours and drowns the high grounds from it ... and sends the herds of wild cows from their resting places
It hunts the ibexes when it rises over them ... even if they went far in fleeing from panic
And a rope from Habalah is renewed ... I showed to its people nothing but remembrance
It overlooks me at Dumah, O my people ... whenever I said it has risen, it turned back

Zuhayr said:
To whom belongs a ruin like writing, he left his dwellings ... Al-Rass was effaced of it, then Al-Rasiss, then 'Aqil
Then Raqad, then Sarat, then the sides of Min'aj ... then the east of Salma, its basin, then its water holes
Then Wadi al-Badi', then Al-Tawi, then Thadiq ... then Wadi al-Qinan, its width, then Afakil

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
Zuhayr also said:
They sacrificed a little at the dunes of Asnimah ... and from them at Al-Qasumiyat is a battlefield
Then they continued and said: Indeed your drinking place ... is water at the east of Salma, Fayd or Rakak

Al-Aswad ibn Ya'far said:
The people of Al-Khawarnaq and Al-Sadir and Bariq ... and the palace with balconies of Sindad
They settled at Anqarah, flowing upon them ... the water of the Euphrates flowing from mountains
A land chosen for the goodness of its resting place by ... Ka'b ibn Mamah and Ibn Umm Du'ad

Al-Muthaqqib said:
Why did the litters overlook from Sabib ... and did not arrive from the valley for a time?
They passed by Sharaf, then Dhat Rijl ... and veered from Al-Dharanih to the right
And they were like that the day they crossed Falaj ... their loads were on ships

Ibn Maqrum said:
He swerved from the watering places of Batn Amr ... and Al-Kura' deprived him of the coast
So the nearest water source from where they went ... is Athal or Ghamazah or Nita'

Abd Bani al-Has'has said describing rain:
Its light illuminates the hills, the hills of Mutali' ... and how dear that lightning would be if it were high
I delighted in it in mind and became certain that it ... brings down the ibexes and the anchored rocks
And the wind did not move it until I thought it ... at Harrat Layla or at Nakhlah, staying
So it passed over the water holes, and its cloud roared ... and thundered for a long time, pouring water quietly
Heaped up, pouring water from every opening ... and leaving in the lowlands turbid and clear [water]
And it passed over the mountains, the mountains of Tayy ... as you watered the hoof-injured, barefoot
Hoarse, thundering, its torrent with its rain ... you see the wood of the thickets floating in it
It has partitions of it circling around it ... bursting the holes in the soft grounds
When it lowered to the mountains and their people ... and the people of the Euphrates, it crossed the sea, passing
It wept its sorrow and raged until I thought it ... from the thunder when the thunder rumbled, chanting
So the bulls became drowned, so ... the women of Tamim became picking up the horns

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text: Description of the distance of twenty-four days from the Arabian Peninsula in natural poetry, and published with the description of camels and deserts, except Ahmad ibn Isa al-Rada'i, may Allah have mercy on him, from Khawlan Al-'Aliyah. He lived in Rada' from the land of Yemen, and from there he described the lands to Mecca on the highway of Sana'a in the land of Upper Najd. I have heard something by a man from Basra describing the road of Basra which is not satisfactory, rather weak. Abu Yusuf ibn Abi Fadalah al-Abnari, grandfather of Abu Yusuf who was in the time of Muhammad ibn Yu'fir, said poetry in the highway of Sana'a, a weak Urjuzah poem, so it was abandoned and neglected until it was erased and those who recited it were lost, except for verses that have no strength or nature. Many of the people of Sana'a, especially the Abna' (Persian descendants), had changed things in Al-Rada'i's poem out of rivalry and envy, so there was no correct copy of it in Sana'a. I ceased not to seek its correctness until I heard it from Ahmad ibn Muhammad ibn Ubayd from Banu Layf of the Persians. He did not enter into partisanship nor diminish anyone's right. The family of Layf were two groups, a group living in Rada' and a group in Sana'a. He said to me: Ahmad ibn Isa recited it to me in Rada' ten verses by ten verses until I memorized it while I was young, so it will not leave me. It is as I heard it with all its dialects, except what was defective in it due to necessity and had no benefit, so I educated and corrected it. I explained from it what its language did not fall to the common people. This Urjuzah is unique in its art unless followed by a glorious rhymer and an eloquent poet. He had other poetry which was not bad.

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
The Hajj Urjuzah
Ahmad ibn Isa al-Rada'i, may Allah have mercy on him, said:
The first of what I begin my speech with ... is praise to the Bestower, Possessor of Majesty
And bounty, blessings, and favor ... and dominion and high elevated grandness
Count, my friend, how many nights have passed ... of the month of Dhu al-Qa'dah with Shawwal
Then sleep on the saddle on a swift she-camel ... 'Idiyyah or a long-tailed male camel
The place of the ropes has become thin from him ... then call the people to depart
Youths of truth from the sons of your father ... for they are more worthy of what concerns you
And the quickest of people to what pleases you ... I will purify for you what I purify for you
So listen to my saying when I advise you ... commands multiples of what he gives you
Whoever you see him desiring and increasing in you ... then call upon a Lord, an Owner, a King
For He is more worthy to suffice you ... and say my companions, depart quickly
He said and recited:
For He is more worthy of who suffices you
Some Arabs say for Abd al-Malik: Abd al-Malik. Maymun ibn Hariz said:
He did not throw a gathered rock ... and compete in highness with Abd al-Malik
Until when they became cheerful for departure ... for they are at Kawr al-Mays and Al-Shalil
The back of a white, wide-stepping, frightening she-camel ... a slave blacksmith did not tread her on a young camel
And she did not turn before the afternoon ... to a young camel, no, nor a young foal

book_title: Description of the Arabian Peninsula (Sifat Jazirat al-Arab)
text:
And she did not submit to the excellent male camel ... then Al-Hash, then Al-Aghwal, then Al-Ghalil
These are five places in 'Urush Rada'. Muhayyil means frightening whoever sees her. Lam tatumha: did not check on her when she longed for the foal.
At the two Ajra's then Hima Akrab ... then Al-Damanin to Al-Shahbab
So they entered Ihram from it to Al-Tha'lab ... places protected in sides
Then to Habban, possessor of humps ... its source from the watering place of Al-Tarhab
Then to Gharbiyat al-Ansab ... a thousand pure camels, legs of the giver
A dark cloud debated her ... with a pouring, abundant flow
So she is a strong, stubborn she-camel whenever ... the shepherd excited her when he sang
I likened her to the strong, colliding wild ass ... the Aquarian (cloud) debated her when it poured
And milked the Nawa' (star) of Al-Simak al-Murzim ... with a high lightning when it blazed
Or a thunderer of continuous rain then rumbled ... so the plant became mature by it and flourished
Yellow and Hawdhan and starry herbs ... and Silliyan and black Nasiy
These are types of plants. He likened the she-camel to a wild donkey.
That is her pasture, and Talh and Gharz ... and Thayyal which the jumping one surrounded
And the obstacle of Baqhar from Dhat al-Sharz ... so the back became fat from it and became strong
And the caper bush ascended high and rose ... and the neck vein from her became silent so it was silent
And the dry elbow appeared and protruded ... with a thick upper arm so it became compact
So she is like the wolf of the desert at the spurring ... hasty when the rider in the stirrup jumps
He likened the she-camel to a wild donkey. Al-Gharz is the stirrup of the saddle, and Al-Gharz is where he spurs with his heel. Admza means lowered. And the she-camel kept silent on her cud means she closed her jaws. He mentioned the upper arm here and feminized it in a second place saying 'with a thick upper arm'. Al-Sid is the wolf.

He says: Whenever he plants his foot in the saddle, she [the camel] leaps, just as Dhu al-Rumma said: 'Until when he settled into her stirrups, she leaps... behold that one with the early riser in front of the riders... A strong, high-humped camel that has fulfilled the time of the girdle strap... in a lush pasture and a moist existence... pacing briskly in the shade of a spacious courtyard... at a sweet watering place and fertile grazing land... in that, she does not bend affectionately to the voice of the young camel. It is You I call upon, so answer, O my Lord... You are my hope, my trust, and my sufficiency... and my Companion in my distance and my proximity... so forgive me the sin and accompany my companions.' The 'Mart'a' (pasture) is the place she grazes in, meaning she visits it; and 'tastann' (pacing briskly) means she grazes freely. It is said: 'Give the riding camels their 'sanan',' meaning their direction/course. 'Rata'a fi sannihi' means in his intended direction. From that comes 'Sir 'ala sananika,' meaning on your intended path. 'Sanan' is running with stability. 'Haqab' is a long time. 'Rakb' is a location. 'I call upon You, O Possessor of glorified sovereignty... and Possessor of highness in His eternal might... He who has not ceased existing since pre-eternity and will not run out... and He who did not beget a child and was not begotten. Send blessings upon the Guide, the guided Prophet... upon the chosen Prophet, Muhammad. And resurrect him, O Possessor of Grace, on the Day of Witnessing... [to] his Praiseworthy Station, devoid of hardship. And give him from Your eternal might... a share that is painful to the hearts of the envious. And succeed him in his progeny and his family... O Lord, and whoever supports them, support him. And increase him in honor upon his honor... and extend provision to him from Your lawful bounty. And give him from You the abundance in his wealth... O Lord, and whoever is hostile to them, discard him... by his deed, O Lord, or his speech... and take him in blindness due to his error. And devise against him, O Lord, in his devising... and intervene against him, O Lord, regarding his impossible ambiguity.'

The Travel Supplication at the Exit: 'O Lord, O Revealer of the verses of the Surahs... forgive us the sin, for You are the most worthy to forgive. Then suffice us against emaciation and the hardship of travel... and evil from the return at the chest [heart/return]. And fold for us the distance and bless the trace... and grant us wellness, O Lord, from the evil of the gaze... regarding family and wealth, and from the evil of destiny... and ease the rough terrain and the caution of distress. O companion, stand and depart, and leave behind the thought... and say: O Deity of creation, keep hardship away from us.' The word 'Dhanb' intends sins, just as it is said: 'He is ja'd al-sha'rah' (curly of hair) intending hair [plural]. 'Wa'tha' al-Safar' means the hardship. 'The beginning of his journey, then drive the white camels with a sharp chiding... possessing a pace, not a tottering trot... and call unto Allah, the Majestic, the Judge... the Ratifier of the matter of the unseen and the decreer. O Lord, so divert the occurrence of symptoms... from my company and the presentation of diseases. Then meet us from You with a pleased face... until when she passed the 'Farad'... where the torrent, possessor of overflow, flowed... in a green place possessing meadows and gardens.' These are locations between Dara' [Yemen] and Asbil [Yemen]. The 'Anaq', 'Hadajan', and 'Ifad' are types of walking/marching. 'The people took their mid-morning rest and said farewell... and it was said to the riders who saw them off: Stand and greet your companions then return... so eyes flowed revealing the longing. Then the young female camels moved quickly, glistening... just as the falling sandgrouse moved quickly.' And the people said 'Allahu Akbar' together and gathered... and the people ascended a high path towards 'Ans [Yemen]... where the filled 'Karif' (cistern) flows out... then Al-Haruj [Yemen] and upon it is the watering place.' Meaning like the flying of the sandgrouse from their nesting hollows. It is narrated: 'Then young female camels moved quickly, limping.'

And it is narrated: 'Then they moved quickly, freely, glistening.' The 'Mulammi'' is a march in which there is looking back. The 'Karif' is a large hollow in a rock where water remains for a year or more. Al-Haruj is a location in the land of 'Ans of Madhhij [Yemen]. 'Then the rest stop of her night is Asiyy... where the Prophet built his bath. Until when the riding camels fell down [to rest]... and drowsiness began to overtake the soul. And a night covered him possessing a humming sound... she blew/moved as the Kudri sandgrouse moves... from the back of Shoukan [Shoukan, Yemen] having a hunger... a croaking camel-driver urges her on... his concern is the night journey and moving forward... then the mid-morning stop is the thirst-quenching spring.' By 'his bath', he intends the Bath of Solomon son of David, peace be upon him. 'Khawa' means extended in his stride/reach, and from it 'Khawa' for prayer, meaning he opened up [his arms], and the camel 'hawa' meaning opened up while kneeling. Imru' al-Qais said: 'Like the palm trees of Shoukan [Shoukan, Yemen] at harvest time.' 'Possessor of a hump, then the second evening rest stop... Yakla [Yemen] and her crossing point upon me are equal. And she has fulfilled her needs from the wells of Al-Khawlani [Bi'r al-Khawlani, Yemen]... from a lush watering place... surrounded by peaches and pomegranates... and her concern is the journey possessing submission. Sana'a [Sana'a, Yemen], I mean the Garden of Gardens... where the Palace of Ghumdan [Ghumdan Palace, Sana'a, Yemen] was constructed. The land of piety, righteousness, and kindness... within it is my resting place and within it are my brothers.' He said: 'Ab'ur' (wells) while intending the Well of Al-Khawlani because the location is called by this name, and in it are wells, just as he said: 'To the dunes (Kathibat) a path that has been decided.' And the dune is one. Likewise, the Arabs say: 'We took the path of the 'Shaqarat'' while it is one 'Shaqrah' (anemone/plant), and 'We took the path of the 'Dahad' (slippery places) to Najran [Najran, Saudi Arabia]' while they are two slippery spots. Another said: 'When the riders mounted the two slippery spots... they were content with fatigue and exhaustion.' 'Sana'a [Sana'a, Yemen], possessor of houses and fortresses... and the most ancient antiquity, possessor of the ancient kings (Quddam)... and the glory from the possessor of power, the oppressor... Sam [Shem] son of Noah laid its foundation with knowledge.'

'With the knowledge of a Lord, a King, All-Knowing... when Sam [Shem] sought it out without delusion. And he sought it out two thousand years before... between the two slopes of Nuqum the Vengeful [Mount Nuqum, Sana'a, Yemen]... and between Ayban the Visible, the Lofty [Mount Ayban, Sana'a, Yemen]... so he laid its foundation in the days of old.' The 'Atam' are fortresses raised from clay/mud, so he likened the homes of Sana'a [Sana'a, Yemen] to them due to their height. The 'Quddam' is the King. 'Dhu al-Satwa' (Possessor of Power) is Tubba'. It is mentioned that the first to build it after the Flood was Sam [Shem], and that it was inhabited between Adam and Noah for two thousand years. Nuqum and Ayban are the two mountains of Sana'a [Sana'a, Yemen]. 'So it is, by the saying of knowledge without doubt... the enclosed knowledge and the abode of kingship. And the protection of the frightened refugee until the destruction [of the world]... Nay, by the runner of the cleaving ships. An oath not mixed with falsehood... indeed Sana'a [Sana'a, Yemen] has surpassed the Abode of Polytheism. In time, from the glory of a complaint-worthy spring... and it became a mine for the people of worship. May rain fall on Sana'a [Sana'a, Yemen] with a generous flow... and followed by glory of high elevation.' 'Al-Ma'zul' is from 'Al-Azl', the frightened one. And he says: It surpassed the houses of polytheism in the Jahiliyyah (Pre-Islamic period) and surpassed in Islam through the worship of its people. 'A land of a king, he who measures errs... a land against Sana'a [Sana'a, Yemen] which has a foundation. As long as he does not count the Haram [Mecca, Saudi Arabia], the Friendly... a land in which is Ghumdan [Ghumdan Palace, Sana'a, Yemen] and Al-Qalis [Al-Qalis Church, Sana'a, Yemen]. Built by the Possessor of Valor, the Chief... Tubba' the King and the daughter of Bilqis [Queen of Sheba]. So it is the oldest, ancient structure... by a truthful statement in which there is no obfuscation. If 'Sha'wa' (calamity/war) clearly bared its teeth... the glory is in it, and the generosity and the cunning.' It is narrated: 'Sharh and the daughter of Bilqis dye/color it.' Ghumdan and Al-Qalis are the two castles of Sana'a [Sana'a, Yemen], and we have mentioned their news in the book Al-Iklil. 'Sana'a [Sana'a, Yemen], may the black clouds shower you... with a frowning [cloud] whose rain is heavy. A land in which I have the knotted homeland... brothers of truth, masters, witnesses. Their actions are the pursuit of generosity and bounty... for within it, they are high-nosed, noble, proud.'

...their assembly is its witnessed gathering... Where the numbered cold is close. A dweller throughout eternity who does not perish... The father asks the born about it. 'Mahdud' means continuous, flowing (rain), defeated; and similarly 'Arid munhazim' (a flowing/pouring cloud) and 'Ra'd hazim' (thunder). Al-A'sha said: 'So a sweeping, pouring (munhazim) torrent brought them.' If the suspicion of a time event disturbs it... The suspicion of an enemy, a war of grudges. Two tribes stood and protected it... Qahtan and the freemen of Sasan. Two tribes of truth, if the perpetrator... Ignited the fire of war by declaration. They were like the lions of the forest from Khaffan... She remained in it, not misleading nor weak. Cool of eye with the righteousness of my affair... Among youths like the flexible spears. Until when the time of resting rose... And the departure from it approached and drew near. The young she-camels with the people hurried around... Wadi Shu'ub and in it is the flood channel. Then Al-Hasbat and it has a quick pace (dhamil)... Then Al-Juraf and it has a slip (zalil). It does not incline from the highlands of Al-Muqaddim... So in Al-Rahabat it has a burning thirst. At the palace there is a short pause... Like ghouls, its trotting is easy. It is narrated: 'Khayl' from 'khuyala'' (pride), 'kha'il', 'khawwal', and 'khayl' is anomalous. He means Al-Hasbah, Al-Juraf, Banat al-Miqdam, Rahabah, Qasr Khawwan, and Khawdhan Aswad next to A'ram. And her concern is the palace called 'Amad... And Marmal, the second for the one supported by the cold. Then upon Al-Hayfah with diligent marching... To Dhu 'Aram, straight, purposeful. Then to Raydah marching, so he intended... For the fertile watering place in the level plain. Rayd, may you be watered with generous rain from a land... A land in which is the numerous spring water and numbers. And security is not snatched in it from anyone... So may it remain populated throughout eternity. He means Qasr 'Amad, Marmal, Al-Hayfah, A'ram al-Bawn, and Raydah. And by 'the watering place' (Al-Manhal) he means...

...the pond (Birkat) of Raydah; there is no pond in Yemen around which a thousand camels revolve other than it. And we have crossed its field and its length... The desolate desert possessing ease. Then we ascended aiming for Al-Gulah... In it is the post-stage (Barid), a rock well-built. Mute, deaf, yet it is questioned... O Lord, make my Hajj accepted. Then suffice my companions against terrifying distresses... And from Ajib protect our loads. A difficulty, and fold for us its descent... And make the riders and the loads reach. He means the stop of Ajib. Al-Gulah is a great ravine having a 'ghul' meaning depth. And his saying about the rock of the post-stage that it is 'questioned' means writing is read upon it. Ajib is a high mountain pass (Manqal), difficult for the riders in litters upon it. And what is Ajib? If you saw Ajib... You would see a lofty, towering, formidable mountain. Neither an easy habitat nor near... Solid rock, hard, firm, tough. It wears out the docile, noble camels... And the hoof is seen worn out by it. How many supplicating, repenting ones you see... The caller in it does not hear the answerer. With the abundance of rebuking, nor the welcoming... Mention of the beloved consoles the lover. Meaning wearing out (tanqib) appears in it. And he means the answerer is not heard by the caller nor the welcoming, with the abundance of rebuking the camels and singing to them (huda'). Until when it passed Najd al-Dayn... Intending Jarfah or Dhaqin. Not complaining of the girth with the strap... Longing was stirred for it from 'adaj' (noise/cry). Her mates did not long for the fetus... O she-camel, this is seriousness, so hear me. The strong nose-rein in my right hand... Or you will choke on the blood of the aorta. Then she hastened like the oryx doe of the spring... Among young camels moving quickly like ships. 'Adajat' is like 'Sajarat' with longing. Najd al-Dayn, Jarfah, and Dhaqin are places between Al-Kharif and Wada'ah.

Then Athafit appeared to the riders and the camels... Blossoming with grapes. In it is the post-stage surrounded by the hollow (Jwab)... Then I called out to my companions. Old men and young men like lions of the forest... Go in the evening to Al-Jabjab of the loud noise. Then upon Al-Masra' from Ashqab... Then Anis, without doubt. To Naqil al-Faq' of the steep ascent... To Al-Hawariyyin in approach. Athafit is Athafah, the land of the Kabbariyyin. And Al-Jawb is a hollow created in the rock. Al-Jabjab, Al-Masra', Ashqab, and Anis are places in the land of Al-Sabi'. Al-Faq' is a mountain pass. Al-Hawariyan are two small passes between Wada'ah, Bakil, and the people of Khaywan. Then Al-Salul, then to Khaywan... Land of the proud kings of Hamdan. Banu Mu'id and Banu Ridwan... And the fertile watering place of branches. Whatever you wish, you see at the garden... Of fresh dates and colored grapes. And of maidens like gazelles... I did not desire them out of lust for singing girls. But the haste of man called me... Then we went in the evening to Bawban. Al-Salul is a pass to Khaywan. The people of Khaywan are the family of Abu Mu'id from Banu Yarim ibn al-Harith, Banu Ridwan, the family of Abu 'Ashan, the family of Abu Hajr, and the remnants of the family of Khaywan ibn Malik. The maidens of Khaywan and Najran are known for preciousness, beauty, and coquetry. The birthplace of Al-Khayzuran, mother of Musa al-Hadi and Al-Rashid, was in Najran. Then she was sold to Jurash, then to Mecca. We aim in the march for the pass of Al-Adamah... In it is the post-stage, a rock erected. And we had crossed before it Jahannamah... And Tumu' with the leading young camels. And we had made the vanguard of the vanguard... Youths of truth like lions of the battle. On docile, solid young camels... For the people at night upon them is a murmur.

They stick from Burkan to every narrow pass... And from 'Ayyan its rugged ground and hill. Jabal al-Adamah is between Bakil and Wada'ah. Jahannam is a well at its bottom. Tumu' is a land belonging to Banu Ma'mar ibn al-Harith ibn Sa'd ibn Abd Wadd ibn Wada'ah. Burkan and 'Ayyan are the land of Banu Salman from Arhab. 'Musattamah' means authentic in lineage, not mixed; from that is 'al-hasab al-sattam' (pure lineage) and 'alf sattam' (a complete thousand), not broken. And we had crossed before it Shabariq... And Tali' and before it Shamaliq. And they turned from 'Azalim in groups... Embracing, greeting a dark night. Where the post-stage was not separating... So she came from her night to Al-Gharanik. I slept and met a night-visiting phantom... From the specter of Hind, spending the night embracing me. And my eye recovered a yearning beloved... Stealing sleep and exhausting the lover. Shabariq, Tali', Shamaliq, 'Azalim, and Al-Gharanik (which is a water in Al-Amshiyah); these are the places of the Hujn from Arhab. They are the children of Dha'fan, and their mother is Ghara'ib, so they were named Al-Hujn (with Fatha on Ha and Sukun on Jim [text says Tahrik - movement/vowel on Jim, likely Fatha or Kasra depending on dialect, usually Hujan]). Likewise, the Hujn of Tayy and others. Then I rebuked the sleep of the Riyab... By saying: Arise and depart, my companions. So they rose, intoxicated without drink... To the sides of Sarh al-Hubab. To Al-Halawi, the highland of hills... Then Al-Amashiyyat without refusal. Then 'Amish, so traverse, my loved ones... Passing to Majza'at al-Ghurab. And from Sanam, the scattered hills... Al-Mas, the swaying of the wind, possessor of removal. Al-Riyab are heavy sleepers. Bishr ibn Abi Khazim said: 'So the people found them Ruba (heavy/tired), sleeping.' Al-Halawiyan are two passes. Al-Amashiyyat are open lands. 'Amish is a place with water. Majza'at al-Ghurab is a place. Sanam and Al-Mas are black hills. All these places are from the land of the Hujn from Arhab. Then upon Al-Habat with a tiring march... To the post-stage of the erected rock.

To Khatarir Madhab, so toil... Then to Al-Uqlah, draw near in approach. Then drive the white camels with a rebuke that excites... Aiming for Al-A'yun, possessor of Al-A'lab. And the fertile Shar' with sweet drinking place... And under my saddle is one of the daughters of Al-Ashab. A strong one like the white oryx, lean-bellied... Traversing the desert after the desert. Al-Habat: water in a valley that is not exhausted. Khatarir is a long hill seen from the top of Jabal Hadur and the top of Jabal Maswar. Al-Uqlah is a pass and is called Al-Khatwah. Al-A'yun is a water spring and a pass. Al-A'lab is the plural of 'Ilb (Sidr tree), meaning the streams; it is the last of the land of Hamdan and the border of the land of Khawlan. Al-Liyah is the wild bull (oryx). Al-Aqabb is long-horned. Until when she led to Wadi Asal... And came to the plain and the mountain left her. I said to her while she complained of the saddle: Hal (Stop)... It is nothing but settling then departing. Then advances from place to place... And night journey and neglecting laziness. And traversing at midday when the shadow is straight... As long as my soul is safe and the term (death) has passed it. Or you drop at Bakka at the lawful House (Kaaba)... So she hastened, reckless like the deaf wolf (Sim' al-Azal). Asal is an exterior (Zahir) inhabited by Banu Humrah from Khawlan and Al-Hanajir from Hamdan. His saying to her 'Hal' means 'Hali', a rebuke for she-camels. 'Addani' means passed me/missed me. Al-Sim' al-Azal is the small-bodied wolf; it is said when its rear is 'azall' (lighter/smaller) than its front, meaning lacking. So I said: O she-camel, with seriousness, aim... So she dragged along like the solitary wild cow. Traversing the desert after the desert... And the barren heat after the heat. Cautious of a twisted, tightly woven [rope/whip]... She folded Tabar after Wadi al-Mutarrad. As if she were, after the sleep of abandonment... A ship of the sea, great, foaming. She deviates at times and at times is guided... O she-camel, deviation does not concern you, so aim straight. His saying 'Ya Naq' means 'Ya Naqah' (O she-camel), so he apocopated (Tarkhim). Al-Hijan is the wild bull. Al-Sahid is the low ground where heat settles and scorches.

Al-Mumarr is the rope/whip. Tabar and Wadi al-Mutarrad are two places in Asal. So she tucked up when the quick pace gathered her... From Al-Khiyam, and she has a rustling sound. The grinding of her canine tooth is heard... Like the stallion, the hired hand gestured towards him. As if she, with the violent driving... Where Thaqif founded its abode. Possessing stripes (khadam), on its back are spots... A falcon seeking its prey, lean. Or a lively [wild donkey] and a herd, graceful... The autumn contended with him at Al-Ajra'. With a frowning [cloud] possessing cumulus, raining... He hastened to it from Waghl al-Hanajir. Like the wild ass out of fear of the snoring hunter... When you sensed the rebukes of the rebuker. When the Mahri camels approached... She twisted the saddle of the night-journeying traveler. She has cut across, after the sleep of the night-talker... The streams of Al-Khaniq possessing monuments. Where it is prepared for the night-talking post-messenger... commanded among lean young camels. Al-Khiyam is a place and a village of Thaqif in Asal. He says: As if she is a stallion camel when the hired hand covets his nose-rein. Dhu Khadam is a falcon with striped wings. Al-Arin is the wild donkey. Dhu Khadam means possessing stripes (khadmah) on its claws; singular is khadmah. Waghl al-Hanajir is a place in Asal. Al-Hanajir are from Wada'ah. Al-Waghl is between the ravine and the valley. He means like the snoring wild ass passing out of fear of the hunter. Snoring (Shakhir), braying (Sahil), and hee-hawing (Nahiq) are sounds of donkeys. He attributed the monuments (Ma'athir) to Al-Khaniq, which is a place, because there is a Jahili dam in it. The night-talking post-messenger (Barid al-Samir) is the effaced inscription. It is said: 'Amir al-ard wa samiruha' (The inhabitant of the land and its night-talker/ruin), meaning its effaced traces; it is said 'Amiruha wa Ghamiruha' (Its inhabited and uninhabited parts). Exiting from the wing of a dark night... Tamed, the swift young camels. Mahri camels, their eyes are calm... In groups, with gentleness, the pilgrims. Descending, trotting in Dammaj... I conversed with her in some of what I converse. O she-camel, join the midday march with the night journey... You have no turning away from Sa'dah.

As long as you do not pour the blood of the jugular veins... Until you visit the House possessing the Door. Her eyes are black (Sawaji), initially. Al-Rufaq (Groups) is plural, singular is Rufqah. Dammaj is a valley pouring into Al-Khaniq then to Najran. Dha al-Ritaj (Possessing the Door) means possessing the gate. Then the white camels slipped away from Rahban... To Al-Hawiyat, then to Qaddan. O she-camel, to Sa'dah without hesitation... Aim for its watered watering place. Sa'dah, may you be watered with rain from a place... Where the resting place was good for you, my brothers. Among smooth fresh dates and pomegranates... And the alfalfa (Qatt) in its markets is cheap (Majjan). In it the House of Akil was built by a builder... And Yarsum are two branches from Khawlan. Insalabat (Slipped away) is like one slipping out of his garment or from his mother's belly. Akil are the heads of the family of Rabi'a ibn Sa'd ibn Khawlan ibn Amr ibn al-Haf ibn Quda'a. Yarsum's call is attributed to Banu Sa'd ibn Sa'd, and they were marked (tarassamat) according to the custom of Dhu Sukhaym, and they are from Al-Kila'. Al-Qatt is alfalfa (Qadb). Al-Majjan is cheap; it is said 'Rakhis Majjan' meaning as if it were taken for nothing. Rahban, Al-Hawiyat, and Qaddan are farms of the land of Sa'dah. Until when the departure of ecstasy came... I said to a caller: Call to the people, 'Aqid?' (Proceed?). Then he stripped off; the time of the stripped one has become good... And our concern with the march from it is the moderate one. Jabjab, the house of the Qarazi (tanner), the frequented... Then the two valleys of Nisrin or Bayt Kamad. Umaytir, you have no turning away from it... And from a stream for Rabi' possessing moisture (Tha'd). The white camels have yearned with the joy of driving... For the noble idiots (camels) from the west of Al-Sanad. He means 'Call to the people: Aqid' (Delay/Stop). The Arabs say when something they dislike appears to them from a person: 'Aqid', meaning 'Stop, you have started with evil'. And they say: 'Aqid', meaning 'The time you want has come'. Al-Jabjab, Bayt Kamad, Wadi Nisrin, and Al-Umaytir are places in the north of Sa'dah and in its field (Haql). Al-Tha'd in the earth is moisture. It is narrated 'Dhi Thamad', meaning having little water. It is narrated 'Dhi Ta'ad', meaning the flood comes to it (yata'adda) from places.

O Hind, if you saw the beauty of the sight... Young camels like sandgrouse at Hadbar. And upon them is every bright, large man... And every fool weighed down by drowsiness. Slumber shot his eye with a sleepless one... So he, though not one-eyed, is like the one-eyed. Calling to return with it like the tilted-necked one... O Hind, were it not for a group for a group. By the power of Allah, the Most Mighty, the Greatest... They would not return, O Hind, until the Gathering (Day of Judgment). Hadbar is a place. Al-Aswar is the one whose face tilts towards his nape if you tilt it. A beautiful youth tilts (yasuru) women towards him, meaning inclines them towards him. Leave this and return with the stout young camels... Dal'an, and descend with it to Sarum. From Matrat al-Hajr, the aimed-for... I mean a post-stage of good structure. You exchanged wormwood (Shih) and southernwood (Qaysum)... And saltwort (Rimth), Sinam, and Asnum. Folding the deserts of the wilderness with a pace... Whatever you wish of a desolate desert. You have cut across while the people are in silence (Wajum)... Before the stream of Al-Tamrah, the pouring one. Dalwu' (with the L raised/vowelled with Damma) is a mountain south (Qibla) of Sa'dah. This Sarum is Sarum al-Sarh of Banu Jama'ah from Khawlan. Al-Matrat is a place. Shih, Qaysum, Sinam, and Asnum are shrubs that camels graze on, known. 'Fi Wajum' means in silence; 'Wajama' means he was silent, so he is 'Wajim', not speaking. And from Zabin possessing moisture and washing... She aims, aiming for Barakat al-Ard. To Al-Humayl, rising without closing eyes... Then upon the small Al-Ard she proceeds. Whatever you wish among the people on the morning of the gallop... Of a reticent fool and a delaying slipper. And a holder with stinginess and a payer of debt... And a shower of affection and a concealer of hatred. And young camels examining the surface of the earth... Not complaining of the strap of the girth. Zabin is a place. Barakat al-Ard are places of streams. Al-Ard is a valley pouring into...

...Najran. 'Lahij' means difficult, narrow. 'Al-Gharad' is the girth (Bitan). Al-Ard is the land of Banu Thawr from Khawlan. She aims, aiming for the clear path... At Al-Araqat, destroying the drowned. Then upon Al-Thu'ban, then Al-Maqiq... Where the post-stage is attached to the mountain peak. She aims for Saj', of rugged ground and narrowness... Aiming upon a stout camel like the male camel. Hastening with the pace of quick marching... To Al-Jadliyyat with success. Then upon Al-Qattar of the croaking... To Al-Bardan, the beautiful, the elegant. Al-Arqah is a pass in Araqah overlooking a valley with much water. If a person slips from this Arqah—which is like an overlooking portico—he falls into the water from a far distance. If camels travel on it, one of the two baskets of the litter overlooks the air. Saj', Al-Thu'ban, Al-Maqiq, and Al-Jadliyyat are places. Al-Qattar is water that trickles from Safan to Al-Bardan drop by drop. These places are between Banu Jama'ah and Banu Hayf from Wada'ah. And she ascended Al-Shaqrah after Al-Rakibah... By the praise of my Lord, no calamity befell her. And 'Amdan, she has folded its shoulders... And Hadn al-Shaytan, she traversed its side. To a mosque of Khalid, approaching it... Thuwaylat al-Anjad, nearing in it. Passing to Mahdha al-Ni'al, diligent... Then her morning rest tomorrow is at Tha'ibah. If my Lord wills, no doubt disturbs her... Lord, reward my saying with a good outcome. Al-Shaqrah, Al-Rakibah, 'Amdan, and Hadn are places. Al-Thuwaylah is a pass. The Mosque of Khalid is under Al-Thuwaylah; it has a wall without a roof. Mahdha al-Ni'al and Tha'ibah are places, all belonging to Banu Hayf from Wada'ah. Then she folded the highlands of Mu'ridin... The folding of the hand of the stingy one of the rope strands. She covers to Mahjarah the rugged grounds... Where you see its post-stage pawned (hostage).

Then I ordered the people all together... 'Seek provision of food that suffices us. And bring back the white camels, for we have quenched our thirst... Then leave its east to the right. A delegation, by the praise of Allah, safe... Going early with satisfaction, returning.' Mu'ridin is a place in the land of Wada'ah. Mahjarah is a village in Al-Mandaj. 'Al-Shahahah' is the miser twisting the ropes; he extracts it on 'Fu'alah'. 'Al-Manin' is the group of rope strands (Aminnah), and 'Niss Manin' (Text is strong?). It is said Al-Manin is the strand (Mannah) itself. Then drive the dark-eyed mounts, the quick pacers... Indeed, their morning rest is at Ghayl al-Mandaj. You have no turning at Al-Zalif... So seek an exit for its rugged ground. Reach the water in the morning, the arrival of the night traveler... Then drink a quenching drink from sweet Hashraj. No turbidity in the drink nor slipping... Then return from it to Sadd al-Manhaj. As if my saddle, of the twisted evening [rope]... Was tied to the back of a male ostrich, black and white. Ghayl al-Mandaj is the stream of Ali from Wada'ah. Al-Mandaj is a great pass. Al-Zalif is a mountain at the head of Al-Mandaj. Sadd al-Manhaj is your destination; it is said: 'Aghni Saddaka wa Ana Aghni Saddi' (Suffice your side and I will suffice my side/direction). Al-Khurjah is a color of ostrich colors, black with less whiteness. Then the white camels were stripped, saving themselves... Like ghouls at Aqawiyat. Or like the Kudri sandgrouse, approaching... To Shatat, hastening together. Traversing the face of the earth, possessing wilderness... Aiming for the overflow (Fayd) of Rayyah. From Al-Talah, looking out... To the rock post-stage of Thalath. They went, by the praise of Allah, safe... O Lord, save them from secondary illnesses (Illat). Aqawiyat are highlands, exemplified by their cold. Shatat, Thalath, and Rayyah are places. Al-Talah is the place of Talhat al-Malik. All these places are in the land of Wada'ah from Hamdan, and they are from the environs of Uraynib.

I say when she took Jalajil... And the rugged ground and stones (Jarawil) squeezed her. Like the two lips squeezing the fingertips... O Lord, make us reach a quick arrival. Lord, and promise us good in the future... And protect from destruction whoever of us is returning. And forgive a dead one who was descending from us... And make the riders and the mounts reach. And convey the good things from us to the hoper... Its immediate, O our Lord, and the deferred. Jalajil is a narrow valley. He says when she took it, it squeezed her with its narrowness along with the rugged ground and stones in it—and 'Jarwal' is stones. Then he likened them to the two lips when they squeeze the fingertips. This is like the saying of Zuhayr: 'So they and Wadi al-Rass are like the hand in the mouth.' 'For a dead one who was descending from us': meaning for every dead person whose grave we pass while we are riding? Jalajil is the end of the land of Wada'ah. What do you see in the young camels, the tracers... Moving quickly in the sides of a dark night. They rush from Mukhtalif al-Zaha'im... To Manshari 'Uqdat Bayt Na'im. They examine with hoof-pads and toe-pads... A courtyard on the left of the standing post-stage. Descending in the low ground (Khabt) like ostriches... With the people, some awake or some asleep. The glare of the hot winds (Sama'im) reached it... So it is, upon the saddle-bow (Wasit), possessing murmurs. 'Al-Ma'j' describes the movement of snakes. A 'Ghashim' night is dark; it is said: 'He stood in a Ghashmah of the night', meaning a darkness/dusk. 'Ightashama al-qawm': they traveled by night in darkness. Al-Mukhtalif is from the dwellings of Sanhan from Janb, and it is called Al-Hamrah and Al-Manshar. It was named by this name when Madhhij and Quda'a met in it and spread out (Nasharu) in it all of them, meaning they lined up in it for fighting. Al-Uqdah is the head of the valley. Wadi Sarum is a valley with crops, vineyards, and fruit trees. Al-Wasit is the saddle-bow (Wasit al-Kawr), which is the grip (Maddabah) at the chest of the rider. I said to her at the inclination of a dark night... While she throws desert after desert.

Folding from the side the throwing of the abyss (Nafnaf)... With a nose-rein possessing a thick shank (Wazif). And a gathered upper arm and a hollow armpit... And a full withers and a high neck. And a relaxed lip and a dark cheek... Smooth, grown above a slender jawbone (Sabi). And a stout hip and a slender shank... When she ascended the passes of Al-Shafshaf. Meaning throwing the abyss. 'Muwazzaf' means having a large shank. Al-Sabi is what protrudes from the jawbone in its middle. He mentioned the shank and sufficed with it by feminizing the upper arm. Al-Shafshaf are passes in the lands of Ubaydah from Janb. A hard, active she-camel like the strong male camel... Folding the waymarks of it with a worked hoof. Among she-camels like the fleeing ostriches... Mahri camels of the secrets (Sirr?), with beautiful legs. With youths like the quivering spears... How many a desert, a wilderness, an unknown place has she folded. And a pass, and a pass, and a pass... Traversing with hoof-pads the solid rock. Traversing after the sleep of the negligent... To Al-Jumaylan without hesitation. 'With a worked (Mu'mal) hoof' means thick. It is said of everything that is solid and firm: 'Mu'ammal' and 'Mu'mal'. 'Marin' means accustomed to much walking and that she does not stop for a journey. Al-Jumaylan are two mountains containing two passes in the land of Banu Ubaydah. 'Without Ta'ammul' means without delay; 'Ta'ammala Amrahu' means he delayed in it. O she-camel, march and hear my speech... Indeed, we have no staying at Al-Far' al-Radam. Of a need to be fulfilled, nor a residence... Aim with hoof-pads and a high gaze. 'Ara'irayn, what an intent... After hurrying at Dhu al-Ramram. To the rugged ground of Al-Tarfa' and the hills... Where the post-stage is, and the residence is second (?). She has left Furjah with determination... For Al-Thajjah, the great, overflowing water. Al-Far' and Al-Radam are rocks piled one upon another, as is said of 'Murtakim' (piled) 'Rukam'. 'Ara'iran is a place. Dhu al-Ramram and Al-Furjah are a well. Al-Thajjah is a watering place.

She folded 'Afarin and Wadi al-Khanqah... And Dhat Ushsh with determination, hugging [the neck]. Where the post-stage is a firm rock... And from the stream of Tarib, its east. And the rugged ground of Haythan, she covers its paths... She slithers in the darkness of a covering night. Small Shihat trees like the wild ass, free... Stout like the white stallion, lean. She passed by Saf'an, covering its plain... Jarmi, Mahri, created [for excellence]. 'Afar is a place. Al-Khanqah and Tarib are the place of Tayy from which they migrated to the Two Mountains. Jabthan and Saf'an are places. Salfa' is a mountain also in the region. To the plain possessing wilderness from Dhat al-Qasas... Aim for the milestone when the milestone appears. With a high [camel] like the trunk, safe from crookedness (Qa'as)... O she-camel, march, it is not the time of waiting. She turns away, and the white camels practice the pace... Increasing when the mounts decrease. The load of the dark, rising [cloud?], hunted... The hoof-pads represent, she does not give shoes to the courtyards. With them she ascends the plain possessing the smooth pebbles... To Al-Kutinats, a road that has been effaced. 'Najin min Qa'as' means safe from a knot, which is the bending of the neck towards the withers. Al-Jawn is the wild ass that escaped the hunter's arrow. 'Tahammala Nidabuhu Mahulluhu' (?). Katnah is a village. Dhat Ushsh is a place containing the graves of the martyrs; I do not know at what time they were killed. Dhat al-Qasas is a bottom and a mountain. 'Kahasa': effaced. March to Katnah, the march of seriousness... Straight, and deviation is not like the straight path. Aim with the delegation, the road of the delegation... Aim for water, fresh for the arrival.

Where the post-stage of the hard rock is... O Katan, possessor of the barren stone heaps (Rujmat). You were watered by the pouring of the dark clouds... From every pouring [cloud], thundering. A home in which are two tribes of generosity and glory... Shahran my maternal uncles, and the tribe of Azd. Al-Rujmat is the plural of Rujmah, which are Al-Rijam, like hills (Al-Ikam), which are rocks smaller than hillocks in the bottom. Al-Rumd means black. He said 'Rumd' referring to the plural of clouds (Sahabat), just as he said 'Al-Na'am Al-Mujfal' (The Fleeing Ostriches) referring to 'Al-Na'amat Al-Mujfal'. O Hind, if you saw at the landmarks... She-camels like the veins of gold (Sam). Carrying every noble, aspiring man... Kindling the fire-sticks, of high status, a chief. A doctor (Tabib) directing the Halal and Ihram... And every weak, dull one (Daghabusiyyah). A fool, stupid, pious, sleeper... Stingy with what is in his saddle, heavy. He does not fear the blame of the blamers... You have preferred peoples over peoples. 'Ayaniq': meaning red she-camels like veins of gold. 'Barda'': high/elevated; from it is 'Barda'at al-Sanam' (hump pad) and 'Barda'at al-Nab'' (elevated land?). 'Tabb': knowledgeable of the lawful and prohibited. 'Daghabusiyyah': he means a Daghabus (weakling), i.e., inferior to people. It is said of a stallion if he does not know how to cover: 'Ayaya' Tibaya''. When they leaned with the swift young camels... A'ibla, they cover the ghoul of Al-Ghawwala. To the white bottom (Qa'ah) from it is a shaking... And the ravine, she has traversed its bottom by night. How many a dwelling and stage she has folded... And a desolate wilderness and a misleading desert. And a difficult watering place and rugged stony ground... Descending its interior, then its interior. Until she came to Ya'ra, swift, worked camels... And under my saddle is a strong, swift she-camel. A'ibla is a place from Al-Qa'ah. Al-Qa'ah is from Dhat Ushsh to Banat Harb. 'Zalzalah' means it shakes by the trampling of the hoof-pads. 'Majhalah': misleading and unmarked, with no sign in it. 'Dakhkhalahu': its middles and its middles. Ya'ra is a valley belonging to Julayhah from Khath'am, containing palms and wells. 'Qay'' is from Al-Qawa' (desert); from it is 'We made it a reminder and a provision for the desert-dwellers (Muqwin).'

Then at Ya'ra, not staying... Except falling at the valley, staring. Eating food and drinking... At the post-stage of the lonely rock (Al-Safat). Then she threw with 'Aqay'iyyat... Like the herd of receding [stars/animals], preceding. To Atb in the march, pitching tents... Approaching Yabambam for the arrival. So drinking then returning... With the people when they woke up, hastening. 'Al-Safat' is the solitary; from this it is said 'Rajul Safat', meaning a poor man with nothing with him or on him. Al-Safat is also the large body. 'Al-Siyar' is a dialect for 'Al-Siwar' (herd). 'Faritat' means turning back. Latb is a place, and some Arabs call it Tabiyy. 'Habbu' from sleep means they woke up. In the low ground from Dhat al-Salam the paved... In it is a post-stage of hard rocks. Mute, questioned, and if not asked... It clarified what is in it, even if it did not reason. To Ashab, then Rahah, then Juljul... She has left Najr, the quenching watering place. To Banu Dad with trotting and sending... To the post-stage of the leveled rock. She aims for Harjab with a hurried march... To Banat Harb she did not turn. Dhat al-Salam is a place. 'Mute, questioned' means that on a post-stage is a writing informing which post-stage it is from the number. Ashab, Rahah, Juljul, and Ibna Dad are places. Harjab is a place other than Harjab Rada' which he mentioned. Banat Harb is a village, and some gold may be found in it; it is a valley containing palms and wells. Najr is a valley containing two wells. The proverb refers to the women of Najr: He said she returned from it and did not exhaust it, and it is quenching whatever it was. Until when the guest departed... And most of my concern was your untied saddle. And from Sinan, its terrifying ravine... So a lean she-camel was stripped. From the calamity of the ravine, she has a slipping away... To Al-Rabadhat where the Ghoul is found.

In it is the post-stage of the braided rock... And highlands surrounded by plains. There are no crops or streams in it... Except the ghouls, the fear, and the Hadhlool (wolf). Sinan is a ravine near Banat Harb, called Lahy Jamal. Al-Rabadhat is a place between mountains with great piled rocks like large fortresses (Atam), which are rocks piled one upon another. The place was named after them. It is a place of panic for camels. It is exemplified by the Ghoul of Al-Rabadhat. I have traveled it more than once at night and did not sense any frightening thing in it. They say: The travelers of Yemen used to, if they spent the night there, have someone come out at night throwing embers of fire and calling some of the travelers he knew, telling him about his family and things he knew, and his voice would be denied (unknown). The origin of that is that some of those before us had seen ghouls and Ghilan of hideous beasts there. Likewise Al-Udar, which is the serpent. And Al-Hadhlool is the wolf, named so for its swift running (Hadhlan). Then she has in the wide expanses... A determination of marching, what a determination! She has left behind with trotting and hastening... Hasasat al-Arfat possessing bare patches. Ashen from it to Tila'... Where the post-stage does not answer the caller. Ask the passion about your burning heart... About some of what you are to Hind a shepherd. A caller called you out of passion for Hind... In sleep, while the white camels were ascending. Al-Bastan is a place. 'Al-Ida'' is a description of fast walking. 'Ghadarat' means left; from it 'He does not leave (yughadir) a small or large sin but He has enumerated it', meaning He does not leave. Al-Hasasah and Tila' are two places. The correct form was 'La yujibu al-da'iya' (accusative), but he left it with a kasra and protected the inflection with the Alif and Lam. To Al-Jasda', staring for water... Then longing for a slender one seized me. A houri, a virgin, rightly guided, fair... Lean-bellied, shapely, with cool teeth. Like a pearl clearing the darkness of gloom... She circled my saddle in the darkness of a mist. So I said when my consolation returned to me... To the people: Urge the white camels for salvation.

Trotting to Aghlab then Al-Rakha... Then Al-Ghaddar then to Al-Maytha. Al-Jasda' is a watering place containing wells. Al-Aghlab and Al-Markha are places. Al-Ghaddar has a stressed Dad, so he lightened it. 'Aqabat al-Ghaddar' is a choking strait. Al-Maytha is a place. All these places are from Ya'ra belonging to Khath'am. Until when I brought her to Ranum... Its valley and the known watering place. Where the post-stage ceased not to be bitten (held fast)... She threw Suhayy behind her, blamed. Leading camels complaining of fatigue and boredom... Following a sturdy, strong male camel. Aiming for the direction of the Kaaba, the stars... Following its intended path. The highlands of Thawr, lean, emaciated... Enduring from it the endured mine. Ranum: a watering place with a deep well. The Rajiz said about it: 'Indeed Ranum has cut my ropes... And left every new thing worn out.' Suhayy is a place. Nijad Thawr has the mine of Bisha Ba'tan, a gold mine. Then at Ba'tan, the revealers of the quick pace... Aiming from Bisha for Wadi Turj. With a strong [camel] possessing a long-stepping foot... Splitting the wilderness, what a splitting! Ascending with it Al-Nahqah of the ravine... Where the post-stage of the rock is like the infidel (Al-'Ilj). At Dhu Simar, not the march of the pasture... Traversing a midday march, the blazing of dust. For a close [Hajj] fearing missing the Hajj... O she-camel, aim for the straight path, do not crook. Ba'tan is a land belonging to Khath'am to which Bisha is attributed, and it is one of the large broad valleys (A'rad) of Najd. Turj is like it, valleys of lions, and it is a valley of palms. Both have fortresses (Atam). Al-Nahqah is highlands and a pass. Dhu Simar is a place between Turj and Tabalah; to it are attributed the Jinn of Simar. Next to it is 'Arabat. 'Al-Aqabb' is the one close to attaining. Then upon Dhat al-Dimagh, oh what... A desert assassinating whoever arrives at it. Ascending to Sahwat Jabah... The rugged ground of Al-Hazinat, covering a condition.

Ascending the post-stage of the rock inevitably... I said to a 'Ansi (camel): What a saying! While she urges the pace with the saddle (Rahhalah)... Like the tender, swaying prostitute. Dhat al-Dimagh and Al-Hadhinat are two places next to Dhu Simar. 'Tahuththu': extends the pace of the march. From that, 'Haththa al-ba'ir': he brought out its pace completely. He borrowed 'Al-Rahhalah' for the saddle (Al-Rahl). Al-Rahhalah is for horses, and they are the saddles of the Bedouins. This is the explanation of Abu Ubaid. I say: He was mistaken about Al-Rada'i, because Al-Rada'i is too knowledgeable to say 'Al-Rahhalah' for 'Al-Rahl'. Rather, he said 'Al-Rahhalah' (The Great Traveler/Saddler) just as it is said for the genealogist and knower 'Nassabah', 'Arrafah', 'Jakhkhafah', 'Thaqqalah', 'Nammamah', and 'Hayyabah'. So she arrived with the painful march... Among fat, weary camels and among emaciated ones. They rush into a drooping, dark, diminishing [night?]... Meeting sprinkling with the afterbirth of abortion. They drink in a flowing stream... To Al-Bardan, filled cisterns. So I said to the people in a state of burning heat... At a resting place not of hurry. Untie the heads of the white camels for the meadows... Traversing from it the heat of the pebbles. He produced the plural of 'Ba'ik' as 'Buk' following 'Tumk'. The plural of 'Ba'ik' is 'Bawa'ik'. It is as if he went with the view that its singular is 'Abuk' and 'Bawka''. This has occurred in the like of 'Ha'il', 'Hul', and 'Hawa'il'. Al-Bardan is a well in Tabalah with good, sweet water. Likewise Tabalah is a village with merchants, and merchandise comes to it. It had palm trees and a stream. Most of its inhabitants were from Quraysh, so the Bedouins ruined it. The 'Jadwal' is the stream. Riyad al-Khayl (Meadows of Horses) is a place called by that. So they became smooth like the approaching sandgrouse... With the people, trotting, the riding camels went away. Noble camels joined to noble camels... Wading through the breadth of the earth possessing shoulders. In a dark [night], moist on the sides... Khalafat the water, little, drying up. Where the post-stage of the rock, the side one... The turbidity of the drinking places has been effaced from it.

How many faces of deserts she has folded... Jarra, reaching for Aqran al-Tha'alib. 'Khadil' is cold on both ends, moist. A 'Khadil' night also, except that it is cloudy and dark. Khalafa is a well. 'Nadid' is little; from this it is said 'Ma nadda ma'ak', meaning what you obtained. 'Al-Majanib' is a description of the rock, like the woman avoiding (Mufariq), scratching (Mukhalib), and turning away (Mudabir). Jarra and Aqran al-Tha'alib are hills. Then she headed with the night-traveling crowd... Groups of swift young camels. To Al-Qurayha, the main roads... Drinking in its watering place, the cisterns. Approaching, not swimming... Seeking from it the casting of exits. Wading through a midday heat like the blazing of the surging [sea]... The two noses of Amaylah, the steps. Where the post-stage is like the covered, the calm... And under my saddle is a raging stallion. Al-Qurayha is a watering place and a feeding place. There was a village in it that fell into ruin. It is on Wadi Ranyah. 'Ajij al-hajir' is its intense heat and blaze you see like mirage and like waves. Amaylah is a mountain. Al-Madarij are highlands. 'Al-Ba'ij' is the still one with no movement. From that is their saying: 'His affair saddened him so he became still (baha)', meaning as if he died from his confusion and absentmindedness. 'Al-Ma'ij' is from waves. A stout she-camel speeding like the speeding of the Jab... From the croaking of the rebuker, the croaker. To Ajrab, possessor of the flooding watering place... Sweet drops of arrival for the drinkers. Returning from it to A'bab... Throwing at Al-Ahass, the rugged, possessor of hills. With a nose-rein forgiving of foot-soreness... Then Kura' al-Bab, what a door, a door! The rocks of the Harrah, the hard ones... O Lord, save her from illnesses. 'Tanda'u' means speeds. 'Al-Jab': the donkey, wild donkey. 'Na'ban' from the croaking (Na'ib) of the raven. Ajrab is a watering place with a well. A'bab is a place. Al-Ahass is from 'Husas', which is pebbles, not from 'Al-Ahass' the bald, because he mentioned it has hills (Hazabi). 'Af' is forgiving (Mu'fin). Kura' al-Harrah is a gate of it with rocks removed for the road. The people of Sana'a say—and I do not know if with support or otherwise—that the road is easy in it. This is a Harrah that he finds and exits from...

...at the time he enters it, according to the pace of the caravan. The Rajiz said: 'Harrah of Najd, may you not be watered with rain... From Al-Kura'ayn to Wadi Kara.' Another said: 'O Harrah possessing ruggedness and stones... We will ascend you with every strong camel. Rubbed in the gaps between legs, soft of joints.' Then the white camels were released, blowing the nose-rings... Connecting with the midday march the causes of the night journey. To Dhu Fadayn, the peaks withered from it... Hollow-eyed ones, trimmed by the journey, what a trimming. The Pass of the Harrah, going away from it... Where the wild ass passed the post-stage. Then upon Al-Rafdah intending Kara... Then at Sharyanah, not where the villages are. Then Rakha, as you count Karkar... In it you see that dusty post-stage. Dhu Fadayn is a place in the Harrah. Thaniyah: he means of the Harrah. 'Ghayyara' is plural of 'Gha'ir', meaning proceeding to his destination. From it is the saying of the Jahiliyyah: 'Shine, Thabir, so we may raid (nughir).' From that is the penetrating arrow (Al-Sahm Al-Gha'ir). 'Ayr al-Fara' is the wild ass; it has Hamza but he left the Hamza. Barah is a place in the Harrah. Al-Rafdah is a place in it. Kara is a deep valley in the Harrah containing palms and water; it is one of the sinks of the waters. One descends to it by a pass and ascends from it by another. Al-Sharyanah is a depression in the Harrah; the flood once took away some of the caravan of Sana'a in it, so it was named the Year of Al-Sharyanah. A flood struck them, and had they not been early, no one would have survived. Karkar is a place in the Harrah also. Then Al-Kura' and they have a strut... They rush to the feeding place of Abidah. To its water, approaching, straying... To a watering place whose scarcity she felt safe from.

It extends a prepared distance... beneath me are ancient noble she-camels. Strong 'Idiyyah camels, accustomed to travel... from the slave, having folded a long distance. Leaving behind a high paved tower... swinging their gait, strong in their trot. The second Kur'a (leg/projection) is from the other side of the Harrah [Volcanic Field], and Raydah comes from 'Iradah' (will) as one says from 'Idarah', and the Arabs say: 'Do you have a dirah' meaning a trick/means. Abidah is between the Harrah and Nahiyah, and in it is a great valley, one of the greatest valleys of Najd called Turabah [Turabah, Saudi Arabia]; when it flows, it extends to Ar-Raqiq: a place that does not complain of the pain of deep travel... nor the traversing of the night of terrors. It trampled Waraqah with cunning... then sobbed like the braying wild donkey. The rough grounds and sands of Aqawiyat... then the lands resembling the calves. Then Nahiyat, then Dar' al-Ijlal... then Khalqan, then Dhu Ghazal. Where the rocky path marked with milestones lies... and the water is fresh, filling the buckets. Waraqah and Aqawiyat are locations, the first is also called Aqawiyan. Diha', Nahiyah, Dar' al-Ijlal, Halaq, and Dhu Ghazal are water sources and desolate places. The 'Shahj' is the wild donkey. Then she leaned in her march from it, the driven one... when she heard the humming of a driving singer. To a dragging place, crossing the highest dragging place... to the ravens of the erect Qarin. Then Al-Kharida with a tiring trot... then to Safn, quenched in drink. Neither muddied drink nor moss-covered... then upon Rukbah, the riders passed. Where the path of the two rocky markers is gray... the smaller one like the path of sandgrouse. 'Mulhib' is one who is serious in his camel-singing, and 'Mashab' is a place where the heavy/slow people are dragged, and they might prepare themselves on a main road of it, which is also one. The 'Sarrah' is the one who has not performed Hajj, and the 'Sarrah' is the one who has not married women. The 'Ghurab' is an erect peak, and 'Al-Kharida' is a wide land. Safn is a water source to which fodder comes from the rains of the direction of At-Taif [Taif, Saudi Arabia]. Ibn Abi Fadalah said: If you want loss, all loss... then pass by the provision of...

The people of Safn and Rukbah. He mentioned it and Dhu Ghazal. As for Ghazal, it is in the direction of Usfan [Usfan, Saudi Arabia], and regarding it Kuthayyir says: I call out to you as long as the pilgrims perform Hajj and say Takbir... at Fayfa Ghazal, a group that raised their voices in Talbiyah. And a group did not say Takbir above Rukbah... nor did they mark the sacrificial animals and raise their voices at Dhu Ghazal. Al-Arkab: A group (or mountain) to which I said in a dark, gloomy night... at a resting place, what a resting place. To the rough ground of the clear water source... O she-camel, the month is about to pass. So resolve with seriousness, not slackness... So she rose with a high, towering hump. Like the trunk, the trunk of a fruit-laden palm tree... like a mother of chicks returning to chicks. From Dhu Tuwa, possessor of saltwort and salt marshes... approaching the water toward Kilakh. Awqah is a water source on a valley with fresh water. It was said to a sick man from the people of Sana'a [Sana'a, Yemen] while he was in his home, 'What do you desire?' He said: 'A drink from the water of Awqah.' Kilakh is a valley whose water is heavy and salty. All these lands from Tabalah [Tabalah, Saudi Arabia] to Nakhlah [Wadi Nakhlah] are the dwellings of Hawazin, containing all their clans. Dhu Tuwa is a place, and Dhu Tuwa is also in Mecca [Makkah, Saudi Arabia]. O Hind, if you could see with your own eyes... young camels trotting in Jaldan. Among the people are the awake and the sleepy... and every tough one, steadfast of heart. Amazing, gracious to the brothers... not a deceitful dullard nor a reminder of favors. And every weakling, present but stingy... turbanned with blame, holding a grudge. Gathering obscenity, a confused sleeper... You would know who possesses virtue among the riders. Jaldan is a place, a wide plain. 'Khabb' is heavy; it is said he is a 'Khabb Dabb' (deceitful/tricky).

When the people lean upon the reddish camels... away from Dhat Asda', the humps of fine fat. The tall, strong 'Idiyyah camels... and the long-necked one has folded the wide desert. Where the rocky path is west of the roads... I say to the lightning striker when it flashed weakly. To the flashes of the glittering Yemeni lightning... Is it to the left of Na'man [Wadi Nu'man] when it split the horizon? You stirred sorrows for one of clinging longing... and the white camels carrying loads leaned away. Dhat Asda' is a place, and Al-Fatq is a feeding place. As-Suhq means the tall ones among camels and palm trees, hence it is said 'a deep/distant void' (sahiq). 'Idiyyah: the 'Ha' is an addition. Na'man is above Arafat [Mount Arafat] in the land of Najd. Al-Hantawah is a place, and it was a stage where the people of Sana'a were afflicted by a year of drought/famine, so it was called the Year of Hantawah. So I said when my composure returned to me... and the heart had something like a flame in it. Console the passion from your enraged heart... while the white camels fold the earth with endurance (Mizaz). Fearful of a restraining driver... descending to the lowlands from Okaz [Souq Okaz]. They folded the mountain passes of the earth with vigor... with hard, round hooves. With young men, not obscene nor rude... no, but narrators of truth, protective. 'Al-Mizaz' is from 'Mumazah', which is dispute and hardship. Okaz is the gathering place of Hawazin and the ancient market of the Arabs, and it belongs to Banu Hilal today. 'Indi'az' is rushing/impulsion. 'Al-Mujmar' is the round hoof with hard sides. So the groups stripped away with gentleness... 'Idiyyah camels with full shoulders.

Leaving Qarran to the mountain passes... where the hand of the scribe drew the milestone. And Sharbb in the darkness of an entering night... with every pure-bred of good nature. Calling upon Allah, the supplication of the one who desires... fearful of his sin and repentant. He says, while the matter rests on the consequences... 'O Lord, grant me the best of gifts.' 'Al-Muf'am' is the filled one. Qarran and Sharbb are two places in the land of Okaz, and this Qarran is different from Qarran of Al-Yamamah, and Qarran of Al-Jawf (Jawf Arhab). These places are part of Al-Jarda'. The mountain of Al-Hadn strikes on the east of all these places from the main road for a day and a fraction. Then the people turned left from Qarran and Sharbb, ascended the top of As-Sarat, which is Al-Manaqib, five obstacles including Al-Ghamdah and others. They descended through them and landed at Qarn al-Harad, which is the one the Prophet (peace be upon him) designated as the Miqat for the people of Najd; and for the people of Tihama, Yalamlam [Sa'adiyah]; and for the people of Syria and Egypt, Al-Juhfa [near Rabigh]; and for the people of Iraq, Dhat Irq [Ad-Dharibah]. Until when the approacher brought the Kaaba near... by the strength of the Bestower, not by weakness. She exchanged fear for the Abode of Safety... and came to the Miqat, the Valley of Qarn [As-Sayl Al-Kabir]. And a mosque surrounded by the adornment of beauty... in it the Hajj is initiated before the Corner (of the Kaaba). And those marking the sacrificial camels are the people of sacrifice... and obscenity is scolded away so he does not speak foully. And he leaves the immorality that does not avail... and the argumentation of speech that does not concern. In Qarn, there is a mosque of the Prophet (peace be upon him) and his well; it is a valley with palm trees and fortresses, situated at the head of Al-Bawbah. That is when the people headed to Qarn... so they washed with water or performed Tayammum. And they garlanded the sacrificial animals as they were taught... and entered Ihram and marked (the animals) and made them known. And the marked Yemeni garment was spread... for the people, then they advanced or arrived. Until when they completed a prayer, they saluted... and raised their voices and entered Ihram. And they glorified their Lord and honored Him... and sought forgiveness from their Creator and sought His mercy.

He said: 'And spreading the burd (garment)' he intends the plural 'burud', just as the Arabs say: 'The camel is few' (meaning camels), 'the garment is few', 'the garment is expensive', and 'the dinar is mighty', while they narrate 'the clothes are expensive', 'the camels are few', and 'the dinars are few'. This is while they are in the mosque of the Miqat... then they lined up upon the working camels. Until when they rose, hump-less... they answered (Talbiyah) the Doer of Beautiful Deeds, the Possessor of Goodness. In a language among the best of languages... hoarse and disheveled, raising their voices. Arriving by march to Al-Bawbat... their saying: 'O Fulfiller of Needs. Forgive us, O Hearer of Supplications... and pardon the living and the dead.' Al-Bawbah is a land leading to Wadi Nakhlah, and its ascent to Qarn is a sand dune that the weak and emaciated camels can hardly cross. 'Majbubat' means the saddles have eaten into their humps; the singular is 'jabba' and the male is 'ajabb', and among people 'majbub' (castrated/cut). Then the white camels resolved with determination... returning to the Known Mosque. Heading towards Al-Kafu and Al-Yasum... to the rocky path of the crisis (or narrow pass). And the people are in glorification and exaltation... hoping for the pardon of the Forgiving, the Merciful. And a dwelling in the Garden of Bliss... by the pardon of a vast, generous Lord. And the white camels are in a dark intense night... on a path of truth, straight. The Known Mosque is the Mosque of Ibrahim (peace be upon him) at the head of Wadi Nakhlah; people descend there, pray, and supplicate. Al-Kafu and Al-Yasum are two mountains in Nakhlah. 'Al-Bahim' is the night because at the beginning of the month it is confusingly dark on the road. To the estate of the Talhi, going straight... departing from it, aiming for Az-Zaymah [Az Zaymah, Saudi Arabia]. Then upon Sabuhah, the ancient one... where the enduring rocky path lies. Moving steadily in a march of determination... to Arik, ascending its core. Praiseworthy in the caravan, not blameworthy... her noble veins remaining.

I hope that Salimah will be seen... praised in the caravan, not dispraised. The estate of the Talhi from Quraysh implies old palm trees. Az-Zaymah is a place containing the orchard of Abdullah bin Ubaydullah Al-Hashimi, and in the days of Al-Muqtadir it was at the peak of cultivation, yielding five thousand dinars (mithqal). In it is a fortress for fighters built of rock, protected by Bin Sa'd; its inhabitant is 'Arwan', and the number of its trunks (palms) is in the thousands. In it is a flowing stream extracted from Wadi Nakhlah, abundant, leading to a fountain in the middle of the garden under an arch to a large reservoir. It contains bananas, henna, and types of vegetables. Sabuhah is a place. Arik is a mountain pass added to a place, so it is said 'Aqabat Arik' with a Damma on the Alif, and 'Arik' with a Fatha is what Al-A'sha mentioned in the area of Uwarah. The road then from the top of Al-Manaqib to Mecca faces between the west and the south, with the sun in the late afternoon on your right temple. Then she leaned into a trot with speed... to the well of Al-Judhami with gathering. To Hunayn [Wadi Hunayn], the overflowing water source... until she arrived at Al-Mashash. Where the rocky path lies, do not avoid it... she clamored with yearning for an overwhelming longing. And she remembered the mate and the livelihood... filling the trellis like nests. Then Al-Hawl from Nashwah, then Al-Akhshash... places of pasture and night grazing. 'On inkimash' means with speed; it is said a horse is 'kamish' in running, meaning swift. The wells of Al-Judhami is an inhabited well; Al-Judhami is from the people of Mecca. 'Bi-htiyash' means with gathering; 'hasha' the game means he gathered it. Hunayn is where the Battle of Hunayn took place between the Prophet and Hawazin. Al-Mashash is a place where the pilgrim road of Yemen and Najd meets the road of Iraq and Bahrain. Al-Arsh, Al-Ishash, and Nashwah al-Akhshash are places in Rada'; 'al-infash' is for sheep and 'al-ir'a' is for camels grazing at night. Then in the lawful Najd, then As-Safah... she has a flowing pace, what a pace. In the glow of the heat of an exposed hot wind... trotting to its drawn fountain.

And the quenched watering place, not the shallow one... in the safe Sanctuary (Haram), not the permissible land. I call upon You, O Possessor of Grace and Reformation... O our Lord, O Splitter of the Daybreak. A Sanctuary for bodies and souls... for he who comes seeking nothing but righteousness. 'Najd al-Hill' is the boundary between the lawful land (Hill) and the Sanctuary (Haram). The Fwwarah (fountain) is on the appearance of the stream that pours into Bir Zubaida [Ain Zubaida] in Mecca. On the fountain is a great structure built by Zubaida bint Ja'far bin Al-Mansur, the wife of Harun and mother of Al-Amin. Then to the Great Shib (Valley) of the Sidr Tree... she has a march that is not deceptive. To Hira [Jabal al-Nour], then to Thabir [Jabal Thabir]... to the Well of Maymun without shortcoming. Then to Shib al-Khuz under the well... from Shib Kharma, keep left then go straight (or divert). To the dwelling of houses and palaces... to my blessed, inhabited home. Every matter must have a destination... O she-camel, you have followed the march. With a pass in the forbidden Sanctuary... drop my saddle there, O she-camel, and be safe. In a dwelling that belonged to the ancient group... then from Al-Hujun [Al-Hujun, Mecca], do not hesitate. To its great, huge reservoirs... then drink if you wish or proceed. From it to the filled barrier of sovereignty... the barrier of Banu Makhzum, the nose-pierced (noble). Until you kneel at the Greatest Gate... and drink your fill at the Basin of Zamzam [Zamzam Well]. He says: You have followed the march with days of rest; 'Ar-Rahah' is the obstacle/pass, and from that: his saying 'Aqabat al-Mashi' meaning his riding to rest. He means by 'the ancient group'... (text cuts off). The 'Jawab' are the watering places of the Zubaida pond due to its depression; 'Jawabiyha' means its basins. And he said 'Bab al-A'zam' (The Greatest Gate) meaning...

At the Greatest Gate, so he annexed it to it as Allah Almighty said: 'Closer to him than the vein of the jugular (Hab al-Warid)'; the 'Habl' is the 'Warid'. And praise be to Allah who has bestowed favor... He journeyed us in His land and kept us safe. Until we came to His Sacred House... from us, so we honored it along with those who honored. Then He guided us to our rituals and taught... as He guided our father Adam before. Then we circumambulated it seeking sanctity... and a Sunnah performed by he who submits (becomes Muslim). Then we touched its Honored Corner... then we bowed and arrived at Zamzam. Then we went out to As-Safa, the Gate of As-Safa... where you see the pilgrims praying, devoted. Then upon Ar-Rahwah, walking quietly and stopping... and among them in the valley are those who moved fast. Jogging after walking with shackles... calling upon a Lord who has long been benevolent. That He may turn the shackles away from them, a turning... striving, you see them distressed and trembling. And among them are those who shaved and trimmed... and a single one for the shaving has stayed behind. 'Inthat' (spread) the pilgrims over the face of the group. 'Halla' is from entering the state of being Halal (non-Ihram). 'Jaffa' means supplicating for him. Until when they departed from the scenes... they returned to a lofty, high House. Marked for Ibrahim, possessor of covenants... and for his son, truthful in promises. When they raise the House of foundations... and dig the water of resources. So the people are between drinking and praising... and circumambulating, bowing, and prostrating. And devoted to Allah, not denying... O our Lord, whoever plots against him is a plotter. It is as if he said 'to a constructed house' (Mashid) so he derived it as 'Sha'id' (constructor/high), just as it is said 'a sleeping night' and 'a tiring life' meaning one sleeps in it and tires in it, and 'a content life' meaning contented with.

So be in wait for him, O our Lord... and increase him in righteousness and honor, may he increase. In a mosque, the likes of which is not for the prostrators... and a brimming spring, thirst-quenching in resource. A spring from Paradise that has not dried up... in front of a high, constructed House. It has been surrounded by brocade, not stripped... and pearls, corals, and aquamarine. And a corner of ruby and two doors of gold... Oh, what a House of clear sovereignty! He means by the 'spring of the mosque' Zamzam, and he refers to the covering of the Kaaba and what hangs on it in the 'Shamsiyyah' (upper part) of jewels, gold ('Asjad'), and gold. Until when the Imam departed... with a Sunnah by which Islam was enacted. And the banners and flags marched... he returned to a people who broke their Ihram. Then the groups proceeded to Mina [Mina, Saudi Arabia]... then they spent the evening and slept there. Until when the darkness receded... they prayed the Dawn there together and fasted. Voluntarily, and no fasting was obligated there... then they proceeded, having no stay. Until they came to where the Standing is... at Arafat [Arafat, Saudi Arabia], and in it is the Definition (Ma'raf). A day in which Iblis is howling, shouting... from what he sees of the turning of what is turned. From the mercy of Allah which cannot be described... and from the giving of Allah which is not exhausted. From maidens of wide eyes in the heights, blinking... longing for their husbands, looking down. Blessed are the people of Hajj on the day they moved fast... with righteous deeds for what they sent forth. The Ifadah (Departure): Until when the light of day turned back... and the sun set, the bare-headed ones flew.
